titleStmt.title: An history of apparitions, oracles, prophecies, and predictions with dreams, visions, and revelations and the cunning delusions of the devil, to strengthen the idolatry of the gentiles, and the worshipping of saints departed : with the doctrine of purgatory, a work very seasonable, for discovering the impostures and religious cheats of these times / collected out of sundry authours of great credit, and delivered into English from their several originals by T.B. ; whereunto is annexed, a learned treatise, confuting the opinions of the Sadduces and Epicures, (denying the appearing of angels and devils to men) with the arguments of those that deny that angels and devils can assume bodily shapes ; written in French, and now rendred into English ; with a table to the whole work.
titleStmt.author: Bromhall, Thomas.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN HISTORY OF Apparitions, Oracles, Prophecies, and Predictions, With Dreams, Vi≈øions, and Revelations. AND THE Cunning Delu≈øions of the DEVIL, to ≈øtrengthen the Idolatry of the GENTILES, and the Wor≈øhipping of Saints departed; With the Doctrine of Purgatory.
A Work very ≈øea≈øonable, for di≈øcovering the Impo≈øtures and Religious Cheats of the≈øe Times.
Collected out of ≈øundry Authours of great Credit; And delivered into Engli≈øh from their ≈øeveral Originals,
By T. B.

Whereunto is annexed, A Learned TREATISE, confuting the Opinions of the SADDUCES and EPICURES, (denying the appearing of Angels and Devils to Men) with the Arguments of tho≈øe that deny that Angels and Devils can a≈ø≈øume Bodily ≈øhapes.
Written in FRENCH, And now rendred into ENGLISH.
With a Table to the whole Work.
LONDON, Printed by John Streater, dwelling in Well-Yard, near the Ho≈øpital of S. Bartholomews the Le≈ø≈øe, 1658.

div.head: TO THE HONOURABLE, THE Lord Cholmley, Lord Vi≈øcount Kell, &c.
div.p: I Should in the fir≈øt place (if po≈øsible) anticipate your wonder; when the≈øe rude Lines ≈øhall plainly ≈øalute You, Defender and Protector of their Innocencie: Since I, who have thus prepo≈øterou≈øly run them, am not ≈øo happy as to be known to Your Honour. I ≈øhall therefore humbly take leave to declare the grounds of this my pre≈øumption (for I dare not call it otherwi≈øe, unle≈ø≈øe by your permi≈øsion). The fir≈øt is, your unbounded Goodne≈ø≈øe; to which I am relatively obliged, and much acquainted by the frequent commemorations of my neare≈øt Relation, who≈øe Father had the happine≈øs to live and die under the benevolent influence of Your honourable Service; And, by the Information of tho≈øe who≈øe expre≈øsions proceed from the dictates of their own Experience, find, That where You have once obliged any by Your incomparable benignity, Your favours flowed down infinitely to all Relations. The next is, The Worthine≈øs of tho≈øe Learned Authours, by who≈øe Care and Indu≈øtry the≈øe Examples were left for the u≈øe of future Ages: who≈øe A≈øhes might ju≈øtly ri≈øe up again≈øt me, if (being ≈øo unworthy to mention, much le≈øs to collect their Labours my ≈øelf) I ≈øhould not commend them to the Patronage of one mo≈øt Noble and Ingenious: Nor do I conceive it the lighte≈øt con≈øideration, That Your Lord≈øhip being acquainted with the≈øe Collections in their ≈øeverall Originals, mu≈øt nece≈øsarily (for the communicative quality inherent in all truly noble and generous di≈øpo≈øitions) wi≈øh they were accommodated to the apprehen≈øions of inferiour capacities.

I ≈øhall not trouble Your Honour with what Motives I had for expo≈øing this Work to publick View; Since the≈øe ≈øo much Saducean and Socinian Times, most loudly, proclaim an eminent nece≈øsity of utmo≈øt endeavours in this particular: And ≈øince it is the duty of all men, to ≈øtudy rather the Publick, than their own private, advantage.

It being a Stranger, needs the more Encouragement. Be≈øides, being u≈øher'd into this our Engli≈øh World by ≈øo unworthy a hand, mu≈øt con≈øequently participate of the weakne≈øs of my endeavours: But however defective, or expo≈øed to injury, Your acceptance will abundantly ≈øupply it, and your Patronage ≈øecure it from the imputation or prejudice of any Momus.

Should I further que≈øtion that invincible Courte≈øie which I hear every where extoll'd, I might thereby aggravate, in≈øtead of extenuating, my Pre≈øumption. Therefore I ≈øhall cea≈øe to trouble you further, but with this one reque≈øt, That You will favourably interpret my boldne≈øs in ≈øub≈øcribing my ≈øelf,

closer.signed: Your Honours mo≈øt humbly devoted Servant, Thomas Bromhall.

div.head: AN HISTORY OF Mo≈øt ≈øtrange Phanta≈øies and Apparitions, with the various ≈øleights and cunning delu≈øions of Devils.
div.p:
MArcus Brutus and Ca≈øsius, who had murther'd Cae≈øar, came together to Sardis, where it is reported, Brutus was acco≈øted with a horrible Vi≈øion. He was a man, naturally very watchfull, and one ≈øo laborious and continent, that he afforded him≈øelf but a very ≈ømall part of his time to ≈øleep in. In the day he re≈øted not at all, in the night very little; and that when (all men being drowned in ≈øleep) he had neither any employment to do, nor per≈øon to conver≈øe with. And, at that time, being engaged in a War, and agitating things of a mo≈øt high concernment, he was ≈øo carefull and intent concerning the pro≈øecution and event of tho≈øe affairs, that, having fir≈øt (for a ≈øhort ≈øpace) refre≈øht him≈øelf with ≈øleep after Supper, he wholly ≈øet apart the re≈øt of the night for the promoting of his urgent occa≈øions. And if it happened, that he had fini≈øhed his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe before, he betook him≈øelf to his ≈øtudy untill the third watch; when, all his Centurions and Tribunes were wont to repair unto him. When he was (I ≈øay) at Sardis, and projecting how to convey his Army out of A≈øia, in the beginning of the night the Moon began to abate of her wonted lu≈øtre, the Camp being in a deep ≈øilence. While≈øt Brutus was deeply cogitating of ≈øome ≈øerious matters, he thought he heard the foot≈øteps of ≈øome one near him; whereat he looking back towards the door, behold, a prodigious Apparition, one of a mon≈øtrous and horrid ≈øhape and bigne≈ø≈øe ≈øtood by him, without ≈øpeaking one word. Brutus, not without ≈øome reluctancy, ask't him, What Man or God art thou? or what is thy bu≈øine≈ø≈øe here? The Vi≈øion an≈øwered, O Brutus, I am thy evil Angel, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øee me again at Philippi. At which Brutus nothing daunted ≈øaid again, I ≈øhall then. But when it was vani≈øhed, he called together his Servants, who averred to him, they neither ≈øaw nor heard
either Vi≈øion or voyce; after which Brutus took his re≈øt again. When it was light, he went to Ca≈øsius, and told him of this Phanta≈øm. When, after Ca≈øsius was ≈ølain at Philippi, while≈øt he prepared for a ≈øecond fight, wherein he was conquered, after he had been Victor in the fir≈øt; In the night (as the ≈øtory ≈øayes) the ≈øame Vi≈øion appeared again to Brutus in the ≈øame ≈øhape, not ≈øpeaking a ≈øyllable, but ≈øo vani≈øht. Plutarchus in Bruto.

WHen Marcus Antonius became bankrupt at Actium, Ca≈øsius of Parma his Partner fled to Athens; where, in the dead of the night as he lay in his bed ingulph't with cares and perplexities, he phancied, a man of a mon≈øtrous magnitude, a black and ugly hue, his beard incompt and ≈øqualid, and his hair di≈øorderly hanging down, came to him; And being askt who he was? an≈øwered, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , i.e. thy evil Angel, or Genius. Being at la≈øt affrighted with ≈øo horrid a pre≈øence, and ≈øo evill a name, he called in his ≈øervants, and que≈øtioned them, whether they ≈øaw one of ≈øuch a dre≈ø≈øe and vi≈øage either come in, or go out of his Chamber? and when they had a≈ø≈øured him they ≈øaw none ≈øuch, he again compo≈øed him≈øelf to his re≈øt: but pre≈øently the ≈øame Phanta≈øm haunted him; Wherefore he ca≈øt off all thought of re≈øt, and commanded a Candle up to his chamber, and enjoyned his ≈øervants not to depart from him. Between this night and his execution inflicted by Cae≈øar, was but a very ≈øhort interval, as you may read in Valerius Max. l. 1. c. 7. and Sueton. in Aug. and Plutarch. in vita Antonii.

DIon of Syracu≈øa, after the Syracu≈øans were made free, and a little before he was ≈ølain by Calippus, as he ≈øate by chance in his Porch in the evening full of carefull thoughts, heard a ≈øudden noi≈øe; and looking about him, (it being yet day-light) he ≈øaw a huge woman, in face and habit nothing differing from a Tragick fury, ≈øweeping the hou≈øe with a Broom. He, very much terrified, called his friends, and acquainted them with the ≈øight, and intreated them to ≈øtay and lodge with him that night, for he ≈øhould ≈øink under his terrour, if they ≈øhould leave him, and the Gho≈øt haunt him again. The Gho≈øt, indeed, troubled him no more, but his Son, being almo≈øt arrived to Manhood, by rea≈øon of ≈øome ≈ølight and puerile cro≈ø≈øe, became ≈øo ≈øorrowfull and enraged, that he precipitated him≈øelf from the hou≈øe top, and ≈øo peri≈øhed. Plutarchus in Dione.

ALexander the third, King of Scots took to Wife Joan Si≈øter to Henry the third, King of England; which Joan dyed without i≈ø≈øue: after which he married Margaret, daughter of the ≈øame King Henry, who bare to him Alexander, David, and Margaret; All the≈øe dyed; yet the King not altogether di≈øpairing of an Heir and Succe≈ø≈øor of his body, married the third time one Iola, daughter of a Knight of Draconum; while≈øt by night they were celebrating the Wedding Fea≈øt, he ≈øaw the likene≈ø≈øe of a dead Man follow the Dance. The ≈øame year the King was knockt off his hor≈øe and ≈ølain.
Hence aro≈øe all that ≈øedition and de≈øtruction which bla≈øted that, formerly, flouri≈øhing Kingdome. This fell out in the year of our Redemption, MCCL. Cardanus de rerum varietate, l. 16. c. 93.

THere is a noble Family, and among the chiefe≈øt of Parma, called by the name of the Tortells, which have a Ca≈øtle, wherein there is a Hall; In it about the chimney, an old woman for this hundred years u≈øes to appear when any of the Family dyeth, or is like to dye. On a time a gallant Matron, by name Paula of Barbia, which was one of the ≈øame family‚ñ™ when we were at Supper together at Belzois, told me, that one of the Maids of the hou≈øe was very ill, and that the old woman appeared; all were of opinion that ≈øhe would dye: But it fell out otherwi≈øe, for ≈øhe recovered; but another of the family which was well, dyed ≈øuddenly. They report, that this old woman, who≈øe Gho≈øt is now ≈øeen, was formerly very rich, and was by her own Nephews murthered for her moneys ≈øake, and hackt in pieces, and thrown into the Privy, Cardanus, ibidem.

ANtonius Urceus Codrus, a Grammarian of Brixia, the very ≈øame night he dyed, thought he ≈øaw one of a huge magnitude, a bald pate, his beard hanging down to the ground, fiery eyes, carrying Torches in both hands, and terrible all over, and he ≈øpake to him thus; Who art thou, which walke≈øt up and down alone thus like a Fury, in that time of the night, when men are fa≈øte≈øt a≈øleep? Speak out, what do≈øt thou look for? or whither goe≈øt thou? When he had thus ≈øaid, he skipt out of his bed to avoid him, ru≈øhing in violently upon him. Bartholomaeus Bononien≈øis in ejus vit√¢.

JAcobus Donatus, Patricius of Venice, and al≈øo rich, when on a night ≈øleeping with his Wife he had a taper light, and two Nur≈øes al≈øo were a≈øleep in a truckle-bed with a young child, not a year old, he ≈øaw the chamber door open by little and little, and a man, I know not who, put in his head; the Nur≈øes al≈øo ≈øaw him, but no body knew him; The young man being affrighted, as well he might be, ≈ønatcht his Sword and Buckler, each of the Nur≈øes great Tapers, into the Hall they come, which was near adjoyning to the Chamber, where all things were clo≈øe. The young man comes back with great admiration, the ≈ømall Infant, which was well in health, dyed the next day. Cardanus de Rerum varietate, lib. 16. cap. 93.

VVHen Cur≈øius Ruffus, in his family notable for nothing of worth, did act as Quae≈øtor at Adrumetum, a City of Africa, walking up and down at noon in the porch, he ≈øaw the ≈øhape of a woman of a more comely hue, far beyond any mortal creature, which ≈øpake unto him, Thou art Ruffus, which ≈øhalt ≈øhortly come Vice-Con≈øull into this Province. He being hopefully advanc'd with this prodigie, not long after enjoyed the Procon≈øul≈øhip of Africa by Tiberius
Cae≈øar, whereby the event of the Vi≈øion was fulfilled. Fulgo≈øus lib. 1. cap. 6.

EDwinus being bani≈øhed by Ethelfred King of the Northumbrians, fled to Redovaldus King of the East-Angles. Not long after, when Ethelfred by ≈øome in authority ≈øought to kill him, he began to take great care to ≈øecure him≈øelf. In the night, when all was ≈øtill, one of an unknown face and habit, having met with him, ask't him what he would give him, if he told him that which would free his mind from all manner of ≈øadne≈ø≈øe. Edwinus made him this an≈øwer, what≈øoever was his, that he might lawfully reque≈øt, and was in his power, that he will freely give him. Then he progno≈øticated to him, that ≈øo ≈øoon as he could make an e≈øcape out of his Enemies hands, he ≈øhould then recover the Kingdome of his Ance≈øtors, and when he had conquer'd his Enemies, he ≈øhould enlarge it, both far and wide; immediately laying his hand upon the top of his head, he ≈øaith; When any one Edwinus, ≈øhall come to you, after you enjoy your own, and ≈øhall in this manner lay his hand upon your head; be you then mindfull to keep thy promi≈øe. When he had done ≈øpeaking thus, he on a ≈øudden vani≈øhed. The young man being in a wonderfully manner tran≈øported with this Oracle, a long time ruminating within him≈øelf of this matter, dur≈øt not open it to any. But when Ethelfred was ≈ølain, he being brought home into his own kingdome by Redovaldus, being advi≈øed by Ethelberg his Wife, the ≈øi≈øter of Edbaldus King of Kent, to embrace the Chri≈øtian Religion; when he on purpo≈øe delayed the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and could by no per≈øwa≈øion be made pliable, Paulinus a devout man, which by long intreating could do no good, in the interim being taught by an Oracle from Heaven, (as we mu≈øt believe) came to him, who made ≈øtay at York, and putting his mo≈øt ≈øacred hand on his head, reque≈øted him, that he would call to mind what that meant. Eduinus being amazed at the Oracles ≈øudden i≈ø≈øue, in≈øtantly fell down at the Prelates feet, and was with his fellow Chri≈øtians wa≈øhed in that holy Fountain. Anno 627. Polydor. Lib. 4. Hi≈øt. Angl.

MAcchabaeus Co≈øen German to Ducanus King of Scotland and Banquho Stuart a valiant man travailing through a forre≈øt towards the Court, met three Women of an unwonted and ≈øtrange habit and appearance, One of them ≈øaid, Hail Macchabaeus, Thanus Glammis, which was a Title of Honour he had lately received. The ≈øecond ≈øaid to him, Hail Caldarius Thanus, another and higher title of honour: and the third, Hail Macchabaeus, Thou ≈øhalt hereafter become King. Then ≈øaid Banquho, Me-thinks you are ≈øomething unkind who≈øoever you are to prefer this man not onely above all the noble Men of the Land, but even unto the Throne, and give me no promotion at all. To this the fir≈øt an≈øwered. Yea we declare unto thee far greater things than the≈øe; for this man, indeed, ≈øhall reign, but his dominion ≈øhall have an unhappy end with him for none of his po≈øterity ≈øhall ever enjoy his King≈øhip after him: whereas
(although thou ≈øhalt not become King thy ≈øelf) thy po≈øterity for a very long ≈øucce≈ø≈øion ≈øhall obtain and hold the Throne. When the≈øe words were ended, they all vani≈øhed out of their ≈øight. ALexander in his ≈øecond book of his Merry dayes, writes of Alexander, that he had an intimate friend of an undoubted credit, that took upon him the care of his friends funerall, and as he was going from thence to Rome from whence he came, night drawing on, he turn'd into the next Inne in the road, and there being very weary, he went to bed. THe ≈øame Alexander mentions ≈øtories of the ≈øame nature in his 4th book, and 9th chapter, in the≈øe words. WHen Alexander the Lawyer of the City Naples lay ≈øick in his bed at Rome, he ≈øaw plainly before him as he was awake the ≈øpecies of a woman of an excellent beauty: which when he looked upon, a long while mu≈øing, ≈øaying nothing, and bethinking him≈øelf he might be deceived. THe ≈øpirits which go to and fro in hou≈øes, are either harmle≈ø≈øe, or fierce and cruel ones, the harmle≈ø≈øe may be termed Lares which at midnight chiefly haunt hou≈øes, and ≈øeem by ≈øome kind of noi≈øe to do ≈øomething, when as indeed they do nothing. IN the mettal-mines both kinds are to be found, Te≈øte Georgio Agricola libro de animantibus ≈øubterraneis. Such an one was Annaebergius that Hobgoblin, which killed twelve labourers, or more at a bla≈øt in the Cave, that is called Corona Ro≈øacea, left by that name, although it abounded with Silver, this puffe came forth by opening his mouth when he appeared like a hor≈øe, having a long neck, and horrible eyes. They ≈øeem to be drow≈øy dotards, habited like the mettal-men, The≈øe are inoffen≈øive to them, although ≈øometimes perhaps they may provoke the workmen with throwing gravell, but they never hurt them unle≈ø≈øe by jeering or railing they provoke them. THeodo≈øius the Emperour, having ≈øpent and exhau≈øted his trea≈øure by continual Wars, impo≈øed a new ≈øub≈øidy upon his Cities, onely the city Antioch refu≈øed to make paiment of it: and not onely ≈øo, but having made a mutiny, the people in a contumelious manner, drew up and down the City, the Image of Placella the Empre≈ø≈øe (though already dead) fitting and fa≈øtning a rope to her feet. AMong the Italians there was a Governour of a City, which mo≈øt proudly and covetou≈øly domineer'd over his Citizens, and by his high words, and fierce deeds was wont to puni≈øh his ≈øubjects in a ≈ølavi≈øh manner, though they did tho≈øe things he commanded, and performed them well, yet for ≈ømall cau≈øes did he torment or fine them. When the Governour under≈øtood it, being very angry, and with a ≈øtern and menacing countenance grievou≈øly chiding him, commanded him to be ca≈øt into a mo≈øt ba≈øe pri≈øon, and there being fa≈øt bound, was kept in a mi≈øerable cu≈øtody. Within three dayes the ≈øame dores being ≈øtrongly barr'd, that very ≈øame he, which of late was deputed to pri≈øon, every one being ignorant thereof, was again forc't and thru≈øt into the ≈øame Pri≈øon, and like to one in an amaze, reque≈øted that he might with all ≈øpeed be admitted to his Lord, for he had ≈øomewhat of con≈øequence to tell him in all ha≈øte, which was not to be delayed. And when he was pre≈øently brought to him, he told him he was relea≈øed by ≈øome of the infernall crew, that ≈øince he could not endure the ugline≈ø≈øe of the Pri≈øon, he was grown de≈øperate, and being afraid of his doom, not knowing what to do, he

A little while after the Devill appeared to him in the ≈øame Pri≈øon, of a deformed ≈øhape and terrible countenance, and that he had agreed with him that he ≈øhould free him from thence and all Iron bolts and locks, and ≈øhould ca≈øt him into the infernall places, great depths, and the lowe≈øt part of the Earth, there he might view and behold all things, the torments of the wicked and their ungodly places: their eternal darkne≈ø≈øe and mi≈øeries, loath≈øome and horrible corners, their Kings and chief Rulers, were tortured, covered, as 'twere with thick darkne≈ø≈øe, and tormented with the burning lights of furies: he ≈øaw al≈øo the Bi≈øhops with their mitres and robes, richly adorn'd and beautified with gems, and many other wretched effigies of all ≈øorts, ages, and ranks, afflicted in ≈øeverall habits, lying along in profound and deep gulphs, puni≈øh'd in eternall torments, and their damned wickedne≈ø≈øes everla≈øtingly tormented with grief and wo, among≈øt whom he had noted many which he knew in their lifetime, and e≈øpecially an intimate and familiar friend of his, who while he was living was his companion, and he ≈øaid to him ≈øpeaking unto him, he knew him very well, and calmly required of him, what bu≈øine≈ø≈øe he had there, and what he expected there. He making an≈øwer, that his country was by hard duties and rigid government ent ‚Ä¢ ralled, was charged, to tell the Governour, and bid him have a care, that he did ≈øo no more, and that he ≈øhould not oppre≈ø≈øe his ≈øubjects by burthen≈øome taxes, and unju≈øt toll-money, for he foretold him that there was a place, which he ≈øaw not far off lefr for him. And that he might not doubt his promi≈øe, he ≈øaith that he ≈øhould call to mind, their private con≈øultation and mutuall agreement, which they made when they were Souldiers together, whereof no body knew; which when he had readily declared and recited not onely what was ≈øaid and covenanted, but every word, and their promi≈øes, whereby they were both obliged to each other: the governour hearing the≈øe things in order, being more ≈øerious, and attentive, was wonderfully amazed, and great trembling fell upon him, when he con≈øidered how tho≈øe things, which were di≈øclos'd to him alone, and never to any other, that dull pate, and blocki≈øh fellow, as 'twere in≈øpired with ≈øome deity, ≈øhould know them, and repeat them with an undaunted look. To this miracle al≈øo is added, That he asked him, with whom he was talking with in Hell, who appeared in hand≈øome and neat habit and attire, whether they were any wayes puni≈øh't, that went in rich apparell, and ve≈øtments of Gold; he replyed, with everla≈øting burning and among≈øt the greate≈øt torments they were with continuall wo oppre≈ø≈øed and tormented, and that which before glittered with Gold and Purple, was now all flame and fire. He willing to make triall thereof, put his hand nearer to the Purple, being warned by him not to touch it, and yet it could not be, but by the bla≈øt of heat, the palm of his hand which he put forth to the Purple, was on fire. For it was almo≈øt wa≈øted with bli≈øters and vile Ulcers, as

Moreover they which went unto him, relate that he, after he was got from Hell, was ≈øore troubled in mind, and his ≈øen≈øes of hearing and ≈øeeing were very much ≈øtupefied, that he was alway mu≈øing, ≈øeldome ≈øpake a word (though oftentimes ask't). A Certain Hetrurian ploughing in the fields belonging to the Tarquinii, his Plough going too deep into the ground, one named Tages, as the ≈øtory goes, brake forth in ≈øtature like a child, but in Wi≈øedome a grave and di≈øcreet Senatour, and ≈øpake to him that held the Plough, he being affrighted, cry'd out. ONe Polycritus an Aetolian, made by the people chief governour of Aetolia for three years, married Locrides for her vertue ≈øake, with whom he ≈ølept three nights, In the fourth he died. THe Devill having transformed him≈øelf into an Angell appeared to Rathbodus commander of Fri≈øia, with a Golden Diadem, on his head, and many jewels thereon, and his ve≈øture wrought with Gold, ≈øaying, Mo≈øt valiant Sir, who hath ≈øeduced and mi≈ølead you, that you would go from the ≈øervice of God? ABout the year of our Lord 1096. near a place called Wormatia, there appeared a great troop of armed men for many dayes and nights, running to and fro; and ≈øometimes back again into a mountain, from whence they were wont to come. After his death, every day in the Evening ≈øuch ≈øtrange Apparitions were ≈øeen in his ≈øtately hou≈øes, that every body left them, and no body dur≈øt inhabit them. That Rich Epicure appeared with his gue≈øts
in the dining room, which he had divided for his delicacies, and dainties; that ≈øervants ≈øtood by giving attendance, with lights in their hands‚ñ™ ≈øetting on Golden cups and Ve≈ø≈øels upon the Table and filling it with mo≈øt gallant di≈øhes: the Fidlers moreover, and Mu≈øicians were ≈øtanding by, and no gallantry was wanting, that this rich man u≈øually enjoyed, when he was alive. By God's permi≈ø≈øion, and the operation of the Devill, the≈øe ≈øpectrals were obvious to the eyes of men, that others might be terrified from that horrid impiety and ungodline≈ø≈øe of the Epicureans.
‚Ä¢ incelius lib. 2.

IN the year 1559. In Marchia fell out a very ≈øtrange thing, which many of great account and credit did affirm truly ≈øo to happen. In harve≈øt time, on a ≈øudden appeared ≈øome men in the fields, at fir≈øt fifteen, at la≈øt twelve, all of an unwonted magnitude and an odious ≈øhape, both fir≈øt and la≈øt were without heads. All the≈øe having ≈øiccles did on a clu≈øter reap down the Oats, that the noi≈øe of the Iron was ea≈øily heard, yet all this while no Oats were cut. Immediately the report of this marvellous ≈øight came to the Court, and many, both of the Courtiers and Citizens went forth, and were eye-witne≈ø≈øes of this miraculous Vi≈øion. Many al≈øo going nearer to them, aske of them who they were, and of what Countrey, and what they would have? To which they made no reply, but fel ≈øtoutly to their work which they had begun. Some al≈øo did dare to lay hands upon them, and to hold them, but they quickly e≈øcaped out of their hands. Whereupon it evidently appeared to all that were then pre≈øent, that they were Spirits. That Illu≈øtrious Prince of Marchia having convocated many of his mo≈øt eminent Divines, de≈øired to know of them what they thought of this ≈øtrange prodigy: Mo≈øt of them were of opinion, that it was the omen of an en≈øuing Plague. Fincelius lib. 3.

IN the year 1530. on the 18, 19, and 20th of July, near Spira, there was a Vi≈øion on this manner: Three fi≈øhermen, when endeavouring to catch ≈øome Salmon in the River Reine, they lo≈øt their labour, they wa≈øhed their Nets, and laid them down to ≈øleep. When they had ≈øo done, a Monk coming to them, rai≈øed one of the Fi≈øhermen, and bid him go on the further bank of Reine. The Fi≈øherman was ob≈øequious to the Monks commands, and in≈øtantly came ≈øix more, in look and habit like to Monks, who going into the Ship, ≈øailed along with them over the River Reine. The≈øe coming forth, the Ship was with a mo≈øt violent and ≈øwift cour≈øe brought back again through Reine, and pre≈øently ≈øome other Monks entering into the ≈øame Ship, pa≈ø≈øed over the River as the former had done. At la≈øt, the Fi≈øherman being returned to the place, where he had laid him≈øelf down to take re≈øt, ≈øhortly after fell ≈øick. On another night, another Fi≈øherman was awakened in the ≈øame manner, to tran≈øport ≈øome Monks over the River Reine, who coming to the ≈øhip, Saith one of the Monks, this Ship will not hold all that are to
go over, you mu≈øt get a bigger. And pa≈ø≈øing over the ≈øecond time, came 12. Monks, clad partly in white, and ≈øome in black, with ugly hook-no≈øes, and they going into the Ship, were al≈øo carried over, who when they went out, others pre≈øently ≈øtepped in, and failed over. But whither the Monks went, and whither the Ship, or how he came back to the place of his re≈øt, the Sailer knew not. And he al≈øo within a ≈ømall time was very ill. On the third night the like chanced to the third man, who being awakened, was likewi≈øe charged to make u≈øe of a new Ship, to tran≈øport more Monks, who not knowing where to acquire one, ≈øeemed to go through rough places, and rugged Rocks, till he found a Ship that was new made, into which many Monks, (≈øome of ≈ømall, others of a great ≈øtature, having on black, white, and ≈øeverall kinds of hoods) were Shipped, pa≈ø≈øing ≈øtraitwaies through the ≈øame River, not ≈øpeaking one word, and when they were come to an uneven place be≈øet with Trees, they refu≈øed to go out, bidding them to Sail on. When the Monks went forth, the Ship of it ≈øelf came again≈øt the Tide, near the City Spira. The fi≈øherman not knowing him≈øelf; was returned home, and the Ship re≈øtored again into his own place. The Monks, when at fir≈øt they que≈øtioned them whither they went, an≈øwered towards the City Ba≈øill to the Councill. There is one that de≈øcribes the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages in an Epi≈øtle, that calls him≈øelf Suredabus Cancrinus, who al≈øo di≈øplayes and unfolds this Apparition to the life.

div.head: Of the ≈øame Spectacle, out of an Elegy of GEORGE SABINE.
div.l: THere is an ancient City ≈øeated on,
The River Reine, not far from Vangion.
People, cal'd Neme ‚Ä¢ es, enjoy'd it; there
Four Roman Generals intombed were.
Cae≈øarean coh'rts made it their ≈øeat of old,
Whence the name Spira at this day't doth hold.
Here liv'd one who no noble birth could vaunt,
Of a ≈ømall fi≈øhing Ship, an occupant;
In which when Titan had withdrawn his beams,
He us'd t'deceive the Tenants of the Streams.
Whilst he his Nets and Hooks did fit and trim,
Of gliding Reine almo≈øt upon the brim.
Behold a ≈øhape pre≈øented to his ≈øight,
Of one he knew not in the edg of night:
His ve≈øture was (as Friars u≈øe to wear,)
Such a black coul, his crown was ≈øhaven bare,
The Fi≈øher greets him at his wonted rate,
And asks him, What makes him abroad ≈øo late?
He an≈øwer'd he was ≈øent from far by's Lord,
De≈øir'd him he would waft him o're that Foord;
That he might th'≈øooner gain the other ≈øide,
Which curte≈øy he granted, nee'r deny'd.
Now the night's near half ≈øpent, Bootes wai ‚Ä¢
Had turn'd its cour≈øe, when, in the virid plain,
Behold five more in Hoods towards him came,
Whom he ≈øaluted in good Fortunes name;
And ask't them, Whither they ≈øo late were bound,
When night had fini≈øh't half her constant round.
One of the five reply'd: Dangers con≈øtrain
Us thus by night, our ≈øafety to obtain.
We are infe≈øted by a wicked rout,
That ≈øeek to kill us, 'cau≈øe we are devout.
If in thee any love of good abide,
Then waft us in thy Boat to th'other ≈øide;
That we may pa≈ø≈øe the waters by thy means,
And be not hindred by the ≈øwelling ≈øtreams;
So ≈øhall thy labour pro≈øper at thy will,
And ≈øo thy Nets the Pi≈øh ≈øhall crouding fill:
He gave con≈øent, and them his Boat affoarded,
Whereby his Ship they ≈øoon and ≈øafely boarded;
But then (≈øayes he) who ≈øhall the fraught defray,
One of them an≈øwer'd, We've no coin to pay,
(Thou know≈øt) to th' people ≈øince we are ≈øo hatefull,
They ≈øeldome give us ought, but wee'l be gratefull,
If once our fortune ≈øhall e≈øtabli≈øh't be,
Wee'l well reward thee for thy curte≈øy.
He loo≈øt from ≈øhore, now's Ship did gently glide,
Almo≈øt i'th middle of the plea≈øant Tide:
When, ≈øpi≈øsy clouds ore-veild the Stars, the Sails,
Were over-fill'd with storming Southern gales.
The waters roar, with rouling waves; now rain,
Adds to the ≈øtorm, and joyns the Stars to th' main.
The Marriner, with horrour being ≈øtruck,
Cries out, What cau≈øes this unthought ill-luck?
I ≈øaw no pre≈øage of a coming ≈øhower,
When Sol departed to his We≈øtern bower:
No Swallow hover'd o're the waves, my eyes
Did ≈øee no Heron: when the Moon did ri≈øe,
She was not black, nor pale, nor Phaebus light,
Abated of its lu≈øtre near the night.
The≈øe words di≈øturbed were, by th' ≈øtorming rain,
And by the raging waves oth' foamy main:
The Ship was neer o're-turned by the blast,
The Waves had almo≈øt covered the Ma≈øt.
The Marriner with ≈øtretcht-out hands to Heaven,
Implored thence the divine aid. What even
Thou wicked wretch, do≈øt pray? (≈øayes one
Oth' five) cea≈øe Sirrah, and let God alone:
And then took up an heavy Row, which th' poor
Unhappy Man had us'd to wield before;
With which his ≈øhoulders he ≈øo ba≈øted o're,
That even unto death he beat him ≈øore.
At la≈øt the Devils wiles appear'd; 'twas plain,
There did no part oth' fraud un≈øeen remain.
Their bodies vani≈øht into the whirling Wind,
Nothing was left but ≈øtinking ≈ømells behind.
Then ≈øoon the Clouds were drawn, and day appear'd,
The Winds allayed and the weather clear'd.
Frighted herewith, e'n ≈øen≈øele≈øse he doth bie,
With's Ship toth' ≈øhore, and there onth' Gra≈ø≈øe doth lye;
'Till Sol appear'd, when by a neighbour ≈øwain,
Unto his home he is convey'd again.
When telling all to tho≈øe his friends were by,
Clos'd up his eyes, and ≈øo is ≈øaid to dye.
When bright Aurora did next Morn appear,
And with her Crocean Chariot th' sky did clear.
A pa≈ø≈øage like to this, the time except,
And better i≈ø≈øue to the thing, expect.
When fir≈øt bright Sol on th' top oth' Mountain ≈øhone,
A traveller 'gan t'journy all alone.
Whil≈øt he was on the coa≈øts of Vangion,
Ju≈øt where they placed had the fir≈øt Mile-Stone,
Behold a Coach, all of a ≈øable hiew,
Filled with Monks, which ≈øeven hor≈øes drew,
Yoked in order; but one of the four
Wheels, with the axetree, from the Coach were tore.
The Coachman that did rule the reins therein,
Had a mo≈øt rufull no≈øe, and vi≈øage grim.
The frighted traveller ≈øtood whil≈øt it pa≈øt
By him, ≈øo found they Spectrals were, at la≈øt
The Coach onth' ≈øudden, mounted into th' Wind,
When fire and ≈ømoak did follow it behind.
And the ≈øad Omens of en≈øuing war,
A noi≈øe as arms ith' Ayre did cla≈øh and jar:
He made return toth' City, told it, and t ‚Ä¢ me
It was made known by good authority.
Therefore to you, wh' in other regions dwell,
I thought my meter bound the≈øe things to tell,
And had they wanted an Interpretation,
I would have made it. Now the German Nation,
By their King's di≈øcords, heard of nought but jars;
And now their Monks inflamed had the Wars.
This was the Tempe≈øt, this the disjoynted Wheel,
This was the ≈ømoak and flame, This joyntly wee'l
Commend unto our God; de≈øire him lay
The≈øe Tempe≈øts, hee'l be good to them that pray.

div.p:
MAgdalena Crucia Hi≈øpana, in the chief City of all Corduba Baetica, in her tender years, was (whether by rea≈øon of Poverty, or Devotion it is uncertain) by her poor Parents, placed in the Nunnery of St. Clara ‚ñ™ (which ≈øhe afterwards re-built all anew, and endowed with a fair revenue). This Magdalena, I ≈øay, being in≈ønared by a Devill that appeared to her in the form of an Aethiop u≈øing many ≈øugred and plea≈øureable enticements with which tender years are mo≈øt taken; began to conver≈øe very familiarly with him, but with mo≈øt ≈øevere interminations, that no mortall ≈øhould be made privy to their familiarity. She conver≈øing with the Devill almo≈øt every day, grew more in knowledg then could be expected from her youth, and was admired of all that knew her for her ≈øtupendious knowledg, and ingenuity, and ≈øingular piety, which the ≈ømoothne≈ø≈øe of her behaviour, and the au≈øterity of her life did ≈øeem to manife≈øt; ≈øhe had ≈øcarce attained the age of twelve years when this evill ≈øpirit, taking the opportunity of bringing her into his full and ab≈øolute po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, with glorious and gilded words moved a marriage betwixt them, and ea≈øily for the experience ≈øhe had had of her improvement, by his means, was this ambitious girl per≈øwaded to it. They joyn hands, are married, and at la≈øt lye together. Magdalena in lieu of a Dower, promi≈øes him the u≈øe of her body, to di≈øcour≈øe with her, conver≈øe with her, and lye with her. The Aethiop on the other ≈øide, promi≈øed to make her a large Dower, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould by rea≈øon of her illu≈øtrious ≈øanctity and wi≈øedome, bear great ≈øway throughout all Spain for thirty years and upwards, in≈øomuch that ≈øhe ≈øhould excell, or at lea≈øt equall the mo≈øt famous that ever went before her. Nor would this lying ≈øpirit, in this particular, ≈øeem fal≈øe that ≈øo by this his bride, he might deceive all Spain. And when≈øoever they enjoyed their ≈øtolen delights, his ≈øervant (for this Aethiop for the honour of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, kept his man) taking her coule, to the life imitated (like ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øititious Sofia) in the Cloi≈øter abroad, or in the Temple, her countenance, behaviour in walking, ≈øinging, praying, eating, and all other the like. And if perchance, when he had wearied his Lady with plea≈øures, he went (in pretence of looking that things went right in his Mannour) about the World, at his return he told her all that hapned in his travell worth the telling. So ≈øhe being taken pri≈øoner of Franci≈øcus King of the Gauls; ≈øo comming to the Knowledg of Romes being ≈øack't, and telling ≈øhe was told it by divine Revelation, ≈øhe grew in great e≈øteem with the chief and noble Men of the Kingdome, and obtained the dignity of Abbe≈ø≈øe, all the other Nuns willingly yielding to ≈øuch eminent ≈øanctity: and entertaining the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe with exceeding joy in that they conceived great part of the glory, redounded to them who were her in≈øtructours. She was famous for many miracles, but tho≈øe onely lu≈øory,
and vain fancies. In a ≈øolemn pomp upon a fea≈øt day, ≈øhe was taken up into the Ayre three or four cubits high, and often holding the Image of the ble≈ø≈øed child Je≈øus in her arms, making her eyes the Sluces from whence Rivers of tears i≈ø≈øued, ≈øhe did ≈øuddenly extend the excre≈øcency of her hair unto her heels, and by degrees did vani≈øh away. And as often as the Monks at ≈øet times and ≈øea≈øons, did take the Sacrament in the Euchari≈øt-basket, there alwaies wanted one of the round pieces of the my≈øticall bread (being fir≈øt of all diligently reckoned): which Magdalene did openly ≈øhew that ≈øhe had it in her mouth, and that ≈øhe received it by the admini≈øtration of Angels. Hence ≈øo much was the fame of her ≈øanctity ≈øpread abroad that High-Prie≈øts, Emperours, Kings by their letters commended them≈øelves to her prayers, and therefore did Charls the fifth's Queen take great care that her Son Phillip ≈øhould be wrapped in tho≈øe ≈øwathing clothes, which Magdalene had ≈øanctifyed by her prayers. Thirty years at the lea≈øt being ≈øpent in this diabolicall marriage, at length in the year of our Lord, 1546. by Gods ble≈ø≈øing and favour, and not by rea≈øon of her Merit, Magdalene returned to her ≈øelf, and began to dete≈øt the Devill, but the Aethiop taking grievou≈øly her apo≈øtacy, and after diver≈øe manners tormenting her, ≈øhe, beyond all expectation freely di≈øcovered her wickedne≈ø≈øe, to them whom they call the vi≈øitors of that Order, and to them ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed her ≈øin, implored help, and was by them impri≈øoned. Neither did the Devill, notwith≈øtanding all this, leave the place, but at morning prayers to the great wonder and amazement of the Monks, was pre≈øent in the ≈øhape and ve≈øture of Magdalene, and oft did perform other her offices. The Monk now abhorring their Abatte≈ø≈øe, whom for twelve years they had entertained, at the la≈øt they were very importunate that the whole manner being found out, Magdalene might be expelled the Cloi≈øter, that ≈øo tho≈øe enchantments might cea≈øe. Neither was there any great puni≈øhment inflicted on her, becau≈øe of her ≈øerious repentance and ingenuous confe≈ø≈øion; and that, As by her feigned and daemoniacal ≈øanctity, ≈øhe had encrea≈øed the ≈øuper≈øtition of many, So by her true and Chri≈øtian penitency, ≈øhe ≈øhewed by this memorable example, that the fountains and floud-gates of Gods mercy are not dam'd up, or ≈øhut to any repentant ≈øinner.

IN the year 1532. a Noble man out of his tyrannicall malice commanded one of the country men which he had power over, that he ≈øhould carry home a great Oak out of the wood at once by his hor≈øe-Cart, and threatned him ≈øore if he did not execute his command; the clown ea≈øily under≈øtanding that it was utterly unpo≈ø≈øible for him to obey his Ma≈øters precept, entred the Wood with great ≈øighs, and ≈øad complaints: there came to him a Devill, haveing taken upon him a humane ≈øhape, and enquired of him the cau≈øe of his grief, to whom the ru≈øtick revealed the thing in order. The Devill bad him be of good cheer, and return to his hou≈øe, he would bring the Oak to his Ma≈øters hou≈øe without delay; the
Clown was ≈øcarce got home ere the Devill threw the huge Oak loadned with thick boughs, a thwart before the hou≈øe of the Noble man, and ≈øhut up the pa≈ø≈øage by rea≈øon of the thickne≈ø≈øe of the Tree boughs; and, when the Oak had contracted an adamant-like hardne≈ø≈øe, neither could it by any ≈øtrength or Art be cut, the Noble man was glad to break a wall on the other ≈øide of the hou≈øe, and to make a new gate in his other hou≈øes, not without great trouble and co≈øt. Fincelius, book 2.

THere appeared to a certain hone≈øt Matron, a widow, a kin≈øwoman to Phillip Melancthon, ≈øitting alone in her Parlour, her Husband being dead a day or two before, having for his companion a Monk of tall ≈øtature. The husband ≈øpoke to his wife with all the ≈øugred and loving expre≈ø≈øions he could, ≈øaying, Be of good comfort my Wife, for I am thy Husband, and weighty bu≈øine≈ø≈øes have compelled me to come to thee; when he had almo≈øt talked with her a whole hour, he exhorted her that ≈øhe would take care that Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øhould be celebrated for him being dead; and going away, he importun'd her that ≈øhe ≈øhould reach forth her right hand to him, which being reached out, he coloured it as black as a coal and her hand was marked and blotted with that colour all her life after. Fincelius, Book 2.

IN the year 1555. there was a ≈øpectrum appeard after this manner. At Brun≈øviga in the Village of Gehern, two miles di≈øtant from Blomenaw there was a certain country man, being imployed with his hor≈øes and Cart, going into the wood, ≈øaw before the entrance of the wood, ≈øome troops of hor≈øemen, harne≈ø≈øed all with black armour, whereat being terrified, he ran back to his hou≈øe and reported that a great troop of Souldiers appeared abroad; the Elders therefore and the Mini≈øter of the Word there, accompanying them, ha≈øtily went forth, and almo≈øt a hundred per≈øons (≈øome men and ≈øome women) went with them, and did ≈øee the≈øe hor≈øemen, and they reckoned them to be about fourteen troops, which immediately divided them≈øelves into two companies, and they being Mar≈øhalled into order, one company ≈øtood oppo≈øite to the other. At the la≈øt there i≈ø≈øued out a tall man of a black hue very formidable, out of each company, and both of them lighting from their hor≈øes, did view accurately each company. Which being done, they mounted their hor≈øes again, the Army being ≈øet in rank and file, and the troops ≈øet again≈øt one another, the hor≈øemen went forward, and filled the whole camp; the country men were ≈øpectatours of their march untill night came on. But when they heard no further at that time of any war or marching of the foot or hor≈øemen, they all agreed that it was a prodigy from the Devill, or a ≈øign of Gods anger. Fincelius, fir≈øt Book of Miracles.

IN the year 1567. in Trawtenaw, a City of Bohemia, there was one Stephen Hubener, that gathered ≈øuch great Riches, built ≈øuch ≈øtately hou≈øes, and was ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull that all admired. And at la≈øt falling ≈øick, dyed, and was very honourably inter'd. But a ≈øhort while after his death and buriall, his body (or that which is more likely, the Devill by his Diabolicall power, carried about his body) did pinch many men with ≈øuch ≈øtrait embracements, that many of them died, yet diver≈øe recovered again, who all with one con≈øent confe≈ø≈øed that they were thus cla≈øped or beclipped by this rich man, in that very habit in which they had ≈øeen him alive, therefore the Magi≈øtrate of that place, that he might void or lay this Satanical ≈øight, commanded the body of that man to be digged out of the grave, after he had lain in the Earth twenty weeks, yet was not corrupted or rotten, but fat, as young and well fed bodies u≈øe to be; the body was delivered to the Hangman, to be carried away to the place of execution, where he cut off his head with his Axe, and anatomizing him, took out his heart, and did cleave it: there i≈ø≈øued out of his body bloud, as if he had been alive (witch-like) to ≈øu≈øtain puni≈øhment, therefore the Hangman threw the body into the fire, a great company ≈øtanding by, his head being bound to his feet, and ≈øo he tyed neck and heels.

ABout two hundred years ≈øince, in Hammel, a Town in Germany, the Devill in the likene≈ø≈øe of a man walked about the ≈øtreets of the City, playing many youthfull pranks, inticed many boyes and girls to him, and drawing them without the City gates unto a bordering mountain, he together with them vani≈øhed away: which when it was told to the Citizens, by a wench which was afar off, and ≈øecure, they with great care ≈øought their children in the Rivers, woods, and all about the Country, but none ever knew why or how they were thus deprived of them. Which Hi≈øtory is recorded in the Annals of that forementioned City, and is read by many Famous and illu≈øtrious men. Fincelius, fir≈øt book.

ON a time the Devill made a great moan and complaint as though he was afflicted by ≈øome terrible pain, ≈øaying, he was the Soul of this and the other man, that he might delude men, there are very many Hi≈øtories of this kind, and we have reckoned ≈øome before. Peter Mamorius ≈øaith, there was a thing happened about the River at Vienna in France, in ≈øome hou≈øes of Capland, in the year 1458. that the Devil did give out, he was the Soul of one decea≈øed, filling all places with his ≈øighs, clamours and lamentations, wi≈øhing he had ≈øome prayers made for him, and that pilgrimages might be undergone, and declaring very many other things, But, ≈øaid one to him, If thou woulde≈øt have us to believe thee; ≈øay, Have mercy on me O God according to thy great mercy in Chri≈øt: He made an≈øwer, he could not do ≈øo; then they that ≈øtood by mocked him, and he being fretted went away.

D. Bartholomew Fayus writes, when Nicolas Alberia Vervinen≈øis, had prayers made at his Grand-fathers grave, there came out of the ground a man wrapped with a ≈øheet, who ≈øpoke to a woman, and told her, he was her Grandfather; and, that he might be delivered from Purgatory, it was needfull that they ≈øhould ≈øing Ma≈ø≈øe, and have a Progre≈ø≈øion into the hou≈øe of the Virgin Mary; then uncovering him≈øelf, ≈øhe ≈øaw he was her Grandfather; then ≈øhe procured a great company of Ma≈ø≈øes to be ≈øaid: but when ≈øhe cea≈øed from their celebration, ≈øhe was grievou≈øly tormented, and at la≈øt he confe≈ø≈øed that he was Beelzebub. But this ≈øtory being blazed about all France, I ≈øhall ≈øay no more of it. But now ≈øee another new ≈øtory which is well-known to the Citizens of Paris, al≈øo printed, which happened at Lutetia, at the ≈øign of the Red Hor≈øe in the Street of St. Honoratus.

A certain man called Metaxarius, when he ≈øaw a Neece of his who was an Orphan, he took her home. Whil≈øt ≈øhe prayed at her father Gerva≈øe's grave, the Devill met her in the ≈øhape of a tall man of black colour, and taking her by the hand, ≈øaid; Friend, do not fear, thy father and thy Mother are in a good place. But yet, there ≈øhould ≈øome Ma≈ø≈øes be ≈øaid, and ≈øhe ≈øhould go a pilgrimage to our Queen and Lady of vertues, and ≈øo ≈øtraightway they ≈øhould go to Paradi≈øe, to the Virgin: She asking who he was; he gave this an≈øwer, That he was Satan, and admoni≈øhed her lea≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould be afraid: the maid did what he commanded, which done, Satan bad her take a pilgrimage to St. James. To whom ≈øhe ≈øaid, I cannot take ≈øuch a long journey: from that time Satan gave not over importunately to urge her, and familiarly calling her, ≈øaid, How cruell thou art; ≈øaying, ≈øhe will not put her ≈øhears into her bo≈øome for me, which when ≈øhe had done ≈øo to ≈øatisfy him, that ≈øhe might free her ≈øelf from his importunity, he furthermore asked that ≈øhe would give him ≈øomething; at the la≈øt proceeding, ≈øo far that he asked one of her hairs; ≈øhe gave him one: ≈øometimes he a≈ø≈øayed to per≈øwade her to drown her ≈øelf, and at another time to ≈øtrangle her ≈øelf, and he putting a rope about her neck, had been choaked if ≈øhe had not cryed out, and ≈øometimes her Uncle de≈øirous to defend her, was ≈øo beaten, he knew not by whom, that he lay ≈øick above 15. dayes, and once the Evill ≈øpirit offered to lye with her and to offer violence to her cha≈øtity, but ≈øhe ≈øtrongly re≈øi≈øting, was ≈øo beaten with his ≈øtripes that the bloud gu≈øhed out of her body in divers places. Among≈øt tho≈øe that ≈øaw her, there was a certain Secretary of the Bi≈øhop of Valenti ‚Ä¢ e named Choinius, who told the maid that the be≈øt way to drive the Divell away, was, not to give an≈øwer to his words, although he bad her pray to God, which he never did, but after a bla≈øphemous manner, or mocking that devotion, u≈øing it to created beings; the Devill ≈øeeing that the maid would not an≈øwer him, and that he could do no good of her in that ca≈øe, took her and threw her upon the ground, and from that time ≈øhe never ≈øaw him after. Bodin relates the≈øe things in his Treati≈øe of Magicall Demon. Book 3. chap. 6.

MIchael Curopalates Rancabes Imp. had a certain maid that was his bond-≈øervant, which at an Eclip≈øe, or conjunction of the Moon with the Sun, was ≈øtruck with Madne≈ø≈øe, and cryed to the Emperour, De≈øcend, de≈øcend, and give place to others: this being often done, made the Emperour afraid, therefore taking coun≈øell of his ≈øervant Theodatus Michael F. asked the wench that was mad, to what hou≈øe of the Palatinate that might belong or concern, and by what ≈øignes and tokens he might know, When the maid was in her frantick fit; and asked, ≈øhe did intimate and ≈øignify the Armenian Lion namely, and de≈øcribed its marks and its fa≈øhion. But when ≈øhe commanded Theodatus to come down from his Tower, ≈øhe did Prophecy of two men which ≈øhould meet him, whereof one of them ≈øitting on a Mule ≈øhould be he that ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe and enjoy the Kingdome. Theodatus went to that appointed place, to ≈øearch about the thing, and there knew the man by his token which the girl had before taught them, and ≈øo they perceived that ≈øhe did not prophecy fal≈øe, by rea≈øon that ≈øhe was in≈øpired by the Devill, by whom ≈øhe was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Cedrenus and Zonaras, tome 3.

ERa≈ømus Roterdamus in an Oration which he writ in the prai≈øe of Phy≈øick, ≈øaith, that he ≈øaw a Man, one Phliarius Poletanus by name, who being an Italian, and not at all skilled in the Dutch, yet perfectly did ≈øpeak that language, as though he had been po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Devill. Wherefore he was taken in hand by a famous Panacean Phy≈øitian, and giving him Phy≈øick, brought out of him a great ≈øort of Worms, and ≈øo freed the man of his di≈øea≈øe, and al≈øo deprived him of his Germain language. Cardan de Rer. var. Book 8. chap. 43.

NOrbertus at Nigella u≈øing exorci≈øms to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe a certain maid that was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the Devill, was derided by him, who did repeat the Canticles from one end to the other, in the mouth of the girl, and after did Interpret it in the Latine and Germain tongue; but at la≈øt a Bi≈øhop ≈øharply with≈øtanding him, he was expelled out of her in the year 1122. As the continuator of Sigebert hath it.

IN Italy there was a certain Virgin po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Devill, and utterly ignorant of the Latine Tongue, and being asked by Lazarus Bonamicus, a Bononian Profe≈ø≈øour, which was the be≈øt Ver≈øe in Virgill, ≈øhe an≈øwered, or rather the Devill out of her.
Di≈øcite ju≈øtitiam moniti, & non temnere divos.
Be warn'd to learn right, and obey the gods.
Manlius, fir≈øt Book by the relation of Phil. Melancth.

IN a Wilderne≈ø≈øe of the Countrey of Tingut the voices of Devils and ≈øpirits are heard, who call tho≈øe by their own names who are walking alone, or el≈øe wandring a≈øide from their company, and
feigns the voices of their companions, and ≈øo mi≈øleading them out of their way, he hurries them into de≈øtructions gulph, ≈øometimes a con≈øort of mu≈øicall in≈øtruments are heard, but more oftner the noi≈øe of Drums. Mun≈øters Co≈ømograph. Book 5.

THere was a certain Citizen of Erphord that for ≈øome years together kept a Crow in his hou≈øe, and when he ≈øaw any ≈øilent or ≈øorrowfull, he u≈øed the≈øe words after a je≈øting manner; O my Crow, what makes thee ≈øo ≈øad, what thinke≈øt thou of? To which, beyond all expectation, the Crow, or the Devill in it, clearly, and with a lively voice, recited a Ver≈øe out of the 77. P≈øalm, I have thought of old, and I have had eternity in my mind, and thus the Devill ≈øpoke out of the Crow. Ca≈øpar Goldw. in his Book of Miracles.

HIeronimus Cardanus told his Father that there appeared ≈øeven ≈øpirits which did di≈øpute with him about divers wonderfull things, and did enucleate and unmask hidden my≈øteries that were before unknown out of the Manu≈øcript writings of Averroes, of Phy≈øitians principles.

IN the raign of Trajan, a Crow, but rather the Devill out of the Crow, began to ≈øpeak with humane voice, and cryed out of the Capitol in Greek, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , omnia bell√® ≈øe habebunt, i. e. All things ≈øhall be well; from whence came that di≈øtick of an unknown Authour.

q.l: Est bene non potuit dicere, dixit Erit.

div.p:
A Mo≈øt certain argument to prove that tho≈øe men are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, is, they ≈øpeak tho≈øe tongues which they never learnt: Bodin ≈øaith, there was one who≈øe name was Samuel, being but twelve years of age in the Village of Wantelet ad Laod, he was the Son of a Noble man, Lord of the Land, who was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Devill a Month after his Mothers death, and grievou≈øly vexed and buffe ‚Ä¢ ted, al≈øo the Devill had power over his body, and if any one would withdraw the bo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he did retract him again by violence, his father would not have him exorci≈øed (for Religion's ≈øake which he profe≈ø≈øed). And whether or no he was freed from it, the twelfth or thirteenth year he was pa≈øt, in which the woman of Vervinens was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by an evill ≈øpirit, but ≈øhe had an exorci≈øm I know not: which Hi≈øtory I pa≈ø≈øe over, becau≈øe it was related in diver≈øe books, which are now printed. Italy and Spain abounds with ≈øuch demoniacal per≈øons which had need be bound up in chains; tho≈øe can
≈øpeak Greek and Latine, and other tongues which they never learnt (or which is more likely, the Devill ≈øpeaks in them): for if at any time that Woman of Vervinen≈øis had put out her tongue a great length, the ≈øpirit then ≈øpoke mo≈øt Eloquently. Melancthon reports that he ≈øaw a woman in Saxony that was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, who could neither read nor write, yet did ≈øpeak Greek and Latine, and Prophe≈øie of that cruell war in Saxony, ≈øaying; Great mi≈øery ≈øhall come upon this Country, and Famine upon this people. Fernelius, in his book of the ≈øecret cau≈øes of things, tells, that he ≈øaw a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Boy ≈øpeaking Greek, for all that he knew no letters. Hippocrates, in his Book De Sacro morbo, thought it to be the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, but ≈øome afterwards in Greek did accurately note the difference; For tho≈øe who were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed ≈øpoke divers languages, and prophe≈øied, which could not be ob≈øerved in tho≈øe who had the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.

IN the reign of Argyropolis Emperour of Rome in the Thracian Province at the bottome of the Fountain of Curena, there was a mi≈øerable dolefull noi≈øe heard, mixed with howlings and lamentations not onely for once or twice, but continually dayes and nights from March to July. And when ≈øome came to ≈øee the place from whence the voice was heard, there was another howling thwarted them. I ≈øuppo≈øe this miracle did foretell the ≈ølaughter of the Romans in Coclo≈øyria. Cedrenus.

CAlligraphus, a reverend man of Alexandria, going out of his hou≈øe in the night time, at midnight he ≈øaw brazen ≈øtatues ≈øpeaking with a loud voice, that Mauritius the Emperour of Constantinople was ≈ølain, together with his children at Byzantium: going forth in the morning, he related it to Augustulus, who warned him not to tell it to any, and pre≈øcribing a day, in the ninth day, there came a Me≈ø≈øenger declaring the death of Mauritius. Then Augustulus did publi≈øh to the people the Devills Prophecy. Paul. Diacon. Book 17. of Romane Hi≈øtory; and Nicephorus, Book 18. Chap. 41.

HIrcanus ‚ñ™ 3d Captain of the Jews, and High Prie≈øt, when he had deputed his two ≈øons, Ari≈øtobulus and Antigonus to the ≈øiege of Samaria, and the Samaritans having implored help of Antiochus Cyzicenus, it was reported that in the very ≈øame day in which his ≈øons had entred battell with Cyzicenus, the High Prie≈øt being alone in the Temple, heard a voice that mentioned the new gotten victory of Antioch by his ≈øons, which he ‚Ä¢ and by going forth publi≈øhed to the people, and a while after his Oracle came certainly to pa≈ø≈øe. Jo≈øephus Book 13. chap. 18.

WHen the Romans in a great battell with the Tarquinians ≈øent away L. Junius Brutus Con≈øull, but in the following night, ≈øuch an affrightment ≈øeized upon the Enemies, The Tarquinians and the Vejentes in ≈øilent troops returned home as conquer'd
men. The report is, that in the next night after the battell out of the next wood (which Livy calls Ar≈ø ‚Ä¢ a, and Dyoni≈øius ≈øaid it was a Holy wood) a loud voice was heard whether it was the voice of a Faune or Silvaine it could not be re≈øolved, which happened more then once in the Hetru≈øian war, which prodigy did ≈øo affright the enemies that they yielded them≈øelves as conquer'd. Sabellicus Book 7. Ennead 2. Valerius Book 1. chap. 8.

IN that day which Cae≈øar fought with Pompey at Phar≈øalia, C. Cornelius of Patavia, being Augur, when he had taken augury, at the fir≈øt ≈øight ≈øuddenly turning to tho≈øe that were by him; ≈øaid, now the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is done, now the men begin their work, and trying his augury the ≈øecond time, he with a loud voice cryed out; O Cae≈øar, Thou overcome≈øt, they that ≈øtood about him, admiring at the thing he took the Crown from off his head, and ≈øwore he would not put it on again untill the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe made his art believed or credited. Livius and Plutarch in Cae≈øar and Pliny, ≈øaith, there ≈øuch a noi≈øe came when two armies were fighting one again≈øt the other to the augurs ≈øitting on the Patavian Mountains, being bold to affirm by that, either the world would be di≈ø≈øolved quickly, or Cae≈øar was fighting with Pompey. Sabellicus Book 7. Ennead. 6. out of the 15th Book of Gellius chap. 18.

WHen Antonius fell from Domitius, and a great war was expected in Germany, the City being affrighted, and the people of them≈øelves without any other author, di≈øper≈øed the ≈øame of the victory, and a report going throughout Rome that Antonius was killed, and that no part of his army was left alive, it was ≈øo really believed that a great part of the Magi≈øtrates ≈øacrificed. But when the Authour of the rumour was ≈øought out, but none appeared, but the news was put off from one to another, every one clearing them≈øelves of it, and being as it were labrynthed, and plunged in a va≈øt Ocean, they could not make it appear from what original or Fountain it proceeded, the fame of which quickly over≈øpread the City. But a Me≈ø≈øenger and letters meeting Domitian in his journey, leading out the Legions to war, intimating victory, ≈øo that one day was the day of Trophyes and of Fame too, in places di≈øtant more then two thou≈øand five hundred Miles. Plutarchus in Aemilio.

SO≈øipatra a woman of Alexandrina, at a certain time being among≈øt her acquaintance, and a di≈øputation ari≈øing about the Soul, ≈øhe was wrapt by a certain fury ≈øuddenly, ≈øhe ≈øeemed as though her voice was taken away, and was for a while dumb, by and by ≈øhe began to cry out, My Cozen Philometor being tran≈øported in a Charriot, is now ore-turn'd in a thorny place, and hath hurt his ellow and his hands are wounded, and a certain man complaining, the thing was a while after known which confirmed the truth. Eunapius in Aede≈øio.

THamus an Egyptian Pilot, ≈øayling to Rome late at night near the Echinad I≈ølands, night being far ≈øpent, heard the voice of an unknown Author, which cal'd him by his own name: they that were in the ≈øhip were all amazed, and when it called the third time he an≈øwered; then ≈øaith the voice, When thou come≈øt into the next I≈øland, the voice being heard as if it were on the foredeck. Thamus being a≈øtoni≈øhed, and religiou≈øly given, obeyed its commands, and immediately after it had given its precepts, ≈øuch howling, mourning, and lamentations was heard in the Ayre, that all thereabouts was almo≈øt dead with fear. The news quickly arrived at Rome, and Tiberius Cae≈øar commanded Thamus to be brought before him, and examined, that he might know the truth of it; the Augures and High Prie≈øts con≈øulting about it, they an≈øwered, Pana perhaps was born of Mercury and Penelope. Plutarch relates this in his book of Oracles, which Oracles then were made dumb, in which place although we may acknowledge the ≈øubtily of Satan, and the Devill being bu≈øied about bringing the death of Chri≈øt into que≈øtion, and to mock it by ≈øuch a fiction, except he would by Pans death infer that mens Souls after death ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed, or annihilated.

MOnobazus the King of the Adiabenians, his ≈øirname was Barles, being in love with Helens ≈øi≈øter, married her, and of her had Monobazus, and other children of other wives. At the la≈øt lying with his wife big with child, and laying his hand upon his wives belly, he thought he heard a certain voice bidding him to take off his hand from her belly, le≈øt he ≈øhould oppre≈ø≈øe her young; which as it was begun with divine providence, ≈øo it was likely to have a pro≈øperous end. He was affrighted with this voice, and ≈øhewed the thing in≈øtantly to his wife, and he called the Son Izatch that was born at that birth; And by rea≈øon of this prediction he made him Heyre to the Kingdome. But he together with his mother embracing the Jewi≈øh Religion, re≈øtored Artabanus the King, again to the Parthian Kingdome, and fortunately fought again≈øt the Arabians and Parthians in the 55. year of his age and 24. of his reign, he died and left the Kingdome to his Brother Monobazus. Ex Jo≈øeph. Book 20. chap. 2.

NIcephorus Phaeus the Emperour, did fortify the Palace of the Con≈øtantinopolitan Tower, in which it was foretold him that he ≈øhould dye. At what time the walls of the Palace was builded, in the night ≈øea≈øon a certain man ≈øailing on the Sea, cryed out after this manner: O Emperour, thou make≈øt up thy walls, and although thou rai≈øe≈øt them up to Heaven, whil≈øt that which is within is evill, the City may be ea≈øily taken: He that ≈øpoke tho≈øe things, was a long time and very much ≈øought after, but never could be found out, the wall was fini≈øhed, he peri≈øhed that ≈øame day that he had the keyes delivered by him that had the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe committed to him. Cedrenus.

WHen Opicinus Cacia Novaria, being very thoughtfull or Melancholly, walked alone in his hou≈øe at noon-tide, he heard ≈øomething call him by his name, but ≈øaw no Man, and afterwards ≈øaid, Would≈øt thou be willing that thy Son ≈øhould dye? To whom he an≈øwered, (having no time to con≈øider of it) he would, but afterwards coming to him≈øelf, quickly denyed that which he had a≈ø≈øented to, and was very ≈øorry for the cruelty of the prodigy; therefore within three dayes his ≈øon John Bapti≈øt having no more, fell ≈øick, and two dayes after dyed. Fulgo≈øus, Book 1. chap. 4.

BEfore Neroes death, there was a confu≈øed murmure mixed with laughter, and a tumult in the Theater with great mourning was heard when no man was there. In Albania it rained bloud, and both the dores of Mau≈øeolus (in which were the Tombs of the Cae≈øars, he being the la≈øt of that ≈øtock) and the dores of his bed of their own accord flew open, out of which there was heard a voice calling Nero to him. Xiphilinus ex Dione.

M. Antonius Majoragius reported that in the Moneth of Aprill there was heard, in Eupilus Lake, a ≈øound, or voice crying after this ≈øort, Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh; The fir≈øt part of which had a Mu≈øicians ≈øong, the latter part of the voice had their brief, and in tho≈øe years, nor in any other, were there ever a more plentifull encrea≈øe of Wine, Wheat, and other things. Cardane Book 15. chap. 85. de rerum Varietate.

THere appeared to Hircanus the Captain of the Jews, and being al≈øo High Prie≈øt, a certain ≈øight, which enquired about his ≈øucce≈ø≈øour, being carefull of Ari≈øtobulus and Antigonus his elde≈øt, which he loved above all their other brethren. But when God had ≈øhewed the picture of Alexander, the younge≈øt ≈øorrowfull that he ≈øhould be ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull and pro≈øperous in all his proceedings, commanded that he ≈øhould be brought out of Galilee, le≈øt he ≈øhould be in any capacity of having the Kingdome after him, but the event made the Oracle be believed, for he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Kingdome after Ari≈øtobulus who before had ≈ølain Antigonus, and killed the other brother that with≈øtood him, but the other that was contented with a private life he honoured, Jo≈øephus, Book 13. chap. 20.

BEfore Camillus's bani≈øhment M. Cedicitius a vulgar per≈øon declared, or gave it out, that in the night before he was called out of his way (which they call the new way) by a loud voice and looking back, and ≈øeeing no man, he heard a voice greater then a mans, which ≈øpoke thus to him: Go to M. Cedicitius, and tell the Tribunitian Souldiers, betimes in the morning, they may expect the French within a few dayes, The Tribunes de≈øpi≈øed and laughed at tho≈øe relations. A little after this came Camillus's di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and the Inva≈øion of the French. Plutarch. in Camillo; et Sabellicus, book 9. Ennead. 3.

LYcurgus hapned to come to Olympia, and was a ≈øpectator of the games there: it is reported that this befell him, viz. that there was a voice like the voice of a man behind him rebuking him and wondring at him why he did not ≈øtir up his Citizens to celebrate that ≈øolemnity, he turned him≈øelf about, and finding no man that ≈øpoke to him, then he was per≈øwaded it was a divine voice, and gathered Iphitus and his companions to him≈øelf, and made a great fea≈øt by which the ≈øolemnity became much more remarkable. Plutarchus in Lycurgo.

CA≈øsius Chaerea, captain of the Guard, with ≈øome others, made a con≈øpiracy again≈øt Caligula. And when he was going into the Court, he heard a voice from among the multitude, commanding him to perfect their de≈øignes, the Gods being their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants. At fir≈øt he ≈øu≈øpected that their plot was betrayed by ≈øome of the Con≈øpirators, but afterwards he perceived, that he was incited thereunto, either by ≈øome that knew it, or by an Oracle from God. On the 3d day therefore they ≈ølew Caius Circen≈øis. Jo≈øephus, lib. 19. cap. 1.

PErtharis, King Arithpertus his Son, who being bani≈øhed by Grimoaldus, and in his bani≈øhment ≈øailing into Britain, was warn'd by an unknown voice, that Grimoaldus being dead by Phlebotomy, he ≈øhould ≈øeek for his fathers Kingdome. Whereat being moved, though he knew not the Authour, yet returning into Italy, within three Moneths after the death of Grimoaldus, he was made King of the Lombards. Platina in Dono.

C. Ho≈øtilius Mancinus the Con≈øull, going into Spain, as he was taking Ship at Hercules his Haven, whither he went on foot, this ≈øounded in his ears: Mancinus, ≈øtay. He being affrighted herewith, turn'd his journy, and went unto Genoa; and when he had there ≈øhipped him≈øelf, a huge great Snake appeared to him, and pre≈øently vani≈øht out of ≈øight. He being conquer'd by the Numantes, yielded ba≈øely. Valerius Max. lib. 1. cap. 6.

HEnry the third being Emperour, kept the Fea≈øt of Penteco≈øt at the City Ments in Almaine. Where aro≈øe a di≈ø≈øention between the ≈øervants of the Archbi≈øhop of Mogun, and the ≈øervants of Abbas Fuld, about their hire. They went from words to blows, and fighting with Swords, they polluted the Temple with mans bloud. The Bi≈øhops running to them, brake off this bloudy battle, and again purged the Temple. The tumult being afterwards pacified, when they ≈øang, Thou ha≈øt made this day glorious. The Devill was heard to cry aloud through the Temple. I have made this day quarrel≈øome. The Emperour amazed at this ≈øtrange noi≈øe, endeavoured to force away the Devill by giving many Alms, and he him≈øelf with his Nobles, di≈øtributed to the poor tho≈øe dainties which
were provided for his own Court. Nauclerus, Volumine 2. Generatione 36.

WHen (Rome being pillaged and undone by a home bred con≈øpiracy) Con≈øtans the Emperour had remained ≈øix years in Sicily, he died at Saroga≈øa a City thereof, in a Bath called Daphne. For one Andreas went with him into the Bath, and killed the Emperour by throwing down a Ve≈ø≈øel on his head as he was wiping him. Con≈øtans his death was known in the City the ≈øame day he died by a voice coming forth out of the Ayre. Zonaras & Cedrenus.

BOdin ≈øaith of Con≈øtantinus, who is accounted among≈øt the skillfulle≈øt workmen of the Mettal-Art in France, and is the mo≈øt famous in all the Kingdome. I have heard his comrades, when blowing a long time, no hope or likelihood of any good appeared, ask advice from the Devill, if they did right, and might accompli≈øh what they de≈øired: But he replyed in one word, Travaillez, take the pains; the blowers being animated with this, blew ≈øo ≈øtrongly that they brought all to nothing; and they would ≈øtill have blowen if Con≈øtantine had not told them this was the Devills u≈øual cu≈øtome, to an≈øwer doubtfully: But that word, Take the pains, imployed that Alchymy ≈øhould be laid a≈øide, and he ≈øhould fall to ≈øome labour, and hone≈øt Art or ≈øcience commodious to get a living: he is a mad man, that thinks Gold can ≈øo quickly be made, in making whereof nature ≈øpends more then a thou≈øand years.

A Souldier gave a Hor≈øe to his kin≈øman, that when he died, he ≈øhould ≈øell him‚ñ™ and give the Money to the poor. He ≈øold the Hor≈øe and kept the Money to him≈øelf. Thirty dayes after, his Soul returning; (It was the Devill) ≈øaith, Thirty dayes have I bin tormented in Hell; but thou, who gave≈øt not to the poor what I had thee, ≈øhalt go thither to day, and I ≈øhall be tran≈ølated from thence into Paradi≈øe. replyed: Tell the Deputy, for he hoped he would confirm his purpo≈øe. JOhn Fernelius relates in his ≈øecond Book of occult cau≈øes, That when a certain Man was travelling in Summer time, he was very dry in the night, and ri≈øing out of his dream, and being awakened, and finding no drink, he by chance catched hold on ≈øome evil thing which he met; and commanding it, he perceived that his jawes were ≈øhut together as though by a hand, and was like to have been ≈øtrangled: and when he was thus be≈øieged and be≈øet with this ≈øpirit, he thought he ≈øaw in the dark a great black Dogg, and feared to be devoured by it; who afterwards being re≈øtored to his right wits again, did relate it all in order: Many judged, this man, by his pul≈øe, and heat and roughne≈øs of his tongue, and by rea≈øon of too much watching, was meerly mad and di≈øtracted. The ≈øame Author reports, That there was another young man, of a Knights Family, for ≈øome few years by the ≈øhaking of his body, was judged to have the Convul≈øion fits; for ≈øometimes he would ≈øo move and fling his left arm, only, ≈øometimes his right, ≈øometimes onely one finger, otherwhile a leg, and both at other times, and the trunck of his body with ≈øuch ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe, that being laid down, he could ≈øcarce be held in by four ≈øervants; But his head laid without being ≈øhaken or ≈øtirr'd at all; and he had his tongue and ≈øpeech free, and was in his right mind and ≈øen≈øes; yea, in the height of his Convul≈øions, he was taken with it at lea≈øt ten times every day, but was well in the intervals, but ≈øomething worn out by pain. skilfull Phy≈øitians con≈øulted with about it, and they did think it was a Convul≈øion, near bordering on the Epilep≈øie, together with a malignant and venomous vapour that did beat again≈øt the backbone, out of which the vapour came, which did flow into tho≈øe nerves, which are ≈øprigg'd from the back-bone into the joynts all about, but not into the brain; this cau≈øe being taken for granted, that it might be removed, they mini≈øtred to him divers gly≈øters and ≈øtrong purgations of all ≈øorts, and Cupping-gla≈ø≈øes were fa≈øtened to the roots of the nerves, nouri≈øhing things, oyntments, plai≈øters, which fir≈øt were for purgation, after for ≈øtrengthening, to drive away this malignant and poy≈øonous humours; the≈øe doing him little good, they procured him ≈øweating in Baths and in wa≈øhes, in the juice of the Ebeene Tree of Guaiaca, which did as little help him, becau≈øe all of us ≈øtrayed far from the knowledg of the truth; for being fir≈øt taken with it, in the third moneth a certain devill, being the author of all this mi≈øchief, did betray him≈øelf with a voice, and in uncouth words and phra≈øes, and ≈øentences, as well Latin and Greek, although the afflicted party was ignorant of the Greek tongue; he did detect many ≈øecrets of Phy≈øitians, that he had circumvented them with much danger, and that they had by their fruitle≈ø≈øe Medicines almo≈øt choaked his body. IN the year, 1536, at Franckford at Ucadra, there was a Maid, being the daughter of Marcus the Fi≈øherman, that was taken with a pain in the head, and by a phren≈øie, one Georgius a Kuli≈øch, a Citizen, pitying her condition, took her into his hou≈øe; at length, when ≈øhe was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Devil, ≈øhe did very wonderful feats, what≈øoever ≈øhe fingred, whether it was a cloath, any bodies brea≈øt, beard, head, ≈øhe ≈ønatched at it, and afterwards ≈øhe got the Coyn that was u≈øed in that Country, and forthwith throwing it into her mouth, ≈øhe chewed and did eat it; And ≈øhe did take away money which was held fa≈øt in their hands, at which they admired greatly. ANno 1559. not far from Joachims Valleys, there was a Smith had a daughter excelled in mode≈øty and hone≈øty, being diligently conver≈øant in exerci≈øes of Piety, (by Divine permi≈ø≈øion) ≈øhe was ≈øet upon by Satan about Lent-time, oftentimes the divel took her, and threw her upon the ground, as if ≈øhe had been vexed with the Falling-≈øickne≈øs; Which thing troubled her Parents ≈øo, that they ≈øought coun≈øel of them that prophe≈øie of future things, by a Pythonick or divelli≈øh ≈øpirit. To which things Helias replyed, Let thy Dance lead thee into the bottom of Hell. The Devil an≈øwered, Go thy waies, now thou ≈øhalt ≈øee dances. The≈øe words being uttered, he roared and bellowed, and by and by entring into a ≈øtove, he appeared in the ≈øhape of a Catt and Dogg; the≈øe with wonderful leaping did lead the Dance, and at la≈øt vanqui≈øhed: He played many pranks of this kind: Two dayes after Trinity-Sunday the holy Prie≈øt did ≈øet upon the Devil again, enquiring of him by what means or power he had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed her? by the command of God, ≈øaith he, from whom I am ≈øent, that I might torment the body, but I cannot hurt her ≈øoul; that I might give notice to Men, that they ≈øhould ab≈øtain from pride, u≈øury, gluttony, and other ≈øins of that nature: and although it be ≈øore again≈øt my will to promulgate the≈øe things, yet I am commanded by God, and forced to do it: At the la≈øt day I know, that I ≈øhall have more ≈øouls then God him≈øelf will have. To which the Mini≈øter of the Word of Schlackwalden≈øis replyed, Thou lye≈øt, ≈øaith he, O ≈øacrilegious Wretch, for if ≈øinners ≈øhall repent, they ≈øhall have ≈øalvation; but the eternall God at the day of Judgment, will thru≈øt thee and thy companions into Hell fire. And this conflict did la≈øt near two hours: Among≈øt other things, the Mini≈øter ≈øaid, Behold, thou that hast been the chiefe≈øt and beautifulle≈øt of creatures, and the vertex of the Creation, veils thy ≈øelf under the ugly mask of a hog, or other unclean bea≈øt. Some few daies being pa≈øt, the Pious Prie≈øt brought out the Maid, and there in a great Congregation of people they did pray to God, and prai≈øed him with Hymnes and P≈øalms, and as often as Je≈øus Chri≈øt was named, the Devil did rage with a bellowing and hideous noi≈øe, as though a ruine was threatned to ≈øeize on all things: The≈øe things performed, they went away.
