IN the Year 1567, in Trawtenaw, a City of Bohemia, there was a certain Man, who did ≈øo gather up Riches, and erect famous Buildings, and was ≈øo fortunate in all his enterpri≈øes, that every one admired at him; at length he fell into a ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and dyed thereof, and was very honourably buried: But a little while after his death and burial, his body (or rather a Devill, who by his diabolical power carried his body all about) did cla≈øp and embrace very many men ≈øo ≈øtraitly, that many of them dyed; yet ≈øome of tho≈øe recovered again, who all with one con≈øent confe≈ø≈øed, that they were thus beclipped and hugg'd by this rich man, being in the ≈øame habit that they had ≈øeen him when he was alive: Therefore the Governour of that place, that this Spectrum might be laid and repre≈ø≈øed, commanded the body of that man to be digged up, and the grave opened; and although he had layn in the ground for the ≈øpace of 20 weeks, yet he was not rotten, but was as fat and plump, as young and well nouri≈øhed bodies u≈øe to be; the body was delivered to the hangman then, who carried it away unto the place where malefactors u≈øed to receive their puni≈øhment; he cut off his head with an ax, and when the body was wrapt up, he took out the

CAe≈øarius Colonien≈øis writes in his dialogue, of a Prie≈øts daughter that was much tormented by a wicked ≈øpirit, and was mad; her father was coun≈øelled to do after this manner, That he ≈øhould ≈øend his daughter beyond the River Rhene, and by that means the Devil departed from her; but he did ≈øo beat her father, that about three dayes after, he dyed.

THere are, ≈øaith Bodinus, in Spain, Italy, and e≈øpecially Germany, that are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the Devil for ten or twenty years, that they cannot be driven away; ≈øo there were found ≈øome boyes of Am≈øterdam, in the year 1556, who were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed 30 years, and the Devils could not be driven away by any Exorci≈øm. APollonius being in India with the Brachman-Philo≈øophers, reports that he ≈øaw very ≈øtrange wonders: he ≈øaid that the≈øe Philo≈øophers at their plea≈øure could make it fair and foul weather, bring tempe≈øts, or make calms, and could prepare fea≈øts with all the Ve≈ø≈øels fitting for them (yea, he ≈øaith that they did it in his pre≈øence) when there was none to be ≈øeen, who make ready the banquet, or waited in ≈øetting on, and taking off the di≈øhes. IN the Ephe≈øian Letters, there is mention made of tho≈øe, who with wonderful facility, as by a divine in≈øpiration, attained to what they de≈øired; for they report at Ephe≈øus, there are divers Notes, and magical voices, by the u≈øing of which they are victorious in every bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, as Diogenianus, Eu≈øtachius reports by tho≈øe Letters, That there were divers words like to riddles, having no coherence, written in the feet, girdle, and crown of Diana. IT is reported, that Zoroa≈øtres, the King of the Bactrians, found out the Art of Magick, and hath written a hundred thou≈øand of ver≈øes upon them (as Pliny witne≈ø≈øeth); Some would have this King to be Mizraim the ≈øon of Cham, others ≈øay he was not ≈øo; he flouri≈øhed above eight hundred years before the Trojan War, which was in Abraham's time; But he, as we read in Clements Itinerary, being willing to contemplate God, and much given to A≈øtronomy, and minding the Stars, did ≈øtrike out ≈øome ≈øparks out of the Stars, that the rude multitude might be a≈øtoni≈øhed at the miracle. THe report went, that Per≈øes and Aeta, two brethren, ruled both at one time; this in Pontus, the other in Taurica, both of them being of a truculent and ≈øavage di≈øpo≈øition; Hecate ≈øprung from Per≈øes, nothing inferiour in cruelty and immanity to her father; which while ≈øhe was a Virgin, u≈øed to ≈øhoot darts (as the cu≈øtome was then); But her greater ≈øtudy was to make poy≈øons; ≈øome attribute the invention of Henbane to her, and was accu≈øtomed to experience the nature and ≈øtrength of poi≈øons upon ≈øtrangers; within a ≈øhort ≈øpace ≈øhe attempted to kill her father by her poy≈øon, and thereby unravell'd the clew of his life, by who≈øe death ≈øhe got the Kingdom; at Taurica ≈øhe erected a Temple to Diana, at who≈øe Altar ≈øhe offered, ≈øtrangers, whither≈øoever they came, from Sea or by Land, ≈øhe did enact, that they ≈øhould be ≈øacrificed, and by this means ≈øhe thought her fame would be ≈øpread in all Countries. After which, ≈øhe with a ≈ømall company of Women, was reported to keep a de≈øerted I≈øland in the Ocean; but the likelier report is, that ≈øhe came into Italy, and re≈øted in the Latian Promontory: then that Iland from her inhabiting there, got the name of Circei. BUt another that ≈øate upon a hor≈øe, and ≈øpurring him in a race, and as the hor≈øe was running, would get upon the ≈øaddle, and ≈øtand right up on the top of it, and would ≈øometimes with his legs being folded together, ≈øit upon the hor≈øe's main, and on his forehead, and on his buttocks, and flying to and fro, as though he were a bird; and ≈øometimes he would light off from his hor≈øe as he was running, and then catching hold on his tail, would leap upon him again, and was ≈øeen ≈øitting on his ≈øaddle pre≈øently, and lighting and ≈øhifting from another ≈øide, or part of his ≈øaddle, he would turn him≈øelf under his belly, and pre≈øently a≈øcend on the other ≈øide of the hor≈øe, and was carried by the hor≈øe, and when he did the≈øe things, he did not neglect to whip the hor≈øe to obtain the race, and the≈øe things did another of the Magitians. JA≈øon the ≈øon of Ae≈øon, Nephew to Pelias the The≈øsalonian King, wi≈øhing to do ≈øomething worthy of memory, and to imitate ≈øome heroick deeds of Per≈øius and others; Pelias did con≈øent to his de≈øire, not that he might encrea≈øe the glory of his youth, nor adde ≈øplendour to it, but hoping that he would quickly be ≈ølain in ≈øome warlike Expedition or other; for he feared his brother Ae≈øon, le≈øt by the help of his ≈øon, he ≈øhould get the Kingdom from him. Medea promi≈øed, that by her craft ≈øhe would kill Pelias, and would deliver the Kingdom unto them without any danger, and that ≈øhe would do her task too; for ≈øhe was to in≈øtruct them in every thing; and ≈øhe from the Palace was to give ≈øigns of the whole Affair (≈ømoke by day, fire by night) to the Keepers of the Watch-Tower on the Sea-coa≈øt; therefore preparing Diana's Image, which was convex and hollow, in which ≈øhe hid divers kinds of venomous things. Afterwards by her medicines making her hairs gray, and her face to be ≈øo rugged and wrinckled, that ≈øhe ≈øeemed to all that lookt on her, to be an old woman; then taking Diana's image, went forth into the City, and ≈øtirred all up to ≈øuper≈øtition, as though
≈øhe came from the Northern Countries for the King and Citie's good and welfare; divers wor≈øhipped her religiou≈øly as a Godde≈øs, all the whole people was ≈øo be≈øotted; and they brought Medea into the King's Palace: The≈øe things much increa≈øed Pelia's ≈øuper≈øtition, yea, and his daughters were ≈øo bewitched by Medea's Inchantments, that they were per≈øwaded that ≈øhe was a godde≈øs, that was come for the pro≈øperity and felicity of the Kingdom; for ≈øhe did affirm, that Diana was carried through the Ayr by Dragons, and that ≈øhe had gone about the greate≈øt part of the World, and that ≈øhe might be perpetually wor≈øhipped, they ought to choo≈øe the mo≈øt Religious King they could get; and moreover, that the Godde≈ø≈øe had commanded her, that with ≈øome Medicines, ≈øhe ≈øhould take away the old age from Pelias, and turn him young again. At which words the King admiring, commanded Medea to try the experiment upon her ≈øelf, that they might believe what ≈øhe ≈øaid. She required, that ≈øome pure water might be brought her by one of his daughters, and when ≈øhe had ≈øhut her ≈øelf up in her bed, ≈øhe anointed her body, and by the ≈øtrength of herbs ≈øhe was reduced to her former age; It is reported, that ≈øhe by her enchantments cau≈øed a Godde≈ø≈øe in the likene≈ø≈øe of Dragons to fly through the air, and ≈øupported by the Hyberboreans, which ≈øeemed to turn towards Pelias; Pelias e≈øteemed very much of Medea, and diligently commanded his daughters to do what ≈øhe commanded, and be ob≈øervant of her, and what≈øoever ≈øhe gave in charge to be done about her body, that they ≈øhould do it: In the following night it's reported, that Medea ≈øhould ≈øay, that it was nece≈ø≈øary that the body of Pelias ≈øhould be boyled in Copper, which when the Virgins were about to do it, they required one experiment, that they might give tru≈øt to her words; then there was a Ram that was kept in the hou≈øe for many years, to whom ≈øhe promi≈øed to the Virgins, if ≈øhe ≈øhould fir≈øt boyl that, ≈øhe would afterwards re≈øtore it into its former condition again. PHilip Melancthon reports, that he was told by Chri≈øtopher Gro≈øs and Sigi≈ømund Galenius, that a certain Virgin of Bononia, that was conver≈øant among≈øt men two years after her death, and who was at a Banquet whereunto ≈øhe was invited, not ta≈øting any meat, and ≈øitting among≈øt other Virgins, by chance a Magitian pre≈øent knowing the fraud of the Devil, ≈øaith to them that were pre≈øent; This pale Maid hath been dead, and coming ≈øtraight to her, taketh from under her right ≈øhoulder, an inchantment, whereupon ≈øhe appeared an ugly dead corps. A Studious young man of Sffordia, with the raging love of a Virgin, became almo≈øt mad by the violence of his pa≈ø≈øion; he being intimately acquainted with one skilfull in the Magick Art, was to ‚Ä¢ d by him, that he would by his skill ≈øo work, that the Maid with whom he was ≈øo much in love, ≈øhould come to him, ≈øo that he would ab≈øtain from the imbracing of her; the young man promi≈øeth

IN the year of Chri≈øt, 1543, a certain Italian, by name Andreas, a jugler of Sathan, coming up and down among≈øt the Sepulchres, and leading a red blind dog, by which he did many prodigious things; ≈øometimes in the middle of the Market, Andreas (a great company ≈øtanding about him) would cau≈øe them to throw down upon the ground gold, ≈øilver, and Iron rings, behind this dog, which after he had mixed together, the Dog at his command would deliver every one of them as they were taken a≈øunder to his proper owner; in like manner divers ≈øorts of coyn and moneys being confu≈øedly heaped together, he would at his Ma≈øters command in order di≈øcern, and deliver to the right owners; and if he were askt, who were fornicators, adulterers, or men of great authority and credit, he would mo≈øt certainly declare; and if any ≈øuch required the knowledg of any thing from him, he would ≈øuddenly ≈øatisfie them: wherefore ≈øome did not doubt to affirm, that he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a Pythonical or Satanick ≈øpirit. WHen Valens was Emperour of the Romans, Libanus, a Rhetorician, and Jamblicus, the Ma≈øter of Proclus, are reported by the divination of a dung-hill cock, to have found out who ≈øhould be Emperour after Valens; and moreover, after this manner it was found out; Twenty four letters are written in du≈øt, and a grain of Wheat and Barley is put to every letter; then the Cock, certain ver≈øes having been recited, is let loo≈øe, and they conceiv'd out of what letters he took the corns, the ≈øame being joyned together, would declare the thing that was inquired after; which when they had done, the Cock took the corns out of the letters Œò Œï Œü Œî. JOhn Fau≈øtus, a filthy bea≈øt, and a ≈øink of many devils, carried about with him an evil ≈øpirit in the ≈øhape of a dog; At Wittenburg, when the Edict of the Prince to apprehend him was promulgated, he fled away; ≈øo coming to Norimburg, and being ≈øet down to dinner, he began to be very much troubled, and ≈øuddenly paying what was due to the Hoa≈øt, went his way; he was ≈øcarce gone out of the dores, but the Serjeants inquire concerning him: at length, the fates compelling him, being brought to Wittenburg, he ≈øate down, being very melancholy, his Ho≈øt de≈øired him to tell the cau≈øe of his ≈øorrow; his an≈øwer was, I pray you be not terrified this night, though you hear a huge noi≈øe, and the very ≈øhaking of the whole hou≈øe; in the morning they found him dead in his chamber, his neck being turned top≈øie-turvy. IN the year of our Lord, 1323, Frederick of the Au≈øtrian Family, challenging to him≈øelf the Title of Emperour, again≈øt Lewis of Bavaria, Emperour, waged a cruel Warr, in which Frederick being taken, was for three whole years detained pri≈øoner in a Ca≈øtle near the famous Town Naburg, ≈øcituated by the River Nabus. When night was come, both of them went into a Circle de≈øigned, and prepared by Magicall incantations, the Magitian by his charms, rai≈øed a ≈øpirit, which appeared in the likene≈ø≈øe of a Man, receives the Mandate to bring Frederick home, if he did not refu≈øe to follow him: Therefore the ≈øpirit immediately in the night, comes to the Captive Prince, ≈øaying to him, Thy Brother Leopold hath ≈øent me hither to take thee out of Pri≈øon; Wherefore ari≈øe, and mount this Hor≈øe, and I will ≈øafely conduct thee to thy Brother. In the Chronicle of Hedion, book 4.

IT is reported that in the year of Chri≈øt, 1271. one John, an Almain, a Prie≈øt at Halber≈øtadium, was ≈øo skillfull in the Magick Art, that upon Chri≈øtmas Eve in the morning, he ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe thrice. IN the year of our Lord, 1272. came to Cruce natum, a Town in Lower Germany, a Magitian full of tricks and Legerdemains who cut off his ≈øervant's head publickly in the Market place, the people being ≈øpectators, and within half an hour, joyned that to his body which lay as it had been dead, upon the ground; the ≈øervant immediately recovering life, and becoming as ≈øprightful as ever he was. Hedion. book 5.

IN the year of our Lord, 1558. in a neighbour Town of Ahena, a certain Magitian cured many mad-men by hearbs which the Devill had ≈øhewed him. The wife therefore of the Carpenter with his kindred, accu≈øe the Magitian of man-≈ølaughter, for which cau≈øe he is convented before the Senate at Ahena, and being examined by torments, he confe≈ø≈øed this murder, and other impious and mo≈øt wicked deeds, and that he had learned his Magick of a certain old Woman in the neighbourhood, which lived at the Wood Hercynia for which mo≈øt horrible and flagitious arts, they cau≈øed him to be

MArtin Luther u≈øing many words concerning Witches, tells that his Mother was many wayes vext by an inchantre≈ø≈øe, a neighbour, in≈øomuch that ≈øhe was wont for fear to ≈øhew her much kindne≈ø≈øe, and by intreaties and courte≈øies, u≈øed to procure her good will: for this Witch did ≈øo torment her Infants by inchantments, that with continuall crying, they expired their lives. ALexander the ≈øixth, when he was Cardinal, ≈øpent his time both day and night, in contriving how he might obtain the Popedome; and that he might more ea≈øily accommodate his de≈øire, he ≈øet his ≈øtudy upon the Satanical Art of Magick, and ≈øo far proceeded therein, that he promi≈øed the Devil diligently to ob≈øerve him, if he would ≈øatisfie him in tho≈øe things he inquired: He de≈øired that the Devil ≈øhould take the ≈øhape of a Pronotarie; Satan therefore according to his wi≈øh, appeared to him in the form of a Pronotarie at the day appointed, and promi≈øed to tell him whatever
he demanded; He de≈øires to know whether he ≈øhould obtain the Pontificial dignity? which when Satan affirmed, he moreover demanded, how long he ≈øhould continue in that dignity? The ≈øervant an≈øwered, That he came thither for the Pope's book. To which the Devil replyed, What doe≈øt thou call the Pope? I am the Pope. When the Pope being ≈øick, by his Mini≈øter, heard the≈øe things, he was greatly afraid, and ea≈øily under≈øtanding how the ca≈øe ≈øtood with him, by his own command he was carried into the inner Conclave, whither as ≈øoon as he was come, the Devil taking the habit of a Po≈øt-me≈ø≈øenger, cometh and knocketh ha≈øtily at the door, and being let in, cometh to the Pope lying in his bed, and tells him, that the time was now expired, and therefore he mu≈øt ≈øpeedily depart this life: Whereupon there aro≈øe contention, whereby tho≈øe who were pre≈øent, under≈øtood the ≈øtrife betwixt them, to be concerning the number of the years; but Satan evidently demon≈øtrating to him the rea≈øon, that the number of the years were expired, went away; and in a very ≈øhort time after, the Pope gave up the gho≈øt.

GRegorius Martinus told Martin Luther, 1538, a ≈øtory much to be bewail'd, of a certain Virgin, that in≈øtead of tears, wept drops of blood; being brought to that mi≈øerable condition, by the malice of an Inchantre≈øs, and that the Witch was pre≈øent, though ≈øhe took no notice of it when ≈øhe poured out ≈øuch tears; He ≈øaid, that it was not convenient that there ≈øhould have been any delay or putting off the puni≈øhment hereof; nor that Lawyers or Judges needed to hear any further te≈øtimony, evidence, or demon≈øtration. to be taken with them, that the example may be a terrour to others.

IT was reported, that ≈øome years pa≈øt a Magitian was ≈øu≈øpended; but vani≈øhing away when he was upon the Gallowes, there hanged in his ≈øtead a bundle of ≈øtraw. The ≈øame Witch did often ≈øell to men, ≈øwine, which after they were bought, turned into bundles of ≈øtraw; at la≈øt Divine Ju≈øtice brought him to a de≈øerved puni≈øhment at Norburg, (with two women that were his complices) he and they, by diabolical tricks which they u≈øed, when they were not ob≈øerved, ≈øtole mens goods, of which being at la≈øt detected, they were apprehended and ca≈øt into pri≈øon together; and a rich Woman, who was till that time reputed a Matron of good conver≈øation, was confe≈ø≈øed by the women, to be guilty of the ≈øame wickedne≈ø≈øe of ≈øtealing and fornication, which by their legerdemaines they exerci≈øed; and therefore ≈øhe was likewi≈øe ca≈øt into pri≈øon; but the chief Magitian him≈øelf, though put to great torments, would confe≈ø≈øe nothing; and when it was conjectured, his art, and ≈øpirit or familiar, was in the hair of his head, they cut away his hair. Whereupon he confe≈ø≈øed all his notorious wickedne≈ø≈øes, and after a few dayes, fir≈øt the two women, and immediately after the Magitian, were de≈øervedly hanged.

THe horrid and much to be admired example of the power of Satan, which he ≈øheweth by his cur≈øed in≈øtruments, Witches, are fully demon≈øtrated to us, in the book called, Malleus Veneficarum. And although the power of Sathan be great, and that God ≈øuffereth him ≈øometimes to ex ‚Ä¢ rci≈øe his mi≈øchievous cruelty again≈øt ≈øome men for their ≈øins and unbelief; yet ≈øometimes al≈øo it plea≈øeth Almighty God, by the envy of the Devil, to try and prove his own dear Children; Neverthele≈øs, we are a≈ø≈øured, that their very hairs are numbred, and that not ≈øo much as one of them can fall to the ground contrary to his will: therefore we may ea≈øily arm our ≈øelves again≈øt the power and ≈ønares of the Devil, if we diligently
beware and take heed of ≈øin, and per≈øevere firm and con≈øtant in faith and prayer. But becau≈øe the Devil hath to this day ≈øhewed his greate≈øt power among≈øt Papi≈øts, therefore I will declare ≈øome examples out of the forenamed book, by which it mo≈øt manife≈øtly appears how great the power of Satan is, and what inveterate envy and malice he hath towards mankind; He who de≈øires to ≈øee variety of di≈øcour≈øe to this purpo≈øe, let him peru≈øe the ≈øaid Author.

OF the filthy commixtion which Witches u≈øe with the Devil, it is a ≈øhame to tell; who≈øoever de≈øireth to know how the≈øe filthy Plagues and bea≈øts do commerce with the Devil, (whereby they have oft deformed births, and exerci≈øe nothing but Satanical deeds) let him, be≈øides the fore≈øaid Author, peru≈øe Au≈øtin in his third book, and ≈øecond chapter, de Civitate Dei.

AT Ratisbone one of two Witches which were burnt to a≈øhes, being one that waited upon a Bath, co ‚Ä¢ fe≈ø≈øed, that ≈øhe was compelled by the Devil, to u≈øe ≈øeveral means to ≈øeduce a cha≈øte young Virgin, the daughter of a certain hone≈øt and very rich man, to lye with the Devil; to which end the devil thought it his be≈øt cour≈øe to invite the Virgin to his Chamber, upon an Holy-day, where he might talk to her in the ≈øhape of a young Gallant; which having often a≈ø≈øay'd, the Maid alwayes ≈øigning her ≈øelf with the ≈øign of the Cro≈øs, his de≈øign was fru≈øtrate.

ANother Virgin of the Dioce≈ø≈øe of Argentinum ≈øtaying alone at her fathers hou≈øe, upon a Sunday there came to her a certain old woman of the ≈øame Town, who after many ≈øcurrilous words which ≈øhe u≈øed, ≈øhe invites her to go along with her to a place where ≈øhe ≈øhould ≈øee all the hand≈øome≈øt gallants of the Town; the young maid overcome by the ob≈øcene enticing words of the old woman went along with her to her hou≈øe, they were no ≈øooner come to the hou≈øe, but the old woman ≈øaith, we will go up to the chamber where the young gallants whereof I ≈øpoke of are, but take heed you ≈øign not your ≈øelf with the ≈øign of the Cro≈ø≈øe. The young maid hearing what the old woman ≈øaid to her, as ≈øhe followed her up the ≈øtairs, was ≈øtruck with ≈øudden fear, and therefore ≈øhe ≈øigning her ≈øelf with the ≈øign of the Cro≈ø≈øe, by prayers commendeth her ≈øelf to Almighty God. Whereupon the Devils vani≈øhed; which the old woman perceiving, with a grim and devilli≈øh countenance, raging, and cur≈øing the young maid, thru≈øt her out of dores. Ibid.

IT was likewi≈øe confe≈ø≈øed by this woman that waited at the Bath, who was formerly ≈øpoken of, that ≈øhe was likewi≈øe deceived by an old woman, who brought her to the Devill in a way, to whom ≈øhe pro≈øtituted her ≈øelf, and that he in every re≈øpect, performed the office of a lu≈øtfull man, and was alwayes prepared for that; and that for eighteen years denying the faith, ≈øhe ≈øerved the Devill in diabolicall letchery.

IN the Brixien≈øian Dioce≈ø≈øe, a young man being inamoured with a certain young maid, much de≈øired to have her to wife, but I know not upon what occa≈øion altering his affection, married another, at the ≈øolemnization of the marriage, not having altogether forgot his old love, among≈øt others, invited his former paramour, who refu≈øed not the invitation, and when the hone≈øt Matrons and Virgins offered their gifts, this impudent bea≈øt comes forth, and ca≈øting her hands towards the bride; ≈øaith to her, From this day forward thou ≈øhalt not enjoy one day of health. Which words, when they under≈øtood the levity of the impudent curte≈øan, they took no great notice of; but the Nuptials being ended, by the force of Inchantments, ≈øhe lo≈øt the ≈øtrength of all her members, and for ten years mo≈øt mi≈øerably afflicted, ≈øhe kept her bed, and then ended a mo≈øt pittifull life.

A Certain Earl of an illu≈øtrious extraction of the Westravien≈øian territories, bordering upon the confines of the Dioce≈ø≈øe of Argentinum, having married a Lady of an illu≈øtrious family, being by inchantments deprived of naturall ≈øtrength, for begetting i≈ø≈øue, could by no means under≈øtand the rea≈øon thereof. It happened that after he had been three years married, he going to the City of Men≈øes, to expedite ≈øome bu≈øine≈ø≈øe which he had, that he fell into the company of a certain woman, who for ≈øome years before his marriage, had been his Concubine, whom he di≈øta≈øted not for what had formerly pa≈ø≈øed betwixt them, nor did he ≈øu≈øpect her concerning the Witchcrafts with which he had been afflicted, but kindly talks to her of their old love, which he was plea≈øed to acknowledg, and inquires of her, her condition, and whether ≈øhe were in good health; She perceiving the pitty and goodne≈ø≈øe of the Earl, inquires of him, whether he were in good health, he an≈øwered, That he was well, and that all things ≈øucceeded happily and pro≈øperou≈øly with him. She amazed for a little while was ≈øilent; which when the Earl perceived, he by gentle ≈øpeeches, invited her to di≈øcour≈øe; whereupon ≈øhe inquires his Wives condition, he an≈øwered that ≈øhe was well: She again asketh whether he had any Children by her. The Earl an≈øwered, I have had three Sons by her, ≈øhe bare me one every year. Then as one ≈øtupefied, ≈øhe was ≈øilent. IN a certain Town of the Argentinen≈øian Dioce≈ø≈øe, one who≈øe name for mode≈øty ≈øake I conceal, had at his hou≈øe one of his Tenants cutting wood, whom a Cat of a va≈øt magnitude at unawares ≈øet upon, which when he had driven from him by blows, another more fierce joyneth to the former, again≈øt whom, whil≈øt he more ≈øharply contends, a third comes, ≈øo that at fir≈øt he was put to a ≈øtrait, being for ‚Ä¢ ' ‚Ä¢ to u≈øe the utmo≈øt of his ≈øtrength again≈øt three ≈øuch maine and cruell Cats, neither could he drive them away, and free him≈øelf from them without the receiving of many hurts and wounds; which Combat being fini≈øhed, the man falls to his work, pre≈øently two Serjeants, apprehend him and carry him before the Judge, who being exceedingly moved with rage and fury, commanded them to ca≈øt him into an ugly pri≈øon, his groaning and often ≈øighings, nothing availing him for clearing or making manife≈øt his innocency;

AN hone≈øt woman of Oenipontus, returning home from a Garden, ≈øhe had adjoyning clo≈øe to a woman-neighbour, and having perceived that this neighbour of hers came oft into it, but ≈øu≈øpecting her a Witch, dur≈øt not ≈øo much as reprehend her for it; yet ≈øhe of her own accord, without any provocation of the hone≈øt woman, meeting with her, with brazen-fac'd impudence flying into the very face of her, ≈øaith, Thou ≈øu≈øpecte≈øt that I often pa≈ø≈øe thorow thy Garden. Then the VVitch ≈øtanding in the mid≈øt between two women, ≈øaid, Behold, this ≈øcurvy creature ≈øcorn'd I ≈øhould be her Midwife; but I'le be reveng'd of her. [Ibidem.]

IN a part of Suevia, a Country-man walking over his ground to ≈øee his Corn in a dry ≈øea≈øon, with a little girle, a daughter of his with him, wi≈øhed that it would rain a good ≈øhower. WHat power the Devils have to afflict Brutes, Cattle, and all other creatures, and how they can rai≈øe ≈øtorms and tempe≈øts, you may find ≈øufficiently laid open in the 14. & 15. chapters of the forecited Author: the examples are very horrible, nor do I think it nece≈ø≈øary to commemorate any more of them. THere were two brothers, to whom their Father left a competent e≈øtate when he died, the one of them took upon him a Mona≈øtick life, the other married, and ≈øet up a common Inne; and mo≈øt earne≈øtly gaping after Riches, u≈øed all means po≈ø≈øible to defraud, not onely his gue≈øts, but their bea≈øts by fal≈øe weights and Mea≈øures, and conveighing their provender from before them. Whil≈øt he thus ≈øtrove to be rich, his e≈øtate went to wrack on every ≈øide, and the more he took care to heap up, the more and greater lo≈ø≈øes he ≈øu≈øtained. When his brother the Monk came to him to part the e≈øtate with him according to his Fathers Will; he de≈øired his brother that he would forbear pro≈øecuting him for the divi≈øion of the goods at pre≈øent, for he was poor and in a very low condition and notwith≈øtanding that he u≈øed all means po≈ø≈øible for the gaining of an e≈øtate, yet all the fraud he could u≈øe profited him nothing; when the Monk heard this, he ≈øaid; O my Brother, if you order your Family ≈øo unju≈øtly, 'tis no wonder that things go ≈øo ill with you. For you keep ≈øuch a gue≈øt that con≈øumes all, and more than
you can po≈ø≈øibly gather: and if thou wilt ≈øee him, follow me into the bottom of the Cellar, and I will ≈øhew thee who con≈øumes thy e≈øtate. Whither when they were both come, the Monk by his adjurations, made the Devill that lay hid there, ≈øhew him≈øelf to his brother. And pre≈øently a bea≈øt of an immen≈øe bigne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo fat that, without much ado, he could not move him≈øelf, appeard, which when the Monk ≈øaw, he ≈øaid, O what a gainfull Inne do≈øt thou keep, and turning to his brother, ≈øaid, Behold that bea≈øt thou ha≈øt pampered by thy fraud, for what≈øoever thou fraudulently gotte≈øt from any man, this ugly bea≈øt devoured. Therefore hearken to me; Be faithfull and upright in thy dealing towards all men, u≈øe an equall mea≈øure, and defraud no body; and after four years I will come again, and then divide my Fathers e≈øtate with you. His Brother follows the Monks coun≈øell, and as much as he went backwards in the world before, he now came on, and in a ≈øhort time had ≈øuch experience of divine goodne≈ø≈øe, that he was Ma≈øter of a great e≈øtate. At four years end, came his brother the Monk, to ≈øee what condition his brother was yet in, who received him with great alacrity, and told him he had followed his advice, de≈øiring to ≈øee the bea≈øt now again, in which the Monk gratified his brother, and commanded the bea≈øt that lay hid in the Cellar to appear, which when he came was ≈øo lean, his bones would ≈øcarce hang together.
