But if thou ≈øhalt hereafter order thy affairs with the like Ju≈øtice, thou ≈øhalt alwayes learn experience of the great ble≈ø≈øing of our great and good God.

NOt long ≈øince; ≈øayes Bodinus, in Vallis (which is a name of the Suburbs of Laodunum) a certain Witch by her inchantments, freed a woman from her di≈øea≈øe, who was mo≈øt grievou≈øly afflicted, and thus ≈øhe effected it. Falling down upon her knees, and looking towards the ground, ≈øhe called upon the Devill very often, and with a loud voice, that he would cure the Woman; and pronouncing certain ≈øtrange words, gave her a mor≈øell of bread to eat, and by this means the woman recovered. Which kind of cure is plainly ≈øuch, as if the ≈øick woman had prayed to the Devill for health, than which it were better to indure the mo≈øt painful death. Daemonomaniae, lib. 1. cap. 6.

I Remember about 20. years ago, at Lutetia, in a Noblemans hou≈øe there, I ≈øaw a young man by often reciting certain French words in the pre≈øence of many hone≈øt people (which I think not good to mention at this time) make a ≈øeive dance, and move at his plea≈øure, And that he had a Familiar to help him is manife≈øt, for that when he was gone, and another repeated the very ≈øame words, he could effect nothing of that nature by it. Idem. Lib. 2. cap. 1.

NO Country-man (≈øayes the ≈øame Bodinus) is ignorant, that if two Ver≈øes out of the P≈øalms be recited while the Milk is a c ‚Ä¢ urning, there will no butter be produced by any Art. I was at Chillis of the Vale≈øians, when a boy ≈øtanding at the maids heels, hindred the butter to come or gather: but ≈øhe threatning cur≈øes from God upon him, if he did not cea≈øe and remove his Ver≈øes, made him ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat prepo≈øterou≈øly, and backwards as 'twere, and then the Butter came after ≈øhe had ≈øpent almo≈øt a whole day about it. If you put but a little Sugar into the milk, it will make no butter; for this proceeds from an antipathy in nature, and by the ≈øame rea≈øon, if but a little Cyprian-bra≈ø≈øe be ca≈øt into a Furnace of Iron it will never melt, but turn to a≈øhes, and therefore the Forge-men when they kindle the fire, ≈øee that there is none in the Furnace, nor any one near the Chimney.

THere is a diabolicall art called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or Ring Magick which is performed by putting a Ring upon a bowl of water. This a famous VVitch, an Italian born, u≈øed at Lutetia in the MDLXII. year of Chri≈øt, muttering out with all ≈øome kind of words, and by this conceit, gave an≈øwers aright to ≈øome that con≈øulted her: but mo≈øt were deceived by it. Joachimus Cameren≈øis tells us that Hieronymus the Stage-player, who≈øe ≈øon became Chancellour of Mediolanum, had a ring that ≈øpoke, or rather a Devill ≈øpeaking in a Ring, which rightly rewarded the Ma≈øter of it at la≈øt, for it cau≈øed him to be excommunicated and cur≈øed. Bodinus, Daemonom. lib. 2. cap. 1.

I Once ≈øaw a Phy≈øitian of Tolo≈øa exerci≈øe „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or rod-Magick, and with a low voice murmure out ≈øome (I know not what) words, till the two ends of the rod met, and touch't each other. But when it profited nothing to the cure of the affected, he blamed their incredulity, and cutting it into pieces, he cau≈øed it to be put about the necks of tho≈øe that had the quartane Ague, for their remedy. Ibidem.

OF all wicked devices of this nature, none arrive to that community and perniciou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as that of re≈øtraining new-married people doth: This the common people call the binding of the Ligula, which boyes practi≈øe with impunity, and with high impudence, ≈øome bragging of it. Nor is this a new thing, for we read in Herodotus, that Ama≈øis King of Aegypt was ≈øo bound in this nature, that he could not have to do with his VVife Laodice, till with exorci≈ømes and ≈øolemn prayers he was freed. Paulus Aemilius al≈øo te≈øtifies in the life of Clotarus the ≈øecond, that his Concubines u≈øed this trick again≈øt Hermamberga. Some Epicurean Philo≈øophers laugh at this miracle, becau≈øe the≈øe Arti≈øts in knotting the Ligula that are abroad, make people wonder when they ≈øee that they can by no means cure the ≈øame. And therefore the Canon ≈øayes thus, If at
any time by Witchcraft and ≈øor ‚Ä¢ ery through the hidden, but alwayes ju≈øt Judgment of God permitting, and the Devill preparing them, thy copulation is hindred, repair to God by humble confe≈ø≈øion. Out of which place we may note four or five Axioms, or undeniable po≈øitions. Fir≈øt, That copulation may be hindered by Witchcraft, which all Divines unanimou≈øly confirm, and Thomas him≈øelf upon the fourth book of Sentences, in the 24th di≈øtinction, where he ≈øaith; That a man may be re≈øtrained in that particular, as to one woman, but not otherwi≈øe; and in his la≈øt chapter of Frigid things. The ≈øecond is, That it is done occultly, but by the permi≈ø≈øion of God in ju≈øt Judgment. The third, That it is performed ab≈øolutely by the Devill. The fourth, That in this ca≈øe God is to be repaired to in Fa≈øting, which la≈øt head is chiefly to be ob≈øerved, lea≈øt tho≈øe that are troubled with the≈øe things (as many do, and as the Devill de≈øires and intends they ≈øhould) run to Diabolical means for remedy.

ESpecially it is ≈øtrange, that little boyes by pronouncing ≈øome words, ≈øhould be able mo≈øt exqui≈øitely to perform this inchantment. I remember Rioleus, general Emba≈ø≈øadour to the Ble≈øen≈øes told me, that a little boy was ≈øeen tying this knot under his hat, while≈øt Matrimony betwixt two was celebrated in the Church, and that the boy being ≈øeized on, e≈øcaped with the knot. While≈øt at Pictavium I acted as Vice-Procurator in the year 1567, there was brought a ca≈øe before me of this nature; which when I told to my Landlady, a very vertuous woman, ≈øhe (as if mo≈øt skill'd in that Art) in the pre≈øence of Jacobus Bauva≈øius an Attorney in the cau≈øe, declared there were above fifty wayes of tying this knot, whether to tye a married man, or a woman onely, that the one de≈øpi≈øing the other's infirmity, might run after adultery, but that the man for the mo≈øt part was bound, but ≈øeldom and hardly the woman, and that they might be bound for a day, a year, or ever, or for as long as the knot ≈øhould la≈øt, unle≈ø≈øe it were di≈ø≈øolved. That there was a knot, whereby one might be brought to love another, and not to have reciprocal returns, but extream hatred; and that there was another way to make two love one the other mo≈øt affectionately; but if they came to lye together, that they ≈øhould ≈øcratch with their nails, and beat one the other mo≈øt inhumanely. As I heard at Tholo≈øa, there were two thus illigated for three years ≈øpace, and then reconciled, and had a very fine child. And (which I mo≈øt admire) the woman while≈øt ≈øhe was ligated, declared ≈øhe had little tumours like warts ro≈øe upon her as ≈øigns of children ≈øhe ≈øhould have had, but for this ligature. She ≈øaid, there were knots to be made to hinder procreation, and not hinder copulation, that there were men could not be ligated, and ≈øome that might before marriage, and ≈øome after; but tho≈øe few, and the Urines of men might be ≈øtopt by this trick, whereof they were not few that dyed. I found a poor boy almo≈øt dead with this thing; and the man that did the feat, loo≈ø'd again the knot, and ≈øo
gave his urine vent. And not many moneths after, this very Sorcerer dyed of a like ligature.

THis mi≈øchief proceeding to a community in the Countrey of the Picts, the chief Quae≈øtor of Niortum, when a new-married wife accu≈øed a Neighbour of hers for re≈øtraining her husband, in the year of the VVorld, 1560, he cau≈øed her to be ca≈øt into a very loath≈øome pri≈øon, threatening her ≈øhe ≈øhould never come thence till the man were loo≈øed; and after two dayes the impri≈øoned woman gave leave to the married people to enjoy each others bed; and when the Judge heard the man was freed, he freed the woman from pri≈øon.

THis is worthy our ob≈øervation, That it pa≈ø≈øes the skill and power of the Devil, or any of his Agents, to re≈øtrain mens ≈øen≈øes, or bind others from eating or drinking, by intercepting their power or ≈øtomach; or deprive a man of the u≈øe of any member, ≈øave only that ≈øecret one, and ≈øign of our virility, which in Germany they often deprive men of, by making them run up into their bellies. So≈øprengerus tells of a man of Spira, who when he thought he had lo≈øt his premi≈øes, ≈øent for Phy≈øitians and Chirurgeons to ≈øearch for them, who found no ≈øcar or wound at all; therefore he repair'd to the VVitch he had offended, and appeas'd her, and ≈øo was cur'd. Al≈øo a Citizen of Ratisbone furni≈øhes us with another example, of one who violently laid hold upon a VVitch, and threatening to ≈øtrangle her, compell'd her to loo≈øe him from that nodus. All the≈øe Bodinus relates in chap. 1. of his ≈øecond book.

IN≈øulanus, Abbot and Lord of the Novallians, who now is ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadour to Con≈øtantinople by the King, and Polonus (who is al≈øo called Pruniskus) Amba≈ø≈øadour for France, told me, that one of the greate≈øt Kings of the VVorld being very de≈øirous of the knowledg of the number of his years, and the time of his death, ≈øent for Jacobius, a Sorcerer, who when he had ended Ma≈ø≈øe, and con≈øecrated the Ho≈øt, commanded a fir≈øt-born ≈øon, or man-child of ten years old, who was provided for the purpo≈øe, to be beheaded pre≈øently, and putting the head upon the Ho≈øt, pronounced certain words, and in≈øcribed ≈øome characters not nece≈ø≈øary to be known by us; Then he ask'd the head, what he would have? which an≈øwered only two words, I ≈øuffer violence. At this the King was inraged, and cryed, Take away the head; and pre≈øently in that fury dyed. This ≈øtory is very common in the Country, wherein it was acted, and very certainly reported, although there were onely five per≈øons pre≈øent at the thing. The≈øe things thus writes Bodinus.

JOhannes Charterius, that wrote the Hi≈øtory of Charls the VII. tells us how one Guilhelm. Edelinus, a Doctor of Sorbon, was condemned for Sorcery upon Chri≈øtmas Eve, in the year, 1453, who confe≈øt he had often in the night-time been carried abroad to a great meeting of Magitians, where he alwayes renounced God, and ador'd the Devil in the ≈øhape of a Goat, ki≈ø≈øing his po≈øteriors.

A Certain poor man, when his Wife often went forth in the night, and forth would remain the man knew not where, making for her excu≈øe to him, either that ≈øhe went to ≈øtool or bath with her neighbours; wherein when he had often di≈øprov'd her, he began to ≈øu≈øpect her cha≈øtity, and threatned to kill her, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øhe directly told him where her haunt was. She being terrified with the ≈øen≈øe of pre≈øent danger, told the matter plainly, as it was, in every particular; and furthermore, that he might experience the truth of what ≈øhe ≈øaid, promi≈øed him he ≈øhould ≈øee, and go him≈øelf whither ≈øhe u≈øed to go. And to that purpo≈øe giving him an oyntment, wherewith they being both anointed, and ≈øhe having pronounced ≈øome words, the Devil immediately carried them from the Countrey of the Lochii, to the Burdegalen≈øian Sands (which are di≈øtant no le≈ø≈øe than fifteen dayes journey, or more); when the man ≈øaw him≈øelf in company with Magitians, Witches, and Devils, (in a humane, but horrid ≈øhape) a thing very unu≈øual to him, and in a ≈øtrange Countrey, he began to ble≈ø≈øe him≈øelf, and ≈øay, Good God, where are we now? At which words the whole company vani≈øhed. Then he under≈øtood that he was naked, and was forced ≈øo to wander up and down the fields till morning, when he light upon ≈øome Countrey-man that ≈øet him in his way. And ≈øo making the be≈øt ≈øhift he could, he returned to Lochium, where he accu≈øed his Wife po≈øitively of all the≈øe things before the Magi≈øtrate, who commanded her to be apprehended: But ≈øhe mi ‚Ä¢ igating the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe as much as ≈øhe could, confe≈ø≈øed the mo≈øt part of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and acknowledging her fault, returned from her wickedne≈ø≈øe.

AL≈øo ≈øome few years ≈øince, a woman of great quality at Lugdunum, ro≈øe in the night, and taking a gally-pot out of her clo≈øet, anointed her ≈øelf with it, muttering ≈øome words withall; a ≈øtallion that lay with her that night, ob≈øerving her, when he could not ≈øee her, ro≈øe to look for her; and when he found nothing but the gally-pot, taken with novelties and curio≈øity, he al≈øo, as he had ≈øeen her before, anointed him≈øelf with the oyl that was in it, when he immediately found him≈øelf to be among≈øt a great company of Witches and Sorcerers in the fields about Lotharingia, whereat he was much amazed. But in the fir≈øt place calling upon God to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, the whole company di≈øappear'd; and he, finding him≈øelf all naked, returned to Lugdunum, accu≈øed the Witch, who confe≈ø≈øing all the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, was burnt for it.

A Thing of the ≈øame nature befell a Nobleman of Maldunum, who by ≈øome words of a Milner, together with the in≈øtigation of his own curio≈øity, was induced to go among≈øt a company of Witches to ≈øee fa≈øhions for≈øooth; but when he was among the thicke≈øt of them, an extream horrour ≈øeized of him, in≈øomuch, that although he did not invoke Divine aid, the devil ≈øaid with a very loud voyce, Who is this that is ≈øo fearful? And when he ≈øought to depart their company, the Witches all vani≈øhed. And when he returned, he intended to di≈øcover the Sorcerers, but they fled for their ≈øafety. Bodinus Daemonom. lib. 2. cap. 4.

WE read in Paulus Grillandus, a Lawyer of Italy, a man very well experienc'd in the facts of Witches and Sorcerers, That there was certain Country-man not far from Rome, in the year of the world, 1526. who when he ≈øaw his Wife ri≈øe naked in the night to anoint her ≈øelf, and that thereupon pre≈øently ≈øhe was gone out of his ≈øight, and could not be found in the hou≈øe, the next day provided him≈øelf of a good cudgel wherewith to be labour her ≈øides, untill ≈øhe ≈øhould tell him whither, and to what end ≈øhe ≈øo conveyed her ≈øelf la≈øt night, which ≈øhe pre≈øently doing, he pardoned her, upon condition that ≈øhe would convey him among≈øt her fraternity. She the next day anointed both her husband and her ≈øelf, and then they were pre≈øently mounted each of them upon a Goat, and ≈øo pre≈øently brought among≈øt the mur≈øter of Witches. Now his Wife had forewarned the man, he ≈øhould by no means name God or Chri≈øt, unle≈ø≈øe in ≈øcorn and opproby to him: when they were thus in the croud, the wife appointed her husband to ≈øtand a little aloof till ≈øhe had ≈øaluted the Prince of them, (who was mo≈øt magnificently cloathed and guarded about with a great ring of men and women; all honouring and waiting upon this their Lord) and that by ≈øo doing, he ≈øhould ≈øee the whole of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. When they had done thus, they began a ring-dance, (which is now taken up among the Countrey-people) that dancing backwards, they might not ≈øee one the others faces: It may be to the intent they might not know, nor accu≈øe one another, if perhaps they might be arraigned in the pre≈øence of one another, after: which Tri≈øcalanus did, to whom Charls the Ninth gave leave and liberty, that he might di≈øcover his fellows. He told him, being in a great a≈ø≈øembly of young men, That there were many there that adored and wor≈øhipped a Goat in their meetings, and ki≈ø≈øed his very po≈øteriours (or ar≈øe-hole in plain Engli≈øh, if you will have it ≈øo). Then by rea≈øon his back was towards them, he not ≈øeeing them, they danced together, and the devils copulated together in men and womens ≈øhapes. After their dancing, the tables were covered and furni≈øhed with meat; the woman then moved the man to ≈øalute the Prince, and ≈øitting down with the re≈øt of the company to the table, ≈øeeing the table furni≈øhed with meat, he called for ≈øalt; and when ≈øalt was brought to the table, before he ta≈øted any thing,
he ≈øaid grace, which being ended, pre≈øently men, meats, and table vani≈øhed away, and he was left de≈øolate alone, being very cold, and not knowing where he was; As ≈øoon as it was day, he came to ≈øome ≈øhepherds, of whom being asked, Whether he knew where he were? He an≈øwered, That he knew him≈øelf to be in the Beneventanian Earldom, in the royal command of the Pope. The≈øe things were done a thou≈øand miles from Rome, from whence travelling, he was forc'd to beg his meat and rayment, and at length coming home upon the eighth day after, poor and lean, he apprehended his Wife; by whom many more being accu≈øed, and confe≈ø≈øing the truth, they were all hanged.

THere is in the ≈øame Author, in the year 1535, that a young Maid in the Dukedome of Spoleto, of the age of thirteen, ≈øaid, that ≈øhe was brought by an old woman into the company of Witches, and ≈øeeing the convention of them to be ≈øo wonderfully numerous, ≈øhe cryed out, Ble≈ø≈øed God, what meaneth this? which as ≈øoon as ≈øhe had pronounced, all vani≈øhed away; and the poor girle, being found early in the morning by a Shepherd, told the whole bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to him, who bringing her home, the Witch was accu≈øed by the Maid, and, being found guilty, put to death by fire.

THe ≈øame Paulus Grillandus in his Book de Sortilegiis writeth, that being invited by a certain Nobleman to the Ca≈øtle of Saint Paul in the Dukedome of Spoleto, coming thither, he told him of three ≈øage matrons, one whereof tru≈øting in his promi≈øe that ≈øhe might freely ≈øpeak without danger, confe≈ø≈øed that fifteen years ≈øince, ≈øhe was brought by a ≈øage old Woman into the company of Witches, where the Devill being pre≈øent, obliged them by an oath to renounce God their Creator, Faith, and Religion, and to be faithfull to him, and that with their hands laid upon a book of mo≈øt ob≈øcure writing, he al≈øo bound them to ≈øome ≈øolemn ≈øervices to him in the night, and that they ≈øhould whenever he commanded them upon Holidayes, or ≈øet dayes, come whither≈øoever he ≈øhould conduct them; the Devil on the other ≈øide promi≈øed to them mirth and felicity eternall: ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed further that at that time ≈øhe killed four men, many Cattle, and brought much hurt to the fruits of the Earth, and if it happened at any time that ≈øhe came not to their meeting, without ≈øhe were able to give good rea≈øon for it, ≈øhe was ≈øo vexed that ≈øhe could neither ≈øleep nor take any re≈øt; when She came to their meetings, She heard the voice of a Man which called the Devill little Lord, and ≈øometimes Mr. Martinetus; and as ≈øoon as ever She had anointed her ≈øelf with a certain unction, She mounted a Goat that ≈øtood ready at the door, and held by the hair and tail; by which Goat She was ≈øuddenly conveighed unto the great coverture of Beneventum, where She found a very great company of Witches and Inchanters. There when She had vow'd allegiance to the Devill, She danc't, ≈øate at
Table, and la≈øt of all, every Devill concopulated with her, or him they had to their peculiar protection; and when they had thus done, every one getting upon their own Devills, returned particularly, with the ≈øame incredible ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe that they came thither, and that al≈øo they did privately at home adore the Devill, when this was all confe≈øt, and compared to the confe≈ø≈øions of two more there were many others accu≈øed who acknowledged the crime, and together with their oyntments and powders, they were all burnt alive.

AL≈øo in the third book of Tarquamadas of Spain, among≈øt others you have this more modern ≈øtory. That a Magitian being very importunate, at la≈øt per≈øwaded a companion of his that he would be a mo≈øt happy man, if he would but be of his Faith, and come to their meetings. And when he had given him his con≈øent, he on a night took him by the hand, and ≈øpeaking ≈øome words, they were both carried through the Ayre to a great company of Witches in which an incredible company of both men and women compa≈ø≈øed a Throne, whereon ≈øate the greate≈øt of the Devills in the ≈øhape of a Goat, to whom all of them went to ki≈ø≈øe en la parte ma≈øuzia quatenta (which, to tho≈øe that under≈øtand Spani≈øh, is tho≈øe parts which are not fit to be named in Engli≈øh). When this new-comer ≈øaw this, he ≈øaid to his companion that he could no longer patiently behold the≈øe things, and pre≈øently calling upon God with a loud voice, they all di≈øappeared with a great tempe≈øt and Whirlwind, and left him alone there, who was three whole years before he could reach his own countrey again.

BOdinus al≈øo writeth, That Joanna Halveria, born at Verberium in the Countrey of the Compedoen≈øians, did confe≈ø≈øe, that by the decree of the Council, by the confirmation of the Judge San≈øifianus his Mother was condemned to the fire, and that he being twelve years of age, was offered by his Mother to the Devil in form of a black man, with ≈øable apparrel, boots and ≈øpurs, and a ≈øword at his ≈øide, having a black hor≈øe at the door, and u≈øing words to this purpo≈øe; Behold my daughter, which I have e≈øpou≈øed to thee; and to her, Behold thy Love, in whom thou ≈øhalt be happy. And that from that time ≈øhe renounced God and her Religion, and that he lay with her, as men u≈øe to do with women, and ≈øhe found no difference 'twixt him and other men, but that his ≈øeed was cold, and that the Devil once asked her, Whether ≈øhe would be gravidated by him, which ≈øhe refu≈øed, lib. 2. cap. 7.

WEE find in writing that at a great Se≈ø≈øions for examination of the Potezanian Witches, held by Andreas Fertius the Kings Deputy over the Laodunen≈øians, where divers were burnt, out of who≈øe confe≈ø≈øions ≈øome things follow. Margaret of Bremontinus Wife of Noeles Lavertus, walking with Mary his Mother the Munday next after into the convent at Franqui≈øanum near Lognium,
which ≈øtandeth in a Meadow, her Mother putting a Broom betwixt her legs, and ≈øpeaking ≈øome words (here omitted) ≈øuddenly both She and her Mother were carried to a place where they found Joanna Roberta, Joanna Guillimina, and Maria the Wife of Simon Agnus Guilelina, the Wife of one Gru≈øsus, with whom were ≈øix Devills of humane ≈øhape horrid to behold, &c. And after ≈øome dancing with them, the Devils lay with them, and had to do with them; and that one that took her to dance with him, after he had ≈øaluted her twice, lay with her for half an hour together, and that the ≈øeed he ≈øpent was very cold. Joanna Guillemina a≈ø≈øents with her in the≈øe things, confe≈ø≈øing that it was very true, that at lea≈øt half an hour they were in copulation, and that the ≈øeed ≈øhe received was very cold.

WE read al≈øo in the 16th book of Johannes Meyerus who mo≈øt accurately wrote the Hi≈øtory of Flanders, That in the 1459th year of Chri≈øt, there was a very great company of both men and Women burnt in the Town Atrebantium, who mutually accu≈øed one another, that they met in the night, danced, and lay with the Devill. Likewi≈øe Jacobus Sprangerus, and four of his colleagues al≈øo tell us, that from the mouths of many wi≈øe and good men, they have been confirmed that many Witches had at the ≈øtake in Germany confe≈ø≈øed, and in particular at Con≈øtantia and Ratisbon in the year 1485, that the Devill lay with them after they had by his in≈øtigation denied both God and all Religion. And that not a few had repented, and turned off them≈øelves from that wickedne≈ø≈øe, and confe≈ø≈øed that whil≈øt they were Witches the Devill had often to do with them. It is written likewi≈øe that very many came, and freely acknowledged, though no man accu≈øed them, that they had been guilty formerly of commerce with the Devill being Witches, to the≈øe things Spangeus adds, that Witches did very oft copulate with the Devill, in the ≈øight of the Sun, or clear day, and did ≈øtrip them≈øelves in fields and Woods, and were often ≈øeen naked in the fields, and were ≈øometimes taken by their husbands in the manner with devils which they conceiv'd to be men, and therefore they ≈øet upon them with Swords whereby they could do no execution upon them. Paulus Gralandus, a Lawyer of Italy (who knew very many VVitches) doth declare in his book de Sortilegiis that he was commended by an Abbot of St. Paul's at Rome, in the year 1526. in the Moneth of September, to take cogni≈øance of three Witches, who among≈øt other things, confe≈ø≈øed that every ≈øorcere≈ø≈øe had a particular Familiar to commerce withall, in the Hi≈øtory of St. Bernard, we read there was a Witch who u≈øually copulated with the Devil; her Husband not perceiving her, though he lay in the ≈øame bed with her.

IN the flouri≈øhing Garden of Antonius concerning Turquomeda of Spain. I found another Hi≈øtory concerning a noble Spani≈øh woman, who related that ≈øhe was induced by an old Witch when ≈øhe was eighteen years of age, and from that time ≈øhe had to do with the Devil; which was burned alive, and unpenitent, being a Cerdenate. The ≈øame doth declare that another did repent, and was put into a Mona≈øtery. Adamus Martinus the Laodunen≈øian Proctour of Confe≈ø≈øion, told me (≈øaith Bodin) that he had a Witch of Biebra (that is a Village two miles di≈øtant from Laodune) in que≈øtion, in the Juri≈ødiction of D. Boan, the Captain of the Verumandians, in the year 1556. who was fir≈øt condemned to be hanged, and afterwards to be burnt; but ≈øhe was delivered alive to the fire by the fault of the Hang-man, or rather the ju≈øt Judgment of God, who did ≈øo demon≈øtrate, that the puni≈øhment ≈øhould be equall to the offence, neither was there any mi≈øchievous act that did more de≈øerve fire. Therefore ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed, that Satan (whom ≈øhe called her companion) was wont to have to do with her, and that ≈øhe did feel his cold ≈øeed.

WHen I was at the great meetings of Pictavius in the year 1567. performing my office among≈øt the under ≈øervants of the general Proctour, I took two filthy and beggarly Magitians, which did beg alms at a rich mans hou≈øe; who being denied, did ca≈øt in Witchcrafts, and all the hou≈øhold being driven into fury, died mad. Daemonum, libro 3. capite 1.

THere was a crafty Taylor at Lutetia a Magitian, who onely touching with his hand, did cure a Quartane Feaver, but he was in no wi≈øe cured that would not believe that he could cure him. And there was a certain Italian old woman at Audes curing di≈øea≈øes in the year 1573. who when ≈øhe was inhibited by the Judge to cure any more di≈øea≈øes, called a Court of Parliament, her cau≈øe was pleaded Eloquently, and likewi≈øe Learnedly, by D. Johannes Baltruus, Lawyer to plead the ca≈øes of the Parliament; fellow officer with the Lord of Matratius, and my Countreyman; but it is proved that the means by which ≈øhe cured, did di≈øagree with nature, as with the Brains of a Cat, which is poy≈øoned; the head of a Crow, and other ≈øuch like things; which things do plainly convince, that it was not done by the ≈øtrength of the excellent Oyl, or of the healthfull Oyntment (which many good men, and lovers of the poor do make) but by means beyond Nature, or by charms of healing.

JOdocus Darmudanus doth write in Praxi crim. cap. 37. that there was a Witch at Bruga in Flanders, having the greate≈øt repute of Holine≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe ≈øhe could cure innumerable di≈øea≈øes, but fir≈øt ≈øhe did take care for this, that they ≈øhould believe that ≈øhe could cure them, afterwards ≈øhe did make known fa≈øting dayes, and commanded that Pater no≈øter ≈øhould be ≈øaid divers times, and that they ≈øhould go to Compostella at St. James's, or to St. Arnolds, but at length ≈øhe was convinced of many Magicall charms, and de≈øervedly puni≈øhed.

Johanna Harvilleriae, which (as we ≈øaid before) was ca≈øt alive into the fire, confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe ca≈øt in charms, that ≈øhe might kill a man which had beaten his daughter, but he having excelled her witchcrafts, ≈øuddenly felt pain in his loyns, and his whole body. But when (as ≈øhe was greatly renowned for the fame of her Art) it was told the man that the grief could not come to him from any other per≈øon, then ≈øhe promi≈øed that She would work means whereby he ≈øhould recover, and took him into her cu≈øtody: to that end She did require it earne≈øtly of the Devill by intreaties, and She did labour by many means (which it doth not concern us to de≈øcribe) for his healing, which Satan an≈øwered it could not be done. And therefore She ≈øaying to him, that for that cau≈øe he ≈øhould come no more to her, the Devil an≈øwered her, that he would not come. A little after the ≈øick man died, and the Witch hid her ≈øelf, but although ≈øhe was hid, ≈øhe is found, and ≈øuffered de≈øerved puni≈øhment for her wickedne≈ø≈øe.

BOdin writeth that he ≈øaw a certain Arvernian Captive at Lutetia, in the year 1579, ≈øometimes curing Hor≈øes and men, with whom was found a very large book, full of the hairs of Hor≈øes, Cattel, and other bea≈øts of all colours. This man if at any time he ca≈øt his Charms on a hor≈øe, he con≈øulted, and having the hair of that ≈øo he did cure him, that he might deliver his Witchcrafts to another, but he took no money, and if he did take it, he affirmed that he did not care for it: And therefore he walked about in a very old Ca≈ø≈øock, repleni≈øhed with a thou≈øand patches. But when once he had ca≈øt his Charms upon the hor≈øe of a certain Noble man, being asked, he cured him, transferring his enchantments upon the ≈øervant of the ≈øame man: he an≈øwered, tho≈øe that came again to have him cured, that they mu≈øt know of the Noble man, whether he had rather lo≈øe his ≈øervant, or his Hor≈øe? In which thing the Noble man being in doubt, and ≈øtriving to be advi≈øed; the ≈øervant died, and the Magitian was apprehended.

I Heard from the Lord Turnerius the Aurelien≈øian Coun≈øellour concerning Hulinus Parvus the Aurelien≈øian Materiarius. This man by chance being deadly afflicted by Magick, did take care that a man ≈øhould be ≈øent for, (who promi≈øed that he would drive away all di≈øea≈øes, being ≈øu≈øpected of the Magick Art) that he might cure him. But he an≈øwered that he could not re≈øtore health to the man, unle≈ø≈øe he ≈øhould transfer the di≈øea≈øe to his ≈øon then ≈øucking. The Parent con≈øented to the murder of his ≈øon, to ob≈øerve the thing, that the malice of Satan might ≈øo much the better be di≈øcovered. The Nur≈øe having called it to remembrance, fled away with the child, while the Magitian was touching his Father to cure him. The Father being cured by his touch, the Magitian doth require the child to be brought, which being not found, he ≈øuddenly cryed out, I am undone, where is the child? and when he was going away he had ≈øcarce put his foot out at the dore, when the Devill kill'd him pre≈øently, and his dead carca≈øe was as black, as if any one had dyed it with a black colour on ≈øet purpo≈øe.

I Heard al≈øo (≈øaith the ≈øame man) in the Judgment of a Witch at Nauntes, (which was accu≈øed of ca≈øting in charms to her neighbour) that the Judges commanded that ≈øhe ≈øhould touch the woman that was troubled with the charm, which is done very often by the Judges of Germany in the Imperial Camera; ≈øhe refu≈øed, but ≈øeeing her ≈øelf to be compelled, ≈øhe cried out, I am undone, and together touched the woman that was afflicted with the enchantment: ≈øhe recovered, and the Witch being dead fell down, her dead carca≈ø≈øe being condemned to the fire. I received the ≈øtory from one of the Judges that was at the Judging of him.

I Heard al≈øo at Tholo≈øa, that a certain Student of Burdeaux, ≈øaid to his friend, being very ≈øick of a quartan, that he would give his Feaver to one of his enemies; but he an≈øwering, That he had no enemy; he ≈øaid, Give it therefore to thy ≈øervant. At length, when it was a doubt of con≈øcience to him to do it, the Magitian ≈øaid, Give it me; Then the ≈øick man con≈øenting, the Magitian dyed, being oppre≈ø≈øed with the Feaver; and the ≈øick man revived. Bodin. lib. 3. cap. 2.

BUt this is no news, and unheard of; For we read in Gregory the Turonen≈øian, lib. 6. cap. 35. that the Wife of King Childebert, as ≈øoon as ≈øhe heard that her ≈øon dyed by a mi≈øchievous act, in her feminine fury ≈øhe commanded a great number of Witches to be apprehended, burned, and put upon wheels; which acknowledged, that the King's Son was killed by them, that they might ≈øave Mummo, a great Magi≈øtrate: Therefore Mummo being taken, and put on a hor≈øe, he ≈øaid, That certain oyls and potions wer ‚Ä¢ given him by the Witches, to procure (as he thought) the favour
of Princes; and he commanded the hangman that did torment him, to tell the King, that he perceived no grief from him. Then the King commanded that he ≈øhould be ≈øtretched on the wrack, and ≈øharp points of iron to be put between the nayls of his feet and hands, as it is the cu≈øtome of puni≈øhment in the Ea≈øt, which was without the breaking of members; the pain was intolerable. After ≈øome dayes being carried to his men of Burdeaux, he dyed.

BUt Experience doth teach us, that a di≈øea≈øe happening by a natural manner, not by witchcraft, cannot be taken away by Magitians. Quae≈øitor Sprangerus doth bring an example; when he knew that there was a Counterfeit Magitian among the In≈øprugen≈øian Witches of Germany, who ≈øeeing his poor neighbour to be mo≈øt heavily afflicted, as if her bowels were ince≈ø≈øantly pierced with ≈øwords: I will try, ≈øaith he, if thou art troubled with charms, and will cure thee. Then poured melted lead into a round iron thing with a hole in the mid≈øt, being full of water, and putting it to the ≈øick woman, and uttering certain words, which it doth plea≈øe me to conceal, he perceived certain Images in the hardened lead, by which he knew that ≈øhe was afflicted with charms. This being done, he took the husband of the woman with him, and both beholding the upper po≈øt of the door, they found a waxen Image ≈øet up in honour of a victory, at who≈øe two ≈øides two Needles did ≈øtick, with other du≈øt, grains, and Serpent's bones, all which he ca≈øt into the fire: But the woman, when ≈øhe had given her ≈øoul for a pledg to Satan, and the Magitians, to whom ≈øhe had gone for her health, was recovered.

OGerius Terrerius, a mo≈øt learned Phy≈øitian, when I was at Tholo≈øsa, hired hand≈øome hou≈øes, and ≈øcituated in a very good place at Bur≈øa, for very little, in the year 1558, becau≈øe an evill ≈øpirit did trouble the Inhabitants of them, being not right owners; which he did no more care for, then Athenodorus the Philo≈øopher, who dur≈øt dwell in a hou≈øe for≈øaken by the Athenians, and the Inhab ‚Ä¢ tants, becau≈øe of an empty ≈øpirit: But when he heard that thing which he never believed, that he could not go to the Cellar ≈øafely, neither ≈øometimes take re≈øt, having admoni≈øhed Lu≈øitanus a certain Student, to be in the City, who did exhibit hidden things to be ≈øeen in the nail of a little boy, he cau≈øed that this Student ≈øhould u≈øe his art: But a girle full of knowledge, ≈øaid, That ≈øhe ≈øaw a woman mo≈øt exactly adorned with mo≈øt pretious chains and gold, which did bear a torch in her hand to a certain pillar: and therefore Lu≈øitanus an≈øwered the Phy≈øitian, that he ≈øhould take care that the ground ≈øhould be digged in the Cellar at the pillar, that he might find the trea≈øure. The Phy≈øitian rejoycing, commanded it to be digged up. But when he thought the trea≈øure was almo≈øt found, a whirl-wind ari≈øing extingui≈øhed the light, and going out of the vent of the Cellar, brake fourteen foot of the battlements of the walls in the neighbouring hou≈øes, part whereof fell together into the
porch of the dore, part into the vent of the Cellar; part upon a woman carrying water, who≈øe water-pot was broken. There was nothing ever after heard of the Spirit. Lu≈øitanus the day after, being more ≈øurely certified of the whole matter, ≈øaid that the ≈øpirit carried away the trea≈øure, and he wondred becau≈øe it did hurt the Phy≈øitian, who after two dayes related the Hi≈øtory to me. The≈øe things were done on the fifteenth day of December, in the year 1558. the Heaven being fair and clear as it is wont to be in Halcyon dayes. And we at the ≈øame time ≈øaw thorough the battlements of the next hou≈øe that were ca≈øt down, and the porch broken to the Shop. Bodin Daemonomaniae, Lib. 3. cap. 3.

MElancthon doth bring a Hi≈øtory very like to this: Ten men were overwhelmed by the ruine of the Tower Magdeburg, when they did dig to find trea≈øure; which Satan had ≈øhewed them. Gregorius Agricola in his Book de Spiritibus ≈øubterraneis writeth, that at Annaeberg, in that ruine, which is called the Town of Ro≈øes, there was a ≈øpirit in the ≈øhape of a Hor≈øe that killed twelve men, and made them withdraw from the mine full of Silver, which Magitians found by the help of Satan.

I Heard of a certain Lugdunen≈øian, in the Temple of the Virgin Mary, that there was Campellanus of Lutetia, who with his companions revealed the trea≈øure of Arcolius near Lutetia by Magick-Art: but when they thought to have the Che≈øt in which it was hidden, it was carried away with a Whirl-wind, but part of the wall fell upon him, by which he was made lame for the whole term of his life. And when the Noribergen≈øian Prie≈øt had found the trea≈øure by the help of Satan, and long ago was about to open the box, the hou≈øe was aboli≈øhed with a fall.

I Heard al≈øo from a Lugdunen≈øian practitioner in the Law, that he with his companions went in the night, that they might ≈øeek out a trea≈øure by uttering Conjurations, and when they began to dig, they heard a voice as it were of a man, which was put on the wheel, mo≈øt horribly crying to the thieves: ≈øo they were turned to flight: but evill ≈øpirits in the very ≈øame moment pur≈øuing them, ≈ølew them even to that hou≈øe from whence they came, and they entered it with ≈øo great a noi≈øe that the Ho≈øt thought it had thundered, and from that time he ≈øwore that he would never ≈øeek after trea≈øure. Bodin.

BOdin al≈øo proves by an example that ≈øorcerers can bewitch mens eyes, and move laughter, and make the ≈øpectators a≈øtoni≈øhed concerning Tri≈øcalanus that Magitian, which ≈øaid of a certain Curat, all the Pari≈øh Prie≈øts being pre≈øent; See ye that Hypocrite, who feigning to bring a Regi≈øter, doth bring play-papers! Then the Curate willing to ≈øhew that he brought a Regi≈øter, he ≈øeemed to
him≈øelf to have play-papers, and who≈øoever were pre≈øent, ≈øeemed to them≈øelves to ≈øee papers, ≈øo that the curate ca≈øt away his book of account, and went away a≈øhamed. But others coming a little after, gathered up the Regi≈øter book, being freed from that likene≈ø≈øe of Papers: by which thing it was manife≈øt that Satan did delude men in many things, and al≈øo bind fa≈øt every ones eyes. For tho≈øe which were not pre≈øent at the former action, when the ≈øorcerer ca≈øt his delu≈øions before the eyes of tho≈øe that were pre≈øent, did ≈øee a true book of account, when others on the contrary did perceive but an appearance of papers, &c.

THe Germanes being about to ≈øearch, what Witch had made a hor≈øe feeble and decaying, did draw the bowels of another hor≈øe to certain hou≈øes, and not entring the gates, but a Cellar or Cave under ground, did burn tho≈øe bowels. Then the Sorcere≈øs which had committed that evil, feeling the pain of the Collick all within; She runneth ≈øtreightway to the hou≈øes, where the bowels were burn'd, that ≈øhe might ask for a burning cole; and her pain did cea≈øe. But if the doors were not opened, the hou≈øes were darkened, ringed with horrible thunder, and threatned ruine, unle≈ø≈øe tho≈øe that were within would open the door: which Sprangerus writeth, that he ob≈øerved, and ≈øaw in Germany.

I Heard from D. Antonius Lonanius, the King's general Legate, that there was a Sorcerer at Ribemont, who having pronounced certain words, did di≈øcover another by a ≈øieve. All the names of tho≈øe that were ≈øu≈øpected were brought, and when the name of that man who was in the fault was brought, the ≈øieve did move unce≈ø≈øantly, and the Magitian acce≈ø≈øary to the ≈øame fault, came, which being found, the Sorcerer was condemned. Bodin lib. 3. cap. 4.

I Remember, that D. Bodin the King's general Procurator, ≈øometimes related to me, When all his cattel remained in a Village at Moldena, that it was told his Wife, that a certain bea≈øt mu≈øt be ≈ølain, which here it doth not plea≈øe me to declare; and he ought to hang it with the feet upward under the thre≈øhold of the ≈øtable, with pronouncing certain words (which it is not needfull here to in≈øert); this being done, there did none of his cattel peri≈øh. Idem. ibid.

JOhannes Martinus performing his turn of Ruler of Laodunum, declared to me, that when he was to try a Witch by the Authority of S. Proba, (for ≈øhe had tormented a Ma≈øon with ≈øo great ≈øickne≈øs, that his head did hang down almo≈øt between his legs, his body being crooked, which evill he did ≈øu≈øpect to come to him from the ≈øorcere≈ø≈øe) the Judg having regarded it well, he commanded, that word ≈øhould be brought to the Witch, that ≈øhe by no other means could ≈øave her life, then by healing the Ma≈øon. And therefore ≈øhe commanded a ≈øwathing band to be brought home by her daughter;
≈øhe calls upon the Devill, ca≈øting her countenance on the ground ≈øhe muttered certain charms before them all, and delivering the ≈øwathing band to the Ma≈øon, ≈øhe gave commandment that he ≈øhould be wa≈øhed in a bath, and that which was ≈øhut in the ≈øwathing band, ≈øhould be put into the Bath with the≈øe words: Get thou gone in the Devills name. She ≈øaid that there was this and no other means of recovery. The≈øe things being done, the Ma≈øon was cured. But yet before tho≈øe things were ≈øeen in the Bath, ≈øhe being willing to know what was in the ≈øwathing band (which ≈øhe had forbidden to be done) they found three little corns in it: But the Ma≈øon while he was in the bath, perceived as it were three great fi≈øhes in it, when he came forth of it, although they did ≈øeek them very diligently, yet neither the fi≈øh, nor the arm was found. The ≈øorcere≈ø≈øe was burned alive, and remained without repentance, Idem. lib. 3. cap. 5.

WE read in horto Antonii de Tarquamedia, lib. 3. of a certain Magitian, who ≈øaid to a ru≈øtick man, whom he ≈øaw bitten by a mad-dogg, That he was one that delivered from harm, that he might not lo≈øe his life. And when he prick'd his no≈øe thrice to let forth blood, he was cured.

CA ‚Ä¢ olus Martinus, Governour of Laodunum, being certified, that a poor woman in the valley (that was the name of the Laodunen≈øian Suburbs) was bewitched by a Sorcere≈øs her Neighbour, and taking pity of her, he threatned death to the Witch, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øhe took away the di≈øea≈øe from her Neighbour. She fearing, promi≈øed to heal her; and therefore ≈øhe came to the beds feet, looked ≈øteadfa≈øtly on the Earth, joyned her hands, called on the greate≈øt Devil with a loud voice; afterwards renewed her prayers, repeating ≈øome unknown words, and delivered a cru≈øt of bread to the ≈øick per≈øon, which in the ≈øame moment began to recover. This being done, the Governour returning home, did appoint that ≈øhe ≈øhould be apprehended, and be burned as ≈øoon as might be; but ≈øhe was not ≈øeen in tho≈øe parts from that time. Idem. ibid.

WE ≈øhall bring a fre≈øh example from an honourable man, Pre≈øident of Vitriacus Francus, who was a≈ø≈øigned to all the greate≈øt meetings of Bru≈øis, in the year, 1577. When we wanted his help, I did earne≈øtly ≈øollicite him, that we might a≈ø≈øi≈øt each ‚Ä¢ ther in the publick burden, le≈øt he ≈øhould go out of his place before the States were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed; he an≈øwered, That he had a certain friend who lay ≈øick to death, he was ≈øent for by him, and was made his heir, he thenceforth was ≈øick five or ≈øix years, his members failing him, and therefore his father being adverti≈øed, that there was a man in Flanders, who could cure his ≈øon, went hither pre≈øently: The Sorcerer unfolded the di≈øea≈øe of the ≈øon (which he had never ≈øeen) to the Father, and ≈øent him away into Lu≈øitania to another Magitian (who≈øe name he told him) living in the King's
Court. The Father bearing this patiently, went into Lu≈øitania, where the Magitian ≈øaid to the Father (before he did onely proffer to ≈øpeak); Friend, thy ≈øon ≈øhall be cured in a ≈øhort time, go into France, thou ≈øhalt find a certain man named M. Benedictus, towards Noviodunum, about 20 miles from thy hou≈øe, (but there are many of the ≈øame name) this man ≈øhall cure thy ≈øon. And therefore the Father wondring that he ≈øhould undertake ≈øo great travail, that he might ≈øeek that afar off, which was near, took courage, and went to M. Benedictus. But he ≈øaid to the Father, Thou ha≈øt ≈øpent very much labour going into Flanders, and Lu≈øitania, that thy ≈øon might be re≈øtored, Go, command him to come to me, I am he, that will heal him. The Father an≈øwered to the≈øe things: Now he hath not gone out of his bed for above the≈øe 5 years, and hath not truly the lea≈øt faculty of moving in him. But at length, with no little trouble, the ≈øick per≈øon was brought thither, and he was ea≈øed in part, but yet he was not long well. Idem. ibid.

JAcobus Sprangerus the Commi≈ø≈øioner, to enquire after the crimes of Magitians, by the ≈øame argument doth write, that he ≈øaw a Bi≈øhop in Germany, who being very ≈øick, he knew by an old witch, that he was ≈øick by witchcraft; neither was there any other way to recover his health, then that the ≈øame witch ≈øhould peri≈øh by enchantment, who had ca≈øt the charme upon him. The Bi≈øhop wondring, ≈øent with all ≈øpeed to Rome to the Pope Nicolaus, V. that he might get leave to be cured by this meanes. The Pope, which did love him ≈øingularly, did grant his reque≈øt with this ≈ømall ≈øentence, that of two evils, he ≈øhould flye the wor≈øt. The Letters Patents being brought, the Witch ≈øaid, Seeing that it plea≈øeth the Pope and the Bi≈øhop, ≈øhe would perform it. So in the middle of the night the Bi≈øhop was re≈øtored; but the Sorcere≈øs which had bewitched him, fell into the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe from which he was freed. But in the mean time, that Sorcere≈øs, which dyed, would never con≈øider, but unce≈ø≈øantly committed her ≈øelf to Satan, to recover her health.

IN the field of Poictiers in France, in the year 1571. Charls the eleventh King, after dinner commanded, that Tri≈øcalanus (whom he had pardoned, that he might di≈øclo≈øe the partakers of his fault) ≈øhould be brought to him. He confe≈ø≈øed before the King, and a great a≈ø≈øembly of his Nobles, the manner by which Sorcerers are conveyed, their dancings, ≈øacrifices offered to Satan, dete≈øtable copulations with Devils, having ≈øhapes of men and women: Moreover, he added, That du≈øt was taken by many, with which they killed men, cattel, and fruit. Every one admiring at the≈øe his ≈øayings, Ca≈øpar Collignius, Admiral of France, (for he by chance was pre≈øent) ≈øaid, That a youth was apprehended in the field of Poictiers, ≈øome moneths before, being accu≈øed concerning the death of two Noblemen, he confe≈ø≈øed, that he was their ≈øervant, and he ≈øaw them with du≈øt ca≈øt into the hou≈øes, and the corn, ≈øaying the≈øe
words: A cur≈øe on that fruit, on that hou≈øe, on that Region: And therefore he having gotten this du≈øt, took it, and ca≈øt it into the bed where tho≈øe two Nobles did lye; ≈øo both were found dead in the bed, but ≈øwelling, and very black. The Judges did di≈øcharge the boy. Then Tri≈øcalanus hearing that, di≈øcovered al≈øo many things of that kind. But it may be believed, if the King (who≈øe body otherwi≈øe had the ≈øtronge≈øt joynts and complexion) had commanded this Prince of Magitians, and his other followers, to be burned together, that God would grant a longer and more ble≈ø≈øed life to him for the≈øe Judgments. For the Word of God is alwayes manife≈øt unto him, that he who quitteth a man worthy of death, doth return his de≈øerved puni≈øhment on him≈øelf; as the Prophet ≈øaid to King Achab, That he, becau≈øe he had ≈øhewed favour to a man that did de≈øerve death, ≈øhould dye. Ibid.

IT is manife≈øt unto all men, that the man of Rochell, who was wounded to death, of who≈øe health all Chirurgions did de≈øpair, was ≈øo ordered by the help of a certain Magitian, that he could walk and ≈øpeak ≈øome dayes; indeed Satan, and not any other, did bear him, that he might ≈øhew his power to the Magitians. Ibid.

JOachimus Camerarius doth declare in his book, de natura Daemonum, When by chance a certain Butcher went by a Wood in the night, he heard a noi≈øe, and dancings; and therefore having ≈øought the thing diligently, coming, he ≈øaw ≈øilver cups, which things, (as ≈øoon as the Sorcerers and Devils were ≈øeparated,) pre≈øently the Butcher took, and the day after brought them to the Magi≈øtrate: ≈øo they, who≈øe marks were in the Cups, did accu≈øe others, being ≈øummoned to the Court, and were all de≈øervedly puni≈øhed.

THere is another more excellent example of that execution, which was made at Pictavium, in the year, 1564. the hi≈øtory of which execution I learned as well from many in the ≈øame place, as al≈øo from Salvertus, Pre≈øident of the people of Poictiers, (who was then ≈øent for to hear the Judgment with Daventonius the Pre≈øident of Poictiers, with other Judges); and all in that region know it. Three men with one woman being Sorcerers, were condemned to be burned alive together, when they were proved guilty of the death of very many men and cattel; du≈øt being brought to them, as they did confe≈ø≈øe, by the help of the Devil furni≈øhing them, which they hid under the ground of Sheep-cotts, and the thre≈øhold of hou≈øes. But they declared, That they were wont to go thrice to the greate≈øt meeting, whither innumerable Magitians came together to a certain cro≈øs-way where Fea≈øts are ≈øolemnized, which did afford them the u≈øe of an Image; there was before them a great black hee-Goat, ≈øpeaking to tho≈øe that were pre≈øent with humane rea≈øon, that they ≈øhould leap all into the circuit of his embracements; and then
every one with a burning candle ki≈øs his hinder-parts: This being done, the Goat was con≈øumed with fire, of who≈øe a≈øhes every one took, that therewith they might kill the Ox of an enemy; this man's Sheep; that man's Hor≈øe; that they might torment this man with feeblene≈ø≈øe, that man with death. La≈øt of all, the Devil with a terrible voice did thunder out the≈øe words; Revenge your ≈øelves, or ≈ølay: So every one did return by the help of the Devil the ≈øame way that they came. The Pre≈øident Salvertus, a mo≈øt vertuous man, ≈øaid moreover, that it did appear from antient acts; for Magitians were condemned for the ≈øame cau≈øe 100 years before, and by the like confe≈ø≈øions; and that it was done in the ≈øame place at the ≈øame cro≈øs. Two of the≈øe did repent, and two dyed in their ob≈øtinacy.

I Read al≈øo a Judgment again≈øt the Sorcerers of Potezana, which Adrianus Ferreus the King's general Vicar imparted to me at Laodunum. In it their confe≈ø≈øion is after this manner; That they near Lognium at the Trenqui≈øanian pri≈øon, certain words being uttered, were carried away with brooms, and there found others furni≈øhed with brooms ready at hand, and with them ≈øix Devils, who≈øe names are kept. After that they had for≈øaken God, they being ki≈ø≈øed, adored the Devils in humane ≈øhape, but yet having very bad countenances; and danced, having them in their hands: afterwards the Devils had to do with the women, but they required the du≈øt to kill cattel: La≈øtly, it was appointed, that they ≈øhould meet in the ≈øame place eight dayes after, on Monday at the begining of night; and when they had tarried there three hours, they were carried back.

BOvinus the Ruler of Gulick, being ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øador to Biturgium by name, among the Ble≈øen≈øians, affirmed, that there was a Witch burned, he being Judge, whom her daughter accu≈øed, becau≈øe her Mother had brought her to the meeting, and gave her to be in≈øtructed by the Devil; She among other wickedne≈ø≈øe confe≈ø≈øed, that ≈øhe danced in the circuit of the Goat, and at length ≈øhe related the ≈øeveral ge≈øtures of the multitude at the la≈øt time, and in what manner they made u≈øe of the du≈øt. This man ≈øaith, that he had a child killed by her, another a hor≈øe; and he, a tree. But one being found to have done nothing from that time, received many ≈øtrokes on the ≈øoles of the feet, and was derided by all others; She al≈øo added, That it did behove them to have fre≈øh powder often. Bodin. lib. 2. cap. 4.

A Thing like to this, is that which we read in the Judgment of another Sorcere≈øs, who confe≈ø≈øed, That ≈øhe could not re≈øt, unle≈øs ≈øhe did commit ≈øome evil daily, at lea≈øtwi≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhould break a little ve≈ø≈øel; but when her Mi≈øtris caught her breaking her earthen ve≈ø≈øel of purpo≈øe, then ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed the matter, and
was adjudged to dye, becau≈øe ≈øhe ≈øaid ≈øhe could by no means re≈øt, unle≈øs ≈øhe had killed a man, or committed a mi≈øchievous act.

I Remember, ≈øaith the ≈øame Bodin, That Turnerius a Learned man, an A ‚Ä¢ relien≈øian Coun≈øellour, told me, That there was a ≈øpeech all abroad, and found out true, that the convention of Witches was kept at the Cleriacus, and that Devils declared there, what≈øoever was done in divers Nations, becau≈øe they do reduce the ≈øeveral deeds of men, as it were, into a brief Hi≈øtory of all per≈øon's actions; and this is the manner of divination which Sorcerers u≈øe. But that Sorcere≈øs, whom we mentioned, would not ≈øtirr from the ≈øentence given, ≈øaying, She did prefer death before ≈øo great torments of the Devil, from which ≈øhe could not be quiet even for a moment.

BUt this is to be ob≈øerved in the fir≈øt place, That there is no meeting, wherein there is no dancing. So the Witches of Languiana did ≈øing when they were dancing, Har, har, Devil, Devil, leap hither, leap thither, play here, play there; others ≈øaid, Sabbath, Sabbath, (that is) a quiet holy day, having their hands and brooms lifted upwards, that then they might certainly te≈øtifie, with how great cheerfulne≈ø≈øe of mind and diligence they did wor≈øhip and adore the Devil, as al≈øo that they might repre≈øent the wor≈øhip which is due to God.

THere is a fre≈øh Hi≈øtory of Naturall Witchcraft, by a Neapolitane, who doth declare a thing which he tryed in a woman-Witch, who after ≈øhe had anointed her ≈øelf naked, ≈øwounding, and void of ≈øen≈øe fell down, and being returned after three hours ≈øpace into her body, ≈øhe related many things from divers Countries, which were afterwards found true.

I Heard from the Turettanian Pre≈øident, that he ≈øaw in Delphiratus a Witch which was to be burned alive, therefore ≈øhe lying down in the fire, ≈øaying, Remain ye at home with my body, ≈øhe was taken away in a trance, and becau≈øe ≈øhe under≈øtood nothing, her Ma≈øter ≈ømote her with very heavy ≈øtrokes of a rod, and then al≈øo that they might ≈øee whether ≈øhe had departed this life or no, the fire overcame the parts which are mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible, neither did they any further watch her; and therefore lying (e≈øteemed by her Ma≈øter and Mi≈øtris) dead, ≈øhe was left there: ≈øhe was found lying in her bed the next morning. Which when her Ma≈øter admiring, enquired what had happened to her? She crying out, ≈øaid in her own language; Ah Ma≈øter! How have you beaten me? Her Ma≈øter manife≈øting this to the neighbours, a certain man ≈øaid, It is a Witch: and therefore her Ma≈øter did not de≈øi≈øt till ≈øhe acknowledging the thing, did make manife≈øt that ≈øhe had heard the meeting
of Magitians in her mind. So moreover, ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed other offences which ≈øhe had committed, and ≈øhe was delivered to the fire. Bodin. in Daemonomaniae, lib. 2. cap. 4.

JAcobus Sprangerus the Quae≈øtor, who did examine many Witches, doth write that they did confe≈ø≈øe, when they ≈øeemed to be taken away by the ≈øpirit, yet it might ≈øeem otherwi≈øe in the body. We have had another example in our memory at Burdeaux, in the year 1571. when per≈øecution was in≈øtituted again≈øt the Magitians of France. A certain old woman at Burdeaux being a Witch, confe≈ø≈øed to the Judges, that ≈øhe was carried with others, every week where a great Hee-Goat was adored, by which author they did deny God, and did promi≈øe that they would ≈øerve the Devill, every one did ki≈ø≈øe his privy parts, and after they had danced each one did receive the du≈øt. Then D. Belotus, ma≈øter of the Bills containing ≈øupplications, (when the ≈øorcere≈ø≈øe ≈øaid that ≈øhe could do nothing, except ≈øhe was brought out of the Pri≈øon) being willing to try the truth of the thing, did command her to be brought forth; and when ≈øhe had anointed her ≈øelf being naked, ≈øhe fell down as if ≈øhe were dead, and void of ≈øen≈øe, afterwards coming to her ≈øen≈øe and ri≈øing after five hours, ≈øhe declared many things which were found to be ≈øo, as ≈øhe had ≈øaid in divers places.
