Olaus doth te≈øtify that it is frequent in the Northern parts, and that their friends do watch the body of him that is in a trance very diligently, untill with great grief he doth return, and bring with him his ring, letter, or knife, who is ab≈øent 300. miles. Idem. ibid.

THat judgment of ≈øeven Magitians is alike admirable, which I learned at Nauntes in the year 1549. Therefore when they promi≈øed that they would ≈øhew before many, in an hours ≈øpace, what was done ten miles in Circuit, they pre≈øently fell down dead, and did lye void of ≈øen≈øe three hours: ari≈øing, they did relate what≈øoever they had perceived in the whole City of Nauntes, and a longer Circuit, having ob≈øerved places, deeds, and men, all which things were found pre≈øently. And therefore all they being accu≈øed, and found guilty of many mi≈øchievous acts, were condemned to be burned. Idem.

BAro of Razii (who at Nauntes being condemned for his Magicall charms ≈øuffered puni≈øhment) not onely confe≈ø≈øed, that he killed eight children, and deprived others of under≈øtanding, and ≈øacrificed his own young ≈øon to the Devill, and that in her Mothers womb, that he might gratify Satan as much as it was po≈ø≈øible, but al≈øo pro≈øtrating him≈øelf upon his knees in his chamber, did adore Satan appearing in humane ≈øhape; and did ≈øacrifice with Incen≈øe to him. Satan did promi≈øe many admirable things to him; and namely, that he ≈øhould be great. But at length
≈øeeing him≈øelf Captive, and oppre≈ø≈øed with the mo≈øt bitter evils; confe≈ø≈øed all things, and ≈øuffered the uttermo≈øt puni≈øhment. Bodin. lib. 2. cap. 6.

WE read in Sprangerus, when he had intelligence of a certain ≈øorcere≈ø≈øe, which he condemned to be burned, that ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed, (how ≈øhe was a Midwife) that ≈øhe taking children out of the Mothers Womb, did pre≈øent them to the Devill by lifting them aloft into the Ayr; afterwards ≈øhe put a great pin into their heads, ≈øo that the bloud might not run out: then carrying them to be buried, going in the night ≈øhe digged them up, boyled them in a furnace, did eat the fle≈øh, and did keep the fat for her u≈øe. By this means ≈øhe killed fourty children: ≈øhe was a Dane at Ba≈øilea.

CAzereis was a Witch at Tholo≈øsa, who having brought the ble≈ø≈øed bread to the Altar, went away to drown her ≈øelf, and when ≈øhe was brought home again; ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe infected the ble≈ø≈øed bread with poy≈øon; the bread was ca≈øt before Dogs, they dye. She being in bonds, was in a trance more then ≈øix hours, void of all feeling; afterwards ri≈øing up, cryed out ≈øhe was wonderfull weary, and ≈øent back the Me≈ø≈øengers from many places with certain ≈øignes and marks. When ≈øhe was near her ≈øentence of condemnation, and Judgment was ready to be pa≈øt upon her, ≈øhe called upon the Devill, ≈øaying, That he promi≈øed that there ≈øhould come ≈øuch vehement ≈øtorms and ≈øhowers that ≈øhe might not be burned. But for all that ≈øhe was not defended from the violence of the fire. Bodinus Daemonoman. lib. 3. cap. 3.

NOthing (≈øaith the ≈øame Bodinus in lib. 2. cap. 5.) is ≈øo wonderfull and admirable as the Metamorpho≈øing of men into bea≈øts, and to be turned out of the ≈øhape of a man into that of a bea≈øt. Yet the truth is, that this is practi≈øed among Magitians; and both divine and prophane Hi≈øtories do prove it certainly. In the book of Inqui≈øitions again≈øt Magitians, which I have often mentioned; we read of one Statius a certain Magitian that he ≈øuddenly and oftentimes flew, and e≈øcaped out of the Bernates field, out of the mid≈øt of his enemies (for he had very many) and he could never be ≈ølain; but when he was a≈øleep, he left two of his Di≈øciples Hippo and Stadlinus which were the chief Magitians in all Germany, who rai≈øed tempe≈øts, cau≈øed lightning and great ≈øtorms.

THere did ari≈øe a controver≈øy in the Parliament of Dolen≈øi, and the ≈øentence was publi≈øhed the 18th day of January in the year, 1573. about Aegidius Garnerius, Lugdunen≈øis. Which Judgment is not fit to be in≈øerted here at the pre≈øent, when Aurelius at Eligium Giberium at Paris with Peter Hayanum, commended to the French Pre≈ø≈øes; only we will ≈øet down the chief heads of tho≈øe Articles that he was accu≈øed and convicted of. And fir≈øt, That this Garnerius
at Michaelmas time at the wood, in the Cha≈øten ‚Ä¢ yanian Vines, which are a quarter of a mile from Dolen≈øis Town, took a young wench of ten or twelve years old, with his hands, which ≈øeemed like to Wolves feet, and tore her to pieces with his teeth, and ≈øo devoured the fle≈øh of her thighs and arms, and brought part of her to his Wife. And about a Moneth after, he got another girl in the ≈øame manner, and killed her; and being about to eat her, unle≈ø≈øe three men (as he him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øed) had hindered him. And about fifteen dayes after he ≈øtrangled a boy of ten years old, in the Vines of Gredi≈øaniorum, and did eat the fle≈øh of his legs, thighs, and belly. And la≈øtly, He ≈ølew a boy thirteen years of age (being then in the ≈øhape of a man, and not of a Wolf) in a Grove of the Peru≈øan; and being very hungry (as he of his own accord confe≈ø≈øed) if he had not been hindered, would have eaten him al≈øo: Therefore for the≈øe rea≈øons he was condemned to the flames; The Sentence was put in execution.

THere was another Ca≈øe agitated at Ve≈øontion, made known to, or di≈øcovered by John Boinus the Inqui≈øitor, in the year of our Lord, 1521. in the Moneth of December, the cau≈øe was ≈øent into France, Itally, and Germany, which Vierius, lib. 6. of Witchcraft, chap. 13. relates at large, but I will run over a few heads of it; Peter Burgottus, and Michael Verdunus, was found guilty, and confe≈ø≈øed that they had renounced God and their Faith, and had given them≈øelves to the Devill; Therefore Michael brought Burgot in that ≈øtreet of the Carlonian Ca≈øtle, where each of them had a Candle of green wax burning, with a dull ob≈øcure flame; and ≈øo they danced and ≈øacrificed to the Devill. Afterwards they confe≈ø≈øed, that anointing them≈øelves, they were transformed into Wolves, running with great celerity and ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe; then again being turned into men, and a while after into Wolves, and in that ≈øhape had copulation with ≈øhe ‚Ä¢ Wolves, and had the ≈øame plea≈øure with them as they were wont to have with Women; Furthermore it was confe≈ø≈øed, that Burgottus with ≈øeven Wolves feet and teeth, did tear to pieces and cruelly macerate a boy, and had quite devoured him had not ≈øome Countreymen driven him away. And that Verdunus ≈ølew a young maid gathering pea≈øe in the Garden, and was driven away by the Lord of Cunea. And in the la≈øt place, that there were four young la≈ø≈øes devoured by them at a certain place and time, who≈øe age they did relate, and that they could de≈øtroy men by ca≈øting a certain kind of du≈øt or powder.

I Remember that D. Bordinus, the Kings Generall Factour, or Solicitor, did tell me of another example that was ≈øent to him out of Belgia, with the whole Judgment, ≈øigned by the Judges and Clarks and Notaries; which was concerning a Wolf that was wounded in the hanch or Thigh with a Dart, which afterwards being turned into a Man laid in his bed with the Arrow in him, and being plucked out, he that was wounded acknowledged it, this was
proved at that time, and in that forementioned place, both by his own confe≈ø≈øion, and by divers other te≈øtimonials.

JOb Fincelius writeth, that at Padua there was one man fell mad, and his Wolvi≈øh feet being cut off, in≈øtantly he appeared a man that was ≈øtumped, or had his members cut off, by which example (≈øaith Bodinus) the Judgment again≈øt Witches is confirmed, and a great company of Witches in the ≈øhape of Cats were wont to congregate and gather to the Ca≈øtle, and there were ≈øet four or five men, who were ≈øet to watch them all night, and then a great multitude of Cats did invade, and ≈øet upon them, one of them was ≈ølain, the re≈øt were ≈øore hurt, and wounded, but many Cats being cut and hurt, afterwards turned into women, were found to be ≈øore ≈øla≈øh't. But becau≈øe the thing ≈øeems ≈øo incredible, the ≈øentence and Judgment is mute and ≈øilent. Petrus Marmorius in his book of divinations, ≈øaith, that he him≈øelf was an eye-witne≈ø≈øe of this transformation of Men into Wolves in Lubaudia and Henry Colonien≈øis in his Vol. de lamiis of VVitches, affirms it for an undoubted truth, and al≈øo Ulricus Molitor in his book which he dedicated to Sigi≈ømundus Cae≈øar, ≈øetting down the di≈øputation that was made before the Emperour, and proves by many rea≈øons, and al≈øo by his own experience, this ≈øtrange Metamorpho≈øing of men into Wolves, and tells of one that was thus transformed at Con≈øtance, who was accu≈øed, convicted, condemned, and confe≈ø≈øing it, was executed. This is ≈øhewed in many books that are ≈øet forth in Germany, one of which relates that there was a Chri≈øtian King who was lately decea≈øed, that oftentimes turned him≈øelf into a Wolf, that he might be the Prince and chief of Magitians. And the truth is, this kind of VVitchcraft over-≈øpread all Greece and A≈øia, and ≈øome of the VVe≈øtern countries, as our Merchants ≈øay, that there were ≈øome that were put in the ≈øtocks, and impri≈øoned, who turned them≈øelves from the ≈øhape of men into VVolves. Therefore in the year 1542. Sultan Solyman, getting inve≈øted in the Empire, there was ≈øuch a company of VVolves at Con≈øtantinople, that the Emperour was in arms marching again≈øt them with his Praetorian Souldiers, and compelled a hundred and fifty of them to fly, and vani≈øh out of the City, all the people being ≈øpectators. Job Fincelius in his ≈øecond book de Mirabilibus, and the whole Country agree to this. The Germans call the≈øe Wolves Werwolf, the French, Loups garous; Picardians, Loups Warous, as if thou ≈øhould≈øt ≈øay, divers Wolves (for the French put G in the room of W) the Greeks call them „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the Latines, Ver≈øipelles, as Plinius (not Ovid) writing of this Metamorpho≈øis. Pomponatius and Theophra≈øtus, the chiefe≈øt Princes of Philo≈øophers in their age, do confirm that certainly there was ≈øuch a transformation of men into Wolves. Ca≈øper Peucerus, ≈øon in law of Phillip Melancthon, writes, that formerly the≈øe ≈øeemed alwayes but as meer fables and fictions to him; but at la≈øt he was forced to believe that which ≈øo many Merchants of good account and credit did confirm in Livonia, many being accu≈øed,
convicted, and confe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo were executed, and therefore he ≈øets down the manner which they ob≈øerve in Livonia: for every year about the end of December, there was a knavi≈øh fellow who did ≈øtir up all the Magitians, that they might have a Congregation in ≈øuch an appointed place, and if they did not appear there, they were corrected by the Devill with an Iron rod, ≈øo that the common rout were a great while after their Captain, who marching before, Millions followed to a certain River, and pa≈ø≈øing over it, they were transformed into Wolves, and would fall upon men and bea≈øts, and brought great detriment to the Country: and twelve dayes after rowing again over the River, they rea≈ø≈øumed the figures and ≈øhapes of men.

I Have oftentimes vi≈øited one Languetus B ‚Ä¢ rgundus, a Learned man, negotiating about important affairs with the Duke of Saxony, and al≈øo with the King of France for his Lord and Ma≈øter: here he toll'd a ≈øtory not much unlike to this; He ≈øaid, That having ≈øome bu≈øine≈ø≈øe with an old man in Livonia, the thing was known among≈øt the people, I have about me ≈øome letters of a certain German, who was a Pen≈øioner of King Henry the ≈øecond, written to the Con≈øtable of France, by which he certifies the Con≈øtable; the which Intelligence was given at Mo≈øch in Livonia: and furthermore he adds, In tho≈øe Countreys where Herodotus ≈øeems to place the Neurians, among whom there were tho≈øe that could change them≈øelves into Wolves, which was a common and u≈øuall thing in Livonia; many things which were related by Herodotus, ≈øeeming incredible, following Ages have found to be true. And the ≈øame Author ≈øaith, That there were Magitians, that by certain ≈øhort ≈øentences allayed that tempe≈øt in which Xerxes had above fourty Ships ≈øunk and ca≈øt away: And we read in Olaus Magnus, lib. 3. cap. 18. of the Lappi that could ≈øell ≈øtorms, and calms, by unloo≈øing ≈øome ropes, which all Marriners know by frequent experience.

WE al≈øo read in the Hi≈øtory of John Tritemii, in the year 1470, of a certain Jew, Bajanus by name, the ≈øon of Simeon, who when be plea≈øed, could transform him≈øelf into a Wolf, and vani≈øh out of ≈øight, and made him≈øelf „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , invi≈øible.

ANd it is a wonderfull thing, and yet methinks 'tis more admirable, that many will not believe it, when people of all Nations, and Hi≈øtorians with one con≈øent acknowledge and confe≈ø≈øe it: not onely Herodotus hath written of it 2000 and 200 years ≈øince, and Homer 40. but Pomponius, Mela, Solinus, Strabo, Diony≈øius. Afer, M. Varro, Virgilius, Ovidius, and ≈øixty other; and ≈øo Virgilius upon this,
Has herbas, at
que haec Ponto mihi lecta venena,
Ip≈øe dedit Moeris; na≈øeuntur plurima Ponto:
His ego ≈øaepe lupum fieri & ≈øe condere ≈øylvis Moerin.
The≈øe herbs and poy≈øons cull'd, me Maeris gave,
Not a few ≈øuch the briny Mar≈øhes have;
By this I oft Maeris a Wolf have ≈øeen,
When in the covert woods h'as hidden been.
And taking the≈øe, into a Wolf was chang'd,
Hiding my ≈øelf, into Maeris Woods rang'd.
But Pliny, lib. 8. cap. 22. wonders, that Authors ≈øhould agree about this, That men, ≈øaith he, ≈øhould be turned into Wolves, and again return unto their proper ≈øhape, we ought to e≈øteem fal≈øe, or believe all that which we find recorded in fabulous Annals; this he dur≈øt not affirm, fearing le≈øt he ≈øhould be believed; for among the chiefe≈øt of Greek Authors he bringeth Evanthes upon the ≈øtage, who ≈øaith, That in Arcadia, there was one of the Antaean Nation that did ≈øwim over a pool, and was transfigured into a Wolf, and after ≈øome few years coming to the ≈øame pool again, and when he did pa≈ø≈øe over it again, he received an humane ≈øhape. And Agriopas, who writ of the Olympionick games, telleth of one Demaenetus Parrha≈øius, who ta≈øting of the intrals of a boy that was ≈øacrificed to Jupiter Lycaeus, was changed into a Wolf, which M. Varro, the mo≈øt learned of all the Greeks and Latines, as Cicero te≈øtifieth, brings it in for an example, and confirms it for an undoubted truth. Olaus Magnus ≈øpeaking of the Countries of Pilapiae, Narbonia, Fincladia, and Angermania, ≈øaith, The≈øe are heatheni≈øh Nations, and full of wicked ≈øpirits and Conjurers; And in his Hi≈øtory ≈øaith, That men are turned into bea≈øts by them: And he that de≈øires more examples, of which there are millions, (which for brevity ≈øake we will omit) let him con≈øult Olaus, the Saxo Grammaticus, Fincelius, and William Brabantius; I pa≈ø≈øe by Ovid's Metamorpho≈øis, who intermingled many true things with his fabulous ≈øtories; but that which he writes of Lycaon, the Arcadian King, turned into a Wolf, is not incredible;
Territus ip≈øe fugit, nactu≈ø
que ≈øilentia ruris
Exululat, fru≈øtra
que loqui conatur.
Affrighted he did fly, run, howl, and walk,
But oh alas, in vain he ≈øtrives to talk!
Obtaining ≈øilence in the Country there,
As he was mute or ≈øilent every where.
Neither is that fabulous, which Homer relates of Circes the Witch, and of Uly≈øses's companions being turned into hoggs, when St. Augu≈øtine in Civitate Dei, brings in the ≈øame Hi≈øtory, (although wonderful, in his opinion) and he ≈øaith, that ≈øtory of the Arcadians on the Alps was often in his mind; that many prating talkative women in≈øtructed in wicked arts, would give ≈øomething in their chee≈øe to Travellers, by which incontinently they would be turned into
cattel, that they might bear nece≈ø≈øary burdens; and then afterwards when they had done their work, come to them≈øelves again, as we have ≈øhewed before, &c.

WE read of a like Hi≈øtory to this in William the Archbi≈øhop of Tyre; Sprangerus the Inqui≈øitor relates the ≈øame of a young Engli≈øh Souldier in Cyprus, that was turned into an A≈ø≈øe by a Witch; and when he would have ≈øwimmed back unto the Ship where his companions were, he was beaten back by clubs, and went back to the Witch, and was by him ≈øo u≈øed, untill the A≈ø≈øe was ≈øeen in the Church to fall down on its knees, and to do tho≈øe things which could not po≈ø≈øibly be performed by any brute bea≈øt, or meer animal; then they apprehended the Witch which they ≈øu≈øpected to have handled him in that manner, and brought her before the Judges; and after three years was pa≈øt, he was re≈øtored to him≈øelf, and ≈øhe was executed: The ≈øame we read in Ammonius the peripatetick Philo≈øopher, that commonly there was an A≈ø≈øe ordinarily at the hearing of his Lecture.

NOthing is more frequent and u≈øual in Aegypt, as our Merchants report, and Belonius in his Ob≈øervations, printed at Lutetia, ≈øaith, That there was a Stage-Player, which he him≈øelf ≈øaw in the Suburbs of Cayxus, a Town in Egypt, who had a Dialogue with an A≈øs, and ≈øpoke with it, and di≈øcour≈øed with it very familiarly; and he affirmed, that the A≈øs, as he knew by its ≈øigns, ge≈øture and voice, did ≈øhew and intimate, that it took wonderfull well what≈øoever he ≈øpoke to it. And if the Ma≈øter had commanded the A≈øs to pick out the beautifulle≈øt woman in all the company, and would eye her narrowly in all her parts, and would draw near very boldly and confidently to him, it would make much of him. If the Ma≈øter had given out, That there ≈øhould be ≈øome barn or granary prepared for his A≈øs, then it would have ≈øhewed a great deal of exultation more then ordinary, and a great many ≈øuch kind of tricks it played; and many ≈øuch like things at large declared in Belonius. I would ≈øpeak more of them, but I fear that there will be bounds put to them; and I could not have put them in my creed, had I not been an eye-witne≈øs of them among≈øt the Cayxian people.

TO this is added one which Vincentius writes of, in Speculo, lib. 3. c. 109. that there were two gue≈øts which were Witches, which ≈øometimes were wont to change men into bea≈øts; and when they had turned a young man, a Player, into an A≈øs,4 who that he might be in his right wits, did ≈øhew great ≈øport unto Travellers; he was bought by a Neighbour with a great price, who ≈øaid, they would not hold their bargain, nor perform their Covenant, and if he ≈øhould chance to go to a river, and ≈øo e≈øcape, therefore the A≈øs after a few dayes were ≈øpent, went unto the next Pool or Lake, and dipping twice or thrice in it, re-a≈ø≈øumed its pri≈øtine ≈øhape. Peter Damianus, a
man to be reckoned among≈øt the chief of his age, when he was diligently enquired of, of the Ma≈øter and the A≈øs, and of the female Witches, he confe≈ø≈øed it, and of tho≈øe that ≈øaw the A≈øs turned into his humane ≈øhape, it was related before Pope Leo the 7th, and after it was a long while di≈øputed on both ≈øides pro and con, before that Pope; at la≈øt it was concluded on the affirmative part.

ANd by this means may that al≈øo be confirmed which we read in Lucian and Apuleius Athei≈øticall men, to be turned into A≈ø≈øes, who ≈øaid that this happened to the Witches by the The≈øsalonian women, who therefore were enemies to them that they might know for certain whether this was true or no, for both of them were „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ athei≈øticall and accu≈øed of the Magicall Arts. Wherefore Apuleius turns every ≈øtone, and u≈øeth by all means and arguments in his Apology that he might wa≈øh off that accu≈øation of Witchcraft and Sorcery, wherewith he was defamed, &c. Bodinus, lib. 2. cap. 6.

OF all the deeds that Magitians challenge to them≈øelves, you ≈øhall hardly find any more famous then that of cau≈øing Thunder, Lightning, Storms, and Tempe≈øts, as the Law had it ventilated, and has found it for certain, and therefore in lib. 5. Inqui≈øitorum, it is recorded, that in the year 1488. in the Con≈øtantian Dioce≈ø≈øe, there were Storms, Hail, Lightning, and Tempe≈øts, which hurt the corn for the ≈øpace of four miles, the Countrey men in veighing again≈øt the Magitians, there were two of them apprehended, Anna de Mindelen and Agne, which were fir≈øt attached, and when they were examined, they confe≈ø≈øed a part, that one day they went into the field with a little water, and although one of them knew not the others mind or Coun≈øell, yet they confe≈ø≈øed they digged a little hole, or a little ditch, and that about noon-tide, throwing a little water into the hole or ditch, and ≈øtirring the water about, u≈øing ≈øome certain kind of unknown words, and calling upon the Devill; then this being done, they both went home, and ≈øo rai≈øed the Storm: Both of them were burned.

THe ≈øame Author ≈øaith that there was Judgment given out by him again≈øt a Witch of the Con≈øtantian-field, which when ≈øhe ≈øaw all the neighbours of her Village to be merry, and dancing at a marriage, and taking it grievou≈øly that ≈øhe was not invited thereto; in the day time ≈øhe was tran≈øported by the Devill to a hill near unto the Village, (the Shepherds ≈øeeing her) and becau≈øe ≈øhe had not water which ≈øhe ≈øhould throw into the ditch that ≈øhe might ≈øtir up the tempe≈øt (for ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe ob≈øerved this ceremony) ≈øhe made water, and ≈øtirring that about in the ditch, ≈øhe ≈øpoke ≈øome certain words; by and by the Heavens which now were (as I may ≈øay) all Cry≈øtalline clear, were muffled with Pitchy, Jet-like clouds, foul and black masks, and a great ≈øhore of hail came quickly upon the dancers in the Village, and the VVitch returned
into the Village again, they ≈øeeing her, did all verily believe that ≈øhe had rai≈øed the tempe≈øt, and laid hold on her, and the Shepherds did give in their te≈øtimony that they ≈øaw her carried through the Ayr: which ≈øhe being accu≈øed of, and convicted, acknowledged it, and was burned.

WE read a memorable Hi≈øtory in Pontanus 5. libro, The French of Suetia, be≈øieged in the Neapolitan Kingdome by the Spaniards, when all things were parched with drought and heat, and the French in their battell having a great ≈øcarcity of fre≈øh water; ≈øome Prie≈øts being Magitians, did draw-about the Crucifix in the Streets in the night time, and with innumerable railings and bla≈øphemies, they went their proce≈ø≈øion, and threw it into the Sea, afterwards they gave the con≈øecrated ho≈øt to an A≈ø≈øe, and brought him to the Church-porch, and there buried him alive; then after ≈øome Ver≈øes, and horrible bla≈øphemies (which is not fit to be mentioned) there came great da≈øhing ≈øhowers, and made almo≈øt a deluge, and ≈øo by this means rai≈øed the ≈øiege, and were freed from the Spaniards, there was one in the year 1557. who threw all his Images and pictures into a Salt-peeter pit; and afterwards there was abundance of rain.

ANd oftentimes Witches kill Cattle by ≈øprinkling a certain kind of powder upon the thre≈øholds they go over, not that the powder can work ≈øuch an effect, which might rather (as one would think) kill the Witches that carries it about them, then tho≈øe creatures which go over it, e≈øpecially when the Witches hide it one foot under the ground, but onely the Devill is the helper of it. I have heard of three hundred bea≈øts by this means, which were de≈øtroyed in one in≈øtant in a Sheepfold of Biturgia, Neither onely doth the Devill exerci≈øe his power, not onely in rai≈øing of Tempe≈øts, Hail, Lightning, and about Corn and bea≈øts, but al≈øo upon Men, but chiefly upon wicked men, and tho≈øe VVitches (which were burnt at Patavius in the year of our Lord, 1564. which we have mentioned) confe≈ø≈øed that in tho≈øe conventicles in which they were congregated together, they wor≈øhipped the Devill in the ≈øhape of a Kid, and when they were about to depart the place, they heard a great voice pronounced by the Kid, Either ye ≈øhall be revenged, or el≈øe ye ≈øhall dye: and ≈øo there were many men and bea≈øts ≈ølain by him, leaving no other means of pre≈øerving life.

NIderius writeth, that ≈øentence was pronounced by him again≈øt one Stadlinus of the Lau≈øanen≈øian Dioce≈ø≈øe, who confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øeven young Children were killed in the VVombs of the Mothers, and ≈øo al≈øo brought barrenne≈ø≈øe upon all the Cattle that belonged to his family, and being que≈øtioned about the matter, gave an≈øwer that there was a certain bea≈øt, who≈øe name we keep ≈øecret, that was laid there by him at the thre≈øhold, which being taken away, B ‚Ä¢ rrenne≈ø≈øe cea≈øed in his hou≈øe.

WE read in the Mon≈øtreletian Hi≈øtory of a ≈øhort Witch that was taken by a Prie≈øt, who had two Toads that ≈øhe had Baptized, which ≈øhe u≈øed to Magicall u≈øes, which I ≈øhould e≈øteem as ridiculous, were there not daily examples that confirmed it; VVhen Sir John Martin, put in ≈øtead of the Governour of Laodunen≈øis, condemned a VVitch of S. Proba to be burned, who ≈øhook off two great Toads which they found in her Coffers. The Froi≈øardian Hi≈øtory witne≈ø≈øeth that there was one Curio with the Sue≈øionians who asked Coun≈øell of a VVitch that he might be revenged of an enemy who coun≈øelled him that he ≈øhould Baptize a Toad, and give it ≈øome brave name, and give it the Sacrament; which he did, and many other things which is not to be expre≈ø≈øed here, he confe≈ø≈øed. Five Inqui≈øitors after VVitches, declare the≈øe things among≈øt others, that examined a VVitch, which confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe put the con≈øecrated bread in a Napkin which ≈øhe ought to have ≈øwallowed down, and hid in the Cup where ≈øh ‚Ä¢ nouri≈øhed the Toad and put to it the powders which ≈øhe had given her by the Devill, and ≈øo ≈øhe muttered ≈øome few words (which is not fit to be mentioned here) and ≈øo ≈øprinked the Sheepfold thre≈øholds over which the Cattle were to pa≈ø≈øe over the afore≈øaid powder, therefore ≈øhe was apprehended, and burned.

IN the examination of the Valerian Witches in Subaudia which was Printed ≈øtood to be ≈øould; we read that ca≈øting a certain kind of powder upon Plants, they will quickly wither and dye. I have (≈øaith Bodinus) in my power ≈øome Judgments that are ≈øent unto me by that wor≈øhipfull Gentleman, the Lord of Pipemontens de barbu Dorcaea which by a Statute of Parliament 11. of January, 1577. one was ≈øentenced to death by the Governour of S. Chri≈øtopher, to Sanli≈øium which decree was confirmed and e≈øtabli≈øhed, and condemned to be burned, and afterward the Witch confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe had killed three men by ca≈øting a little powder wrapped in a ≈øheet of Paper, into that place by which they were to journey, and murmuring the≈øe words. In the name of God and all Devills, and other Conjuring diabolicall words. Which is not fit to be in≈øerted in this place.

NIderus writes, who examined abundance of Witches, that he ≈øaw one, who onely by his voice could kill men, and another that did turn up and down, her neighbours Gho≈øt being a horrible ≈øpectacle. Anglus al≈øo writes (of who≈øe Hi≈øtory we have formerly ≈øpoken) being the Phy≈øitian of the Palatinate Princes, that in the year 1539. there was an Husbandman of Ulrichus that was afflicted with ≈øuch kind of enchantments, Neu≈øe≈ø≈øurus by name, thorow who≈øe skin there was an Iron nail ≈øtrucken, and was ≈øo gnawed and tormented in his bowells; and de≈øpairing of remedy, ≈øtrangled him≈øelf, and was anatomized, and cut up in the ≈øight of all the Citizens, and there was found in his body a Staff, four Steel
knives, two plates of Iron, and a bottome of hair. And therefore no wonder is it, if the The≈øsalonian Witch at Pamphila cau≈øed a Womans belly to ≈øwell and be tympanized, as if ≈øhe had been about to bring forth three births, and for the ≈øpace of eight Moneths ≈øhe carried about her this burthen. In like ≈øort did that Martinian Witch, which killed the German, not by poi≈øon, as Tacitus ≈øaith, or by a Cocks Egg, but by the help of the Devill. And al≈øo that Witch in the Con≈øtantien≈øian Dioce≈ø≈øe, that did ≈øo puff up a mans body, as though he had the lepro≈øy, and a little after troubled his mind. Sprangerus and other Inqui≈øitors took care that ≈øhe ≈øhould be burned. The ≈øame Sprangerus relates, he being the cau≈øe of it that there was another burnt on the borders of Ba≈øil, and Al≈øatia, which confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe took grievou≈øly a contumely that was offered to her by a good hone≈øt man, a Husbandman, when ≈øhe was asked what mi≈øchief ≈øhe de≈øired to be done unto that Husbandman that did ≈øo reproach her, to which que≈øtion ≈øhe gave an≈øwer, That ≈øhe would have his face to ≈øwell. Not long after the Husbandman was infected with a Lepro≈øy; the≈øe things ≈øhe afterwards confe≈ø≈øed to the Judge, that ≈øhe was not able to do ≈øuch a thing, but that it was done by the Devill; by which argument we prove that all the≈øe things are done by the Devill, who ≈øo in≈øinuates and accommodates him≈øelf to the wills of men that u≈øe him, that who≈øoever ≈øhould cure his enemy, ≈øhould be killed by his ≈øociate or companion.

WE al≈øo read in Sprangerus's Story, of one Plumberus, a certain Conjurer, who lived at Lendenburg in Germany, whom the Devill taught to ≈øhoot at, and pierce a Crucifix with Darts before Venus fea≈øts, by which means u≈øing ≈øome kind of wicked words, and ≈øhooting and darting into the Ayre, he could daily kill and ≈ølay three men which he ≈øaw and knew, although they were encloy≈øtered, and ≈øhut up in the narrow circumference of a little Tower, and ≈øometimes did deliberate and con≈øult whether he ≈øhould de≈øtroy them or no. But at la≈øt the Countreymen did rear him in pieces, without any Law-like Judgment after he had committed many bloudy murthers: The≈øe things were done in the year 1420. Bodinus Daemonom. lib. 2. cap. 8.

AT the Pedemontanians, one Caralius by name, who ≈øeemed to be an Hermophrodite, and when this Epicaene entred into other hou≈øes, and a while after they did kill men; therefore the Hermophrodite was attached and apprehended, and did di≈øcover the conjurations and the conventicles of all the Witches, and many of their diabolical acts, (for there were almo≈øt 40 Witches) which did anoint the outward handle of the gates to kill men; this was done, and happened in the year 1536. And the ≈øame fell out afterwards
at Geneva in the year 1568, where the Plague raged for the ≈øpace of ≈øeven years, of which there dyed many. Cardan writes, That he ≈øaw a certain Witch at Patavia, which quickly kill'd a boy while ≈øhe only gently touched his back with a rod. Glauca being a zealous Witch of Medea, and the daughter of Creon, King, who married Ja≈øon, whom afterwards ≈øhe ≈ølew, who ≈øent her a golden Crown on the Marriage-day; and when Glauca did ≈øet the Crown upon his head, there ≈øhined out a flame, by which he in≈øtantly was burned, as Euripedes writes in Medea,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , he ≈øaith, Non venenis tuis ≈øed pharmacis, not by thy poi≈øons, but druggs and Medicines.

WE have before made mention of a Biebrane Witch, which was burnt at Laodunum, in the year 1556; This Witch did debilitate and weaken men, and ≈øtrangely ≈øcrewed them awry, and de≈øtroyed bea≈øts and fruit; but at that very in≈øtant when ≈øhe was burned, all the≈øe cea≈øed, as we have had intelligence of the Judge who examined her; be≈øides, the ≈øame Judge reported to me, That when the Witch threatned a certain woman, that ≈øhe ≈øhould never after give ≈øuck, it ≈øo happened, that her milk in≈øtantly dryed up; and although ≈øhe bore many children, yet her brea≈øts were dryed up: but the Witch being burned quickly, her brea≈øts abounded with milk; I heard this of a certain Nobleman, that her Aunt did put an ob≈øtacle, or did cau≈øe her to be barren, and bring forth no children; but when ≈øhe dyed, ≈øhe confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe might get a place for her children: but after her Aunt dyed, and as ≈øoon as the clew of her life was unravell'd, or within a ≈øhort while after, the Lady was with child, and bore 2. or 3. children after ≈øhe had been married eleven years. Bodinus.

VIerus tells a ≈øtory of a certain Conjurer which he ≈øaw in Germany, who in the day-time, in the ≈øight of the people, a≈øcended, flew upwards towards Heaven; and when his Wife caught him by the feet as he was flying up, ≈øhe was taken up together with him, and ≈ønatching hold on a Maid, ≈ønatcht her up too, and they hovered a good while in the Air, the multitude ≈øtood wondring at the miracle. A like Example we read in the Hi≈øtory of Hugh Floriacen≈øis, a Manti≈øconen≈øian Earl, howling with a great voice, O friends, help me, was caught up into the Air and carried away, and wasn ever ≈øeen after. The ≈øame Vierus relates, That he ≈øaw men ≈ønatcht into the Air by devils. And it was required of a certain Magitian in Germany, who promi≈øed, that he would bring out the Books of Franci≈øcus the fir≈øt, King, out of the Madrid Tower; he was tran≈øported through the Ayr out of Spain into France; but for all this nothing was done, which was much feared, le≈øt that they ≈øhould ru≈øh upon the Captain, and break all the necks of the ruinators. So there was a Jewi≈øh Magitian, Sedechias by name,
who (as John the Tritemian Abbot relates) did ≈øhoot a man thorough the Ayr, and tore his body, and gathering up his limbs, knit them together again, as did Simon Magus, Nero being pre≈øent, who did gulph up a load of Hay, with Cart and Hor≈øes, and drivers, in the ≈øight of all the people.
div.trailer: The End of the Fir≈øt Book.

div.head: THE VVonderfull Hi≈øtory OF SPECTRALS; AND The ≈øeveral Devices and Delu≈øions of Devils and Evil Spirits. The Second Book.
Of Oracles, Prophecies, and Predictions of Devils.
div.p:
TElephus, the King of the My≈øons, who did prohibit and interdict the Grecians from de≈øcending or going into the lower Countreys, when he ob≈øtinately pur≈øued Uly≈øses among≈øt the Vines; but being hindred, he fell upon the trunk or ≈øtump of a Vine; Achilles was a great way off, who ≈øhot a Dart into the King's left thigh; but Peace being made, and the Greeks returning to their own Country, Telephus was a long time afflicted with the pain of the wound; and when he could not be cured by any means, when he was in great extremity, he was admoni≈øhed by Apollo's Oracle, That he ≈øhould make u≈øe of Achilles and Ae≈øculapius his ≈øons; ≈øo he in≈øtantaneou≈øly ≈øailed to Argos, le≈øt he ≈øhould be denyed of the remedy that was promi≈øed him by the
Oracle; Achilles with Machaon and Podalyrius took care of his wound, and in a ≈øhort ≈øpace, that which the Oracle did predict came to pa≈ø≈øe.

CRoe≈øu ‚Ä¢ , the King of the Lydians, when he had parted with o ‚Ä¢ e≈øon, as Atium, he had another ≈øon that was dumb, and for the cure of it, he left nothing undone, no ≈øtone was unturned; and then he ≈øent to enquire of the Oracle at Delphos, to whom Pythia an≈øwered:
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
Thy ≈øpeechle≈øs ≈øon, great King, Croe≈øus high race,
Wi≈øh not his words to hear, thy long'd-for Grace;
One day thy boon ≈øhall thee di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, when thou
Shalt have with force what thou reque≈øte≈øt now.
The event did give credit to the Oracle; for the Gardi being taken by Cyrus, when a certain Souldier ru≈øhed upon the King, his dumb ≈øon cryed out with a loud voice, when before he never ≈øpoke word, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , O thou man, kill not Croe≈øus; ≈øo that Croe≈øus by his own fault lo≈øt his Kingdom, who by the words of his ≈øon, ≈øaved his life. Herodotus lib. 1.

THe Minyae relate or tell the ≈øtory about He≈øiod's bones, after this manner; The Plague raging upon Man and Bea≈øt, they ≈øent ≈øome to con≈øult with the Oracle, who received this an≈øwer, That to cea≈øe the Plague, there was onely this one remedy; for if they did but carry He≈øiod's bones out of the Naupactian field, into Orchomenium, otherwi≈øe their malady could not be cured: And again they asked of the Oracle, In what part of the Naupactian field that ≈øhould find them? Pythia gave an≈øwer, That a Crow would ≈øhew them the place. And when they returned back into their Country, and tho≈øe that were ≈øent enquiring for it not far from the way ≈øide, ≈øaw a Crow ≈øitting on a ≈øtone, and there they digg'd, and found He≈øiod's bones in the concave of the Monument, with this in≈øcription, Pau≈øanias in Boeticis.

AThenien≈øis, the ≈øon of Catatreus the Cretian's King, when he asked coun≈øel of the Oracle, had this an≈øwer given, That the fates had decreed, that his Father ≈øhould be ≈ølain by him; and de≈øiring to ≈øhun that fate, of his own accord, together with many other Volunteers, went away into the mouth of Rhodes, which is called Camiros Catatreus, by the in≈øtigation of his onely ≈øon, took his journey into Rhodes, de≈øirous of bringing his ≈øon into Creet; It was night time ere he came into the I≈øland, and there was a fight

ALexander, Emperour, in the year of the Lord, 904, as Sigebert writeth, was idle, being given to riot and Magick; He having demanded of his Juglers, Whether he was to live long? he received an an≈øwer, If he had taken away from the brazen Boar in the Theatre, his teeth and privy members. AMong the Biarmians, Laplanders, Bothnians, Finlanders, Northern people, there is this often kind of magicall divining: The Magitian goeth into a clo≈øet, content with one companion and his wife; he ≈ømiteth a brazen Frog or Serpent with an hammer, upon an anvil, with certain ≈øtroaks, and turns up and down hither and thither, with a muttering of ver≈øes; and ≈øtraightway falling, is ≈ønatched into a trance, and layeth along for a ≈øhort time as dead. STephen the Hagio-Chri≈øtophorite, (it is the name of an office) but for his wickedne≈ø≈øe otherwi≈øe called Antichri≈øtophorite, after that he knew from the Devil, by Sethus a Magitian, de≈øtruction to hang over the head of Andronicus Comnenus, by him who≈øe name had its beginning, [J. WIlliam Earl of Holland, King of the Romans, Fri≈øia being ≈øubdued, when as nigh to a certain City he had found a Sepulcher adorned with wonderfull work, and did ask, Who≈øe it was? SIgthune King of Swethland, while he offered ≈øacrifices to his gods at Up≈øala the Mother-City, an an≈øwer being received by the ≈øacrificers, he learned that by a fatall nece≈ø≈øity, the highe≈øt de≈øtruction and death did hang over his head from the mettall of Gold, and therefore he was chiefly to take heed of it: by iron, or Steel, and other mettals he could never be forced or killed. CReophilus in the bounds of the Ephe≈øians, ≈øaith, tho≈øe that built Ephe≈øus, when they were greatly in doubt of the place at length they ≈øent unto the Oracle, tho≈øe which ≈øhould ask, where the City was to be placed. And before he could well ≈øwim over the River, he was fallen upon by an innumerable Army, who had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the brink and bank≈øides of the River. Petrarcha.

MAchabaeus King of the Scots, fearing Magduffus, being admoni≈øhed by Sooth≈øayers, was told by a woman a Fortune-teller, that he ≈øhould not fall by the hands of any man that was born of a woman, and that he could not be overcome before the wood Bernen were carried to the Ca≈øtle Donu≈øinna, which was a great way di≈øtant.
Therefore he fal≈øly thought him≈øelf invincible, and free from all ≈øtratagems and deceits of his enemies, having cut down the wood Birnen, and carried every ≈øtick to the Ca≈øtle, wherewith he compa≈ø≈øed the Ca≈øtle the day before he was overcome: to be ≈øhort, he was ≈ølain by Magduffus, who was not born, but cut out of his Mothers belly. Cardanus de rerum varietate. Lib. 16. cap. 93.

ANtonius of Leva animated Charls the fift, Emperour, to war upon on France, and undertook to be Generall of the Army, although he had been informed by the Oracles, that he ≈øhould be afflicted with cruell ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, dye in France, and re≈øt at the Church of St. Dion≈øiyus, which he interpreted ≈øhould come to pa≈ø≈øe by his extending his Victory to Paris it ≈øelf; but it fell out far otherwi≈øe. For the Cae≈øarian Army which he led, was wa≈øted with a Flux, and he, ≈øpent by watchings and griefs, died near the City Narbo in France, and was buried at Saint Diony≈øius. Sabellici ≈øupplementum, 20.

AMilcarus, Duke of the Carthagenians, be≈øieging the Syracu≈øians again≈øt Agathocles, was told by a Sooth-≈øayer (who gathered this conjecture by the ob≈øervation of the entrals of bea≈øts) that the next night after he ≈øhould ≈øup with the Syracu≈øians, who when he conceived he ≈øhould have obtained Victory over them, by a ≈øally which they ≈øuddenly made out of the City, took him Pri≈øoner, and carried him to ≈øup with the Syracu≈øians, contrary to his will, where by cruell torments he died.

THe Velitri con≈øulting an Oracle there, where Cae≈øar was born were an≈øwered long before from the top of the wall, which by its height threatned heaven, that one who ≈øhould be born in that Town, ≈øhould be a great commander in the World, in confidence: whereof the Citizens did immediately, and long afterwards, make war again≈øt the Romans; at la≈øt by what afterwards they ≈øaw, it appeared that by what was ≈øhewed, the might of Augustus Cae≈øar was portended. Suetonius.

HAdrianus Cornetanus Cardinal, not drawn thereto by malice but an ambitious de≈øire of reigning, looked after the death of Leo the tenth: For he conceived an a≈ø≈øured hope of obtaining the Papacy by the Oracle of a fortune-telling-woman, who telling to him, asking fortune of her, many things pa≈øt of his publick and private fortune, mo≈øt exactly true: ≈øhe al≈øo con≈øtantly affirmed that one Hadrian, an old man, of ob≈øcure birth, a great and ≈øtudious Scholler, who by degrees obtained ≈øacred honours by his own merit, and not by the favour of great men, a≈ø≈øoon as Leo departed this life, would ≈øucceed him in the Papacy: all the≈øe de≈øcriptions he conceived did congruou≈øly and apparantly belong to him. For he was born at a poor Village called Cornetus, in the coa≈øts of Tu≈øcany
de≈øcended of a poor family almo≈øt ≈øordid, onely by the benefit of his learning, attaining the dignity of ≈øacred orders. The Oracle of the old Woman proved true, but Hadrianus the Cornetanian was deceived, for he did not ≈øucceed Leo; but one Hadrian, an old man, a Batavian, ≈øon to a poor labourer, being illu≈øtrious by his learning, after Leo, obtained the prodigious felicity of the Papacy. Jov. in Leonis vita, lib. 4.

WHen Alexander the Great, determined to fight again≈øt the chief City of the Oxodracian Indians, a certain man called Demophon, being one of tho≈øe that u≈øed to make o≈øtentation of predictions, came to the King, and told him, that he had ob≈øerved by Augury, that there was great danger portended to him by rea≈øon of a wound which he ≈øhould receive in fighting again≈øt the Indians, and therefore he admoni≈øhed Alexander to divert his intention from invading that City: who rebuked him for going about to apall the courage of valiant men, and providing all things nece≈ø≈øary for his March, he leading a great Army, arrived at the City, and intending to ≈øtorm it, he placed his Artillery again≈øt it, and making a breach in the wall, broke into the City, killed many, and pur≈øued tho≈øe that fled to the very Ca≈øtle; and whil≈øt the Army of the Macedonians were ≈øeeking to ≈øcale the Walls, He, without any cunctation, ≈ønatching a ladder, and artificially bearing his buckler over his head, he falls a ≈øcaling the wall, and u≈øed ≈øo much celerity therein, that before the drow≈øy Barbarians could get to the wall to defend it, he got to the top thereof: the enemies dur≈øt not approach to grapple with him, but put him hard to it by Darts and Arrows which they threw and ≈øhot at him. The Macedonians with two ladders which they had reared to the Wall, did oft endeavour to ≈øcale the wall, and relieve Alexander, but were ≈øtill repul≈øed by the enemy. Wherefore he being de≈øtitute of any help, alone, and loaded with defen≈øive and offen≈øive Arms, leaped into the very Ca≈øtle, and mo≈øt valiantly defended him≈øelf again≈øt the Indians, who violently ran about him, but he ≈øeeing a tree near the Wall, ≈øtepped unto it, and leaning his back to it, made it ≈øo much his defence, that they could not come about him; and now laying about him at his enemies by dint of ≈øword, though he ≈øhewed great courage by his mo≈øt valiant deeds, which, like a Royall King, to the a≈øtoni≈øhment of his enemies, he demon≈øtrated, in≈øomuch that he ≈øeemed to de≈øire nothing but a glorious death, receiving many ≈øhots and blows upon his helmet and buckler, yet at length an Arrow which was ≈øhot at him, lighted a little under his pap or brea≈øt, and there ≈øticking, he was con≈øtrained by violence of his pain to fall upon his knees; which an Indian who was enraged by a wound which he had received from him ≈øoon perceiving, furiou≈øly marched to him, and fell upon him, but was by one blow with his ≈øword ≈øuddenly di≈øpatched. The King then catching hold of a bough of the Tree within his reach, helped him≈øelf off his knees, and begun to provoke his enemies to fight; in
which interim Peu≈øestes, one of the Squires of the Kings body, ≈øcaling the Wall, was the fir≈øt that came to the defence of his Prince, and after him many more, who put the Barbarians to flight, and delivered Alexander from further danger. Diodorus, lib. 17.

A Certain ≈øervant, a Syrian, born in Apemea, who≈øe name was Eunus, who delighted in Magicall enchantments, and circulatory legerdemains, ≈øerved among≈øt the Eunen≈øians in Sicilia. This fellow would take upon him that he could by in≈øtinct and revelation from the Gods, who appeared to him in his ≈øleep, tell things to come; ≈øhortly after, he bragged that he could foretell future events, not onely for that the gods appeared to him a≈øleep, but al≈øo waking, and that they plainly told him of things to come: when as by many of his Prophe≈øies, he was found a notorious liar, yet in the mean time ≈øome things came to pa≈ø≈øe according to his predictions, which was a rea≈øon that no man que≈øtioned him for his fal≈øe Prophecies, but what he chanced truly to foretell, was ≈øo ob≈øerved and applauded, that the people ≈øhortly had a high e≈øteem of him; at la≈øt he devi≈øed to blow a flame of fire out of his mouth with a certain fanatick fury, he Prophe≈øied like as it had been one of the Prie≈øts of Apollo, to which purpo≈øe he had a nut, or ≈øomething of like nature bored through, in which he put fire, and combu≈øtible matter to nouri≈øh it, and putting it into his mouth, and blowing, ≈øometimes ≈øent forth ≈øparks, and ≈øometimes flames, this fellow was u≈øed before any defection, to brag that the Syrian godde≈ø≈øe did appear to him in his ≈øleep, and tell him that he ≈øhould obtain regall dignity; and he did not tell this onely to the ordinary ≈øort of people, but likewi≈øe he daily related the ≈øame to Antigines the Eunen≈øian his own Ma≈øter: his relation ray≈øing much laughter, and Antigines taking great delight in his prodigious lies, had him as a je≈øter to wait upon him at his fea≈øts, and would enquire of him concerning ≈øtate-affairs, and what would become of all the company, and when he an≈øwered them all with great confidence, and promi≈øed that it would come to pa≈ø≈øe, that he ≈øhould ≈øhew great lenity and clemency to his Lords, he ray≈øed great laughter among≈øt them. The common people ray≈øing a tumult, come to this Eunus, and asked him if the gods favoured their enterpri≈øe: he approving the thing, per≈øwaded them to go on therein, and pre≈øently four hundred of his fellow ≈øervants, taking him for their Captain, brake into the City, and made ≈øuch a horrible ≈ølaughter, that they ≈øpared not very ≈øucking Infants, and this was the beginning of the ≈øervile Warre which made ≈øuch horrible de≈øtruction in Sicily, that Rutilius at length with much ado, made an end of it. Diodorus Siculus, lib. 34.

WHen at the Thermopilae long Mountains pa≈ø≈øing through Graece to the Egaean Sea, three hundred Lacedemonians were to fight again≈øt Xerxes, Megi≈øtias Acarnas, a Propher of the
race of Melpodes, told that it was apparent, That death was imminent over all their heads; though Leonides offered openly to di≈ømi≈øs him, that he ≈øhould not undergo ≈øuch hazard of his life, yet he would not depart, but al≈øo cau≈øed his onely ≈øon to go along with him, and be a Souldier; all the re≈øt of his fellow-Souldiers which were di≈øcharged of their ≈øervice, went their wayes; the The≈øbien≈øian and Theban Souldiers went on, and continuing with the Lacedemonians, they all peri≈øht together. Herodotus, lib. 7.

WHereas it was often given out as an Edict, That who≈øoever either privately or publickly did predict or foretell the death of any man, ≈øhould ≈øuffer death; at length Domitian the Emperour commanded A≈øcletario to be burnt, and Larginus Proclus to be hang'd, for that they foretold the day of his death: the one of the≈øe Fortune-tellers was ≈øent by the Governour of the Province of Germany, to Rome, where he con≈øtantly affirmed what he had predicted concerning Domitian, and named a certain day, not long too, wherein the verity or vanity of his Art might be judged; therefore it plea≈øed the Emperour to defer the execution of his ≈øen ‚Ä¢ ence till that day; upon which, his prediction came to pa≈ø≈øe: wherefore by the favour of the noble Roman, he was freed. P. Aerodius Suetonio.

GRillandus ≈øaith, That Peru≈øinus was the greate≈øt Magitian of all Italy, who ≈øinging Ma≈øs upon a certain day, and coming to that part of it at which he was to turn to the people and ≈øay, Orate pro me, &c. he ≈øaid, Pray for the Ca≈øtles of the Church, who are now expiring their lives: and at the ≈øame in≈øtant, the Souldiers of a Ca≈øtle, twenty five miles di≈øtant from Peru≈øium where he ≈øaid Ma≈øs, were ≈ølain. The like ≈øtory we read in Philip Comineus, of a certain Italian Archbi≈øhop of Vienna, who in the pre≈øence of King Lewis the 11th, celebrating Ma≈øs upon the day of the Epiphanie, at the Church of St. Martin at Turon, when he offered the Pax to the King to ki≈øs, pronounced the≈øe words; Peace to thee, O King, thy enemy is dead. And it appeared, that Charls Duke of Burgundie dyed the ≈øame hour at Nanceum in Lotharingia. Cominaeus telleth many things of this Archbi≈øhop, which ≈øeem to be the certain effects of meer Witchcraft.

div.head: Of the Dreams, Vi≈øions, Revelations, and other ≈øuch kind of Legerdemanes and mockeries of Evil Spirits.
div.p: AGamemnon, leader of the Greeks again≈øt Troy, when he had taken Bri≈øeides from Achilles, Thetis interceding Jove for her ≈øon, that he would ≈øubject the Graecians to the Trojans, till they really perceived, and found by wofull revenge, what lo≈ø≈øe, trouble and vexation they had cau≈øed to Achilles, by their injurious dealing with him: Jupiter ≈øends a dream to Agamemnon, wherein he commands him to draw out his Army, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , for now he ≈øhould take Troy. Jove cannot lye, (that he full well knew) yet he well ≈øaw that he could not take the City that day: Jupiter plaid or ≈øported with him by the ab≈øtru≈øe meaning of the word; for the adverb „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øignifies in the Greek, not onely pre≈øent, but in≈øtant; and hath that latitude, that it ≈øignifies pa≈øt, and not much pa≈øt; and to come, and not far off; Jupiter therefore meant by „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the tenth year, which was then pre≈øent, which was not long from the de≈øtruction of Troy. But Agamemnon interpreting, or con≈øtruing his Dream to mean the pre≈øent day, he drew out his Army immediately, and received a great overthrow. Iliados. Œ≤.

CYrus King of the Per≈øians, leading an Army again≈øt the Ma≈ø≈øagetians, being at re≈øt, dreamed, that he ≈øaw Darius the elde≈øt ≈øon of Hy≈øta≈øpes, having two wings, with the one whereof he over≈øhadowed A≈øia; and with the other, Europe. This Darius being twenty years of Age, at this time was left by his father at Ari≈øtimentum in Per≈øia; Cyrus awakened out of his dream, and ≈øu≈øpended with this nocturnal vi≈øion; and ca≈øting many wayes what ≈øhould be the meaning thereof; at la≈øt ≈øaid, That thereby was revealed to him from the gods, that Hy≈øta≈øpes and his ≈øon Darius did lye in wait to ≈øurpri≈øe him and his Kingdom, he u≈øed therefore his utmo≈øt endeavours to return into his own Countrey, the Ma≈øsegetians being conquered, and leaves his ≈øon in his place; but that Vi≈øion foretold, That Cyrus ≈øhould be ≈øhortly overthrown, and that ere long Darius ≈øhould obtain his Kingdom: which came to pa≈ø≈øe, after a ≈øhort reign of Camby≈øes, which came betwixt this and Darius his Conque≈øt. Sabellicus, lib. 6. Ennead. 2.

SOcrates fore≈øaw in his dreams, that his Scholler Plato would be an excellent Orator and Philo≈øopher; for the day before (he being brought to him by his father) Socrates in his dream ≈øaw a white Swan fly into his bo≈øome, which by his mu≈øicall ≈øtriking of his wings, filled the Ayr; which Dream, as ≈øoon as Plato was brought to him, he declared. Pau≈øanias in Atticis.

HIppocrates in his Epi≈øtle to Philopomenes, relates his Dream thus; That meditating ≈øolicitou≈øly of Democritus, (to whom being called to cure the Abderitani, he ≈øaith, that health would meet him in the morning). I ≈øaw, quoth he, Ae≈øculapius, and as we were both before and even at the ports of the Abderitari, Ae≈øculapius appeared not, as his pictures ≈øpeak him, mild and gentle, but with ≈øqualid habit, and an horrid a≈øpect; and there followed him Dragons, a fierce kind of creeping creatures, of huge length, hi≈ø≈øing in de≈øarts and lawnes; he had in his company likewi≈øe, men that followed him with boxes of medicaments hand≈øomely clo≈øed up: immediately he reacheth forth his hand to ≈øalute me, which, God knowes, I mo≈øt joyfully imbraced; I de≈øired to wait upon him, and to ≈øerve him in his admini≈øtring Phy≈øick; but he an≈øwered, for pre≈øent 'twas not needful; for this godde≈øs of mortals and immortals will conduct thee, being a ≈øtranger: Whereupon turning my ≈øelf, I beheld a goodly fair Lady neatly and gloriou≈øly adorned, about who≈øe eyes there appeared ≈øuch a circle of ≈øhining ≈øplendour, that exceeded the glorious brightne≈ø≈øe of Stars. He thereupon departed, but the Lady taking me kindly by the hand, leads me on a grave pace through the City; and when we approached near a hou≈øe, wherein I thought I ≈øhould have been entertained, ≈øhe departed like a gho≈øt, ≈øaying, To morrow I ≈øhall find you with Democritus. To whom as ≈øhe was going away, I ≈øaid, Dear Lady who are you? and how may I call you? Truth, ≈øayes ≈øhe, but ≈øhe that thou ≈øee≈øt coming towards thee, (and pre≈øently another Lady not uncomely appeared to me, of a more bold a≈øpect, and more fierce) who≈øe name ≈øhe told me was Opinion, and that ≈øhe lived with the Abderetani. When I therefore awaked from my Dream, I conceived the interpretation of it to be, That Democritus needs not a Phy≈øitian, God departing from admini≈øtring of Phy≈øick, when there is no matter or ≈øickne≈ø≈øe which requires it; but that Truth, which alwayes dwelleth with Democritus, ≈øaith he, is in health; and that Opinion which ≈øaith he is ≈øick, remaineth among≈øt the mad Abderetani.

ALexander was de≈øcended from Hercules by Carinus, and from Aeacus on his Mothers ≈øide by Neoptolemus, as it was verily thought. It is reported, that when Phillip King of Macedon fir≈øt courted Olympiades, taken with her beauty, (by the help of her brother Arybba, whom Diodore in his ≈øixteenth book calleth Arymba) who≈øe friend≈øhip he obtained, he ≈øtole her away from her Parents,
and married her, and that the night before they enjoyed nuptial rights, in a dream he thought he ≈øaw Jove touch his belly, being de≈øcended from Heaven in thunder; whereupon there was a huge fire which aro≈øe, and pre≈øently di≈øper≈øed it ≈øelf into flames all about. The ≈øame Philip, a ≈øhort time after his marriage, dreamed, That he ≈øealed his Wives belly, and that the ≈øculpture of the ≈øeal, as it ≈øeemed to him, was the Image of a Lyon; which vi≈øion he declaring to ≈øome that took upon them the interpretation of dreams, they advi≈øed him to ≈øet a ≈øtrict Watch or Guard upon his Wife; but Teleme≈øus ≈øaid, She would bring a Lyon-like child, for that no vain thing is to be ≈øealed; therefore the dream ≈øignified, that ≈øhe would have a child of perfect animo≈øity and courage. Plutarchus, in Alexandro.

SOphocles did often dream, that Hercules ≈øpeaking to him by name, called him thief, becau≈øe he had ≈øtoln a golden ve≈ø≈øel out of his Temple. And that being detected and brought before the State, he confe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf guilty of the theft whereof Hercules accu≈øed him; wherefore from that time ever after, the Temple was called by the name of Hercules his Temple. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 5.

ANnaeus Seneca, a Senator of Rome, being commanded by Claudius, the Emperour, to undertake the Tutor≈øhip of Nero, as yet a child hopefull, by a towardly genius; the night after he received him, (as 'tis reported) he dreamed, that he had to his Scholler Caligula, who≈øe famous cruelty had appeared to the World: Not long after the conditions and manners of Nero changing, or rather being detected, appearing, he proved him≈øelf to have a ≈øoul void of humanity; in≈øomuch, that it was admired, becau≈øe he was ≈øo like Caligula, how it could otherwi≈øe come to pa≈øs, but by the tran≈ømigration of Caligula, his ≈øoul out of Hell, into Nero. Petrarcha ex Suetonio & Dione.

EUdemus a Cyprian, a familiar friend of Socrates, travelling into Macedonia, cometh to Pherae, a rich and famous City of The≈ø≈øaly, but oppre≈ø≈øed and brought ≈øomewhat low, by the inhumane tyranny of one Alexander, he was there taken with ≈øuch heavy ≈øickne≈øs, that Phy≈øitians de≈øpaired of his health; who thus afflicted, dreams, that he ≈øaw a gallant young man, who coming to him, a≈ø≈øured him of three things to come, That he, though now extreamly ≈øick, ≈øhould ≈øhortly recover his health; That the Tyrant of that City ≈øhould dye within a few dayes; And that he within five years ≈øhould go to his own Country. And the two fir≈øt did manife≈øtly come to pa≈ø≈øe accordingly; for he beyond all hopes recovered his health; the Tyrant was ≈ølain by his Wives brothers: the third was ≈øomewhat more ob≈øcure; for about the end of the fifth year, as he was going from Sicily, where he then lived, to Cyprus, he was taken out of this World by Wars at Syracu≈øa: we find, that Interpreters of Dreams excu≈øe the not coming of Eudemus home according
to the dream, by ≈øaying, That by death his ≈øoul was delivered from the bonds of his body, and returned to her Countrey. Petrarcha.

ASpa≈øia, the daughter of Hermotimus, after her Mother Phocen≈øis dyed in labour, together with her child, being educated in penury, and want of a Parent, yet mode≈øtly and hand≈øomely ≈øhe often dreamed, that ≈øhe ≈øaw one, who told her, that her fortune ≈øhould be ≈øuch, that ≈øhe ≈øhould be married to a gallant and hone≈øt Gentleman; it chanced to the Maid, that a ≈øwelling ro≈øe upon her very chin, mo≈øt ugly to behold, which was a cau≈øe of much grief both to her father and her: whereupon her father brought her to a Phy≈øitian, who undertook to cure her, upon condition that he ≈øhould give him three Staters, (which is worth ≈øeven ≈øhillings of our Engli≈øh coyn) for his pains; When the father ≈øaid, 'Twas more then he had, the Phy≈øitian di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the young Maid uncured, who thereupon was mo≈øt grievou≈øly tormented, ≈øo that ≈øhe ate nothing; that night, an opportune ≈øleep ≈øeizing upon her, ≈øhe had a Vi≈øion, wherein ≈øhe heard the≈øe words. Be of good courage, and trouble not your ≈øelf with Phy≈øitians, but take a Ro≈øe of Venus, and beating it together into a ≈øalve, apply it to your ≈øwelling. Which when ≈øhe awaked, ≈øhe accordingly performed, and her ≈øwelling was clean taken away, and A≈øpa≈øia ≈øo far tran≈øcended all the Ladies of her time, in glorious beauty, vertuous life, and incomparable carriage, that Cyrus King of the Per≈øians, enamoured with her excellencies, fir≈øt married her, and after his death Artaxerxes took her to Wife. You may read the Story elegantly ≈øet forth by Aelianus de varia hi≈øtoria, lib. 12. √† principio.

IN the time of Plinius, the Mother of a certain Souldier who ≈øerved in the Praetory, dreamed, that ≈øhe ought to ≈øend to her ≈øon the root of a wild Ro≈øe-Tree, or Sweet-brier, which ≈øhe had ≈øeen and ob≈øerved in a Grove the day before by rea≈øon of its beauty, to drink in milk: This happened in Laretania, being the neare≈øt part of Spain. And it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that this Souldier having been bitten with a mad-dog, whereby he grew ≈øo ill, that he began to fear the waters, and ≈øhew many ≈øymptoms of his infirmity; he received a Letter from his Mother, wherein ≈øhe de≈øired him to make u≈øe of the Medicine which was ≈øhewed her in his Vi≈øion; which he ob≈øerving, and performing, became pre≈øently free from the mi≈øery he was in; and not onely he, but any that afterwards upon like occa≈øion, made u≈øe of that medicine. Plinius, lib. 25. cap. 2.

AESculapius of Athens pre≈øcribed by Oracle to Plutarch an Athenian, and Domninus a Syrian, who brui≈øed by I know not what chance, did ≈øpit blood, that they ≈øhould be filled with Swines-fle≈øh; but Plutarch, though by the Law of his Nation he was not forbidden Swines-fle≈øh, and therefore might have made u≈øe thereof
according to the pre≈øcription, utterly refu≈øed it, and awakened from ≈øleep, ≈øtretching forth his arms in his bed, and beholding the Statue or Image of Ae≈øculapius (for he lay in the porch or entry of the Temple) he ≈øaid, Why did≈øt thou pre≈øcribe this cure to an Hebrew or Jewi≈øh Lord? for neither had≈øt thou bid him to be filled with Swines fle≈øh. Which words when this man had ≈øpoken, Ae≈øculapius (a mo≈øt ≈øweet ≈øound being uttered out of the Image) pre≈øcribed him another way of curing the di≈øea≈øe. But Domninus, having followed the dream otherwi≈øe than the in≈øtructions of the Syrians, do lead unto, not the example of Plutarch, he both then and ever afterwards a ‚Ä¢ e that fle≈øh: and it is reported, if at any time it had cea≈øed one day, the di≈øea≈øe to have waxed wor≈øe, untill they were fullfilled. Suidas.

A Certain Per≈øian, Epixyes by name, a Noble Lord of the upper Phrygia, laid wait for Themi≈øtocles, going down unto the Sea by rea≈øon of bu≈øine≈ø≈øe pertaining to Greece, after that he fled to Xerxes, Pi≈øidians being long ≈øince provided, who in the Town, which they call [Leontocephalon] (that word ≈øignifieth the heads of Lyons) that they might kill him, walking in the night. To whom they ≈øay, the Mother Idea being ≈øet before him by a dream, to have ≈øaid; O Themi≈øtocles, avoid thou the head of Lyons, lea≈øt thou run into the Lyon. For this thing therefore I require from thee the hand-maid Mne≈øiptolema. XErxes, the ≈øon of Darius, King of the Per≈øians, was about to bring war on the Greeks; Artabanus ≈øon of Hy≈øta≈øpes, the Uncle of Xerxes, exceedingly with≈øtood it.
