He ≈øaw a man in a noble likene≈ø≈øe, chiding him, becau≈øe he deferred to bring War on Greece. The thing being talked of with Artabanus, he con≈øtrained Artabanus cloathed with the King's garments, to take a ≈øleep in the King's
Throne. The ≈øame re≈øemblance was al≈øo pre≈øented before the eyes of Artabanus: Therefore he incen≈øed Xerxes unto the Warr of Greece, with no le≈øs diligence than before he had with≈øtood: indeed the evil fate of Xerxes ≈øo urging it, that the mo≈øt proud King might pay the puni≈øhments of his ra≈øhne≈øs and pride. The ≈øame Xerxes ≈øeemed to him≈øelf to be crowned with an Olive-gra≈øs, with the boughs of which Olive the whole Earth was overwhelmed, and pre≈øently the Crown, tyed fa≈øt about his head, vani≈øhed: This dream was more famous and ≈øure than the former. Xerxes had affrighted the world with Warlike preparation, and now ≈øeemed to triumph over Greece, Athens being taken, when as he was by the diligence of Themi≈øtocles broken, he was forced by a ≈øhamefull flight to ≈øhift for his life. Herodotus, book 7.

THe Spartans, Callicratidas being Captain, were to fight at Arginu≈øa in a Sea-battell with the Athenians, the diviners on both ≈øides di≈ø≈øwading them. For the head of a ≈øacrificed bea≈øt lying on the ≈øhore, di≈øper≈øed the Lacedemonians, being drawn through the rage of a wave; the Sooth≈øayers ≈øhewed, all the≈øe things betokened that the Pretor of the Navy was to peri≈øh in that combat. Which thing being heard, they ≈øay Callicratidas an≈øwered, he ≈øhould withdraw nothing from the Spartane worthine≈ø≈øe, if by fighting he ≈øhould fall. But unto Thra≈øibulus the Athenian, who being then Pretor, led the Navy, and to whom that day, the top of Royall Authority had come by lot, by night this dream appeared. It ≈øeemed to him, together with ≈øix other Praetors, to act the Tragedy of Euripides, who≈øe title is in≈øcribed, [Phoeni≈øsas] in the common Theatre. But it ≈øeemed his adver≈øaries acting the Tragedy, who≈øe name is [Supplices], the Cadmean Victory to have happened to them, and all to have peri≈øhed, by imitating the Captains, who had pitched their Tents for the a≈ø≈øaulting of Thebes. The≈øe things being heard, a Prophet being called to interpret, they ≈øo expounded it, that ≈øeven Captains were to fall in that battell. But the holy things otherwi≈øe openly promi≈øing Victory, he bade the Captains, that it may be ≈øhewed unto their companions alone concerning every ones death, but that they divulge a Victory (betokened by tho≈øe very holy things) throughout the whole Army. A battell being joyned, Callicratidas, ≈øome Ships of the Enemies being fir≈øt overcharged, dyed; the conque≈øt remained in the power of the Athenians, 25. Ships being lo≈øt, 77. of the Enemies ≈øunk. They fought on both ≈øides, with little le≈ø≈øe then four hundred Ships, and that battel is mentioned to be the greate≈øt of all, which indeed Greeks with Greeks ever fought. Diodore, in Book 13.

UNto Pyrrhus King of the Epirots be≈øieging Sparta, ≈øuch a dream was offered. All Lacedemon being ≈øtricken with a Thunderbolt, ≈øeemed to him thereby to be ≈øet on fire, and he thereupon to leap for joy. He being ≈øtirred up with gladne≈ø≈øe, commands his Captains, that they ≈øet the Souldiers in order, and expoundeth the
dream to his friends; as if he was to vanqui≈øh the City. Unto which thing when as others wonderfully agreed, the ≈øight plea≈øed not Ly≈øimachus. He ≈øaith, he feared, lea≈øt as the places that were bla≈øted with Thunderbolt, remain inacce≈ø≈øible, ≈øo the god ≈øignified to Pyrrhus, that he was not to enter the City: When as Pyrrhus an≈øwered this man, Tho≈øe were meer delu≈øions, and full of uncertainty, but that every man holding weapons in his hands, ought to bring into his remembrance.
Optimum id augurium, pro Pyrrho exponere vitam.
Of Divination that's the chief,
For Pyrrhus to adventure life.
In the fir≈øt of the morning he ≈øets upon the City. But the Lacedemonians not ≈øluggi≈øhly and beyond their ≈øtrength, defending them≈øelves, he was con≈øtrained to loo≈øe the ≈øiege. Plutarch. in Pyrrhus.

CN. Pompey, having followed King Mithridates unto Euphrates, fell by night. At which time it is blazed by report, that Mithridates ≈øaw a re≈øemblance in his ≈øleep, which fore≈øhewed him things to come. It ≈øeemed to him to ≈øail in the Pontick Sea, with a pro≈øperous wind, and now to fore≈øee Bo≈øphorus, and courteou≈øly to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe that were carried together with him, as who rejoyceth in his ≈øure and undoubted ≈øafety: but ≈øuddenly he was found for≈øaken by all, and to≈ø≈øed in a ≈ømall broken piece of a Ship. His friends ≈øtanding by, ≈øtirred him up, being bu≈øied with tho≈øe troubles and Images, ≈øhewing that Pompey was at hand. A fight therefore (in≈øtead of a bulwark) being begun, he was overcome. Far more then ten thou≈øand were ≈ølain, and the Camps were taken; Mithridates him≈øelf with a draught of eight hundred Hor≈øemen with him brake through the Romans. By and by the re≈øt ≈øliding away, he is left alone with three, among whom was the Harlot Hip≈øicratia, who had alway been of a manly boldne≈ø≈øe: Wherefore the King called her Hi≈øpicratia. But then ≈øhe being cloathed with a man's Per≈øian garment, and carried on a Hor≈øe, neither ≈øeemed ≈øhe to be weary in body from the tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the flight, neither the Kings body and hor≈øe being taken care of, was he tired untill they came unto the Towre or Ca≈øtle Inor, where the Kings Money and Trea≈øures were heaped up. Thence Mithridates took his pretious ≈øtones, which he di≈øtributed unto tho≈øe that a≈ø≈øembled unto him out of the flight. Moreover he gave a deadly poy≈øon to a certain friend of his to be carried with him, le≈øt any one ≈øhould come into the enemies hands. From thence he ≈øtrives to go into Armenia to Tigranes. Which thing, when he forbade him, and had pronounced a hundred talents on his head, the Springs of Euphrates being pa≈ø≈øed by, he bends his flight through Colchis. Plutarch in Pompey.

BEfore the Phar≈øalian fight, it ≈øeemed to Cn. Pompey by night in his ≈øleep, he entering into the Theatre, the people to applaud him; and that he adorned the Temple of Venus the Conquere≈ø≈øe with many ≈øpoils. This ≈øight partly rai≈øed him up, partly made him carefull, fearing ≈øomewhat, lea≈øt Grace and famou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øhould come from him unto Cae≈øars family chanting on Venus, and ≈øome Panick fears awakened him out of ≈øleep: In the fourth watch over Cae≈øars Camps, where all things were quiet, a great light ≈øhined out. A flaming Torch kindled thereby, was brought into Pompey's Camps. Cae≈øar him≈øelf ≈øaid he ≈øaw this, while he went about the Watches. The ≈øame Author, in the ≈øame place.

HEcuba being great with young, ≈øhe ≈øeemed to bring forth a burning Torch, which burned A≈øia and Europe. She not long after brought forth Paris, by who≈øe uncha≈øt loves, the country of Troy being de≈øtroyed, their forces being wa≈øted, Greece was con≈øumed by a long war, and undone. Sabellicus, book 1. ch. 1. Volatteran. book 18. Anthropol.

CAmby≈øes King of Per≈øians, ≈øaw Smerdes (in his ≈øleep) ≈øitting in the Kings Throne, to touch the Heaven with his Crown. He for that thing, fearing le≈øt his Brother Smerdes ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the kingdome; ≈øent Prexa≈øpes to kill him. Neither yet could he avoid even this by his brother-killing Murther; whereby Smerdes the Magitian, who feigned him≈øelf to be the true Smerdes Son of Cyrus, ≈øhould the le≈ø≈øe invade the Kingdome. Camby≈øes going up to hor≈øe, being wounded in the Thigh with a Sword, died. Herodotus, Book 3.

DArius had moved out of Su≈øa again≈øt Alexander, being ≈øupported with a multitude of Armies (for he had ≈øix hundred thou≈øand Souldiers under his En≈øigns) tru≈øting to a certain dream, the which (the Magitians flattering him) had interpreted more than according to the likene≈ø≈øe of truth. The troop of the Macedonians ≈øeemed to ≈øhine together with a great brightne≈ø≈øe of fire. But Alexander to wait on him in the habit wherewith he had been cloathed, when he was [A≈øcandes] that is, a Me≈ø≈øenger, or [A≈øcantes] that is Chamberlain to the King: And when he had entred into the Temple of Belus, to have been withdrawn from before his eyes. By the≈øe things (in my opinion) God fore≈øhewed that the Macedonians were to carry on honourable and famous matters, and Alexander to obtain A≈øia; as Darius had enjoyed it, being of a Me≈ø≈øenger or Chamberlain, made King, but in a ≈øhort time to lay down his life with his glory. Plutarch. in Alexander. Curtius hath delivered, that the King imagined the Camps to ≈øhine with a great brightne≈ø≈øe. Sabellicus, Book 4. Ennead. 4.

THey report, Domitian to have dreamed that a bunch ≈øprang out from him behind a Golden neck; and to have had it for certain, that a more ble≈ø≈øed and joyfull condition of the Commonwealth was fore≈øhewn to be after him. As indeed it ≈øo fell out in a ≈øhort time, through the ab≈øtinence and moderation of following Princes. Sueton.

EZeline, ≈øurnamed Monk, a bloudy and mo≈øt cruel Tyrant, at his re≈øt ≈øaw the fortune of his ≈øons, that night in which he fir≈øt came together with his wife, who was by name Adela, a Tu≈øcian, of the ≈øtock of the ancient Earls of Montaion. For he ≈øeemed to him≈øelf to ≈øee a little hill, in which a Roman Town was (in the Patavine field) placed (the which he commanded, and was thence called Romanus or a Roman) ≈øo to be carried up and exalted, that it touched heaven with its top, and the ≈øame a little after, to be melted as Snow, and ≈øo to be let down, that it could no more ≈øtand up. The chances of his ≈øons brought this effect: For the elder Son, and he Ezeline by name, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the rule of Verona, Patavium, Vincentia, Feltrium, and Cividal, and Marchia. But the younger, Alberick, entred on the Kingdom of Tarvi≈øium, and other places. But afterwards, fortune changing, in the two hundred fifty and ≈øixth year, above the thou≈øandth of ≈øalvation, when as the Pope and the Guelphians together, had moved war again≈øt Ezeline his ≈øon, he lo≈øt Patavium, with the whole land. But when he tru≈øted that he ≈øhould po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the City of Mediolum by craft, and for that thing had pa≈ø≈øed over the River Abdua, being be≈øieged by his enemies, overcome in battell, a wound being received, being taken nigh to Soncinum, in that very ≈øame place he died, and was buried. His brother Alberick being ≈øtrucken with fear by this chance, when as he di≈øtru≈øted that he could keep Tarvi≈øium, he betook him≈øelf into the Ca≈øtle of Saint Zeno. Where, in the year of Salvation, 1200. being betrayed by his own Souldiers, he came into the power of his enemies. There having beheld ≈øix ≈øons to be killed before him, and his wife Margaret with two young maids to be burnt, he him≈øelf being cut through all his limbs by piece-meal, he ≈øaw (as his father had in his dreams) his Roman ≈øtock, or nation, to be ended. Fulgo≈øus, book 1. chap. 5.

THe Mother of Phalaris ≈øaw Mercury (who≈øe Image holding a goblet in his hand, ≈øhe wor≈øhipped at her own hou≈øe, among the ≈øhapes of gods) in her dreams to ≈øprinkle bloud on the ground out of that goblet, and being da≈øhed on the pavement, to bubble back, untill by little and little it overflowed all the hou≈øe up to the top. That which was ≈øeen in one, the bloudy cruelty of her ≈øon made true in many hou≈øes. Ponticus Heraclidus is the Author of this Vi≈øion, a learned man, as ≈øaith Tully, and Scholler of Plato. Petrarcha.

AMilcar Captain of the Carthaginians, be≈øieging Syracu≈øa, ≈øeemed to hear in his ≈øleep, that the next day after he ≈øhould ≈øup within the walls of the be≈øieged City. By that thing being turned to a hope of Conque≈øt, he being chearfull, ≈øet the Army in order in the morning to be≈øiege the City. Unto him con≈øidering and attempting ≈øuch enterpri≈øes, as often comes to pa≈ø≈øe, a great uproar aro≈øe in the Camps, the Carthagenians and Sicilians di≈øagreeing among them≈øelves. The Towne≈ø-men laying hold of the occa≈øion, come ≈øuddenly forth of the Gates, and their enemies being ≈øcattered, the Conquerours take their Captain, de≈øiring to ≈øuccour their ranks being di≈øturbed, and therefore neglecting him≈øelf. And ≈øo being brought into the City, ≈øupping in fetters, he under≈øtood what a fal≈øe expounder of the dream he had been. Valer. Max. Book 1. chap. 7. and Cicero, Book 1. Of Divination. Artemidore writeth, a ≈øhew was pre≈øented to a certain one in his ≈øleep, as that he ≈øhould ≈øup with Saturn; and it ≈øo happened, that the day following, he was ca≈øt into Pri≈øon. Caelius, Book 13. chap. 21. Of Book of Antiq.

JUpiter commanded T. Latinus, a man of the common people, in his ≈øleep, that he ≈øhould tell the Con≈øulls that he was not plea≈øed with the neighbouring Circean playes, of the leaders of the dance, which thing, unle≈ø≈øe being heeded, it were ≈øatisfied by the renewing of ≈øports, no ≈ømall danger of the City was to follow. He fearing lea≈øt with ≈øome di≈øprofit unto his Religion, he ≈øhould extoll the highe≈øt command, kept ≈øilence. And ≈øtraightway his Son, being taken with the ≈øudden force of a di≈øea≈øe, died. He al≈øo at the time of ≈øleep, being asked by the ≈øame, whether he had ≈øufficiently weighed the great puni≈øhment of his royall command neglected, continuing in his purpo≈øe, was recompenced with a weakne≈ø≈øe of his body. And then at length by the coun≈øell of his friends, being brought in a hor≈øe-litter, unto the Con≈øuls Judgment-≈øeat, and from thence to the Senate, the order of his whole chance being explained, with the great admiration of all, the ≈øtrength of his members being recovered, he returned home on his feet. Valerius, in book 1. chap. 7. Cicero, in book 1. Of Divination. And Livy, book 2. Decad. 1.

THe Tartars inhabit beyond the Mountain Belgia, the Sea lying between. Changius, or their fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt Emperour, ≈øaw again a white hor≈øeman, who had foretold unto him the Empire, in his ≈øleep, that it was the will of the immortal god, That in the Mountain Belgia being pa≈ø≈øed over, they ≈øhould go forward into the We≈øt, and ≈øubdue all Kingdoms. But as ≈øoon as they had come to the Mountain Belgia, in that part which the Sea floweth on the Mountain, that they ≈øhould go down, and their faces being turned toward the Ea≈øt, they with nine bowings of the knee, wor≈øhip the
immortal God. Changius obeyed, and all his people being led out, he compelled them to continue all night in prayers. The morning being come, he ≈øaw the Sea to have went back from the Mountain, nine feet, and on that ≈øide he led his whole Army on dry ground thorow the wa≈øte wilderne≈ø≈øes into A≈øia. Haithon the Armenian in his book of the Tartars.

HAnnibal, Captain of the Carthaginians, had decreed to carry away a golden pillar, being found in the Temple of Juno Lucina. But being not ≈øure, whether it was of ≈øound gold, or whether it was gilded with gold nigh the ≈øuperficies, by ≈øolemnizing an a≈ø≈øembly, he tryed it, and being made ≈øure, that it was all of gold, he was confirmed in his purpo≈øe of ≈ønatching it away; unto whom the ≈øhape of Juno ≈øeemed to be pre≈øent, while he dreamed: ≈øhe admoni≈øhed him, that he ≈øhould ab≈øtain from covetous and ≈øacrilegious enterprizes; threatening, if he proceeded, that ≈øhe would deprive him of one eye wherewith he ≈øhould ≈øee the ground, or the Sun; with which ≈øleep, the Captain otherwi≈øe cruell, and who feared no god, there was no Religion, as was written of him, yet it is delivered, being moved, he daring to move nothing out of the place of that very gold, which had fallen out of a hole while he tryed it, he took care to have a warlike Engine made, and to be placed on the top of the pillar. Petrarcha.

VAlens, Emperour, in his ≈øleep, ≈øaw a certain man, ≈øaying the≈øe words unto him;
Be gone with ha≈øte unto great Mimas: thee the grievous force
Of de≈øtiny, dreading thy ≈øelf, ≈øhall from thy life divorce.
He being awakened out of ≈øleep, asked the ≈øtanders by, What place was called Mimas? And when at length, a certain one of the Grammarians or Oratours, who follow the Kings Court, had ≈øaid, Mimas was a Mountain of A≈øia, of which Homer had made mention in his Uly≈øses: And to aiery Mimas. The Emperour laughing, an≈øwered, What nece≈ø≈øity enforceth me of ≈øeeing this place, and ≈øeeking a lot? But when, fighting again≈øt the Alanians, the Emperour was burnt in a little cottage about Adranopolis of Thracia, the Barbarians departing from thence, ≈øome Souldiers of Valens diligently ≈øearched out his dead carca≈øs. In that cottage where he peri≈øhed, was found an old grave of a certain ancient man, with this In≈øcription, Mimas a Governour of the Macedonians, was here laid. Therefore that dream of Valens was fulfilled. Cu≈øpinian.

THat which was once ≈øet before Julius Cae≈øar in his ≈øleep, before that he had moved into neather France, and brought offen≈øive weapons on the City, when at his re≈øt, it ≈øeemed to him, he ravi≈øhed
his mother: By which dream, the expounders ≈øtirred him up unto a mo≈øt large hope, having interpreted, That the rule of the world ≈øhould be given him. The ≈øame dream they mention, was offered to Hippias, ≈øon of Pi≈øi≈øtratus, with no unlike i≈ø≈øue, who being his ≈øucceeder in tyranny, u≈øed his Countrey more cruelly. For a night re≈øemblance of his Mother, with whom he ≈øeemed to copulate, is ≈øaid to be ≈øet before him at the time of ≈øleep; for which thing the Interpreters an≈øwered, That rule was largely betokened unto him. And he being put in mind by his dream, and full of hope, not long after he enjoyed the dominion of Athens. For this is that Hippias, who having attempted a tyrannical power, not without cruel wickedne≈ø≈øe, was more outragious and unbridled than his father, when as being a bani≈øhed man, he had changed his ≈øoyl, he moved wicked arms again≈øt his Countrey. At la≈øt con≈øpiring with Darius, being ≈ølain in the Marathonian fight, he yielded puni≈øhments to his Countrey and hou≈øhold ‚Ä¢ gods. But another ≈øon of the ≈øame Pi≈øi≈øtratus, Hipparch, who exceeded the cruelty of many Tyrants, when as he oppre≈ø≈øed his Country and Citizens with a cruel Lordline≈ø≈øe, a con≈øpiracy being made again≈øt the life of the Tyrant, he was, by Armodius and Ari≈øtogiton, mo≈øt valiant young men, not without the ≈øafety of all, ≈ølain: who≈øe names being devoted to freedom, le≈øt at any time it ≈øhould be lawfull to in≈øtitute ≈øervants, the Athenians e≈øtabli≈øhed with an open abhorrency. Alexander, book 3. chap. 26.

SAbacus, King of Aethiopians, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Kingdom of Aegypt fifty years, which being fini≈øhed, the god, which is wor≈øhipped at Thebes, was ≈øeen to ≈øay unto him, His reign over the Egyptians ≈øhould not be happy, nor of long continuance, unle≈øs, the Prie≈øts of Egypt being all ≈ølain, he ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe thorow the mid≈øt of their dead carca≈ø≈øes with his. This dream being often ≈øet before him, he called together all the Prie≈øts on every ≈øide, and what things he had received through the dream being told them: He would not, he ≈øaith, build a remaining de≈øtruction for any one in Egypt, but had rather ab≈øtain from the Kingdom of Egypt, being pure and free of all wickedne≈øs. Diodore the Sicilian, & Herodotus, book 3.

SEthon, King of Aegypt, Prie≈øt of Vulcan, when as he de≈øpi≈øed the Egyptians, he made u≈øe of a forreign Souldier, and ≈øtripped the Egyptians of their fields. For this wrong, it came to pa≈øs, that after Sennacherib King of Arabians and A≈øsyrians had invaded Egypt with a great Army, the Egyptians would not help him. Then the chief Prie≈øt, void of coun≈øel, betook him≈øelf into the Garret or Chamber of his Hou≈øe, and there bewailed before the Image, how much he was in danger. Therefore while he was lamenting, ≈øleep crept on him, and while he ≈ølept, the god ≈øeemed to ≈øtand by, exhorting him, that he was to ≈øuffer no hurtfull thing, if he went to meet the Army of the Arabians, for he would ≈øend him helpers.
The Prie≈øt tru≈øting to the≈øe dreams, tho≈øe that were willing of the Aegyptians being taken, Merchants, or Factors, and handycraftsmen or labourers, he pitched his Tents in Pelu≈øium; for, in this, is the Aegyptian invaded. When he had come thither, in the night, a great multitude of field-Mice ≈øuddenly ari≈øing, gnawed a≈øunder both the quivers, bowes, and al≈øo the rains of the bucklers in the Camps of their enemies; ≈øo that the next day, the enemies being naked of weapons, made flight, many being lo≈øt. And now in that Temple of Vulcan, the King ≈øtands in ≈øtone, holding a mou≈øe in his hand, and by letters ≈øaying the≈øe words; Who ≈øo looketh on me, let him be godly. Herodotus, book 2.

div.head: Of Miracles of Devils, or of divers deceits and mocks of evil Daemons, to ≈øtrengthen the Idolatry of the Gentiles.
div.p: THe power of Vesta warranted (the fire being gone out) a woman Schollar of the Virgin Aemilia, to be ≈øafe from all blame, who wor≈øhipping, when ≈øhe had laid a Cyprus garment (the which ≈øhe had a very good one) on the hearth, the fire ≈øuddenly ≈øhone out. Valerius, book 1. chap. 1.

THey ≈øay, Aeneas to have placed hou≈øhold-gods brought from Troy, at Lavinium; thence being brought over to Alba, by his ≈øon A≈øcanius, the which he had built, to have returned again to the ancient Chappel: and becau≈øe that might be thought to be done by man's hand, being brought back again to Alba, to have ≈øignified his will by another pa≈ø≈øage. Valer. Max. book 1. chap. 8.

NOt onely the Aegyptians, but almo≈øt all the World anciently wor≈øhipped I≈øis for her Miracles: for this godde≈øs healed the di≈øea≈øes of tho≈øe that were not well in health, in their ≈øleep; and they who did obey her coun≈øel, were cured beyond thought. Al≈øo tho≈øe that were weak in their ≈øight, or in other part of the body, humbly intreating the vertue of the godde≈øs, were re≈øtored unto their former health. Diodore Siculus, book 1. chap. 2. of Ancient Things.

IN the Temple of Ae≈øculapius among the Epidaurians, they who came to pray to the god, they ≈øleep; and in their ≈øleep, do learn the rea≈øon of recovering health. And then they put ≈øquares in the Temple, containing the names of tho≈øe that were cured, and the manner of curing. Pau≈øanias, in his Corinthian affairs. There was the ≈øame cu≈øtome among the Romans, even to the Times of the Antonines, that which we may under≈øtand from a Marble Table of Rome found in the Temple of Ae≈øculapius in the I≈øland Tiberia, and by the Mapheans kept even to this day, in which the≈øe words are read, rendred out of Greek in the Latine ≈øpeech, as witne≈ø≈øeth Jer. Mercurial, a mo≈øt Learned Phy≈øitian, in his fir≈øt book of exerci≈øe. In the≈øe dayes the Oracle told Caius, a certain blind man, that he ≈øhould come to the holy Altar, and ≈øhould bend his knees; he ≈øhould come from the right part to the left, and ≈øhould place

Which by chance was to the unknown God, upon which occa≈øion, Saint Paul began to Preach Chri≈øt to the Athenians. Laertius.

THe Per≈øians being or'ecome and beat back to Platea a City in Boetia. Apollo an≈øwered the Grecians (con≈øulting about a ≈øacrifice) that they ≈øhould rear up an Altar to Jupiter the Liberatour and freer, but before they had ≈øolemnized the ceremonies, they appointed that all fire ≈øhould be extingui≈øhed through the whole Region which was polluted by the Barbarians, and that they ≈øhould kindle all their fires out of that pure fire on the common hearth at Delphos. Therefore by and by the Magi≈øtrates of the Grecians going all about, commanded all them that u≈øed any fire to extingui≈øh it. Euchidas of the Plataeen≈øians, promi≈øed that as ≈øwiftly as that could be done, that he would bring fire from the godde≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo he went to Delphos, and ≈øo purging his body by ≈øacrifice, and wa≈øhing it with water, being Crowned with Laurell, took fire from the Altar, and running backwards, went towards Plataeas, and before the ≈øetting of the Sun, returned, and in that very ≈øame day mea≈øured and travelled a thou≈øand pa ‚Ä¢ es, ≈øo the Citizens were ≈øaved, unto whom he delivered the fire, but he quickly
fainted, and a while after died: the Plataeen≈øians did bury him in the Temple dedicated to Diana at Euclia, and did ≈øuper≈øcribe this Tetrameter Ver≈øe.

lg.l: Euchidas Delphos cucurrit, et die rever≈øus uno e≈øt.
Euchidas unto Delphos one day run,
Return'd again ereth' ≈øetting of the Sun. Plutarchus, in Ari≈øtide.

div.p: IT is reported that Hercules the ≈øon of Alcmena, offering ≈øacrifice to Jupiter in Olympia, when he could not drive away the flies, it is ≈øaid that the Elii called the driver away of them „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and did do ≈øacrifice to him, and when the ≈øacrifice was offered, on a ≈øudden all the flies flew beyond the River Alpheus. Therefore was it re≈øerved and kept by the Eleans to drive away flies from Olympia, and the ≈øame ceremony was u≈øed. Pau≈øanias, lib. 5.

AUrelian the Emperour, when he came again≈øt the Marcomannians unto Mediolanum a Town in Italy, he writ to the Senate that they ≈øhould look into the Sybillaean books, what rites were nece≈ø≈øary to crave the help of their gods. Which when the Senate had done ≈øo, and had it revealed by a divine revelation more then by any humane ≈øtrength or coun≈øels, the Barbarians dur≈øt not go beyond their prefixed limits, affrighted by ≈øuch terrible ≈øights and Wonders, and ≈øo a clear path was laid open for Aurelians Victory. But he, lea≈øt that he might not ≈øeem ungratefull not to acknowledge his help from Heaven be≈øides the great rewards of this Victory, and Thank≈ø-giving being given through the whole City of Rome, he gave fifteen Millions of the weight of Gold, and a great trea≈øure of Pearls, for a remembrance thereof. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 1.

THe Per≈øians commanding A≈øia when they had ≈øpoiled and ran≈øack't all the Holy places and Temples of the Greeks excepting the Temple of Semidea Rhea which was in Ca≈øtamus Cherrone≈øus, neither fortified with Walls nor Watches, and left it unviolated, the plundering Robbers pilling and poling all places, and this was that place which was onely left unwalled, and that might of all other been taken without danger, they report the cau≈øe to be this; the univer≈øall beneficence towards all men, for ≈øhe did teach and in≈øtruct the ≈øick in Dreams, the cure of their di≈øea≈øes, and did recover very many that were de≈øperately ≈øick. Furthermore, tho≈øe Women that were in Travell, ≈øhe delivered them from the perill of Child-birth. Diodorus, lib. 5. cap. 17.

WIthout Crotonis anciently there was a Temple dedicated to Juno Licinia and was very ≈øtrict and hallowed with many Religious ceremonies, and where was a Grove that was hedged about with high Firre-Trees: in the Center and middle thereof there was a feeding place, a gra≈ø≈øe-plot where all kind of Cattle was fed, which was ≈øacrificed to the godde≈ø≈øe, and had no keeper, the flocks overnight would ≈øtear them≈øelves of their own accord to their Stables, being no wayes lyable either to the injury of men or bea≈øts, there was a great wonder and miracle related of an Altar there which was in the day time, never was there any a≈øhes blown away by the violence of the Winds. Sabellicus, lib. 3. Ennead. 5.

A Great barrenne≈ø≈øe comming upon the grounds of Pela≈øgus, they devoted the ≈øpring to their gods, being able to perform their vowes, they neglected to perform it, therefore being exagitated and vexed with a grievous pe≈øtilence, and enquiring of their Oracle, the cau≈øe of that evill, the Oracle an≈øwered, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that having what≈øoever they would, they have not given that which they promi≈øed, therefore to pacify the Deity, they were to pay the tenths. Diony≈ø. Halicar. lib. 1. Eu≈øeb. lib. 4. praeparat. Evangelicae.

THey report that in Italy the Rock of the Po≈øidoniacorians there was ≈øuch a miracle u≈øed: for there was a hunter in that Countrey which is called Andragathia; he was wont to dedicate the heads and feet of tho≈øe things, which he had killed to Diana, and affix them to the Trees, and when he had taken a great Boar in contempt of the godde≈ø≈øe, he ≈øaid, he would onely offer the head of it to her, and tying it to a certain Tree, one day when he turned a little out of the way, to ≈øhroud him≈øelf from the heat of the Sun being then Noon-tide, he ≈ølept under that tree, under which he had tyed the head of it, and fell a≈øleep; then did the garter di≈ø≈øolve and untye of it ≈øelf, and the head of the Boar fell upon his head ≈øo that he dyed. Diodorus, lib. 4. cap. 3.

OEneus the King of Calydonia, there being a great plenty of all Kind of grain in Oetolia, and when he had ≈øacrificed to other gods, onely Diana excepted, the godde≈ø≈øe being angry, ≈øent a Calydonian Boor of a great bigne≈ø≈øe, to de≈øtroy the neighbouring Region thereabout: and Meleager to ≈øtay this, being in full ≈øtrength, taking many con≈øorts with her, killed the Boar, and ≈øo by the con≈øent of all, ≈øhe obtained the reward of the ≈ølain bea≈øt, that was, the skin of the Boor. And when in a hunting time he was with Atalanta, the daughter of Schaenei, being much enamoured of her did concede and grant to her that skin, which was his reward for killing that wild bea≈øt. Which being done, and Thestes ≈øons being Hunters together with him, taking it very ill to prefer a ≈øtranger
Woman before them, and di≈øapproving Meleagrus's fact, they by their traps and ambu≈øhes, took the skin from Atalanta, when ≈øhe ≈øhould return into Arcadia; then Meleager, as well agitated by love, as exagitated and excited by ignominy, at fir≈øt he admoni≈øhed tho≈øe robbers that they ≈øhould re≈øtore the reward of Vertue which was given to that Woman by him, but they, contemning his words, he ≈ølew them all, for they were the Brethren of Althea: but ≈øhe being much grieved for their ≈ølaughter, execrated and cur≈øed Meleager, and beg'd of the immortal gods, who had heard her prayers, that they would put an end to the life of her Son. ≈øome ≈øay that in Meleagers birth, the de≈øtinies appeared to Al ‚Ä¢ hea in a dream by night, and ≈øaid, then ≈øhould the life of her Son Meleager be expired, when that wood (which was a quenched charcolled firebrand) was burned out: the child being born, Althea thinking that by ≈øaving that Wood, ≈øhe ≈øhould al≈øo ≈øave the life of her Child, ≈øhe diligently re≈øerved and kept it. Afterwards being grievou≈øly tormented, and vexed by the death of her Brethren, ≈øhe burned the fireband, and then the cau≈øe of her ≈øons death came to light, and repenting her of the fact, ≈øhe hanged her ≈øelf. Diodorus, lib. 4. cap. 2.

STymphalus a River in Arcadia, maketh a great Lake or Gulph, and percollating, and being filtred through the Veins of the Earth, in≈øinuates it ≈øelf at length into the Argolick field, and there its name is changed; for Stymphalus 'tis called Era≈øinus in the dayes of Pau≈øanias: this miracle happened, when a ≈øolemn rite was very cur≈øorily performed by the Arcadians to the Stymphalian Diana; and in the fir≈øt place the rites, for their countrey being Pretermitted, incontinently the Grove fell upon that cavern, under which the River Stymphalus did drain and ≈øweat through the Earth's pores, therefore the mouth of the pa≈ø≈øage (by rea≈øon of the interveining rubbi≈øh) being dam'd up, and the water making a reflux and flowing retrogradely, the water did ≈øpread and expand it ≈øelf over all the adjacent fields no le≈ø≈øe then 400. paces, and made a great pool or Gulph. And ≈øo by chance it happened that a hunter cha≈øing his Hart, when ≈øhe had ≈øtuck her ≈øelf in the dirt of the fen, being chafed with grief of mind, ≈øwam through the water, and he had not left off the pur≈øuit after her, ere a great cha≈øma or Gulph both ≈øwallowed up him and the wild bea≈øt together (they report) that by and by the ≈øtanding water finding the channel of the River, and following it, ≈øo that the whole Lake was drunk and dryed up in one day, the ceremony being more preparedly and magnificently made to Diana. Pau≈øanias in Arcadicis.
GLaucus the ≈øon of Sy≈øiphus, who ruled at Potnia de≈øpi≈øing Venus's Rites, was torn in pieces by his Mares, which u≈øed to draw his Chariot. Servius, lib. 3. Georg.

HErcules did erect a magnificent Temple to Jolaus his Nephew, and in≈øtituted many hallowed rites to be con≈øecrated in it, and if the inhabitants ≈øhould be wanting at the accu≈øtomed ceremonies they quickly began to be made dumb, but when again they ≈øhould obey, they were to be re≈øtored to their former ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe. Alexandr. ab Alexandro lib. 2. cap. 14.

CYanippus Syracu≈øanus becau≈øe he had neglected to ≈øacrifice unto Bacchus; the god, being angred and provoked, made him run into ≈øuch drunkenne≈ø≈øe, that meeting his daughter Cyane in the dark, although ≈øhe re≈øi≈øted, he defloured her. But ≈øhe ≈ønatching a ring from her father that did ob≈øtuprate her, delivered it to her Nur≈øe, that it might be for a mark and ≈øign of him that violated her. But afterwards when a grievous pe≈øtilence did invade and come upon the City, for ≈øuch a hainous perpetrated wickedne≈ø≈øe, there was an Oracle given out by Pythias, that the Authour of that impiety ≈øhould be ≈øacrificed to the freeing and liberating-gods. Therefore Cyane being con≈øcious of the≈øe things, ≈ølew her father, haling him to the Altar by the hair of the head, that the gods might be pacified. Do≈øitheus, lib. 3. rerum Sicularum: et Plutarchus, cap. 39. Paral.

IN Phocis at the Tithorean Temple of I≈øis, for Religion, the holie≈øt of all them that ever the Grecians con≈øecrated to the Egyptian godde≈ø≈øe, for neither is there any inward acce≈ø≈øe into it by any, but to tho≈øe whom I≈øis in dreams ≈øeems to call to her, beloved afore the re≈øt: to this Tithorean I≈øis are two Fairs yearly celebrated in the Spring and in Autumn, the Merchants or Factors build them up Shops and Stalls of Reeds, and of any other matter that they can light on. At the la≈øt on the third day they that come to Merchandize there, buy ≈ølaves, but in the afternoons apply their minds to their devotions. They ≈øacrifice ≈øumptuous Oxen, and Harts, but Gee≈øe and Meleagrides, birds, more parcimoniou≈øly, &c. Sometimes they ≈øay, a man is prophane when the pile begins to be burned, that through curio≈øity and ≈øelf-confidence dare go into it. And to him if there ≈øhall ≈øeem all places filled full of Hobgoblins, and ≈øuch dome≈øticall homely ≈øpirits, notwith≈øtanding if he turn back to Tithorea, and relate all that which he hath ≈øeen, he quickly dieth. Pau≈øanias in Phocicis.

IT is found by experience that they who violate the Religion of the Cabirorians, the Thebanes cannot e≈øcape condign puni≈øhment for their unexpiable wickedne≈ø≈øe; for when the Naupacti a prophane Generation of men, dur≈øt u≈øurp tho≈øe things that were con≈øecrated by the Thebanes, not long after they paid for their fraudulent impiety. Al≈øo tho≈øe Per≈øians of Xerxes Army, when Mardonius was their Captain, having their fixed ≈øtation or ≈øtanding Camp in Baeotia, one part of which not doubting to enter into the Temple
of the Cabirorians, whether drawn thither by the de≈øire of a great prey, or out of the contempt of the Deity, all of them were ≈øtrucken with madne≈ø≈øe; part of them ca≈øt them≈øelves into the Sea, part of them precipitated them≈øelves from high rocks: and when Alexander in a battell had or'ecome the Thebanes, and did de≈øtroy and depopulate the City and fields with fire and Sword, tho≈øe of the Macedonians that broke into the ≈øacred Temple of the Cabirorians all of them either by lightnings or by fire ≈øent from Heaven, were ≈ølain; Such was the Religion of that Temple from the beginning. Pau≈øanias in Boeoticis.

PEntheus the King of the Thebanes when he had grieved Liber his father, and reviled him with many contumelious terms and other things, he did very in≈øolently, but at la≈øt that he might pry into tho≈øe hidden ≈øacrifices of Women, went to Cytheron, and climbed into a Tree, and from thence he ≈øaw all, which when the mad Prie≈øte≈ø≈øes of Bacchus ≈øaw with a great violence, they tore him being alive, in pieces, and pull'd limb from limb. They ≈øay, there was an Oracle given at Corinthus, that they ≈øhould make inqui≈øition for, and ≈øeek out that Tree, and the finders out thereof ≈øhould be wor≈øhipped with divine honours, therefore by the Item or inkling given by that Oracle, there was two wooden pictures found of his Father, Liber, put in the repo≈øitory of the Temple: be≈øides two mouthes which were anointed with red lead, they name the other Lyfius Bacchus. Pau≈øanias in Corinthiacis: Euripides writing of the daughters of Bacchis Cadmus, and their ≈øi≈øters the Simeles which brought up Diony≈øius, did mention one Pentheus, that each of them tugg'd away the parts of his body. Natales Comes Mythol. lib. 5. cap. 13.

WHen the Potitians had obtained the rites of the con≈øecrated things of Bacchus, which was a≈ø≈øigned for a gift to their nation by him, as an heritage, Appius Claudius the Cen≈øor being the Author of it, did transfer it to the ≈øervile≈øt ba≈øe≈øt office of their ≈øervants: therefore all that were above thirty years of age, Adulti, were ≈ølain and de≈øtroyed, and the name of the Potitians, divided into twelve Families, quickly was quite extinct. And Appius for his part was made blind. Valerius, lib. 1. cap. 2. Livius, lib. 2. Decad. 3.

C. Terentius Varro over≈øeer for the Temples, when he made Circes playes in the Temple of Jupiter, he put a boy of admirable beauty, a player, to keep the watches. Which being done after many years it was as well expiated, as remembred: for a great while after, being made Con≈øull, fighting at Cannus, he pro≈øpered ≈øo ill, that he almo≈øt lo≈øt fifty thou≈øand Romans that were ≈ølain. Valer. Max. lib. 1. cap. 2.

ANnibal and Himilco being two Carthagenian Captains, be≈øieging Agrigentum, commanded their Souldiers that they ≈øhould ca≈øt and throw down all the Sepulchres and Monuments, and ≈øo by that ruine draw and contract a great heap of rubbi≈øh and to bring it to the Wals; neither was the Army ≈ølow to execute this command, nor to bring this work to pa≈ø≈øe: but while≈øt they were digging there, a great reverence of Religion and awe of the gods began to ≈øeize on ≈øome of the minds of the Army. For the Tomb and Sepulchre of Thero, a Monument of great labour and labour and Art, ≈øhaken by lightning, trembled: which miracle being procured for ≈øome of their Prie≈øts, when they ≈øaw the multitude make ha≈øte to pull it down, laboured with all might and main, to ≈øtay and forbid it; and ≈øuddenly a pe≈øtilence invaded the Camp, which de≈øtroyed many, neither did it wre≈øt a few into divers afflictions and calamities in which Annibal the Captain him≈øelf dyed. As al≈øo tho≈øe that did watch by night, did think they ≈øaw ≈øpectrums and gho≈øts, and the ≈øhadows of them that were dead walking and wandring in ≈øhades. And Himilco gave over ≈øpoiling of the Monuments, and quickly performed his Rites to his gods, ≈øacrificed an Infant to Saturn, and drowned a whole company of Prie≈øts to appea≈øe Neptune. Diod. lib. 13.

ILus when he ≈øaw Minervaes Temple on fire, running in ha≈øte, took up Pallas's Image which fell from Heaven, and in≈øtantly he was ≈øtruck blind. A while after the wrath of the Godde≈ø≈øe being appea≈øed, he recovered his ≈øight again. Plutar. cap. 34. Paral.

PEga≈øus bearing the Images of Diony≈øius out of Eleutherae a City in Boetia into Athens, the Athenians did neglect their god, neither did they receive him (as the cu≈øtome was) with pomp. Wherefore their god was angry, and infected the privy members oft he men with a grievous di≈øea≈øe. And enquiring of the Oracle by what means they might be freed from this puni≈øhment, had this an≈øwer, that they ≈øhould receive their god with pomp and honour. And ≈øo from this they carried through the whole ≈øolemnities, pikes adorned with green leaves, as well publickly as privately. Natales Comes, lib. 5. cap. 13.

THe Captains of the Japigans did take out the Images of the gods out of the Temples, who boa≈øtingly ≈øaid it was fit that they ≈øhould give place to tho≈øe that are mo≈øt potent. And becau≈øe of that, they were ≈ømote with darts and fire from heaven. And there did appear Darts afar off, which were ≈øhot out of the Clouds. And all their children unto this day are ≈øhaven unto the skin, and wear long mourning Gowns, and are to all, more rare then good men. Athenaeus, lib. 12. cap. 7.

WHen the Aeginetae invaded the Epidaurians, and carryed away the Olive-tree Images of Damiae and Auxe≈øiae, by rea≈øon of which the Epidaurians yearly were con≈øtrained to bear the rites to Erictheus at Athens (for by that law they had granted the Epidaurians power of their Olive-trees) the Epidaurians refu≈øed to let go their bargain; Therefore the Athenians ≈øent a Cart into Aegina to fetch back the Statues, that they might bring the Images as though they had been made of their wood, therefore they endeavoured with might and main, and ropes ca≈øt about, to draw the Statues into their Ships. But as they drew them, the Images fell on their knees, and from that time they alwaies remained in that po≈øture. Moreover, when there was a great Thunder and Earthquake, the Rowers were made mad, and wounded one another grievou≈øly, and ≈ølew all, ≈øave one that was the Me≈ø≈øenger of this ≈ølaughter, who betook him≈øelf to Phalerus. Herodotus, Libro 5.

ARtabarus a Per≈øian, the ≈øon of Pharnax who had a comi≈ø≈øion from Mardonius, for the Circuit of 60. miles, when he ru≈øhed into Neptunes Temple, and wickedly and irreligiou≈øly upon his Image, in the ≈øiege of the City he was much troubled with the flux of the Sea, and being con≈øtrained to rai≈øe his ≈øiege, when he with his Army retreated into Pallenes, he lo≈øt a great part of it by the overflowing Tides of the Sea. Herodot. lib. 8.

PUb. Scipio Africanus Minor, when he had granted leave to his Souldiers to take Carthage, a certain Souldier going into the Temple of Apollo, did attempt to bereave the Image of the Golden Ve≈øtment: for which thing Apollo being angry, cau≈øed that tho≈øe ≈øacrilegious hands ≈øhould be found cut off, among tho≈øe fragments of the Clothes and the skirts of the Trunk or body of the Image. Valer. Max. lib. 1. cap. 2.

THe Grecians convented and met together in Aulis being to ≈øail to Troy. Agamemnon going a pretty way from the Army, ≈øeeing a ≈øhe-Goat about Dianaes Grove (ignorant of Religion) which was in that place, ≈ømote it with a Dart, not long after Diana being angry, ≈øent the Pe≈øtilence into his Army, a certain Religious Woman affirmed that Diana was vexed for the death of her ≈øhe-Goat, in which ≈øhe much delighted, and that ≈øhe would have puni≈øhment of the Army for ≈øuch a ≈øacrilegious fact, and that ≈øhe could not be appea≈øed before he that was the Authour of this wickedne≈ø≈øe, did ≈øacrifice his elde≈øt daughter, &c. Dictis, lib. 1.

PAncrates Arcadicus, in in≈øcriptis Marinis operibus, declares the fi≈øh Pompilus, called al≈øo Nautillus, is not onely in e≈øteem with Neptune, but with all the gods in Samothrace. When the Golden kind of men as yet lived, Epopaeus, of the Icarian I≈øland, fi≈øhing together with his ≈øon, and ≈øeeing that he could catch no other fi≈øh but Pompills, he did not refrain from eating them, but he with his ≈øon did eat them all. But ≈øhortly after he ≈øuffered for his villany. For a Whale coming to the Ship, ≈øwallowed up Epopaeus in the ≈øight of his ≈øon. Moreover Pancrates doth relate, that the Pompilus is an enemy to the Dolphin, and that they let the Mechi go Scot-free when they have eaten a Pompill, for they become unprofitable; and being troubled after they have eaten them, the water ca≈øteth them on the ≈øhore, where they are food for Cormorants and Gnats. Athaeneus, lib. 7. cap. 7.

THey ≈øay that a certain man hid a piece of holy Money which he ≈øtole out of the Temple of Apollo at Delphos, in that part of Parna≈øsus, which is ≈øhadowed mo≈øt with Woods and Trees. But a Wolf violently killed him ≈øleeping, and afterwards every day, he did make the City re≈øound with his howlings. When the men of Delphos began to think that it could not be done without ≈øome divine providence, following the bea≈øt, they found the Gold which was taken away by ≈øacriledge, and for the memory of the thing, they dedicated a Brazen Wolf to Apollo. Pau≈øanias, lib. 10.

SAmbicus a certain man of Eleus (a City of Thrace) together with ≈øome other of his companions, threw down many Brazen Statues, and ≈øold them. Afterwards attempting greater things, he ≈øpoiled the Temple of Diana their Guardian. For her Temple was in Elis (a City of Achaia) which they called the Temple of Aristarchus. But he being apprehended pre≈øently after, when he refu≈øed to betray his companions, he was torn with new devi≈øed torments, among≈øt which he lo≈øt his life. Plutarch. in problemat. Graec.

PHilomelus, who fir≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Temple of Apollo at Phocis re≈øtrained his hand from the holy things, which nece≈ø≈øity did permit him to take. But Onomarchus which ≈øucceeded him, ≈øpent much of the Money in War. Phyallus the third, the brother of Onomarchus, took away a great number of the gifts which were con≈øecrated in the Temple; to coyn Money, to pay his hired ≈øouldiers‚ñ™ And truly having received 120. Golden bucklers dedicated by Cae≈øar King of the Lydians, which weighed two Talents, he ca≈øt them a≈øide to make money, and likewi≈øe three hundred and ≈øixty Golden Cups, which weighed twenty pounds, and the Golden Images of a Lion and a woman, ≈øo that all tho≈øe things were valued at thirty Talents of Gold, and all tho≈øe things which were coyned
of the Gold, according to the account of Silver, did amount to four thou≈øand Talents. But all the Captains did ≈øpend the ≈øumme of above ≈øix thou≈øand Talents out of ≈øilver things, which were con≈øecrated as well by Croe≈øus, as others: that if the whole value of the Gold and ≈øilver were accounted, it would amount to more then 10000. Talents. But all the≈øe were heavily puni≈øhed for their impiety and contempt of the Deity. For Philomelus fighting again≈øt the Boeotians, the revengers of ≈øacriledge, being wounded in many places, was ≈øhut into a certain ≈øleep place, whence he could not ea≈øily get out (a puni≈øhment which ≈øometimes was wont to be inflicted on Captives); he being afraid, ca≈øt him≈øelf headlong thence, and in the ≈øame manner, paying a due puni≈øhment to the Deity, he died. Diodorus, lib. 16. Onomarchus having his Army vanqui≈øhed by Philip the ≈øon of Amyntas, ≈øwimming to the ≈øhips which were bound for the Athenian ≈øhore, died in the Sea. Phyallus was con≈øumed with a perpetuall contagion. But Phalecus which after all them took away what≈øoever was left of the gifts, lived long enough in fear, and divers great dangers, not that his fortune might be thereby better then the other companions of the wicked mi≈øchief, but that being tormented for a longer time, and made more known to many by his mi≈øery, he might undergo a more famous and much mentioned calamity. Being to≈ø≈øed about with very much wandring, when he did re≈øi≈øt Cidonia in Creet, he was ≈øtricken dead by thunder.

Q. Fulvius Flaccus did not e≈øcape unpuni≈øhed, becau≈øe he carried the Marble tiles that were to mend the Temple of Juno at Lacinium, to the Temple of warlike fortune, which he made at Rome. WHen the Per≈øians, under the conduct of Xerxes, came to the mo≈øt famous Temple at Delphos with an intent to ≈øpoil it, great miraculous things were pre≈øented to their ≈øight. WHen Delos was heretofore the chief Emporium of all Greece and that onely fenced with Religion, it defended all the inhabitants from the injuries of all others. WHen Cytharoedes did di≈øpute in contending for the honour of Juno at Sybarum, for that was the cau≈øe that provoked the Sybaritans to that contentious di≈øputation, and when they had mutually gone to arms, Cytharoedes fled with his Stole to the Altar of Juno: but they forbore not to lay violent hands upon him in that place, but a little after they ≈øaw bloud ≈øprinkled about the Temple, as if it had i≈ø≈øued out of a continually-flowing Fountain. Ju≈øtly will heaped vengeance ≈øend to bear,

POllux Onomastici libro 5. writeth that among≈øt the Athenians,

PHale≈øius a private man builded the Temple of Ae≈øculapius at Naupactum from the foundation. AMa≈øis King of the Aegyptians, married a Wife, (which ≈øome would have to be the daughter of Battus, the ≈øon of Arche≈øilaus: others, of Critobulus, a very honourable man among≈øt his people) by name Ladices, with whom when he lay in bed, he could not perform his marriage duty, as when he made u≈øe of other women. Strabo, lib. 14.

EPidaurus a City of Pelopone≈øus, being ennobled by the famou≈øne≈ø≈øe of Ae≈øculapius, who (as the ancients write) hath cured divers kinds of di≈øea≈øes. But the Temple was filled with a multitude of ≈øick people, and Tables hanging up, in which the di≈øea≈øes that were cured were written. In the ≈øame manner it was in the I≈øland Coa, and likewi≈øe in Trica. The City was ≈øcituated in the innermo≈øt Clo≈øet of the bo≈øome of Saronicus. Strabo, lib. 8. The ≈øame Strabo writeth that there was a famous Temple of Ae≈øculapius at Tetrapolis, which City was inhabited by the Jonians and Carians. That Temple was full of an innumerable convention of ≈øick people, troubled with divers di≈øea≈øes, and the walls were every where covered with painted Tables, wherein were written the di≈øea≈øes and names of them which were cured by that god.

THey record that there is a Temple of Minerva Ilias, in which Dogs are nouri≈øhed, to whom it is given naturally, as al≈øo by ≈øome certain knowledge, to fawn upon the Graecians when they come, but follow the Barbarians with barking where≈øoever they ≈øhew them≈øelves. Coelius, lib. 23. cap. 30. Antiq. lect.

THere is a round Temple of Hercules of admirable ≈øtructure in the bea≈øt-market of Rome, into which (they relate) neither Dogs nor flyes can enter. As no bird can enter into the Temple of Achill ‚Ä¢ s before Borysthenes. Alexander ab Alexand. lib. 2. cap. 14.

THere was a Temple of Pallas at Methon, a City of Peloponne≈øus, Diomedes dedicating an Image, becau≈øe before that, he received damage by mo≈øt violent Winds in tho≈øe parts, blowing very un≈øea≈øonably, which pre≈øently after cea≈øed, when they prayed to the godde≈ø≈øe, and afterwards no ≈øuch calamity came upon the Inhabitants. From whence ≈øhe got the name Minerva. Coelius, lib. 20. cap. 24. Antiq. lect.

WHen Greece was troubled with a continuall drought, and the re≈øt of Greece was no le≈ø≈øe di≈øtracted for want of rain, which was without Isthmus, than all Peloponne≈øus; they ≈øent to Delphos, that they might know by the Oracle the cau≈øe and remedy of the calamity. There Pythia an≈øwered, that they mu≈øt appea≈øe Jupiter, but they mu≈øt make u≈øe of Aeacus to ≈øue for them, ≈øo that he is willing to obey. Therefore when they had received that an≈øwer, they ≈øent out of every City, to entreat Aeacus to undertake the entreaty. He, having fini≈øhed the ≈øacrifices to Jupiter, and offered the vows, repleni≈øhed all Greece with abundance of rain. For the memory of the thing, the Citizens of Argos, did erect ≈øtatues for the Amba≈ø≈øadors. Pau≈øanias, in Corinthiacis

THe Sepulchre of Aristomenes of Me≈øsene, is worthy to be ≈øeen in a Colledge of Me≈øsene, (a City of Achaia in Greece) which they ≈øay in good earne≈øt, is not empty, and a monument ≈øet up for honour of the body not pre≈øent. For although he, being driven from the Spartanes, died in bani≈øhment, yet by the command of Pythius Apollo, his bones were carried back into his Countrey, and ≈øuch things were ordained to be holy. They bound a Bull which was de≈øtinated to the Altar, to a Pillar not far from the Tomb. He, being mad, and raging becau≈øe of his bonds, did ≈øtrive to go away. Which if the vvhile the Bull moveth nimbly, and danceth according to that, it is ominous to the Me≈øsenians: but if on the contrary, the Bull ≈øhal ≈øtand immoveable, they interpret that it portends ≈øome calamity to them. The Lacedemonians report the Heroick Ari≈øtomenes to have been at the Leuctrican fight 187. years after his death, vvho a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Thebans again≈øt them, vvrought ≈øo, that he afflicted
them vvith a great di≈øcomfiture. Pau≈øanias, in Me≈øsenicis.

AT Pachinum, a Promontory of Sicily, Apollo Lybi≈øtinus is wor≈øhipped with great devotion; for when the Lybians were about to invade Sicilie, their Navy having arrived at the Promontory, Apollo being invocated by the Inhabitants, ≈øent the Plague among≈øt their enemies, and de≈øtroyed almo≈øt all of them with ≈øuddain death; whereupon Lybi≈øtinus was added as a ≈øirname to him. Macrobius, lib. 1. cap. 17.

THe Per≈øians, Xerxes leading them to the Chappel of Minerva, which ≈øtandeth before the Temple of Delphos, as they came thither, upon a ≈øuddain a Thunder-bolt from Heaven fell among≈øt them, with the two heads of Parna≈øsus, being rent from the re≈øt of the Mountain, with an horrid noi≈øe tumbled down, and intercepted very many of them; whereupon from the very Chappel of Minerva came mo≈øt joyfull vociferations and jubilations. The Barbarians committing them≈øelves to flight, departing from Delphos, they publi≈øhed their great di≈øcomfiture; tho≈øe which e≈øcaped of them, fled to Boetia, reporting, That two armed men more noble then any of humane nature could po≈ø≈øibly be, pur≈øuing them. The≈øe two they ≈øaid were Natives, and Heroick men at Delphos, the one Phylacus, the other Antonius, the Temples dedicated to them being there to be ≈øeen; That dedicated to Phylacus, ≈øtandeth by the way above the Temple of Minerva; and that which was dedicated to Antonius, near Castalia, under the whirlpool Hyampeum. Herodotus, lib. 8.

IN the Sabine Warr which was waged again≈øt the Romans for ravi≈øhing the Virgins, The Romans made ha≈øte to ≈øhut the gate which was at the foot of the Viminalian Hill, (which afterwards by occa≈øion of what happened, was called the gate of Janus) becau≈øe the enemies did ru≈øh upon it; after it was made fa≈øt, flew open; and when again and again the third time the ≈øame thing happened, more armed men came to the thre≈øhold of it, becau≈øe they could not ≈øhut it, to make it good again≈øt the enemy. And when the enemies fought mo≈øt fiercely on the other ≈øide, it was pre≈øently given out, That the Romans were overcome by Tacitus; for which cau≈øe, which defended the gate or entrance of the City fled. And when the Sabines had made an irruption into it through the gate, it is reported, that from the hou≈øe of Janus, by this pa≈ø≈øage, the great power of torrents ≈øcattering water all about broke out, burning the great and va≈øte numbers of their enemies with ≈øcalding waters, and devouring them with rapacious gulphs. Macrobius, lib. 1. Saturnal, cap. 9.

THe holy ≈øheep of the Sunne; which are at Apollonia in the bo≈øome of Ionicum, which in the day time feed along the River ≈øide, which floweth out of the Mountain Lacmonen through the Apolloniatan field into the Sea; and cho≈øen men, honourable by birth and Riches among≈øt the people, keep them lodged in the night in a Cave not farr from the City, the people every year making new election, for that the Apolloniatae by a certain Oracle were brought to put an high value upon the Sheep. There a certain Gentleman called Evenius cho≈øen to take the care of looking to the Sheep, upon a time fell a ≈øleep, and Wolves entring into the Cave, killed ≈øixty of them; which when the Apolloniatae under≈øtood, they condemned him to the lo≈ø≈øe of his eyes for ≈øleeping when he ≈øhould have watched: upon execution of which ≈øentence, their cattle cea≈øed to bring forth young ones, and the earth to yield her fruit, and they had Cattle at Dodona and Delphos. The Prophets being asked the cau≈øe of this pre≈øent evill; an≈øwered, becau≈øe they had unju≈øtly deprived Evenius the keeper of the holy ≈øheep of his eyes, and that the Wolves were ≈øent by the gods, and that their puni≈øhments for this wrong ≈øhould not cea≈øe till he was ≈øatisfied by tho≈øe who had perpetrated this wrong to him what≈øoever Evenius him≈øelf conceived due ≈øatisfaction; and then that the Gods would ≈øo ble≈ø≈øe them, that they would find them≈øelves happy. The Apolloniatae keeping the≈øe Oracles clo≈øe, cho≈øe certain Citizens to perform them, who come to Evenius ≈øitting in a ≈øtation for the purpo≈øe, and ≈øitting down with him, di≈øcour≈øe of other things, at la≈øt came to ≈øpeak of the mi≈øeries of the times; which making as an introduction to ≈øpeak of his wrong, they demand of him what mulct he would wi≈øh the Apolloniatae to undergo for his full ≈øatisfaction, who having not heard of the ≈øentence of the Oracle, ≈øaid that he de≈øired two mannours which he conceived the greate≈øt revennues belonging to the Apolloniatae, and a hou≈øe which he knew to be the be≈øt in the City: the Citizens pre≈øently a≈ø≈øented, and telling what directions they had received from the Oracle, and buying the Mannours of the Owners thereof, gave them to Evenius, who pre≈øently thereupon obtained divination from the gods, whereby he grew famous. Herodotus, Libro 9. cap. 7.

THe Pilappii inhabit that furthe≈øt part of Scandinavia, bordering upon the frozen Sea, and almo≈øt inclo≈øed with the Sea; The≈øe neither till the ground, nor nouri≈øh any cattle, but the Tarandus or Buff which they make u≈øe of in the Winter when the waters are glaz'd, and all things made ≈øtiff with the Fro≈øt; for they live by hunting and fi≈øhing, and they have ever hitherto wor≈øhipped wood and ≈øtones; when they went on hunting, fi≈øhing, or began any other bu≈øine≈øs, having u≈øed certain adjurations, they endeavour to move out of their place their gods which they con≈øult; which if they ea≈øily perform, they conceive they favour their
enterpri≈øe, and promi≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; but if they cannot move them without much trouble, they think their ≈øucce≈øs is denyed; and if they cannot po≈ø≈øibly move them out of their places, they conclude, that their gods are offended; And therefore they think they are to be appea≈øed by a certain ≈øacrifice, which they order in this manner; They have a brazen ve≈ø≈øel, wherein are the pictures of all kinds of four-footed Bea≈øts, of Birds, and Fi≈øhes, which are common and plentifull among≈øt them; they have the image of a Frog made of bra≈øs annexed to a piece of Iron fa≈øtned to the middle of the ve≈ø≈øel like a plumb; afterwards u≈øing adjurations, they beat upon the ve≈ø≈øel, and into the picture of what≈øoever creature the Frog doth thereupon fall or leap, as ≈øoon as the frog had but touched it, they procure a living creature of that kind; they kill it, and hang the head thereof upon a Tree which they account holy; the re≈øt they cook or dre≈øs, and con≈øume with their friends which they call about them; and according to their ≈øacred rites, (as they think) they anoint them≈øelves with that wherewith the ho≈øt is boyled; ≈øuch holy rites fini≈øhed, (as they ≈øay) they have learned by experience, ≈øuch things they undertake, ≈øucceed pro≈øperou≈øly. Olaus Magnus.

div.head: Of Sathan's wonderful Legerdemains, Deceits, and Impo≈øtures, u≈øed, for the ≈øetting up, and e≈øtabli≈øhing Idolatry, by Invocation of Saints departed this life, wor≈øhiping of Statues and Images, and for confirmation of the doctrine of Purgatory, contrary to the preaching of St. Paul, 2 The≈øs. 2.
div.p: THeodo≈øius the Emperour, unju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpecting John Dama≈øne, a Monk, of betraying the Secrets of the Empire to the Per≈øians, with whom he had been pri≈øoner, puni≈øhed him with the lo≈øs of one of his hands; he therefore imploring help of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, as he was before her Image, had his hand re≈øtored, and perfectly united to his arm in the ≈øight of many, though it had for many days been fixed to the doors of the Church. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 6,

NIcephorus, lib. 15. cap. 23. relateth, That a certain Jew of the Arch-Synagogue was taken as the Author of a tumult, rai≈øed at Con≈øtantinople in the time of Leo the Emperour, and condemned to fearfull torments, in the mid≈øt whereof he cryed out with a loud voyce, O God of holy Sergius, help me! holy Sergius, thou ha≈øt known me and mine innocency. The Judges ≈øu≈øpecting, what he ≈øpoke to be cunning di≈ø≈øimulation, condemned him to be burnt; who when he was in the mid≈øt of the flames, there appeared two hor≈øemen arrayed in white robes, who for many hours kept him pre≈øerved and untoucht by the fire; which the people with much wonder beholding, at length, running into the flames, ≈ønatch'd him away.

WHen the body of the Virgin Levinua was carried through the Towns and Garri≈øons of that part of Flanders which lyeth to the Sea-≈øide, tho≈øe who were ≈øick of the Pal≈øie, deaf, lame, and troubled with other di≈øea≈øes, were ≈øuddenly cured. And two Wax Candles, put out by the wind; as ≈øoon as they were brought
to the bones of the dead Virgin, kindled by vertue thereof. Jacobus Meyer, ex ≈øcriptis Dryonis tunc temporis Morinorum Epi≈øcopi.

MAny blind and lame were brought to the Sepulchre of Pope Martin the fourth, (who had been warlike enough) and recovered their former health, by u≈øing ≈øuch devotions there, as were then u≈øed at the Sepulchres of the dead. Platina.

THe Coach in which the dead body of S. Ladi≈ølaus King of Hungary was carried, the keepers thereof ≈øleeping, and the bea≈øts feeding, without any inforcement went to Varidinum with ≈øuch celerity, that the keepers could not keep company with it, neither could any man by any means po≈ø≈øibly ≈øtay it; As they were committing the body to the Sepulchre, the face of a certain man (which they ≈øay had a loath≈øome ≈ømell) turn'd towards his back, and hanged upon his ≈øhoulder, having tryed many wayes for help, and finding none, comes to the Sepulchre, and cryes out with a loud voyce, O Holy Ladi≈ølaus, I have wronged thee, holy Prince forgive me: And, the incen≈øed divine power appea≈øed by his humble and hearty veneration, his chin was brought to its proper place, and he perfectly re≈øtored. Bo≈øinius, lib. 4. Decadis, 2.

THe Bi≈øhop of Prague in Livonia, by the per≈øecution of the Abdeberti, lo≈øing a finger for the faith of Chri≈øt, the executioners or cutters off of his finger, threw it into a River in the Countrey of the Vandals, in which Countrey he had oft preached; which a fi≈øh pre≈øently ≈øwallowed; whereupon the fi≈øh ≈øhined with a circle of glaring flame: the Fi≈øhers e≈øpying it, and taking it for a wonderfull portent, after great indu≈øtry u≈øed to catch it, at la≈øt obtained their de≈øire; and having taken out the bowels of the fi≈øh, they found the finger ≈øhining with a glaring light. Idem, lib. 1. Decadis ≈øecundae, hi≈øtoriae Ungar.

GEnarius of Beneventum having his head cut off for profe≈ø≈øing the faith of Chri≈øt, it and his blood put into a Viall, were kept in two ≈øeverall Churches; and when they were both ≈øolemnly carried through the City, the blood which was congealed into a ball; when it did but touch the head, di≈ø≈øolved into as fre≈øh blood as it was when it flowed from the Martyr at his decollation; and when it was taken from his head, it congealed again into a round form as it was before: And that we might be more a≈ø≈øured of the truth hereof, we had the te≈øtimonies of them who were diligent ob≈øervers, and eye-witne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 6.

VAlens the Emperour, an Arrian, when he would have tran≈ølated the Head of John the Baptist to Con≈øtantinople, could not po≈ø≈øibly get the Coach wherein he had put it, to be moved or ≈øtirred, and therefore was forc'd to de≈øi≈øt and leave off his undertaking; but Theodo≈øius, an Orthodox Chri≈øtian, did afterwards with much facility tran≈ølate the very ≈øame head. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 6.

IN the time of the Warr of Otho and Philip, Emperours, the bodies of eleven thou≈øand Virgins, three of them Kings, were ≈øeen to return to the Temple of Colonia, from the Abbey of Fulden≈øes in Thuringia, whence they had been tran≈ølated from Colonia. In the morning betimes, while≈øt they ≈øung the P≈øalms appointed by the Church for nocturns, the Abbot and Monks of that Mona≈øtery ≈øaw the bodies of the three Kings going out of the Temple, which not long after were found in the Temple of Colonia, whence they had formerly been tran≈ølated, Idem, ibidem.

WHen John, a devout giver of alms, was dead, a certain woman for three dayes together continuing at his Sepulchre, weeping, for that ≈øhe feared le≈øt a writing (which ≈øhe had delivered to him, and wherein was contained a great ≈øin which ≈øhe had committed, and which ≈øhe had declared unto him) ≈øhould come to the hands of any body that ≈øhould know and divulge it; the Ele√´mo≈øynarian appeared to the woman, and delivered the ≈øchedule ≈øealed, in which the former writing was blotted out, and written in≈øtead thereof, For my ≈øervant John's ≈øake, thy ≈øin is blotted out. Metap. in vita ejus.

A Certain German called Conradus, repenting heartily of his ≈øins, cometh to Rome, Hildebrand then Pope, commandeth him to wear in≈øtead of a ≈øhirt, a covering next his skin, tyed together with five chains ≈øtamped with letters, containing a catalogue of his ≈øins, and commands him to vi≈øit the holy places all the world over, and there to pray for pardon, that he might have remi≈ø≈øion of his ≈øins: he obeys; and travelling long and far, not omitting in his pilgrimage to vi≈øit Jeru≈øalem, at length he cometh to Hungary, where he vi≈øiting the Sepulchre of the holy King Stephen, in the Church called Alba Regalis, and having humbly ca≈øt him≈øelf down in prayer, before the Altar, from the fir≈øt hour to the ninth, being ≈øeized on by ≈øleep the Kingly Saint appears, ≈øaying, Ri≈øe quickly my friend, thou can≈øt not by my merits or help, obtain pardon from the Tribunal of Almighty God, but go yonder to the Monument of my ≈øon Emericus, who by his Virginity procured great favour from Almighty God; whereupon he calling on the name of that Saint, found, that the chains wherewith he was tyed, fell all in ≈øunder, and the ≈øtamps which were ≈øet upon them clean gone, ≈øo that they appeared plain; in≈øomuch, that there could no ≈øinne
of his be read, there not remaining ≈øo much as one ≈ømall letter. Ever after, this Temple was vi≈øited with ≈øuch devotion, that innumerable Votaries came to it from very remote places. Bonfinius, lib. 1. Decad. 2.

ABout the third year after the mi≈øerable ≈ølaughter received by the Turks at Nicopolis, in the time of Sigi≈ømund the Emperour, when many went into the field where that battel had been fought, they heard a voyce among≈øt the bones of the dead, ≈øounding forth the names of Je≈øus Chri≈øt the Saviour of the World, and the Virgin Mary; and looking among≈øt the dead corps, they e≈øpyed out a head, which ≈øaid, Why ≈øtand ye gazing ≈øo ≈øtupidly here? I am a Chri≈øtian, who was ≈ølain here before confe≈øsion, and therefore my ≈øinnes are not yet expiated; the ble≈øsed Mother, Mary, cau≈øeth that I am not afflicted with eternal puni≈øhment, and hath ≈øo pre≈øerved me, that I have yet my ≈øpeech to confe≈øs my ≈øins, and declare my mind to the holy Apo≈øtles; wherefore I pray you ≈øend for a Prie≈øt to receive my confe≈øsion, and give me ab≈øolution. He being asked, How he had de≈øerved ≈øo great favour from the Virgin? an≈øwered, She was my peculiar Patrone≈øs all my lifetime, ≈øeven Fea≈øts every year all my lifetime I celebrated in honour of her, and did mo≈øt ≈øtrictly fa≈øt, eating nothing but bread and water the eves of all tho≈øe Fea≈øts; of all my Patrons and Patrone≈øses ≈øhe was chiefly relyed on by me. A Prie≈øt from the next Town being ≈øent for, he making an exact confe≈ø≈øion, received ab≈øolution; whereupon ≈øilenced, he re≈øted in peace. Bonfinius, lib. 3. Decad. 3.

MErcurius, a certain Hungarian, brought up at the Alben≈øian Temple, when the King, Ladi≈ølaus, had commanded the Tomb of St. Stephen to be ≈øearcht, to ≈øee if any of the Reliques were taken away; being all alone, having retired him≈øelf into the holy Quire, with a doleful countenance, and ≈øad heart, bewailing, that he could not ≈øo much as ≈øee, much le≈ø≈øe obtain a ki≈øs of the ≈øacred body; a young man in the dead of night appeared to him, who was beautified with incredible comeline≈øs, having a mo≈øt chearfull countenance, and arrayed in white apparrel, carrying ≈øomewhat wrapt in a fine cloath, ≈øaid to him, Mercury, receive what thou ha≈øt ≈øo earnestly de≈øired, and be ≈øure highly to e≈øteem this precious gift committed to thy trust, keep it with care and diligence, and view it when time ≈øervs. The ≈øacred Nocturns devoutly fini≈øhed, Mercury going to a private place, opens the cloath, and finds the right hand and ring of the holy King; ≈øhortly after, he being cho≈øen Governour of a Mona≈øtery, built of wood, ≈øcituated at the foot of the hill Carpathius, which divides Tran≈øylvania from Hungary, neither daring to tru≈øt him≈øelf, nor any one el≈øe with the hand, he hides it in the ground, and appointed every day ≈øome of the Monks to watch it, le≈øt any man ≈øhould ≈øteal it away. Then that Mona≈øtery ≈øought to King Ladi≈ølaus, to be of the order of the King's hand, by who≈øe Edict, the Pope's con≈øent obtained, it was ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed; Then the whole Colledg of Prie≈øts declaring to the King the whole ≈øtory hereof, he repairs
the Mona≈øtery, ≈øo that he made it mo≈øt beautifull to behold, and endowed it with great revenues in the year of grace, 1078, and now they call it, The Abbey of the King's right hand. Bonfinius, lib. 1. Decad. 2.

AS Bruno, Bi≈øhop of Hilde≈øia, was ≈øolemnizing the Octaves of the Nativity of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, ≈øhe appeared to him in the Temple, to whom the Bi≈øhop falling upon his knees, cryes out, O Queen of Heaven, wherefore vouch≈øafe≈øt thou to come to me, a wretched poor man? To whom ≈øhe an≈øwered, I rejoyce that thou art the author of the ≈øolemn celebration of the memory of my Nativity, whereby ≈øuch honour accrueth to my Sonne. Which ≈øaid, ≈øhe vani≈øhed away: From this time ever after, the Octaves of the Nativity of Mary were kept holy. Chron. Saxon.

IN the year, 1495, Nicolaus, a familiar friend to the Trea≈øurer of the Bi≈øhop of Quinccle≈øia, as he was coming to the King Uladi≈ølaus at Buda, where he ≈øometimes u≈øed to re≈øide, ≈øaw in the Ayr a great light, which dazled his ≈øight, and with the noy≈øe thereof making an hideous cla≈øhing, ≈øtupified his hearing; he was ≈øo affrighted, that he fell to the ground ≈øurpri≈øed with the ≈øtrangene≈øs thereof, and looking up towards heaven, he ≈øaw the ≈øhape of the Virgin, with her Son, having a glorious ≈øhining circle about them in the Ayr, ≈øteering their cour≈øe towards Buda, and that he at that very in≈øtant ≈øhewed it to a certain ≈øtranger, called Boennus, and his Wife, and to his own Carter, to be taken notice of with reverence, it being the very day that was appointed for celebrating the memory of the Conception of the Virgin-Mother of God, which the Hungarians ever after ob≈øerved with more devotion than formerly they had done. Sabellicus, lib. 1. cap. 1.

SAroltha, the Wife of Gri≈øa, Duke of the Hungarians, being great with child, ≈øaw Stephen the fir≈øt Martyr, who appearing to her ≈øaid, Woman, tru≈øt in the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and a≈ø≈øure thy ≈øelf, that I by Divine commandment am to inform thee, that thou ≈øhalt ≈øhortly be delivered of a gallant and fortunate ≈øon, who ≈øhall enjoy the Diadem of the Kingdom of Pano ‚Ä¢ ia; and he ≈øhall be ≈øo excellent a man, that Panonia ≈øhall never have the like after him to their King: and whereas I am Stephen the fir≈øt Martyr, who ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt thy ≈øon, let him have my name. Which ≈øpoken, he vani≈øhed away. Saroltha, confirmed by her dream that the≈øe things ≈øhould come to pa≈ø≈øe, accordingly commanded holy devotions to be u≈øed at all the Altars of the Protomartyr; and in the year 909 the child was born. Bon. l. 1. Decad. 2.

THe Parents of Nicolas Tollentinates told by an Oracle, what i≈ø≈øue they ≈øhould have, vowed a pilgrimage to Barium, where when they had continued long at their devotion in the Church of the Saint who is there wor≈øhipped; by chance, or rather
providence fell a≈øleep, wherein they were in≈øtructed with an unthought-of adverti≈øement, and their former hopes of i≈ø≈øue much increa≈øed, by a≈ø≈øurance of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to their vows and ≈øolemn devotions, nor were their prayers in vain, for greater and more ble≈ø≈øed rewards followed then the heart of man could pre≈øume, that of unholy Parents, a Saint ≈øhould be born. Sabellicus, lib. 1. cap. 1.

HAldricus the Leodien≈øian Bi≈øhop was afflicted for about a whole year with a Canker, and could receive no hopes of help from Phy≈øicians. Therefore being awakened, for joy he cries out with a loud voice, to whom his ≈øervants (wondring at the noy≈øe) run with ≈øpeed, and removing the cloth wherewith the ≈øore place was bound, found that it was whole, and that there onely remained a ≈øcar in the place where the Canker had been. THere was near Brundulum an holy Temple of Saint Michael, unto which one Temple the people of Clodia, Matemancum, and the Venetians them≈øelves came with great Zeal to do their devotions. It happened al≈øo that at Senogallia, a certain man called Sergius, a Prince in wealth and Authority, was afflicted with a grievous di≈øea≈øe, who heard a voice in the night, which ≈øaid, if he would make a vow to vi≈øit the holy Temple of Saint Michael, he ≈øhould recover his health. Whereupon he made a vow, and according thereto leaving his Country ≈øoyl, vi≈øited the Temple, and be≈øtowing great gifts upon it, returned home to his own hou≈øe being freed from his ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. JOhn Orphanotropus brother to Michael Emperour of Paphlagonia the Phy≈øicians de≈øpairing of his cure, in his ≈øleep he ≈øaw Nicolas the Great, who admoni≈øhed him to go to Myra, a≈ø≈øuring him that a≈ø≈øoon as he came thither, he ≈øhould recover his health. HEnry the ≈øecond, Emperour, when he took with great pain an exact view of the Cities of Apulia, was ≈øo mi≈øerably infe≈øted with the ≈øtone, that almo≈øt all men de≈øpaired of his recovery, but he ≈øu≈øtained his ≈øickne≈ø≈øe with ≈øo great patience, judging it to be as a rod of correction for his ≈øins ≈øent to him from Almighty God, that as he a≈øcended the hill Ca≈ø≈øinum, de≈øiring the interce≈ø≈øion of Saints, Saint Benedict, and Saint Scolastica; for Phy≈øitians could do him no good: He ≈øaw, in his ≈øleep, Benedict ≈øtanding by him, and with a Knife to have opened his privy members, and took out a great ≈øtone, making the wound whole, and putting it into the Kings hand, who awakened from his ≈øleep, ≈øeeing and perceiving the great miracle, called his guard to him that they might fetch his Prince, to whom he ≈øhewed this great miracle, which tran≈øcended humane capacity and belief, together with the ≈øcar of the inci≈øion, out of which the ≈øtone had been taken. MAnuel a Captain under Theophilus the Emperour, who had di≈øapproved the wor≈øhip of Images, and then wavered in his Judgment concerning the ≈øame, fell into a grievous ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, in≈øomuch that it was verily believed he would dye thereby, certain Monks of the Mona≈øtery of Studium, to whom it was ≈øhewed that he was dying, came to him, and approaching to his bed ≈øide, found by his breathing that he was yet alive, and delivered to him the joyfull tydings, that he ≈øhould recover his health; how can this be, ≈øaith he, ≈øpeaking with a weak and low voice, the faculties of his Soul being much weakened, and his body dried up with heat, the Monks an≈øwered, All things are po≈ø≈øible with God, therefore if when he ≈øhould recover his health, he would endeavour that Images might be re≈øtored according to the decrees of the Antients, they a≈ø≈øured him that he ≈øhould be re≈øtored to life and health: which when they had with much certainty declared, they departed. A Certain friend to Julian travayling with much ha≈øte towards him then in Per≈øia, being forced for want of an Inne, to go ≈øomewhat out of his way to a Church which was near, repo≈øed him≈øelf all night therein, whether ≈øleeping or waking, he knew not: he ≈øaw in the night many of the Apo≈øtles Congregated, complaining of the contumelies and di≈øgraces of the Emperour ca≈øt upon the Church, taking coun≈øell among≈øt them≈øelves, what was to be done; and having deliberately ≈øpoken of it, and many things
more, they appearing as it were perplexed, two of them ri≈øing up in the mid≈øt of them, advi≈øing them to be of good cheer, making ha≈øt to de≈øtroy the Empire, they left that coun≈øell or conference. The man who had this admirable Vi≈øion, neglecting the journey he had begun, that he might ≈øee the i≈ø≈øue of his Vi≈øion, ≈øtayes another night, and ≈øleeps in the ≈øame place, and ≈øees the ≈øame a≈ø≈øembly; to whom upon a ≈øudden, they which the night before went to fight again≈øt Julian, came in, as returned from their journey, and declared to the company, that Julian was dead. NAuglerus, lib. 2. Generatione decima-tertia, reports that Ba≈øill Bi≈øhop of Cae≈øaria Cappadocia, by rea≈øon of Julian his threatning to de≈øtroy Cae≈øaria as he returned from the Per≈øian War, proclaiming a fa≈øt to be kept for three dayes in the Temple, to implore the help of Almighty God in the Church of the Virgin Mary, after fini≈øhing whereof, he ≈øaw in his ≈øleep Mercury a Souldier lately dead; who by the command of the Virgin Mary, killed Julian, and that the arms hanging over his Tomb were gone thence: and the keeper of the Church demanded what was become of them, ≈øaid, he knew not, but did affirm by Oath that they were there the la≈øt evening; Ba≈øill therefore returning to the Hill, called others up, and told them that Julian was dead, and going with them to the Sepulchre of Mercury, found his launce re≈øtored to the place it u≈øed to hang all bloudy. But Hermanus Gyges, in ≈øtoribus temporum, reports this in the time of Julian, not by Ba≈øill, but Bla≈øius a certain Bi≈øhop of Cera≈øten≈øes.

EDward the third, King of England, having almo≈øt reigned his twenty fourth year, there was a Ring brought him from Jeru≈øalem, by certain men who came thence, which he long before had privately given to a poor man, who obtained it as an alms which he ≈øought for the love that the King bore to Saint John the Evangeli≈øt: and not long after falling ≈øick, having learnt the mo≈øt ab≈øolute vertue of a Chri≈øtian, which is contentedly to re≈øign his Soul to the mo≈øt great and glorious God, he was buried in the Temple of We≈øtmin≈øter, and ≈øhortly after canonized a Saint; The ring was long after kept with great veneration in the ≈øame Church, which was a pre≈øent cure to all infeebled and weak members of Men and Women, and by the touch of it the falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe was cured, hence it came to pa≈ø≈øe that the Kings of England were wont on Good-Friday with many ceremonies to hallow the Ring, the which who≈øoever put upon his finger, ≈øhould never be troubled with this di≈øea≈øe.
