THe Statue of Saint Paul, an old piece, which Andronicus Comnenus Tyrannus adorning with Gold, placed in the Church of holy Quadraginta, which wept when the time approached that Andronicus was de≈øtroyed; Andronicus hearing thereof, commanded his ≈øervants to find out whether that were true: to which ≈øervice be≈øides others, his beloved ≈øervant Hagiocri≈øtophorita Stephanus by ≈øtairs a≈øcended (for the Statue was in a high place) and wiped the eyes thereof with fine linnen, whereupon tears more plentifully fell from them, as if they had flowed from a ≈øpring, which with great amazement he told. LEo the fifth of Ironomacum, his Mother, as it ≈øeemed to her, ≈øaw in the Temple of the Virgin Mary at Blachernes, a certain woman; her ≈øonne apparelled in white, following her, and the floor of the Church being be≈øprinkled with blood, another woman carrying a Spear in her hand, commanded a ve≈ø≈øel to be filled, and to be given to the Mother of the King; which refu≈øed by her, ≈øhe ≈øaid to her, Thy ≈øon de≈øtroyes and gluts him≈øelf with the blood of all that wor≈øhip we; wherefore I and my ≈øonne are not without cau≈øe moved with wrath again≈øt him. The Mother of the King affrighted out of her ≈øleep, pre≈øently declares what ≈øhe had by Vi≈øion, and earne≈øtly de≈øires him to de≈øi≈øt from the per≈øecution of Images: But he, like the deaf Adder, ≈øtopped his ears, though he was ≈øomewhat afraid, and the more, for that the dream of another was declared to him: For Tara≈øius the Patriarch appeared to a certain man, calling vehemently upon one who≈øe name was Michael, that he ≈øhould go to Leo, and kill him, in revenge of them, whom mo≈øt impiou≈øly and cruelly he had put to death for their Religion. BArdus Durus, a little before his de≈øtruction, dreamed, That as he was making ha≈øte with the Emperour Michael, to the ≈øolemnization of a certain holy-day, to the great Temple, whither when they approached near, they followed certain men apparelled in white, who led them to Seats about the Tribunal, wherein they ≈øaw a certain old man ≈øitting alone, whom he thought to be Peter, chief of the Apo≈øtles, at who≈øe feet Ignatius was ca≈øt down, whom a little before they had ≈øeverely bound and ca≈øtigated in revenge of the wrongs he had done: moreover, Peter delivering a ≈øword to one of them who ≈øtood by, commanding that Theorgi≈øtus (for ≈øo he called Cae≈øar as obnoxious to divine wrath) ≈øhould be placed among≈øt
tho≈øe who ≈øtood on the left hand, and cut in pieces, and A≈øebotecnus; by this name he deciphers that Emperour as an impious ≈øon. Cedrenus.

A Nocturnal Vi≈øion di≈øcovered to A ‚Ä¢ bro≈øe the Mediolanen≈øian Bi≈øhop, the bodies of the Martyrs Gerva≈øius and Prota≈øius, it not being known to that day, where they lay, they appearing to him in his ≈øleep, ≈øuch as when they were found. Fulgo≈øus, lib. 1. cap. 5.

SOzomenus gives a large narration, how Pulcheria, ≈øi≈øter to Theolo≈øius found out the fourty Martyrs, which ≈øuffered under Lucinius at a certain placed Seba≈øtes, in Armenia, who≈øe reliques as by digging ≈øhe caus'd to be ≈øearch't for. Thir≈øus the Martyr appearing to her, ≈øugge≈øted and admoni≈øh'd her to tran≈ølate them to him; and afterwards the fourty Martyrs in a military habit ≈øplendidly apparelled, manife≈øted them≈øelves to her. THere appeared to a certain Husbandman, named Calemorus, belonging to the Nice-Pre≈øident, Chophares near Eleutheropolis in Pale≈øtine, the Prophet Zacharias, who taking into a certain Orchard, ≈øhewed the places digged, wherein his reliques lay. Sozomenus, lib. 9. cap. 8.

IT was commonly reported among≈øt the Venetians, That it was not for a long time known in what place the body of St. Mark lay, and that it was either by divine power tran≈ølated from the place wherein it had there layn, or was ≈øtoln away; but upon publike warning of a ≈øolemn day, ≈øet apart to fa≈øt and pray, and ob≈øervation thereof accordingly, the Citizens following the Clergy to the Temple of the Saint, they ≈øay this miracle happened, that an arm ri≈øing out of a ≈øide of the Church, appeared to the anxious and ≈øolicitous multitude; whereupon with great joy they remove the body, and lay it in a more honourable place; moreover, it was decreed, that it ≈øhould onely be lawfull for the Prince, and Procurators of the Temple, to come to the mo≈øt ≈øacred Tomb of St. Mark. SAint Benedict appeared to Pope Urban in his ≈øleep, and ≈øaid, Doubt not but my body re≈øts at Ca≈øsinum; and for a te≈øtimony of the certainty hereof, thou ri≈øing with thy brethren to perform the office of the Church for Nocturns, ≈øhalt be cured of the Pluri≈øie wherewith thou art now afflicted. BA≈øilius Macedo, who afterwards obtained the Empire of Con≈øtantinople, when he was a child, lo≈øt his father. Cu≈øpinianus, ex Zonara & Cedreno.

ELfred, King of England, heavily afflicted with the lo≈ø≈øe he received by the victory of the Danes over him, Bi≈øhop Chulbert appeared to him in his ≈øleep, ≈øaying, England is ju≈øtly ≈øcourged for her former ≈øins; but Almighty God looks with mercy and compa≈ø≈øion upon the meritorious prayers, ≈øufferings, and tears of his di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øervants and Saints: thy Kingdom is with much cruelty extorted from thee, but after a ≈øhort time of affliction thou ≈øhalt be gloriou≈øly re≈øtored, and firmly ≈øettled in thy Land; and this ≈øhall be the ≈øign of the certainty of what I tell thee, Thy fi≈øhers ≈øhall this next day come to thee laden with infinite ≈øtore of fi≈øh; And, which increa≈øeth the Miracle, though the waters be frozen, ≈øo that

Vincentius, lib. 24. cap. 40. ex Holinand. Et Willielmus, lib. 2. cap. 14. de ge≈øtis Anglorum.

WHen Hungus, King of the Picts, a Chri≈øtian, was to fight with Athel≈øtane King of England, in ayd of the Scots; in the night, the Armies both of Hungus and Athel≈øtane, ≈øaw in the Firmament a ≈øhining cro≈øs in the form of St. Andrews cro≈øs, re≈øembling the Greek letter œá, which was cau≈øe of fear and terrour to them. EDgar King of the Scots, being about to fight again≈øt Donaldus, was admoni≈øhed by a dream, that he ≈øhould bring with him the ≈øtandard of St. Cutbert; therefore having performed ≈øome accu≈øtomed holy ceremonies and devotions, he took the ≈øtandard out of the Mona≈øtery, and the Souldiers belonging to Donaldus for≈øaking him, he was taken without ≈øedition or blood ≈øhed. ULadi≈ølaus and Gey≈øa, brethren, as they were ≈øetting their Army in order to fight a battle again≈øt Salomon, King of the Hungarians, an Angel was perceived by Uladi≈ølaus, to put a crown of gold upon the head of Gey≈øa; who as ≈øoon as his brother informed him thereof, vowed to dedicate a Temple, in the place where he ≈øhould obtain the victory, to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin; and the Enemies being overcome, deliberately advi≈øing concerning the ≈øame, where hard by a Church dedicated to St. Peter, behold, a Stag which had a mo≈øt remarkable head, with broad interwoven horns, upon whom mo≈øt ≈øhining ≈øhapes appeared, he made towards a Wood, and there ≈øtood at gaze, where the Temple was afterwards built, the Souldiers following after the Stag, and ≈øeeking with their arrows to ≈øhoot him, he fled into Danubius, and was never afterwards ≈øeen. Ladi≈ølaus much taken with this wonderfull ≈øight, ≈øaith, No doubt but this was the Angel of God; but what was that appearance of a face in his horns? pre≈øently ≈øaith Gey≈øa, They were not horns, but wings; nor ≈øhapes of bright faces, but mo≈øt glorious ≈øhining feathers; but where he ≈øtood at gaze, is the place wherein we are directed to build the Temple; wherefore hard by the Church of St. Peter, they built a Temple to the ble≈ø≈øed Mother. THe night before Theodo≈øius joyned battle with Eugenius at the Alpes, he dreamed, as Paul Diaconus and Nicephorus write, that two men gloriou≈øly apparelled in white, ≈øitting upon white hor≈øes, commanded him to begin his battle by the break of day, for it was decreed by Divine providence, that he ≈øhould victoriou≈øly overcome his enemies; and that they declared their names to be John the Evangeli≈øt, and Philip the Apo≈øtle, and that a certain Souldier had the like dream, is reported by Theodoretus, lib. 5. cap. 24.

MA≈øsaclerus ≈øent by the Emperour Honorius again≈øt Gildo to regain Africa from his brother, who ambitiou≈øly affected the Empire, in his ≈øleep dreamed, that he ≈øaw the Mediolen≈øian Bi≈øhop, Ambro≈øe, (a dead man long before) with his pa≈øtorall ≈øtaff to ≈øtrike the ground thrice, and thrice to ≈øay, Here, even in this very place. And the next day, Ma≈øsaclerus with much facility overthrew Gildo. Fulgo≈øus.

THe Roman Prince, retreating to Antioch, Andrew the Apo≈øtle appeared to a Prie≈øt, named Peter Pontius, one indued with ≈øimplicity, void of fraud, and ≈øhewed to him the Spear which pierced our Saviour's ≈øide, which lay buried in a Temple dedicated to St. Peter; upon finding whereof, the be≈øieged City, oppre≈ø≈øed with famine, were ≈øo far encouraged, that they made a gallant Sally, wherby they overcame Corbana who be≈øieged the City by command and advice of Belfech Turca King of the Per≈øians, he being encouraged thereunto by divination, gathered from the flying of birds; the Bi≈øhop of Nicene carrying the Lance which had pierced our Saviours ≈øide, among≈øt the Troops of tho≈øe who ≈øallied out in array again≈øt the be≈øiegers. Emilius.

WHen there had been long and doubtfull War 'twixt the Romans and Ro≈øsians, tho≈øe who came from Con≈øtantinople to John Zimi≈øca, auxiliaries to the Emperour, did by divine providence a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Romans: for as it is reported, a ≈øtorm did violently beat in the faces of their enemies, and furthermore a mighty hor≈øeman was ≈øeen of many, who running among≈øt the Romans, broke the Ranks of the Enemies; and it appears it was Theodore, for that a Religious Woman of Byzantium, dreamed the night before that fight, that ≈øhe ≈øaw the Mother of God with a great company, who ≈øaid, O Theodore, thy dear friend John, and mine too, is in a great ≈øtrait, being now in battell. Ut Zonoras, Tomo 3. indicat.

ARiulphus Duke of Spoleto, fighting again≈øt the Romans at Camertes, and obtaining Victory, inquires of his Souldiers who it was that behaved him≈øelf ≈øo ≈øtoutly and gallantly in the battle; they an≈øwered, 'twas a Prince: Whereupon he replies, he was more powerfull then any mortall man, for when ever I was a≈ø≈øaulted fiercely by the enemy, he with a Buckler defended me from their fury: then going with all po≈ø≈øible ≈øpeed to Spoleto, ≈øeeing the Temple wherein the body of Saint Sabinus is intombed, he asked what Church it was; when they an≈øwered, It was the Temple of Sabinus, he ha≈øtily leaps from his hor≈øe, calling his Souldiers, who as they ≈øay alwayes waited diligently upon him, walks into the Church, and ≈øeeing his Image, he pre≈øently with an Oath affirmed 'twas he that protected him from the violent a≈ø≈øaults of his numerous enemies; whereupon 'twas pre≈øently believed that Sabinus was the mo≈øt pious Patron of Souldiers. Ariulphus would not for any thing have wanted the experience of this Protection of Saints, which is ≈øo frequent among≈øt Chri≈øtians. Bonfinius, lib. 8. Decad. 1.

THe great Sfortia for the honour he bore St. Leonard, Chri≈øtned his Son which he had by Catella Alopa, ≈øi≈øter to Pandulphus Alopus, after his name, for that he dreamed he ≈øaw Leonard in the ≈øame ≈øhape he is u≈øually pictur'd in Churches, coming to him being a Pri≈øoner with relief, breaking the Iron bars of the window of the Pri≈øon, and with his power loo≈øing his ≈øhackles. THey ≈øay, a certain woman delivered her ≈øins in writing to Ba≈øill the Great, ≈øupplicating him to pray to Almighty God for the forgivene≈øs of them; he accordingly imploring remi≈ø≈øion of her ≈øins, all were blotted out of the writing, except one more grievous then the re≈øt; wherefore the woman was ≈øent to Ephem the Hermite; but by rea≈øon he was dead, ≈øhe returned (having as ≈øhe conceived, laboured in vain) to Ba≈øil, who under≈øtanding that he dyed that day, after the womans abundant pouring forth of tears, he putting the paper to the brea≈øt of the dead man, who was laid upon the ground, findeth, when pre≈øently he took it away, that the remaining unblotted ≈øin, when he there put it, was now clean blotted out. GRegorius Turonen≈øis (de gloria confe≈øsorum, cap. 97.) ≈øcribit. AN eleven hundred Virgins martyred by the Huns, their bodies were brought to the publick Church; whereupon, when a certain Prie≈øt had obtained the body of one of the Virgins, that he might tran≈ølate it to his Church, moved thereunto by zealous devotion; while≈øt they were at Mattins, ≈øhe re≈øuming her body, and appearing as ≈øhe had been alive, to the great wonder of the whole Colledge of Prie≈øts, who beheld it, wor≈øhipping the great Altar, immediately departed; the chief of the Society comming therefore to the Tomb, could not find the Virgin who was laid therein. DAgobertus the King of France, erected the Temple of St. Diony≈øius from the foundation, taking away from all others, and ≈øpoyling them, whereby he might enrich this alone: neither was any of his predece≈ø≈øors found, who gave ≈øo magnificent and exce≈ø≈øive yearly revenues to Temples out of their patrimony. GEnovepha, a Virgin of Paris, did mo≈øt reverently frequent the Village Catula, where the holy Diony≈øius dyed, to whom ≈øhe dedicated a Cathedrall Church. She humbly went to the Colledge of the Prie≈øts, that they might build a Temple with the collected money. But their poverty

ABout the year of Grace, 1516, Baltha≈øar Hubmeyerus, a Divine at Regen≈øpurg, at his Conventions he ≈øo enflamed the Magi≈øtrates again≈øt the Jews, that their Congregation being cut off, they might build the Temple of the divine beautiful Virgin Mary in the ≈øame Ark. AT Buda, a City of Panonia, two Game≈øters meeting together, the one ≈øaid he playd in the Name of God; and the other, in the name of the Devil: he which made God by his vain words, a favourer of his wickedne≈øs, lo≈øt not onely all his money, but his cloaths al≈øo; and going towards home about mid-night, de≈øperately inraged by his lo≈øs, as he went through a Church-yard, thus po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with anger and fury, looking upon the Image of our Saviour crucified upon a Cro≈øs, he ≈ønatcheth up a ≈øtone, and ≈øtrikes it into the face of the Crucifix, which making a hole therein, ≈øtuck fa≈øt in it; whereupon great ≈øtore of blood miraculou≈øly i≈ø≈øued thence: a Butcher who was troubled with the Gout, living clo≈øe to the Church-yard, being an old man, and in his bed, heard a low voyce, which bid him ri≈øe, and ≈øtrike with his great knife whom≈øoever he ≈øhould meet; which words, when they had been thrice re-iterated, and that with threats of much mi≈øchief to befall him, if he refu≈øed, he re≈øolved to obey the voyce. IN the year of our Redemption, 1383. there was in this Countrey, a certain fellow named Schelkrop, of mean Parentage, one of the infamous rout, who naturally was indued with a bold malignant wit, and by licentiou≈øne≈øs and cu≈øtome was come to a great heighth of wickedne≈øs, wherein he not onely delighted, but gloried, he pa≈ø≈øed his time in Bawdy-hou≈øes and Taverns, and with great eagerne≈øs followed Play; from whence all kind of vices ingender, as fa≈øt as vermin from the putrefaction of a dead carca≈øs; and e≈øpecially impiety towards God, is thereby begot. But I will not confidently affirm it, but it appears plainly, that when he went from his companions, he came to a certain Chappel ≈øeated betwixt the Church of Saint Alban, and the Temple of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, where Images were kept, and ≈øuddenly fiercely hacked and hewed the Image of our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour crucified upon the Cro≈øs, and that with one ≈øtroke he cut off the head thereof, ≈øo that it fell from the body, and that with the edge and point of his ≈øword he ≈øla≈øht and thru≈øt many other Images of Saints which were placed by the Cro≈øs, &c. Hitherto Schelkrop was mad with fury and rage; and what followes, will declare how miraculou≈øly divine revenge ≈øeized on him; for ≈øuddenly, dreadfully, and miraculou≈øly blood flowed from the cuts,
≈øla≈øhes, and thru≈øts, that he had made in the Images, as if not Images made of wood, but living men had ≈øuffered that injury; and Schelkope now as one attain'd to the full mea≈øure of execrable impiety, ≈øtood ≈øtill, not able to move a foot, till he was deprehended in his raging crime by pa≈ø≈øengers, that found him in the place where he had perpetrated that villany, for which they ≈øei≈øed upon him, and brought him before the Magi≈øtrates, by whom he was mo≈øt de≈øervedly condemned to die, and accordingly was burnt in the ≈øight of all the people, not far from the City, in the place which the people commonly call the Jews Sand, becau≈øe they were u≈øed there to interr their dead. And the Images, famous by their hurts and the blood which i≈ø≈øued from them, were tran≈ølated by the hands of Prie≈øts, from that little Church, to the Temple of the Holy Cro≈øs; where to this day that dreadfull blood is to be ≈øeen, and ≈øo religiou≈øly honoured, and many mortals variou≈øly afflicted, making vows to vi≈øit that place, have obtained of the mo≈øt great and good God ≈øuch mercy, as to be cured of their infirmities, and delivered from their afflictions. Theod ‚Ä¢ ricus Gre≈ømundus, legum doctor.

ANd although this impiety and petulancy of furious men is no way to be tolerated, but rather by Laws and puni≈øhments to be repre≈ø≈øed, yet I believe, that, without doubt, the≈øe miracles were wrought by the fraud and impo≈øture of the Devil, to confirm Idolatry in the hearts of men, by the wor≈øhip and adoration of Images, by which they would confine God to dwell in trunks and ≈øtones; which Idolatry was mo≈øt frequent, and to this day is in the Papacy. OTho and Philip contending in War for the Empire, many committed them≈øelves and their goods to the Temple of Saint Govarus, not far from Trevers, becau≈øe the place, as they conceived, was excellently well fenced both by nature and art. GRegory the Great in his Epi≈øtle to Theocti≈øtus, ≈øaith, That a certain Longobard of the Region of Tran≈øpadua, found a golden Key of Peter's, which he ≈øent as a great Pre≈øent to the King of the Longobards, who cau≈øed it to be engraven on his ≈øword; which as ≈øoon as he made u≈øe of, ≈øtruck with Satanical fury, he cut his own throat with it, and dyed the ≈øame hour; Whence had Peter ≈øo pretious a key? and to what purpo≈øe?

UR≈øpergen≈øis & Platina narrant, That John Bapti≈øt appeared to a certain rapacious and ≈øacrilegious fellow, (who came to the Monument of Rothares, King of the Longobards, in a Church built for the repo≈øe of his dead body, and took away all the ornaments wherewith it was buried,) and blamed him for his pre≈øumption to dare to touch his body; who although he had not walked in the ≈øtrict way of truth, yet he had committed him≈øelf to his patronage and protection.
