His dry mouth denudated of fle≈øh and nerves bur≈øt forth into ≈øpeech, an≈øwering, he had been a Gentile, and an Inhabitant of the next Village; and that now his ≈øoul was thru≈øt crowded as remotely deep into the Gulph of infernal perdition, as Heaven is di≈øtant from the Earth; but the incredulous Jews were thrown lower then he, and Hereticks, who endeavoured to pervert with fal≈øhood the revealed truth of Divinity, lower then they. Idem.

CYrillus Hiero≈øolymitanus reporteth, While≈øt in great heavine≈øs he was at prayer, de≈øiring that he might know the condition of the ≈øoul of Ruffus his dead Nephew; he fir≈øt ≈ømell't a mo≈øt heavy ≈øtink, intolerable, if he had not ≈øtopt his no≈øe; and pre≈øently after he ≈øaw Ruffus bound in burning chains, vomiting flames out of his mouth mixt with ≈ømoak, his body all over by rea≈øon of the hea ‚Ä¢ , he ≈øeemed to ≈øuffer within, ≈øparkling fire; and being much affrighted with this ≈øad ≈øpectacle, he earne≈øtly de≈øired to know for what cau≈øe a man, who for his integrity of life was beloved of all men, ≈øhould be judged worthy of ≈øuch puni≈øhments? No fault was objected again≈øt him, (for ought he could find) for which he was ≈øo tormented; but his playing at dice, which he ≈øundry times u≈øing, thought it a light ≈øin, or none at all; and therefore neglected to confe≈øs it to a Prie≈øt. Idem.

A Certain man in the confines of the Province Valeria, before the Prie≈øt Severus came to him to ab≈øolve him of his ≈øinnes, fini≈øhed his cour≈øe pre≈øently; the ≈øame day the Lord looking upon the p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ers and tears of Severus, the young man revived; and being asked what became of his ≈øoul, while≈øt his body was deprived of it? he an≈øwered, That it was ≈ønatched by certain men blacker then Moors, who breathed fire out of their mouthes and no≈øtrils, who carried him through open and rough places; but as he was thus led, being met by young men arrayed in white garments ≈øhining with a glorious light, the Devils were forced to di≈ømi≈øs him, and re≈øtore him to his body; for that they ≈øaid, God had granted
this to Severus, who had by prayer devoutly de≈øired it: Therefore having confe≈ø≈øed his ≈øins to the ≈øame Prie≈øt, and done penance, he dyed the ≈øeventh day again, but more happily then before. Marulus, ex Gregorio.

IN the time that Rome was repaired, after the Goths had wa≈øted it, one, rather wicked then ignoble, being dead, revived. As his friends were bewailing his death, and ≈øaid, Send one to the Church of Lawrence the Martyr, to enquire what Tiburtius the Prie≈øt doth; for I ≈øaw him put upon a pile of wood fiercely burning: I al≈øo ≈øaw another pile, which, with the point of the flame thereof, ≈øeemed to reach Heaven, I heard a voyce breaking out of the flame, which ≈øhewed for whom this puni≈øhment is prepared; which having declared, he was ≈øtricken, not with a Planet, but death it ≈øelf, and again returneth from whence he came; and it appeared, Tiburtius at that in≈øtant exhaled his wretched ≈øoul, whom every man almo≈øt fore-judged, every one dete≈øting his life; for though he was a Prie≈øt, he had nothing belonging to his place be≈øides the figure and name. Idem.

STephen, a Roman, illu≈øtrious in his age, going to Constantinople, fell ≈øick and dyed; and, becau≈øe they who accompanied him; had a de≈øire by rea≈øon of the re≈øpect they owed him, to carry his body to his native Countrey, they enquired for one to imbalm him, by taking out his bowels, and applying Spices and ordinary means to keep the body from putrifying in the Journey: They could find no imbalmer by all their inqui≈øition they made after one, but the next day the dead body was re≈øtored to life, and lived long after, though not ≈øo reformedly as he ought. Wherefore many rebuked him, becau≈øe what horrid ≈øights he had ≈øeen, did not terrifie him from evill-doing. He was wont to tell that he was then carried to Hell, and ≈øaw tho≈øe formidable things which formerly he had heard, and would not believe; and that while he ≈øtood as one guilty before the Tribunal of the Judge, it was commanded that he ≈øhould be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and their mi≈øtake who had convented him, was reprehended; for that it was commanded, that not he, but Stephen the Smith ≈øhould be led thither: The ≈øame hour the Smith departing this life, cau≈øed this to be believed a reall Vi≈øion, and not reputed an idle dream. Marulus, lib. 6. cap. 14.

WIlliam, a boy of fifteen years of age, had a Vi≈øion in the Night, wherein there appeared to him a certain glorious man, who led him to a place of torments, and ≈øeeing men excrutiated after various manners, at la≈øt was brought to the Devill him≈øelf, who in his fiery Man≈øion amid≈øt the flames, ≈øate as a Judge in his Tribunal: pre≈øently a certain ugly ≈øpirit leapt up, accu≈øing the boy; Saith he, I have ever ≈øugge≈øted evill things to this boy, but of tho≈øe ≈øins which he committed lately, he made no mention at all to the Prie≈øt at his confe≈ø≈øion; he that led the boy per≈øwaded him to ≈øign him≈øelf with the ≈øign of the Cro≈øs; which done, all his fear of damnation was taken away. Vincentius, lib. 27. cap. 84.

IT is reported, That in the Sabine Province there was a certain Nunne, who ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved cha≈øtity, but defiled her tongue with fooli≈øh procacity; and when ≈øhe pa≈øt her la≈øt day, being buried in the Church, the Prie≈øt coming into the Church at midnight, ≈øaw her di≈øtended before the Altar, cut through the middle, her higher part burnt with fire, and her lower part left untouched: in the morning therefore telling to his brethren what he ≈øaw, as he looked upon the place in which he ≈øaw her burnt; he ≈øheweth to them the marks which he found in the Marble of the ≈øcorching fire. Gregorius Magnus, lib. 4. Dialog. cap. 50.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Book.

div.head: The Opinions and Arguments of the Sadduces, and Epicures; by which they would prove, that the Angels and Devils do not appear unto Men; Confuted.
div.p: MAny there have been at all times, and in all Ages, which have impugned, and ≈øtifly denied the Apparitions of Devills, Angells, and Spirits: But ≈øome have done it in one ≈øort, and ≈øome in another. For there be ≈øome, who (to ridde them≈øelves altogether from the que≈øtion and di≈øputation, that might be made concerning particular and ≈øpeciall matters, which are often alledged, in regard of the Apparition of Specters) do bend them≈øelves again≈øt them all in generall; That ≈øo by cutting off the root, and undermining the foundation of a Principle well grounded, they may the more ea≈øily cau≈øe the overthrow and downfall of all that which dependeth upon the ≈øame.

They deny therefore, that there are any Angells, or Devils at all: or any Spirits, ≈øevered and ab≈øtracted from a corporall ≈øub≈øtance or body: to the end that by con≈øequence they may infer and conclude, that there are not likewi≈øe any Specters, nor Apparitions of Spirits. Such were the Sadduces, as we may read in the Acts of the Apo≈øtles; and the Epicures; and the greate≈øt part of the Peripateticks; and all ≈øorts of Atheists what≈øoever. Of which la≈øt, there are at this day more huge numbers abounding within this our Realm of France, then would be tolerated. The≈øe men would not ≈øtick to affirm (if they dur≈øt, and were it not for fear of the Magi≈øtrate) that it is free for men to abandon them≈øelves to all kind of iniquity, impiety, and di≈ø≈øolute living: for ≈øo do they murmure, and mumble, when they are alone and by them≈øelves; that there is not either God, or any Spirits at all, good, or evill: nor yet any Hell, where the Souls of men ≈øhould ≈øuffer any pains or puni≈øhment; but that they dye together with the body‚ñ™ And that all what≈øoever is ≈øaid or alledged, touching Hell-torments, is nothing but a vain and ≈øuper≈øtitious toy, and fable; onely to make babes and Children afraid: and to wrap and tye the greate≈øt per≈øons of the World in certain bonds of a Religious ≈øuper≈øtition: for ≈øo are the words of Lucretius, in this behalf. And I do believe, that they do often ≈øay in their hearts, that which Pythagoras, the Samian, is
alledged in Ovid, to have ≈øaid to the Inhabitants of Crotona in Italy,
Why ≈øtand you thus in fear of Styx, and ≈øuch vain dreamings,
Of Manes, and of Spirits, which are nought el≈øe but lea≈øings?

Certainly he that ≈øhould take upon him, to in≈øtruct the≈øe Athie≈øts, ≈øhould but ‚Ä¢ o≈øe his time: becau≈øe they will admit of no rea≈øons, no not of tho≈øe that are meerly naturall. For ≈øeeing they do not believe him which hath the command and rule of Nature, how can they yield any credit or belief unto tho≈øe rea≈øons that are drawn from nature it ≈øelf?

Other per≈øons there are, who, being more religious, and hone≈øter men then tho≈øe former; yet have no le≈ø≈øe denyed the e≈ø≈øence of Angels, Devils, and Spirits: Howbeit they have been of this opinion: that by rea≈øon both of the di≈øtance between them and us, and of the difficulty of appearing in a humane body; they cannot po≈ø≈øibly pre≈øent them≈øelves unto us.

Others al≈øo there have been, who have referred all that which is ≈øpoken of the vi≈øion of Spirits, unto the naturall and perpetuall depravation of the humane ≈øen≈øes. Such were the Sceptikes, and the Aporreticks, who were the followers of the Philo≈øopher Pirrhon: as al≈øo the ≈øecond and third Academy, who held, That the ≈øen≈øes, were they never ≈øo ≈øound, could not imagine any thing, but fal≈øly and untruly.

Again, ≈øome others, with more appearance of rea≈øon then the Scepticks, have affirmed; that abundance of Melancholly, and Choller adu≈øt, Frenzy, Feavers, and the debility or corruption of the ≈øen≈øes (be it naturally, or by accident) in any body, may make them to imagine many things which are not. And they do infer, that ≈øuch as happen to be attainted with the≈øe maladies, do think that they have ≈øeen Devills, and other ≈øuch like Specters. They adde moreover, that the fear, ≈øuper≈øtition, and credulity of many is ≈øuch, that they will mo≈øt commonly ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be drawn into a belief and per≈øwa≈øion of that, which is quite contrary to truth.

To make ≈øhort; Others there be, wi≈øe enough and fine conceited: yet neverthele≈ø≈øe (being great mockers, and incredulous, becau≈øe they them≈øelves did never happen to ≈øee any Vi≈øion, nor have ever heard or touched any ≈øupernaturall thing) they have been of this opinion; that nothing could appear unto men, that exceeded or went beyond the cour≈øe of nature. And of this number, Lucian was one: who (being al≈øo as great an Infidell as any could be) ≈øaid: I believe no part of all the≈øe Apparitions: becau≈øe I onely among≈øt you all did never ≈øee any of them. And if I had ≈øeen of them, a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelves, I would believe them, as you do. Notwith≈øtanding for all this, he oppo≈øed him≈øelf again≈øt all the famous and renowned Philo≈øophers of his time, and held argument again≈øt them, though (as him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øed) they were the chiefe≈øt
and mo≈øt excellent in all kind of knowledg and learning. And he was not a≈øhamed to ≈øtand onely upon his own bare conceit and opinion: impudently maintaining, without any rea≈øon at all, again≈øt them that were as wi≈øe, if not more wi≈øe then him≈øelf, and more in number: that for≈øooth nothing at all, what≈øoever was ≈øaid or alledged touching Specters, ought to be admitted or believed. But what rea≈øons I pray you doth he bring, to confirm his ≈øaying? Truly none at all: but that onely of his own ab≈øolute and uncontrouled authority, he will draw to his incredulity, all others, whom he ≈øeeth to be a≈ø≈øured and ≈øetled in their opinion: Notwith≈øtanding, that they are certainly re≈øolved of the truth, by the exteriour ≈øen≈øes, with which they have perceived and known that to be true, which ≈øo con≈øtantly they do maintain and defend. But how can it po≈ø≈øibly be, that a man ≈øhould think, without any ≈øhew of rea≈øon, by incredulity and mockery onely, to confute and overthrow that, which hath been ever of all men, and in all ages, received and admitted? Certainly, this is the fa≈øhion and gui≈øe of mockers, and ≈øcorners, that that which they cannot deny, nor yet have a will to confe≈ø≈øe, they will find the means to put it off with a je≈øt and laughter: and ≈øo think ≈øecretly to in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the minds and conceits of their hearers; e≈øpecially, ≈øuch as look not, nor have a regard to the truth and ≈øub≈øtance of a thing, but onely to the outward ≈øhadow, and grace of words and glorious ≈øpeeches. Such a ≈øcorner needeth not any great knowledge: becau≈øe it is ≈øufficient for him to be ≈øuperficially skilfull in any thing; ≈øo that he can with a kind of grave and ≈ømiling grace, ≈øhift off the rea≈øons and arguments of tho≈øe, who≈øe knowledge, and learning, is ≈øo exceeding far beyond his, as during his whole life, he will never attain unto the like. Thus did Machiavel carry him≈øelf: who among≈øt the learned, and men of skill and judgment, knew well how to make his profit of his ≈øcoffes, and plea≈øant grace in je≈øting; whereby he would many times ≈øtrike them out of countenance, in the ≈øight of them that heard him; whereas, if he had come to di≈øpute with them, by lively rea≈øons, and ≈øolid Arguments, he would at the very fir≈øt blow have been overthrown and confounded. But in the end he di≈øcovered him≈øelf ≈øufficiently, and was reputed of all men, no other then a Scoffer, and an Athei≈øt, as Paulus Jovius te≈øtifieth of him.

But we will cea≈øe to ≈øpeak any further of him, of Lucian, and of tho≈øe of their humour, and will return to our matter, touching Specters: the which, that we may the better explain (now that we have briefly declared the diver≈øity of opinions, of tho≈øe that in≈øi≈øt upon the contrary) we will an≈øwer unto each of them in order, as they have been propounded. And fir≈øt, as touching the Sadduces, the Epicures, the Peripateticks, we will ≈øeverally an≈øwer their Arguments which they object again≈øt us: Next, we will remove tho≈øe difficulties, which are objected, and ≈øhew how the Angels and Devils may take upon them a body. Afterwards, we will ≈øhew and di≈øcover unto the Scepticks, that the humane ≈øen≈øes are
not ≈øo faulty and uncertain, as they would make men believe. And la≈øt of all, (to the intent we may leave nothing behind) we will not forget to ≈øhew, by what maladies and infirmities the ≈øen≈øes may be hurt and troubled: and the Imaginative power of man wounded and changed: ≈øo as all that which is ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øeen, is meerly fal≈øe and untrue.

To come fir≈øt of all to the Sadduces: It is mo≈øt certain, that of all men they were the mo≈øt gro≈ø≈øe and carnall: and did not believe that any thing was ≈øpirituall: but they did Imagine all to be corporall: becau≈øe they ≈øaid, that the Humane Under≈øtanding doth alwaies work with the Phanta≈øme, and with the thing Imagined. And it appeareth, that in dreaming of any thing what≈øoever, we do alwaies imagine it to be corporall; whereupon they conclude, that all things are corporall; and therefore that even God al≈øo is a corporal Sub≈øtance, which is the greate≈øt ab≈øurdity and Bla≈øphemy that can be imagined in the world. For it we ≈øhould re≈øtrain God into a body, we mu≈øt al≈øo make him ≈øubject to a body: (≈øo ≈øaith Saint John Dama≈øcen) which, in a word, is to re≈øtrain and ≈øhorten the power and omnipotency of God: the which being infinitely above all ≈øub≈øtances, both corporall and incorporall, is not ≈øubject to their Category. The rea≈øon that moved them to believe that God was corporall, was a place of Mo≈øes (for they did not receive nor admit of any Scriptures, but the five Books of Mo≈øes; as ≈øaith Origen) wherein it is written. That God made Mo≈øes to ≈øtay in the Cave of a Rock or Mountain: and putting his hand upon him, did ≈øhew him his hinder parts, not ≈øuffering him to ≈øee his face. And therefore in regard that Mo≈øes attributeth unto God a face, a hand, and other parts, they conclude that God hath a body. Of the ≈øame opinion al≈øo was Tertullian, (as witne≈ø≈øeth Saint Augu≈øtine, writing to Optatus) and the Bogomi ‚Ä¢ es, being certain Heretiques of Bulgary: who thought that God was as we are (≈øo writeth Enthymus): and that from his two eyes, out of his brain did i≈ø≈øue two beams; the one called the Sunne, and the other, the Holy Spirit: which is a mo≈øt bla≈øphemous and intolerable errour.

Now the occa≈øion, why the Sadduces did ≈øo eagerly defend and maintain, that God had a body; was, becau≈øe they would deny all incorporall ≈øub≈øtances: to which effect they thus argued. If God (≈øay they) have created any ≈øub≈øtances, he created them to his own Image and likene≈ø≈øe: and therefore when he made man he ≈øaid, That he made him according to his own Image: ≈øhewing thereby, that he was of a corporall ≈øub≈øtance: becau≈øe that Man, whom he formed to the pattern of his own face, is corporall. And if God have made nothing but what is corporall: It followeth, that the Angells and Devills which are ≈øaid to be Spirits, are nothing but meer fables: and that there be not any Souls, or ≈øpirits ≈øeparated from a corporall ≈øub≈øtance: and by con≈øequence, that the Soul of man is mortall, as the body; and hath no need to be reunited thereunto by the generall re≈øurrection.

But it is ea≈øy to an≈øwer them; by denying plainly, that God is corporall, or hath any body. For albeit, the holy Scripture doth attribute unto God, hands, feet, face, eyes, and other parts of a body: yet this mu≈øt be under≈øtood ≈øpiritually; and by tho≈øe corporall and bodily members, we mu≈øt imagine the ≈øpirituall vertues of God (according as ≈øaith S. Gregory): as, by his eyes, we mu≈øt under≈øtand his fore≈øight and his knowledg; to the which all things are open, and from which nothing is hidden and concealed: By his hand, is meant, his Almighty power and pui≈øsance: By his face, the plenitude and fullne≈ø≈øe of his glory. By his hinder parts, his glory is ≈øhadowed, as under the vail of ≈øome certain form and ≈øimilitude. And whereas they ≈øay, that the Understanding doth work with the Imagination: and that we do Imagine God to be a corporal ≈øub≈øtance: This hath no rea≈øon, nor any appearance of truth at all; but is an errour, common to them, with the Epicures: to the which we will an≈øwer anon. And as touching the Angels: I do greatly marvell how the Saduces can deny the being of them; ≈øeeing that Mo≈øes in many places doth make mention of them, and of their Apparition. We may therefore very well ≈øay of them, that they u≈øe the Books of Mo≈øes, as men u≈øe their Stirrops, in lengthening and ≈øhortning them, at their plea≈øures. This is the rea≈øon, why Ju≈øtine Martyr did not reckon them in the number of the Jews (and that worthily) but reputed them as Hereticks: not allowing them any place in the Jewi≈øh Church, by rea≈øon of the fond and ab≈øurd opinions which they held, not onely of God, but al≈øo of the Angels, Devils, and Souls of men, which they affirmed to be mortall. But as concerning this latter point, we ≈øhall ≈øpeak more hereafter. Let us now con≈øider the Arguments of the Epicures.

The fir≈øt errour of the Epicures is, that God hath a body; as the Saduces did believe likewi≈øe. And their fir≈øt Argument was, That nature it ≈øelf (for≈øooth) did teach and admoni≈øh us, to believe, that both God and all Cele≈øtiall e≈ø≈øences were corporall; for two rea≈øons: The former was, becau≈øe the Gods are not figured in any other, then in a humane form. And the ≈øecond, becau≈øe whether it be in ≈øleeping, or in waking, when we dream or imagine of the Gods, no other form doth pre≈øent it ≈øelf unto our Imaginations, but a humane ≈øhape: And therefore they conclude, that the Gods are in figure like unto men. But unto this Argument, Cicero an≈øwereth ≈øufficiently; That ≈øuch humane ≈øhape, and form, is attributed unto the Gods by the invention of men: and that either it proceedeth from the wi≈øedome of the Antients; who thought thereby they ≈øhould the more ea≈øily draw the ≈øpirits and minds of the ignorant, to the knowledg of ≈øpirituall, and ≈øupernatural things; and that they ≈øhould the ≈øooner bring and reduce them into the way to live well and vertuou≈øly: Or el≈øe, that the ≈øame had its beginning and fir≈øt footing from a blind ≈øuper≈øtition: which doth mo≈øt ea≈øily allure men to adore tho≈øe gods which are portrayed and carved in a form mo≈øt plea≈øing and agreeable unto men; Or el≈øe, that it is but a fiction of Poets and Painters; who have alwaies been audacious
to fain and devi≈øe any thing, rather then that which ≈øhould be according to truth and verity. And this la≈øt point may well ≈øerve to an≈øwer that, which the Epicures ≈øay; that, be it in ≈øleeping, or in waking, the gods do not pre≈øent them≈øelves unto us, in any other then a humane form: For this is certain, that by the portraiture and pictures which we ≈øee of the gods, in tho≈øe forms which are common and familiar unto us; we do imagine (though fal≈øly) that which may re≈øemble unto us, the ≈øame which we have ≈øeen to be painted. In≈øomuch, that Jupiter ≈øeemeth unto us, to have a face and countenance terrible, with his hair black, and hanging backward; as Phidias did engrave him. And Minerva had her eyes blew, or of an azure colour; as Homer de≈øcribeth her. Mercury was painted like a young man, having his eyes alwaies open, as one that was ever waking: with bright yellow hair, and a yellow down upon his chin and cheeks, as if it did but newly begin to frizzle or to curl. Venus had her eyes delicate and wanton, and her locks of Gold yellow. Juno had gro≈ø≈øe and thick eyes, ri≈øing up towards her head, like unto the eyes of an Oxe. And ≈øo generally were the re≈øt of the Gods painted by the Gentiles, in divers forms and fa≈øhions. Notwith≈øtanding, all this proceeded of nothing el≈øe, but from the errour of our Imagination, which ≈øuffereth it ≈øelf to be deceived and ≈øeduced, by the painting, which imprinted in it a kind of fal≈øe notion. I ≈øay, a notion: becau≈øe the ignorant common ≈øort of people, is per≈øwaded of the ≈øame, and ≈øuffereth it to take place in their mind, or Under≈øtanding: which is as ea≈øy al≈øo to be deceived, as is their Imagination. But a man of Wi≈øedome and Judgment, (who hath his under≈øtanding more clear and open) is not ea≈øily therewithall ≈øeduced: but notwith≈øtanding all paintings and fictions, his Intellect, or under≈øtanding power pierceth through the imagination (as the Sun pierceth or ≈øhineth through the Clouds): and ≈øpreading it ≈øelf, with her light, doth ea≈øily believe in a ≈øpirituall manner, that God and the Angels are Spiritual.

The ≈øecond Argument of the Epicures, touching the humane body of God; was, that God took upon him that form, which was, or could be imagined, to be the mo≈øt beautifull in the whole World. And they ≈øay, that the humane form, or ≈øhape, is of all others, the mo≈øt goodly and excellent: And therefore we ought to think that God is carnall and corporall, as men are. Hereunto needeth no an≈øwer to be made: becau≈øe the con≈øequence of their Argument is not good: viz. That God ≈øhould retain unto him≈øelf the figure of a man, becau≈øe the ≈øame is the mo≈øt excellent of all other creatures in the World. For the Divinity of God, neither is, nor can be, in any corporal ≈øub≈øtance: but it is an incorporeall and ≈øpirituall e≈ø≈øence, which hath nothing common with that ≈øub≈øtance which is proper unto the≈øe Earthly Creatures.

The third and la≈øt Argument of the≈øe Philo≈øophers, is a Gradation or heaping up of Syllogi≈øms: which kind of Argument, the
Greeks call a Sorites: and they frame it in this ≈øort; It is held and confe≈ø≈øed of all, that God, and all other cele≈øtiall powers, are exceedingly happy: But no per≈øon can be happy, without vertue: And vertue cannot be pre≈øent in any, without rea≈øon: and rea≈øon can be in none, but in the figure and ≈øhape of man. Therefore it mu≈øt be granted, that the Gods, which have the u≈øe of rea≈øon, have the form of man al≈øo. But the whole frame of this Argument may ≈øoon and ea≈øily be di≈ø≈øolved, by denying, that rea≈øon can be in no other, then in a humane ≈øhape: For both God and the Angels, who have a divine and ≈øpirituall under≈øtanding, have the u≈øe of rea≈øon, notwith≈øtanding, that they be not of a corporall ≈øub≈øtance. And rea≈øon in man, commeth not of the humane body: but from the Soul of man, which is Spiritual and Divine, made unto the likene≈ø≈øe of God, and capable of rea≈øon, of prudence, and of Wi≈øedome.

Now, whereas it might be objected to the Epicures; That in making their Gods to have a humane body, they do therein make them ≈øubject to death and di≈ø≈øipation. To avoid this ab≈øurdity, they do tumble into a greater; affirming, that their body is as a body; and their bloud, as bloud; not having any thing, but the lineaments and proportion of a man, and being exempted from all cra≈ø≈øitude and thickne≈ø≈øe: which in a word, is as much as to ≈øay, that their gods were rather Idols of men, then very men; and rather framed by the pattern of men, then as men in truth and ≈øub≈øtance: which is a thing the mo≈øt ridiculous that can be imagined.

But, will ≈øome ≈øay, to what purpo≈øe ≈øerveth all this, touching our matter of Specters? I have ≈øaid before, that the Sadduces did maintain God to have a body, to the end they might the better deny the appearing of Specters; which are ≈øub≈øtances without a body. Al≈øo the Epicures made their Gods to have bodies; that ≈øo they might hold them in the Heavens idle, and doing nothing: and by con≈øequence might deny their Apparition upon Earth. For as touching Devils or Spirits, they believed there were not any: but did confound them all in the number of their Gods. And, that they did but make a je≈øt of Specters, appeareth by the ≈øpeech of Ca≈øsius in Plutarch: and in that that Cel≈øus (half an Epicure) writing again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, did deny them flatly and ab≈øolutely, (as is to be ≈øeen in Origen, who hath an≈øwered him) and did reprove the Chri≈øtians, in that they would allow of any powers, or Spirits, contrary to the gods: ≈øuppo≈øing (according to his own ≈øaying, and opinion) that there were no Devills. Be≈øides that, he made a mock and a je≈øt of Angels, and of the Re≈øurrection of the body: and generally of all tho≈øe Apparitions, which were made, both in the Old and New Te≈øtament.

And now that we ≈øpeak of contrary powers, it putteth me in remembrance of a ≈øpeech of Plutarch, who reproveth Chry≈øippus, for that in this univer≈øall body of the World, ≈øo well ordained and framed, he ≈øhould grant ≈øo great an inconvenience, (to wit) that there ≈øhould be a kind of Devills afflicting and tormenting men, to the di≈øturbance of the concord and harmony of the World:
Which being well ordained by the Author and maker thereof, ought not to be thought to bear or ≈øu≈øtain any thing which ≈øhould be incommodious to it ≈øelf; and by lap≈øe, and continuance of time, ≈øhould work the confu≈øion and de≈øtruction of the ≈øame. But it ≈øeemeth, that Plutarch reprehended Chry≈øippus, upon a de≈øire and humour of contradiction, rather then moved upon any ju≈øt cau≈øe, or matter of truth. For the Devills do not work any dammage or inconvenience to the World, being bridled and re≈øtrained by the hand and power of God. And if they do torment men, or tempt them, it is to exerci≈øe them, or to manife≈øt the glory and Ju≈øtice of God; of the which they are ≈øometimes made the executioners. And as in each Common-Wealth, well in≈øtituted there be executioners ordained, for the puni≈øhment of Malefactors, and ≈øuch as trouble and di≈øturb the publick peace, and good of the Common-Weal, and yet the univer≈øal body of the Common-weal is not thereby offended, or endamaged: but to the contrary, rather it receiveth much more profit and commodity. Even ≈øo God hath placed, and left here below in this World, Devils and wicked Spirits, to be as tormenters and executioners to wicked men: that ≈øo his Ju≈øtice might ≈øhine the more glorious, to the comfort of the godly, and of his Elect, that live in the love and fear of him.

But to come again unto the Epicures: It is mo≈øt certain, that they were no other, then the followers of nature: and that onely ≈øo far as things did fall under their outward ≈øen≈øes. And if one ≈øhould alledge unto them, that any Specters, Images, and Vi≈øions, had pre≈øented them≈øelves; they would refer the ≈øame, for the mo≈øt part, to the concour≈øe and perpetuall flux of their Atomes: or to ≈øome other like rea≈øons; the which we hold it not ami≈ø≈øe to di≈øcover and decipher at large, as we have drawn them out of Cicero, or of Lucretius. All Images (≈øay they) which do externally pre≈øent them≈øelves unto our ≈øen≈øes, either they are vi≈øible, or invi≈øible; If they be Invi≈øible, either they are created in the Ayre, or in our own minds and conceits. As touching tho≈øe made in the Ayre; it is not any ≈øtrange thing, or abhorring from rea≈øon, that in the ≈øame ≈øhould be engendred certain voices; like as we ≈øee it is naturall, that cold commeth from the Rivers; ebbing and flowing, from the Sea; and heat, from the Sun. And it may be, that ≈øome voice, being ≈øpread abroad within the Valleys, doth not onely rebound back again, to the place from whence it came; but doth dilate and ≈øcatter it ≈øelf here and there, throughout the Ayre, as do the ≈øparks that mount up from the fire. So that for one voice there are many engendred; which running through the empty Ayre, do enter within the Ears of tho≈øe, that knew nothing of the naturall voice; and do put them into a mi≈øconceit, and fond opinion, that they have heard either ≈øome of the Fayries, or Satyres, or Nymphes, playing and ≈øporting amid≈øt the Woods.

As concerning tho≈øe that are bred in the mind; They ≈øay, that for the innumerable cour≈øe of Atomes; all what≈øoever we do dream or think of, commeth incontinently into the ≈øpirit or mind, and ≈øometimes pa≈ø≈øeth by Vi≈øions and Images into the bodily Eyes.

But if the Images be vi≈øible; either they are reverberated and beaten back, from the Chrystall and tran≈øparant Ayre, exceeding clear in her ≈øuperficies? or they come of the Spoyls and ≈øcales of naturall things. Touching the Ayre; That it may of it ≈øelf ca≈øt ≈øome kind of Image, having power to appear, they prove it in this ≈øort; All Ayre that is Chry≈øtalline or tran≈øparent, hath a kind of refraction, as appeareth by the mirrour (whereof Looking Gla≈ø≈øes are made and poli≈øhed) and by the water, and by a thick and darkned Ayre. And this do the Catopticks them≈øelves teach in their principles; Now (by the compari≈øon and ≈øimilitude of the mirror, and the water) all Ayre which hath a refraction, doth of it ≈øelf yield ≈øome certain form. And therefore it is not any thing ≈øtrange if in an Ayre a man may ≈øee certain forms and Images. And they do bring al≈øo this compari≈øon. Even as the Tape≈øtry hangings in a Theater, or a large wide Hall, do ca≈øt abroad round about, their naturall colour, where they find an Ayre oppo≈øed again≈øt them; and the more that the beams of the Sun do beat or ≈øhine upon them, the more bright and ≈øhining lu≈øtre they carry with them; and ≈øeem to have ca≈øt off and left their colour, in the ≈øame place, which is directly in oppo≈øition again≈øt them; So is it mo≈øt certain, that the Ayre may of it ≈øelf ca≈øt abroad certain forms and figures; the which look by how much the more they be made clear, by the light which doth bring and tye them to our object, ≈øo much the more comprehen≈øible ≈øhall they be unto our ≈øight.

In brief, concerning the ≈øpoils and ≈øcales ca≈øt from natural things, of which, in their opinion, Images ≈øhould be engendred. They do make this argument; The Caterpillars (≈øay they) do leave their ≈øpoils in the hedges or bu≈øhes, like unto them≈øelves; ≈øo do the Serpents among the thorns or ≈øtones; and the little creatures, at the time of their birth, do leave behind them their after-burthen; which is a little thin and ≈ølender skin, which they bring with them, from their dammes belly. Why therefore may there not be left or ca≈øt from the bodyes of naturall things, certain thin and ≈øubtill forms, or Images, proceeding from them as well, as a little skin and the after-burthen doth remain of the ≈øuperfluity of little Creatures? But all the≈øe Arguments may very ea≈øily be di≈ø≈øolved.

And fir≈øt, as touching the voyces, which, they ≈øay, may ≈øimply be created of the Ayre; I will not deny that. For it is mo≈øt certain, that the voice, is a certain beating and concu≈øsion of the Ayre, which falleth under the ≈øen≈øe of hearing, (as is affirmed by the Grammarians.) And the matter of the voice (as ≈øaith Galen) is the breath, and re≈øpiration of the Lungs; but the form thereof is the Ayre, without the which, neither can it be under≈øtood, nor can it be called a voice. Be≈øides I will not deny, but that the ≈øounds are rai≈øed within the empty Ayre, be it either by the winds, or by ≈øome other externall cau≈øe. But to ≈øay, that the voices, and the ≈øounds are naturall and adherent to the Ayre, as the Tide to the Sea; and coldne≈ø≈øe to the Rivers; and heat to the Sun: It would then follow, that
without any externall cau≈øe at all, both the voice, and the ≈øen≈øes ≈øhould be treated in the Ayre, and ≈øhould perpetually adhere unto the Ayre, as the Tide doth to the Sea; and cold to the waters; and heat unto the Sun. But ≈øo it is, that the winds are not alwaies in the Ayre: and the ≈øounds and voices are external things, comming into the Ayre, by the means of ≈øome other ≈øubject; the which is nothing to neither in the Sea, nor in the Rivers, nor in the Sun: becau≈øe that in the Seas the Tide; and cold in the waters; and heat in the Sun, are un≈øeparably, and continually. And there is great difference between Accidents that are Separable, and tho≈øe that are In≈øeparable. For the ≈øeparable Accident as the Voyces and the Sounds in the Ayre, may be ab≈øtracted, and drawn from the ≈øub≈øtance of the Ayre, and yet the Ayre ≈øhall neither peri≈øh, nor be the ≈øooner altered thereby; But ebbing and flowing cannot be taken from the Sea, but the nature thereof mu≈øt needs be changed; Nor can the heat be ≈øeparated from the Sun, but that he mu≈øt then lo≈øe his light; Neither can the cold be ≈øevered from the Rivers, but that the quality and nature of the water mu≈øt be changed; which cannot po≈ø≈øibly be; becau≈øe naturally water is cold. And the≈øe three Accidents, are in≈øeparably knit to tho≈øe three ≈øub≈øtances, no le≈ø≈øe, then blackne≈ø≈øe is to the Raven, and whitene≈ø≈øe to the Swan. Moreover, it is a far greater foolery, to ≈øay, that of voices articulated and knit together, the voices them≈øelves ≈øhould be bred and engendred in the Ayre: For that is not onely again≈øt the nature of the Ayre, but again≈øt all order e≈øtabli≈øhed in the World. Neither is it to any purpo≈øe, to alledge for an in≈øtance, the voice of an Eccho: the which being carried in the Ayre, doth ≈øpread it ≈øelf, and ≈øcattereth (as a ≈øpark from the fire) here and there, not onely towards the party that made and di≈øper≈øed the ≈øound, but to ≈øome other places likewi≈øe. For the voice of the Eccho, is engendred of the voice of the party, and not of the Ayre, and is di≈øper≈øed (as them≈øelves confe≈ø≈øe) by the ≈øpeech of the man, from whom it took its Originall and fir≈øt beginning. Neither will I ea≈øily grant unto them, that the voice of the Eccho doth di≈øper≈øe it ≈øelf on all ≈øides, without lo≈øing it ≈øelf, or being extingui≈øhed. For it is a thing very notorious, and ≈øufficiently proved, that if the Eccho be di≈øper≈øed into another place, then that from whence it fir≈øt received her voice, ≈øhe is no more di≈øcerned or under≈øtood as the voice of a man, but onely as a confu≈øed and uncertain ≈øound; which ranging through the Vallies, cannot be di≈øcerned, but onely for a re≈øounding noi≈øe, and not otherwi≈øe. Now as concerning tho≈øe Images, or ≈øimilitudes, which the Epicures alledg to be created in the thought or conceit: ≈øaying, that the mind of man doth refer unto the eyes, what≈øoever it dreameth, or thinketh on; and that by means of the abundance or concour≈øe of the Atomes. I do make them the ≈øame an≈øwer, which Cicero yielded them: that if the mind and the eyes do ≈øo ≈øymbolize and agree together in operations, that what≈øoever the mind ≈øhall imagine and conceive, the eye may pre≈øently ≈øee; It mu≈øt needs then follow, that ≈øome things ≈øhall pre≈øent them≈øelves
to our eyes and ≈øight, which never were in being, nor ever can be. For I may dream, or think of a Scylla, a Chimera, a Hippocentaure, and ≈øuch like conceited fictions, which never were, nor can be. And I may fain unto my ≈øelf, in my mind, ≈øtrange Mon≈øters, and Anticks; ≈øuch as Painters do many times make, which neither are things, nor can po≈ø≈øibly be. To be ≈øhort, if this Argument of the Epicures were true; it mu≈øt needs be, that all things what≈øoever the mind pre≈øenteth, ≈øhould be of a certainty: and they ≈øhould fall ≈øo ≈øubject to our ≈øight, as we might plainly and ≈øen≈øibly ≈øee them: the which is the greate≈øt folly, that can po≈ø≈øibly be imagined. Neither can they defend them≈øelves with the continuall concour≈øe of their Atomes: which (they ≈øay) do unce≈ø≈øantly bring certain Images into the mind, and into the eyes of men. For, be it, that we ≈øhould confe≈ø≈øe, that their Atomes do ≈ølide into the mind of man: how can they conclude thereof, that they de≈øcend into the ≈øight; nay, how can they de≈øcend; but that even by their own rea≈øons, their ignorance and ≈øotti≈øhne≈ø≈øe may be di≈øcovered. For, if their Atomes do enter into the mind, it mu≈øt needs be then by that means, that they be Invi≈øible; and that they do fly up and down very clo≈øely, and ≈øubtilly (as the very word doth al≈øo import.) Now if they fly invi≈øibly in the mind; how can they of them≈øelves ≈øo readily make any thing vi≈øible and apt to be ≈øeen? Certainly, to make their Atomes vi≈øible and corporall, there mu≈øt be of nece≈ø≈øity, beforehand, a great concurrence and huge heap of them drawn together; which cannot be ≈øuddenly done, but will require a great time. Now in the mean while that the≈øe Invi≈øible Atomes ≈øhall be a gathering, and getting together into the mind, they will be flitting and flying away ≈øome other where, as ≈øoon as the mind (which never retaineth one thing very long) hath put them out of remembrance. So that by this means they have not any lea≈øure to form them≈øelves vi≈øible to the eyes of the body; but they return back again, even as they came at fir≈øt, Invi≈øible.

Now let us proceed, and pa≈ø≈øe on to tho≈øe Images, which (≈øay the Epicures) are reverberated from the Ayre, being clear and tran≈øparant in her ≈øuperficies. I do agree with them, that the Catoptike, that is to ≈øay, the Speculative, (being one of the kinds of the Art Optike) doth hold, that the refraction, which is made of forms (be it either in a mirrour in the Ayre, or in the water) commeth either of the den≈øity and thickne≈ø≈øe of the mirrour, poli≈øhed and made bright, the which keepeth ≈øight, that it doth not di≈øper≈øe and ≈øcatter it ≈øelf: whereas otherwi≈øe, if the mirrour were tran≈øparent, or had any pores, whereby one might ≈øee through it, the ≈øight would di≈øper≈øe and ≈øcatter it ≈øelf abroad: Or el≈øe it commeth of the thickne≈ø≈øe of the Ayre next adjoyning: or of the humid and moi≈øt concretion of the Water, which ≈øtayeth and limiteth the beams of the eye≈øight. And that is the rea≈øon, why one may a≈øwell ≈øee his vi≈øage in the water, as in a mirrour or looking-gla≈ø≈øe; and ≈øo al≈øo in the water of the Sea, when it is not troubled nor to≈ø≈øed with the
Winds, but re≈øteth calm and quiet; which Virgil te≈øtifieth in the≈øe Ver≈øes:
Of late (upon the ≈øhore) I ≈øtood, my ≈øelf beholding
In waters of the Sea, no stormy winds then ≈øtirring.

But what will they infer of this, which every man will confe≈ø≈øe to be true and infallible? So it is, (≈øay they) that the Ayre being clear in her Superficies (like as doth the mirrour or looking Gla≈ø≈øe); ≈øo will it yield of it ≈øelf, ≈øome form or figure. Let this al≈øo be granted them: And what of that? For≈øooth they conclude, that therefore in the Ayre, a man may ≈øee figures and Images. But who ≈øeeth not, that this conclu≈øion is ridiculous, and Sophi≈øticall: For it doth not an≈øwer to the terms of their propo≈øition: but ≈øimply carrieth away the Subject, without ≈øpeaking of that, which is thereunto attributed, and which is the knot of the whole que≈øtion. But I would know of the Epicures, how they can prove unto us, that by their Atomes the Ayre may naturally engender forms and Images of them≈øelves, which ≈øhould be vi≈øible: and, which ≈øhould be moving and living, as the Specters are. I do a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf, that they have not any arguments ≈øo good, but they may as ea≈øily be di≈ø≈øolved and avoided, as was the former. But they will ≈øay, perhaps; that we ≈øee often in the Ayre Comets, Fiery Flames, and other Prodigies. True; this I will not deny; but the≈øe things (which they ≈øay are ≈øeen in the Ayre) do not take their originall neither of their Atomes, nor of the Ayre; but are engendred of the vapours dryed up from the Earth, as it is well known by the writings of good Philo≈øophers. And the Ayre is ≈øu≈øceptible and capable of them, by rea≈øon of ≈øome emptine≈ø≈øe in it; which doth ea≈øily yield and give place, and receiveth that which is ≈øent unto it from below. Be≈øides it is very evident, that ≈øuch figures and Images as are ≈øeen in the Ayre, have not any life in them, as have the true Specters; the which al≈øo (the Epicures ought to ≈øhew by good rea≈øons) to be carried to and fro, and to move them≈øelves in the Ayre. For if they had attributed motion and ≈øtirring unto Specters; and had proved, that naturally, without having any Soul or life, they might notwith≈øtanding be ≈øeen wandring, and running hither and thither in our form, or in any other; and that they are not onely to be ≈øeen in all parts of the Ayre, but in all other places what≈øoever; then this might have ≈øtood them in great ≈øtead, to have impugned the Apparition of Specters, ≈øupernaturally, or again≈øt nature.

Moreover, if they will affirm, that the tran≈øparent and thick Ayre, receiving our figure by refraction, doth move it ≈øelf as we do; and doth live and change from place to place, as we do; then mu≈øt they al≈øo prove unto us, that the ≈øame ≈øhould be a Specter; and not the Image of the object oppo≈øed thereunto, the which vani≈øheth away a≈ø≈øoon as the ≈øame doth ab≈øent it ≈øelf from it.

And ≈øeeing we are now in the di≈øcour≈øe of Images, formed in a thick Ayre: It is to be under≈øtood, that their nature is to appear either by the refraction of our own naturall and proper form, or by reflexion. As touching their appearance by refraction, we have already ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently: But as concerning tho≈øe which are by reflexion; It is mo≈øt certain, that their property is to appear by another form then ours: namely, of ≈øome light≈øome body, which groweth into the thick and gro≈ø≈øe Ayre, in the humid and moi≈øt concretion of the ≈øame; or into the Gla≈ø≈øe of a mirrour, making a reflexion of that thing which is reverberated and beaten back again into our ≈øight. Thus by way of reflexion may a man ≈øee within a looking-Gla≈ø≈øe, tho≈øe men which are walking and marching in the ≈øtreets. And ≈øometimes a man ≈øhall think that men are walking near the walls of his Chamber: which notwith≈øtanding is nothing ≈øo; but that onely there is a reflexion of tho≈øe per≈øons whom we ≈øee aloof, walking and going up and down. So likewi≈øe by way of reflexion, may a man ≈øee in the Heavens ≈øometimes a ≈øecond Sunne, the Image of the true Sun; and ≈øo likewi≈øe of the Rainbow. Howbeit that this latter (as Ari≈øtotle would have it) is not any reflexion but a relation of the A≈øpect unto our eye-≈øight. But under his correction, that is not ≈øo: For if the Rainbow in the Heavens do not yield a reflexion to our ≈øight, it would not be ≈øeen in the water, or in a looking Gla≈ø≈øe, as it is, and as daily experience ≈øheweth us. And this al≈øo may ≈øerve for a ≈øolution to that Argument of the Epicures, who by Compari≈øon of the clothes of Tapi≈øtry, that imprint their colours in the wall oppo≈øed, would prove, that the Ayre may al≈øo ca≈øt any form or Image of it ≈øelf. For the colours of the Rainbow, and of Tapi≈øtry-hangings, are for the mo≈øt part lively colours, as Azure or Sky-colour, red, carnation, and green; all which do naturally ca≈øt a great lu≈øtre, which may ea≈øily yield an impre≈ø≈øion upon any ≈øolid thing, and may reflect unto our eyes. And yet neverthele≈ø≈øe, I ≈øee not how this can be a good argument, to ≈øhew that the Ayre can engender forms or figures; which may refer them≈øelves to the eyes, as Specters, and not rather, as Colours.

La≈øt of all, touching that which the Epicures affirm; how, of the bodies of things do i≈ø≈øue and remain certain Spoils: The ≈øame hath not any foundation upon naturall rea≈øon, or upon any apparance of truth. For, is there any likelihood, or probability, that if the creatures do leave behind them their after-burthens, or other ≈øuch ≈øpoils, bereaved from them, in the places where they have been: That therefore the bodies (be they dead, or be they alive) do leave an Image, or impre≈ø≈øion of them≈øelves, in their ab≈øence, after they are departed from tho≈øe places? It is mo≈øt certain, that the bodies of any creatures, have not any thing in them, which either in their life-time, or after that their ≈øub≈øtance is peri≈øhed, can be ab≈øtracted or ≈øeparated from them. For otherwi≈øe, of one body there ≈øhould be two made; which were a ≈øtrange thing, and altogether abhorring from nature. And were not
much different, either from the Fables of the Poets, who of a dead body, made the ab≈øtraction of a ≈øhadow, which they called the Image and Idoll thereof, (as is affirmed, both by Sergius, and Lucian and the Commentator upon Homer) or el≈øe from tho≈øe fabulous and idle dreams of the Rabbins, and Talmudi≈øts, which had their Nephes, as ≈øaith the Author of Zoar. But the truth is, that tho≈øe Creatures which do u≈øe to ca≈øt their ≈øpoils from them, do leave no other then a thin ≈ølender skin, which being ≈øuperfluous, is no more remaining or abiding with the body: Howbeit, that it commeth from the body; as appeareth both by the after-burthens of all creatures (wherein the young ones being wrapped and enfolded in the bellies of their dams, yet in comming from thence, do ea≈øily and naturally ca≈øt them off) as al≈øo by the ≈øpoils of the Serpent, or Snake, and by the skins of the Silk-worms, and the Caterpillars; the which ≈øuperfluities, are drawn and ca≈øt off particularly from the≈øe bea≈øts or Creatures, as a mark to the one, to wit, the Silk-worms, and Caterpillars, that they do change from their former ≈øtate, and to the other, namely the Serpents, to ≈øhew the poi≈øons and ill hearbs and ≈øeeds, which they have eaten all the Winter, according as Virgil writeth of them.

The≈øe Arguments being thus fini≈øhed: Let us now come to that which the Epicures affirm to be the cau≈øe why any ≈øhould be touched and attained with fear; when they ≈øee ≈øuch Images and figures, which they affirm naturally to flit and fly up and down. We (≈øay they) are affected and altered, according to the things which we ≈øee, and which are next unto us. As for example; we perceive, I know not what, ≈øalt humour being near the Sea; and in touching of Wormwood, and of Rue, we find a kind of bitterne≈ø≈øe: and when we are near a Smith, we feel our teeth to gna≈øh, and to be ≈øet on edge, at the noi≈øe of his File, or Saw, wherewith he worketh. So likewi≈øe, when the≈øe Images and figures do pre≈øent them≈øelves unto us, we cannot po≈ø≈øibly abide nor ≈øuffer them; but we find our ≈øelves altered and changed in our under≈øtanding: howbeit ≈øome more then other ≈øome. For like as there be certain ≈øeeds within the eyes of Cocks, which ≈øhining and ≈øhooting into the eyes of the Lions, do ≈øo ≈øtrike and pierce their eye-lids, and do inflict upon them ≈øuch pain and grief, that they are con≈øtrained to fly from them, being not able to abide or endure the ≈øight of the Cock; So are there ≈øome men, who have their ≈øen≈øes ≈øo apprehen≈øive and ≈øubtill, that they cannot hold from being afraid, when they ≈øee ≈øuch vain Images and figures before them.

But hereunto we mu≈øt give them this an≈øwer; that the fear which men have by the ≈øight of Specters or Spirits, commeth in regard that the things are unaccu≈øtomed and admirable to the bodily ≈øen≈øes; and not from any ≈øecret ≈øeeds, which are contrary to our nature, and much le≈ø≈øe from any natural pa≈ø≈øion; ≈øuch as that is, wherewith men are touched, that abide near the Sea, or tho≈øe that ≈øee Rue or Wormwood, or do hear the noi≈øe of a Smiths file or ≈øaw. For if it were of any natural pa≈ø≈øion that this fear proceeded; then would
not the party terrified, be ≈øo confounded and a≈øtoni≈øhed even in the very powers of the Soul, as it is commonly ≈øeen that men are, at the ≈øight of Specters or Spirits: but rather he ≈øhould be onely moved by a certain Antipathy or abomination (as Pomponatius calleth it) and would onely abhor and fly from that which he ≈øo feareth. Be≈øides, things that are ≈øupernatural, do much more touch the ≈øen≈øes of man, then tho≈øe things do, which are natural. Neither are they to be compared with ≈øuch things, as having a natural cau≈øe (howbeit ≈øecret) do happen to be ≈øeen daily and ordinarily. Now I ≈øay, that the cau≈øe of the≈øe things (though naturall) is ≈øecret: For Alexander Aphrodi≈øe ‚Ä¢ s, ≈øpeaking of the noi≈øe of the File, and how it ≈øetteth the teeth on edge, with other things of like nature, ≈øaith, that Nature hath re≈øerved the rea≈øon thereof unto her own ≈øecret knowledg, not being willing to impart the cau≈øe thereof unto men. The like may be affirmed of the greate≈øt part of tho≈øe Antipathies, which being concealed from men, yet cannot come of any ≈øecret ≈øeeds, that are contrary or enemies to nature (as the Epicures dote) but are hidden in the ≈øecret Magazin or Storehou≈øe of Nature, which hath not revealed or laid the ≈øame open unto any per≈øon. Who can tell the rea≈øon why the Conciliatour, otherwi≈øe called Peter de Albano, did abhor milk? Why Horace, and Jaques de Furly could not abide Garlike? nor Cardan could away with Egs. And why that Gentleman of Ga≈øcoigne (of whom Julius Cae≈øar Scaliger ≈øpeaketh) could not abide the ≈øound of a Violl? And of this latter in Cardan you may read the Hi≈øtory. The Phy≈øitian Scaliger writeth, how he him≈øelf knew a Gentleman, his neighbour, which had in him ≈øuch an Antipathy at the ≈øound of a Violl, that as ≈øoon as ever he heard it (were he in any company, even of the be≈øt ≈øort, and that either at Table, or el≈øewhere) he was con≈øtrained to for≈øake the place, and to go away to make water.

Now it happened, that certain Gentlemen having of a long time perceived and known this ≈øtrange nature and di≈øpo≈øition in him, did one day invite this Gentleman to dine with them; and having provided and ≈øuborned a certain Min≈øtrel of purpo≈øe, they cau≈øed him to be kept clo≈øe till the appointed dinner time, when being ≈øet at Table, they had ≈øo placed the Gent. in the mid≈øt of them, as it was not po≈ø≈øible for him to get forth. Now as they were in the mid≈øt of their dinner, in came the Fidler, and began to ≈øtrike up his Violl near unto the Gent. he that never heard the ≈øound of that in≈øtrument, but was pre≈øently taken with an extream de≈øire to pi≈ø≈øe, grew into an exceeding great pain: for being not able to get from the Table, nor daring to lay open his imperfection to the whole company; the poor man ≈øhewed by the often change of his countenance, in what pitiful ca≈øe and pain he was. But in the end he was con≈øtrained to yield to the pre≈øent mi≈øchief, and to reveal his imperfection. He that ≈øhould undertake to ≈øearch and find out the cau≈øe of this ≈øo admirable an Antipathy, I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf he ≈øhould be as long a time about it, as was Ari≈øtotle in ≈øeeking out the cau≈øe of the Flowing and Ebbing of the Seas, (whereof have written Gregory Nazianzen,
Ju≈øtine Martyr, Eu≈øebius, and others) and yet he could never learn the certain cau≈øe thereof.

But as touching the rea≈øon why the Lion doth fly from the Cock: It commeth not from any ≈øeeds that lye hidden within the eyes of the Cock, and which from thence, ≈øhould ≈øtrike into the eyes, and hurt the ≈øight of the Lion: but it is by a kind of Antipathy, whereof we have formerly ≈øpoken. By which al≈øo the Elephant doth fly from the Hogge, and the Hor≈øe from the Stone Taraxippe; Or el≈øe it is, for that the Cock and the Lion, partaking both of them of the nature of the Sun (but the Cock more then the Lion;) it happeneth that the Lion perceiving it, doth pre≈øently fly from him; as the valiant Hector is ≈øaid to fly before Achilles, who was more brave and more warlike then he. Or el≈øe it is becau≈øe the Cock, being a cele≈øtiall fowl, and the Lion a terre≈øtriall Creature, and of a g ‚Ä¢ o≈ø≈øer matter (having the ≈øpirits more ≈øen≈øitive and brutal then the other) doth therefore by nature yield and give place, to that which is more excellent. And this rea≈øon ≈øeemeth unto me in ≈øome ≈øort allowable: the rather, for that tho≈øe Devils which are of a more materiall and terre≈øtrial nature, and be called Devils of the Sun, do fly the voice of the Cock, as well as the Lion (as P≈øellus teacheth us). And thus, in my opinion, you ≈øee ≈øufficiently how all the Arguments and fooli≈øh dreams and fancies of the Epicures, may be ≈øoon an≈øwered, and ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolved.

div.head: The Arguments of tho≈øe which deny that the Angells and Devils can take unto them a body; Confuted.
div.p: THey which do deny that the Angels and Devills can take unto them a body, do not aim at the mark to deny their e≈ø≈øence, (as do the Sadduces:) but they do it onely to di≈øprove and impugne their Apparition. For it is a good con≈øequent; if the Angels and Devils take not upon them any body, then can they not appear: And if one ≈øhould reply unto them and ≈øay; That in our ≈øpirit and under≈øtanding the Angels and Devills may give ≈øome ≈øhew and token of their pre≈øence. To this they have their exception ready: That things ≈øpirituall and intelligible and all ≈øorts of Intelligences, do repre≈øent them≈øelves by things that are ≈øen≈øible. We will ≈øee therefore by what rea≈øons they endeavour to prove, that an Angell or a Devill cannot take a body unto them.

No Body (≈øay they,) can be united to an incorporal ≈øub≈øtance, but onely that it may have an e≈ø≈øence and a motion by the means of that ≈øub≈øtance. But the Angells and Devils cannot have a body united in regard of any e≈ø≈øence: for in ≈øo doing we mu≈øt conclude, that their bodies ≈øhould be naturally united unto them, which is altogether untrue; and therefore it remaineth that they cannot be united unto a body, but onely in regard of the motion: which is a rea≈øon of no ≈øufficiency for the approving of their opinion. For thereof would follow an ab≈øurdity in regard of the Angels: to wit, That they might take all tho≈øe bodies that are moved by them, which is a very great and gro≈ø≈øe errour. For the Angell did move the tongue of Balaams A≈ø≈øe: and yet he entred not in his tongue. And therefore it cannot be ≈øaid that an Angell or a Devil, can take a body unto them.

To this Argument I an≈øwer, That true it is, that an Angel and a Devill, cannot (to ≈øpeak properly) take unto them every body that is moved: For to take a body ≈øignifieth to adhere unto the body. Now the Angels and the Devils do take unto them a body, not to unite it to their nature, and to incorporate it together with their e≈ø≈øence: as he that taketh any kind of meat for ≈øu≈øtenance: much le≈ø≈øe to unite the ≈øame to their per≈øon: as the Son of God took upon him the humane nature: But they do it onely that they may vi≈øibly repre≈øent them≈øelves unto the fight of men. And in this ≈øort
the Angels and Devils are ≈øaid to take a body, ≈øuch as is apt and fit for their Apparition, as appeareth by the Authority of Denis Ariopagyte, "who writeth, that by the corporal forms the properties of "Angels are known and di≈øcerned.

Again they ≈øay, that if the Angels and Devils‚ñ™ do take a body, it is not for any nece≈ø≈øity that they have, but onely to in≈øtruct and exhort us to live well, as do the Angels; or to deceive and de≈øtroy us, as do the Devils. Now both to the one and the other, the imaginary Vi≈øion, or the tentation is ≈øufficient; and therefore it ≈øeemeth, that it is not needfull they ≈øhould take unto them any body.

I an≈øwer; that not onely the imaginary Vi≈øion of Angels is nece≈ø≈øary for our in≈øtruction, but that al≈øo which is corporall and bodily, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew anone, when we intreat of the Apparition of Angels. And as concerning the Devils, God doth permit them both vi≈øibly and invi≈øibly to tempt men, ≈øome to their ≈øalvation, and ≈øome to their damnation.

Moreover they thus agree: That God appeared unto the Patriarchs (as is to be ≈øeen in the Old Te≈øtament, and the good Angells likewi≈øe,) as Saint Augu≈øtine proveth in his book of the Trinity. Now we may not ≈øay, that God took upon him any body, except onely in the my≈øtery of his Incarnation. And therefore it is needle≈ø≈øe to affirm, that the Angels which appear unto men, may take upon them a body.

I an≈øwer, (as doth Saint Augustine) who ≈øaith: That all the Apparitions which were in the old Te≈øtament, were made by the Mini≈øtery of Angells, who formed and ≈øhaped unto them≈øelves certain ≈øhapes and figures imaginary and corporal, by which they might reduce and draw unto God, the Soul and Spirit of him that ≈øaw them: as it is po≈ø≈øible, that by figures which are ≈øen≈øible, men may be drawn and lifted up in ≈øpirit and contemplation unto God. And therefore we may well ≈øay, that the Angells did take unto them a body, when they appeared in ≈øuch Apparitions. But now God is ≈øaid to have appeared; becau≈øe God was the Bu ‚Ä¢ t and mark whereunto by Vi≈øion of tho≈øe bodies, the Angels did endeavour and ≈øeek to lift up unto God the Souls of men. And this is the cau≈øe that the Scripture ≈øaith, That in the≈øe Apparitions ≈øometimes God appeared, and ≈øometimes the Angels.

Furthermore, they make this Objection. Like as it is agreeing naturally to the Soul to be united to the body: ≈øo, not to be united unto a body, is proper and natural unto the Angels and Devils. Now the Soul cannot be ≈øeparated from the body when it will: Therefore the Angels and Devils al≈øo cannot take unto them a body when they will.

For an≈øwer whereof, I confe≈ø≈øe that every thing is born and ingendred hath not any power over his being; for all the power of any thing floweth from the e≈ø≈øence thereof, or pre≈øuppo≈øeth an e≈ø≈øence; And becau≈øe the Soul by rea≈øon of her being, is united unto
the body, as the form thereof; it is not in her pui≈ø≈øance to deliver her ≈øelf from the union of the body. And ≈øo in like manner it is not in the power of any Angell or Devill to unite them≈øelvs to any body as the form thereof; but they may well take a body whereof they may be the moving cau≈øe, and (if a man may ≈øo ≈øpeak) as the figure of the figure.

The affirm moreover, that between the body a≈ø≈øumed, (if I may u≈øe this word) and the party a≈ø≈øuming, there ought to be ≈øome proportion and ≈øimilitude; But between the Angell or Devill, and a body, there is not any proportion; for both the one and the other are of divers kinds, and by con≈øequent both of them are incompatible together.

To this I an≈øwer, That if the proportion be taken according to the quantity, greatne≈ø≈øe, and mea≈øure, there is no proportion between the Angels or Devils, and a body; becau≈øe their greatne≈ø≈øe is not of one and the ≈øame kind, nor of one and the ≈øame con≈øideration. Notwith≈øtanding nothing can let but that there may be a certain habitude of an Angell to a body: as of a thing that moveth to the motion, and of a thing figured to the figure, the which may be termed a proportion.

Another Argument they make, which is this: No ≈øub≈øtance finite (what≈øoever it be) can have in any operations together: An Angell is a ≈øub≈øtance finite; and therefore it cannot both mini≈øter unto us, and take to it ≈øelf a body together.

But this is ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolved: for I ≈øay, that the≈øe two operations, To take a body, and to ≈øerve in their Mini≈øtery, are ordained mutually to the Angels: and therefore nothing hindreth them, but that the Angels may u≈øe both of them at once, and together.

Again they inferre, that if Angells and Devils do take a body either it is a Celestial Body; or ≈øome other, having the nature of ≈øome of the four Elements. Now the Angels cannot take a Celestiall Body, for that the Body of the Heaven cannot divide it ≈øelf, nor cannot make any ab≈øtraction from it ≈øelf: much le≈ø≈øe can the Devils have the power, ≈øeeing the Angels have it not. Be≈øides, they cannot take unto them a body of Fire, for then they ≈øhould con≈øume and burn the body, near to which they do approach: much le≈ø≈øe can they take a body of the Ayre, for that is not figurable; neither can they take any body that is a moveable Element, and retaineth no form; nor yet by the ≈øame mean can they have a Terrestriall body; for we ≈øee it written how the Angels do very ≈øoon and ≈øuddenly vani≈øh away out of ≈øight, as it appeared by that Angell which came to Tobias. And the Devills al≈øo when they ≈øhew them≈øelves in any Apparition, can in a moment withdraw them≈øelves from the ≈øight of men. And therefore being unable and unapt to take upon them any body, either Elementary or Cele≈øtiall; it mu≈øt needs follow that they appear not at all.

To this I an≈øwer, That the Angels and Devils may take a body of any Element what≈øoever, and which them≈øelves will; yea and of many Elements mixt together. Neverthele≈ø≈øe it is mo≈øt likely to be true, and the common opinion is; that they do ≈øoone≈øt of all take unto them a body of the Ayre, by thickning the ≈øame, and forming it of vapours, that mount and ari≈øe from the Earth, and in turning and moving it at their plea≈øure, as the wind moveth the Clouds, being able to make the ≈øame to di≈øappear and vani≈øh away again when≈øoever they will, by rea≈øon that it is nothing but a vapour.

But yet this will not ≈øatisfy them, but they go further, ≈øaying; That every a≈ø≈øumption of a body, is limitted and bounded with ≈øome union: But of an Angell, and of a Body, there cannot be made any of tho≈øe Three means of Unity, of which Ari≈øtotle ≈øpeaketh; For they cannot be made one by Continuation, by In≈øeperability, nor by Rea≈øon.

To this a man may an≈øwer as before. That there is not any union in the a≈ø≈øumption of a body by an Angell. For if there were a union, then in truth that which Ari≈øtotle ≈øpeaketh, ≈øhould be requi≈øite between the Angell and the body which it a≈ø≈øumeth. But there is not between them any union, ≈øave onely that which is of a thing moving to the thing moved, as we have before affirmed.

Again, the good Angels (≈øay they) in appearing unto us, either do take True Figures vi≈øible and palpable, or ≈øuch as are altogether fal≈øe: if they have ≈øuch as be true, it ≈øhould then follow, that if they appear in a humane body, then they do a≈ø≈øume a True humane body; But this is unpo≈ø≈øible, unle≈ø≈øe we ≈øhould ≈øay, That an Angell may enter into the body of a man, which is a thing not convenient nor agreeable unto the Angelicall Nature. And if they have Fal≈øe Figures, this would be much more unfitting and unbe≈øeeming them: for that all feigning and di≈ø≈øembling, or any kind of fiction is very un≈øeemly in the Angels of Truth. And therefore in what ≈øort and fa≈øhion it be, the Angels cannot take any Body upon them.

To this objection I an≈øwer, That the bodies which the Angells do take, have True and unfeigned forms ≈øo far forth, as they may be ≈øeen and perceived by the ≈øen≈øes, be it in their colour or their Figure, but not according to the nature of their kind, For that cannot become ≈øen≈øible but by accident. That therefore is no cau≈øe why a man ≈øhould ≈øay, that there is any fiction and feigning in the Angells: for they do not oppo≈øe and ≈øet before our eyes humane ≈øhapes and forms, becau≈øe thereby they would be thought and e≈øteemed to be men; but to the end that by their humane properties, we ≈øhould know the vertues of the Angels. And like as Metaphorous ≈øpeeches are not therefore any whit the ≈øooner to be reputed fal≈øe, in which by the ≈øimilitude of things, other ≈øignifications are comprehended; So the figures and forms of Angels are not fal≈øe, becau≈øe they
are taken and a≈ø≈øumed to the ≈øimilitude and ≈øemblance of men.

More then ≈øo (they reply) that the Angels and Devills by the vertue of their Nature, cannot work or create any effects within humane bodies, ≈øave onely by the means of their naturall vertues. But their naturall vertues cannot be in things corporall to form any Figure of a humane body, but onely by the u≈øual and determined mean of Generation, to wit, by the ≈øeed naturally ordained to that effect‚ñ™ in which ≈øort the Angells and Devills cannot take a body upon them. And the ≈øame rea≈øon and con≈øideration is there of other figures of earthly bodies al≈øo which they take unto them.

But hereunto this an≈øwer may be made them, That albeit the natural vertues of a body, do not ≈øuffice to produce a true ≈øhape of a humane body, but onely by the due and ordinary mean of Generation: Neverthele≈ø≈øe ≈øo it is, that the Angells and Devills are capable to cloath them≈øelves, and to put on a certain ≈øimilitude of humane body, as touching the colour and figure, and other ≈øuch exteriour Accidents, and that e≈øpecially at ≈øuch a time, as when it may ≈øuffice them by a locall motion to move any ≈øuch bodies; by means whereof both the vapours are thickned, and again purified and made thin, as al≈øo the Clouds are diver≈øly painted and figured.

But they object again, that this is not ≈øufficient: But (they ≈øay) that it behoveth the cau≈øe moving, to infu≈øe ≈øome vertue into the body moved, but cannot infu≈øe any vertue, except it touch it. And if it be ≈øo that the Angells have not any touching nor feeling with the body, it ≈øeemeth that then they cannot move it. And therefore it mu≈øt needs be, that they cannot take upon them any body.

But it may be ≈øaid, that the Angells by their Commandement onely, may move the body with a motion locall, which they give unto it in touching of it, not with a corporall kind of touching, but a ≈øpirituall.

Again≈øt this ≈øolution, they di≈øpute further ≈øaying; It behoveth the mover, and the thing moved, to be connexed, and united together, as appeareth by Ari≈øtotle. But in ≈øaying that an Angell doth command any thing of his own will, it is to be pre≈øuppo≈øed that then he is not together with the body, which is ≈øaid to be governed by him; and therefore he cannot move the body onely by his commandement.

Hereunto I an≈øwer; That the Commandement of the Angell doth demand an execution of his vertue and pui≈ø≈øance: and therefore it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be, that there be ≈øome ≈øpiritual touching of that body by which it is moved.

They in≈øi≈øt yet further, and ≈øay; That the Angells cannot move bodies with any locall motion: and that therefore in vain ≈øhould the bodies be obedient unto them, ≈øeeing they ≈øhould ≈øtill
remain immoveable. And to prove this they bring divers Arguments.

Their fir≈øt Argument is taken from the Authority of Ari≈øtotle, who ≈øaith; That the locall motion is the principall, and mo≈øt perfect of all other motions. Now the Angells (if it be granted that they take a body) cannot u≈øe any le≈ø≈øer or inferiour motions; I followeth therefore by a more forcible rea≈øon, that they can much le≈ø≈øe u≈øe any locall motion, which is the greate≈øt, and the mo≈øt excellent of all others.

But the an≈øwer is ea≈øy, and we ≈øay; That the Angels moving them≈øelves with a locall motion, by the phanta≈ømaticall body which they took, may al≈øo cau≈øe the other le≈ø≈øer motion, by u≈øing ≈øome corporall agents for the producing of tho≈øe effects which they purpo≈øe; like as the Smith u≈øeth fire to ≈øoften the Iron, and to reduce it to that which they have an intention to make of it. And as touching that ≈øaying of Ari≈øtotle; That the locall motion is the chiefe≈øt of all motions; the rea≈øon thereof is, becau≈øe every corporall nature having life, is apt to move it ≈øelf locally by the means of the Soul, be it either rea≈øonable or ≈øen≈øitive, which giveth life unto it:

Their ≈øecond Argument is; That the locall motion of naturall bodies doth follow their forms: But the Angels are not cau≈øes of the forms of natural bodies, and therefore they cannot be a mean to give them any local motion.

Neverthele≈ø≈øe, an≈øwer may be made them, That in bodies there be other locall motions then tho≈øe that do adhere unto the forms: as the flowing and ebbing of the Sea, do not follow the ≈øub≈øtantiall form of the water, but the influence of the Moon; with much greater rea≈øon, therefore, may other locall motions (then ≈øuch as adhere to to the forms) follow ≈øpirituall and incorporall ≈øub≈øtances.

Their third Argument is; That the corporall members do obey to the conception of the Soul in a locall motion, in a≈ømuch as they have from her the beginning of life: now the bodies which the Angells take unto them, have not from them the beginning of life: for then it would behove that the bodies and the Angels ≈øhould be united together. And therefore it followeth, that the bodies by them a≈ø≈øumed, cannot be obedient to any locall motion.

I an≈øwer, That the Angells have their vertue le≈ø≈øe re≈øtrained or hindred then the Souls, in≈øomuch that being ≈øeparated from all corporall ma≈ø≈øine≈ø≈øe, they may neverthele≈ø≈øe take an Ayry body, the which they can move locally at their will and plea≈øure.

Be≈øides all the former Arguments, they reply yet further, and ≈øay: That every corporall motion doth not obey to the command of the Angells, as touching the forming and fa≈øhioning thereof: now the figure which the Angells take, is as a kind of form.
And therefore by the onely Commandement of the Angels, cannot any body take any form or figure what≈øoever, be it either of man, or of any other diver≈øe kind compri≈øed under one gender.

To this the an≈øwer is, That the figure which the Angells take, is in very truth a form which is made by the ab≈øci≈øion and di≈ømembring (as a man may ≈øay) of the thickning of the Ayre, or by the putrefaction of it, or by the ≈øimilitude and motion which may be taken of the ≈øame matter. But there is a very great difference between the Form and Figure that is made ≈øo accidentally, and that which is naturall and according to the true ≈øub≈øtance of a thing, the which cannot po≈ø≈øibly be confounded with this accidentall Figure.

This is not all which they object: for they ≈øay further touching the Devills: That if they do inve≈øt them≈øelves with a body, then they ought to be within the body which they have taken. Now Saint Jerome interpreting that place of the P≈øalmi≈øt; The Lord is in his holy Temple; and the Glo≈øse do ≈øay, that the Devills do command and rule over Images and Idolls externally, and cannot be in them internally: and the Idols are bodies as every man knoweth. And therefore it cannot be ≈øaid, that the Devills can take upon them any bodies.

I an≈øwer, That to be in or within a body of ≈øome ≈øub≈øtance, hath a double and twofold entendment of under≈øtanding. In the fir≈øt ≈øort it is under≈øtood under the Terms of Divinity. And in this manner, nothing letteth but that the Devill may be in a body. In the ≈øecond ≈øort it is meant according To the e≈ø≈øence, as in giving a being to the thing, and in working man in it, which is proper unto God onely: howbeit that God doth not make a part in the e≈ø≈øence of any thing; For God is a ≈øub≈øtance ≈øeparated and abstracted ≈øolely and onely in it ≈øelf. And for the further interpretation of Saint Jerome and the Glo≈øse, which ≈øay, That the Devill is not in Images: we may affirm, that they do privily and clo≈øely reprehend the fal≈øe opinion of the paynims and Idolaters, who made but one thing of the Idoll (were it of Wood, Bra≈ø≈øe, or Stone,) and of the unclean ≈øpirit that remained within it; and by that means would have made a living ≈øub≈øtance of that which in its own nature was ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe and without life, not having either hands to touch withal, or feet to go on, or tongue to ≈øpeak with; except ≈øuch onely as the Devill did ≈øeem to give unto it, by his deceitfull illu≈øions.

To make ≈øhort, they object this Argument al≈øo: If the Angells and Devills do take to them anybody, either they are united unto The whole body, or to ≈øome Part thereof: If they be united onely
to a Part thereof, then can they not move the other part, but onely by the means of that part which they do move. But this cannot po≈ø≈øibly be; for otherwi≈øe the body a≈ø≈øumed, ≈øhould have ≈øuch parts as ≈øhould have the Organs determined to the motion, which is proper to none but living bodies. But if the Angells and Devills be United immediately to the whole body, it behoveth them then al≈øo to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈ø every part of that body which they have taken to them; and ≈øo by that means they ≈øhould be in many places, which is proper and appertaining to God onely: And therefore the Angells and Devills cannot take any body unto them.

To this Argument an≈øwer may be made in this manner; That the Angell or Devill ≈øo taking any body upon him, is wholly in the whole body which it a≈ø≈øumeth, or el≈øe in a part thereof, as the Soul is in the body. For albeit he be not the form of the body which it a≈ø≈øumeth, as is the Soul; yet ≈øo it is, that he is the mover thereof. Now it behoveth that the mover and the thing moved, ≈øhould be together; and it is nothing to the purpo≈øe to ≈øay, that an Angell or Devill, filling a body whole and entire of ≈øub≈øtance, can be in divers places: for the whole body a≈ø≈øumed by an Angell or Devil, is not but in one place onely, albeit the ≈øame be admitted to have many members and many parts.

Thus far have I done my be≈øt, both to ≈øet down and to refute all the rea≈øons and Arguments objected by tho≈øe who deny that Angels and Devils can a≈øsume and take unto them a body; to the intent that from hence forth their mouths might be ≈øtopped, and that they may not e≈øteem as fables the Hi≈øtory of Specters, and of the Apparitions of Spirits.

But before I come to conclude this di≈øcour≈øe, I may not forget to tell you how that many of the Rabbins and Jews which have taken upon them to interpret the holy Scriptures, have held opinion, and been of the belief, that tho≈øe Angels which appeared to the Patriarks and Prophets, did not appear in any body, nor did a≈ø≈øume unto them any body to make them≈øelves vi≈øible. And of this opinion among≈øt others was Rabbi Mo≈øes, one of the mo≈øt learned Rabbins of the Jews, who ≈øaid; That all that which is read and recorded in the Old Te≈øtament of the Apparition of Angels, did come by an imaginary Vi≈øion; that is to ≈øay, ≈øometimes in ≈øleeping, and ≈øometimes in waking. But this po≈øition (as Saint Thomas of Aquine calleth it,) cannot prevail again≈øt the truth of the Scriptures; for by the phra≈øe and manner of ≈øpeeches which are u≈øuall in the books of the Old Te≈øtament, it is ea≈øy to know and di≈øcern a difference, that which is ≈øignified and declared to have Appeared purely and ≈øimply to our eyes, from that which is ≈øaid to be done by the means of a Propheticall Vi≈øion. For when it ought to be under≈øtood, that any Apparition
was made by way of Vi≈øion, there are ≈øome words put down and in≈øerted, which do properly appertain to the Vi≈øion, ≈øuch as the Scriptures do intend; as in Ezechiel, the Spirit of the Lord (≈øaith he) lifted me up between the Heaven and the Earth, and led me into Jeru≈øalem by the Vi≈øions of the Lord. I ≈øay therefore, that when it appeareth that things are ≈øaid to be done ≈øimply, we ought to under≈øtand them as done ≈øimply and truly. Now we read in the Old Te≈øtament, that many Apparitions have been made in body: And therefore we ought to grant, that the Angells do ≈øometimes a≈øsume and take unto them a body, in forming ≈øuch a body as is ≈øen≈øible and ≈øubject to the external and corporal Vi≈øion, as well as ≈øome kind of ≈øhapes do form them≈øelves in our imagination, which do produce an imaginative Vi≈øion, when we are ≈øleeping. But this ≈øhall ≈øuffice touching this matter.
